Does not every human being have the natural desire to live well or be able to lead a good life? What is ‚Äògood‚Äô in our life? What is beautiful? What is valuable? What is the meaning of good? How do we establish the value of a thing? How can life be made good? Those desirous of finding answers to these questions can benefit immensely by an ardent study of this work ‚Äì the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. Who or what is a jƒ´va? What is the relationship between a jƒ´va and the world? What is Divine? What is the relation between jƒ´va and the Divine? These are some of the questions for which answers can be found in the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

Our ancestors have referred to the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ as a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra (a treatise on liberation). The Gƒ´tƒÅ is indeed a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra; but it is a jƒ´vana-≈õƒÅstra (treatise on living) as well. A temple comprises the garbha-g·πõha housing the m≈´rti, the mukha-ma·πá·∏çapa (front porch of the temple), the pradak·π£i·πáa-patha, and the gopura. While there may be one who can scale the tall gopura and touch its golden kala≈õa at the top, the other nine hundred and ninety nine will be content with doing the pradak·π£i·πáa, getting a dar≈õana of the m≈´rti, and partaking of the prasƒÅda. Similarly, while there may be one person benefiting from the instruction on mok·π£a, nine hundred and ninety nine people will derive benefit from the instruction on dharma. Essential lessons on improving one‚Äôs life gradually‚Äîbe it for a scholar or a layman; be it for those well-settled or those who are struggling with difficulty, be it for men or for women‚Äîcan be found in the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. A healthy respect for one‚Äôs life, enthusiasm to do one‚Äôs own duty, courage in the face of adversity, faith that brings solace during moments of doubt ‚Äì are some of the treasures that we can glean from the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

[[The Structure of the Gƒ´tƒÅ Source: prekshaa]]

Prerequisites to the Study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ

A word of caution before we begin. All parts of the Gƒ´tƒÅ cannot be understood at the same level of clarity by everyone. Shouldn‚Äôt instruction befit the aspirant‚Äôs qualification? The amount of benefit we derive from the Gƒ´tƒÅ is directly proportional to our levels of faith, moral readiness, and intellectual ability. Anything beyond our capability might not be understood by us. So it would simply be our loss if we discarded the Gƒ´tƒÅ just because we could not understand a sentence or section of the treatise during our first or second reading, or because something did not seem right to our mind. Taking what we can grasp at the moment and reflecting upon it enables us to subsequently understand higher levels of meaning. If our study has to be fruitful, we must be equipped with the prerequisites of patience and faith. MahƒÅtmƒÅ Gandhi has referred to the Gƒ´tƒÅ as his mother. The kind of unquestioned faith a child has in her mother‚Äôs words, the kind of unquestioned trust a child has in her mother‚Äôs cooking are the kinds of faith and trust we need, without which a great work‚Äôs essence may go unattained.

The subject of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is profound, subtle, and knotty. To understand it, we need a flight of stairs-like arrangement. We‚Äîcommon human beings‚Äîmay be unable to explain the essence completely in one sentence or ascend in one step. The essence of life can be likened to a mountain. Those desirous of climbing it must be ready to do so step by step, resting wherever necessary, breathing in and understanding the rarefied airs as they ascend to the summit level by level. Here, it will not do to be hasty. Haste might cause misunderstanding. Manas-samƒÅdhƒÅna (calmness of mind) and sƒÅvadhƒÅna (patience, caution) are two primary qualities that a votary of the Gƒ´tƒÅ must possess.

Different Schools of Philosophy

Another word of caution ‚Äì about dvaita, advaita, vi≈õi·π£tƒÅdvaita, ≈õuddhƒÅdvaita, bhedƒÅbheda, and other schools of philosophy that have differed in their exposition of the Supreme Truth. These differing schools are about the zenith of experience; about the relation between jƒ´va and Brahman; about the final goal of mok·π£a. Suppose that a person is at the foot of a hill and desires to climb to its summit. In that case, isn‚Äôt a discussion about what is in the temple at the hill‚Äôs peak a waste of time? Isn‚Äôt there a cave behind the temple? Isn‚Äôt it dark? Is it a snake or a rat that‚Äôs inside the cave? Is the rat in the womb of the snake or has the snake been pierced in its eye by the rat? Or are both the rat and snake in yoga-nidrƒÅ*? Or have the snake and rat lost their natural enmity owing to their penance?* This is something that a person who has entered the cave and come out can tell us. It seems that such people have not been available to us.

One could ask, ‚ÄúWon‚Äôt the bhƒÅ·π£yas (commentaries) authored by the ƒÅcƒÅryas of various schools suffice?‚Äù The answer is that there is no unanimity of opinion in those works. Who then do we believe in? The commentators excel in expounding upon the meanings of subtle scriptural passages. Using tarka (logic) and vyƒÅkara·πáa (grammar), it could be argued that advaita is dvaita or that dvaita is nothing other than advaita. The greatest instrument of knowledge in this lofty subject is the personal experience of the knower. That which is agreeable to one‚Äôs experience becomes his or her subjective truth. If one were to ask if Truth had parts in it or if Truth was a ‚Äúwhole‚Äù entity, the answer would be that though Truth is indeed whole and unbroken, the mind perceives it piecemeal. Isn‚Äôt the eye on only one side of the head? The eye can see only one side of an object from one place.

The Truth is one; its appearances are manifold. If this is kept in mind, it can be shown that not only dvaita and advaita schools of Hindu philosophy but even non-Vedic religions such as Jainism, Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity can accept the Gƒ´tƒÅ.* Our goal though in this discourse is to study the meaning of the Gƒ´tƒÅ in such a way as to not oppose any traditional commentator. There is always freedom to choose whenever interpretations differ. Our focus is not on the parts where the interpretation differs but on those aspects acceptable to all. (Readers are encouraged to look at the appendix on the harmony of the three schools).

The Form of the Treatise

The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ is an account of a dialogue; a dialogue between Arjuna and ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa. Both of them are in the battlefield of Kuruk·π£etra where the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas and the Kauravas with their armies are standing in opposition to each other. Arjuna is the the third among the five PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas, ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs bosom friend. Arjuna, who is enthusiastic to fight until the start of the war, sees the multitude of people around him and begins to express his doubts and concerns thus ‚Äì ‚ÄúAh! That I should kill them! Can I kill them? Is it proper to do this for selfish benefit? Is that not a grave sin?‚Äù ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa begins to clarify those questions. Questions and doubts arise again and again with those clarifications. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa answers all of them. Thus expands the work. Those sorrows, doubts, and fears felt then by Arjuna are not his alone; or only of that time. The same dilemmas, uncertainties, confusions, and anxieties affect us every single day. Such fundamental questions of life have always bothered the human animal in all eras, all eons, and at all places in one form or another. The humanness of the human is in dealing with these questions and answering them. Such solutions find a solid basis in the veritable mine of the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. The Gƒ´tƒÅ is thus a scripture of life germane to all times and places.

In our study, the Gƒ´tƒÅ has been viewed from the perspective of the everyman‚Äôs need. Nuances of the ≈õƒÅstra and the duels of logic are not important to us here. This is an exposition created by a common man discussing with another of his kind ‚Äì much like classmates talking to one another.

Is the Gƒ´tƒÅ a ≈öƒÅstra or a KƒÅvya?

This work is termed ‚ÄòGƒ´tƒÅ-≈õƒÅstra‚Äô as well. The words ‚Äògƒ´tƒÅ‚Äô and ‚Äò≈õƒÅstra‚Äô convey widely different ideas in their meanings. Gƒ´tƒÅ refers to a song. Its main function is entertainment ‚Äì delighting one‚Äôs feelings. That does not address the intellect. However, ≈õƒÅstra addresses the intellect. Here, a predominance of feeling is unwelcome. Thus gƒ´tƒÅ and ≈õƒÅstra appear mutually exclusive from a superficial view. However, in ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs dialogue with Arjuna, thought and feeling have come together in a single narrative. For instance, the first chapter of is full of Arjuna‚Äôs despondency and expressions of karu·πáa (pity, compassion), which show mental agitation more than intellectual cogitation. The eleventh chapter of the vision of the vi≈õvar≈´pa (Universal form) is full of adbhuta rasa (wondrous sentiment). The other chapters exude feelings of devotion and Bliss. Juxtaposed with these are a study of SƒÅ·πÅkhya, dhyƒÅna-yoga (the method of meditation), and the teaching of the Yaj√±a principle ‚Äì all of which need significant application of thought. Therefore, it seems to be apt to term this work a ‚Äò≈õƒÅstra-kƒÅvya‚Äô or a scriptural poem.

That the realms of mind and intellect are different, even distant, does not hold in their elevated states. In that elevated station, both of them coalesce into one ‚Äì like an ideal husband and wife. The mind prods the intellect, which in turn indulges the mind. The light of the intellect and clarity of mind combine to yield an internal bliss akin to the joy of experiencing the radiance of moonlight. Like the happiness experienced while the eye conveys the beauty of form with the simultaneous sweetness of music conveyed by the ear. It is impossible as well as improper to separate such a blessed union of mind and intellect. The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ is a ‚Äò≈õƒÅstra-kƒÅvya‚Äô encompassing this dual. This will be discussed further in the appendix.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

*Translators’ Note: Even Prof. M. Hiriyanna famously said that the Gƒ´tƒÅ can become the Bible of any creed. While this might be true of ‘Pagan’ faiths similar to sanƒÅtana-dharma, it appears unlikely in the case of Semitic religions, which are not merely dualistic but also predatory in nature. Like Aurobindo Ghosh said, ‚Äú[Hinduism] is in the first place a non-dogmatic inclusive religion and would have taken even Islam and Christianity into itself, if they had tolerated the process.‚Äù (The Foundations of Indian Culture, Sri Aurobindo Birth Centenary Library. [[What to Expect from the Gƒ´tƒÅ? Source: prekshaa]]

What do we get from the Gƒ´tƒÅ?

What can we expect from the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ?

We normally expect something special from any book we choose. If it is a story, we expect interesting accounts of human character; in a play ‚Äì a range of passions and emotions; in a song or a poem ‚Äì an echo of our caprices and anxieties; in a historical account ‚Äì narratives about different countries and nations; in a manual of astronomy ‚Äì a description of stellar and planetary behaviour. Similarly we look forward to increase our understanding of the subject in treatises on Physics, Chemistry, and Mathematics.

What is our interest in the Gƒ´tƒÅ? By ‚Äòour,‚Äô I refer to common people. What do we reckon as a benefit from a study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ? If we make this clear to our minds, there will be no reason to complain later that this study was a waste of our time.

Let‚Äôs accept that the popularity of the Gƒ´tƒÅ has attracted us. Several scholars and luminaries of our country have worshipped the Gƒ´tƒÅ over many millennia. Our preceptors have used the Gƒ´tƒÅ as a scriptural authority. Many philosophers of Europe have respected it. Our own leaders such as Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Mahatma Gandhi, Aurobindo, and other greats have accepted the Gƒ´tƒÅ as a fount of inspiration to their own lives. It is but natural, therefore, for us to presume that such a famous work must have something special in it.

Our ancestors considered the Gƒ´tƒÅ as a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra (a scripture of liberation). For those who lived a hundred or two hundred years ago, the difficulty of everyday life was not as big a matter as for us. The main means of sustenance then was agriculture.There was nothing to worry about as long as the rains and crops happened on time. There was no contact or distraction from other cultures. The people lived according to the ancient tradition. Traditional rituals, customs, and systems were enough for them. Living peacefully like their fathers and grandfathers was all the pleasure they wanted from life. Hence, with everyday life not bothering them as much and becoming somewhat bearable, their minds sought more after the way beyond. It was thus that mok·π£a became something close to them.

Our burden nowadays is of life in the world. 1 Earning one‚Äôs food and clothes, job opportunities, hopes and desires, loans and taxes, relentless toil, rest-less movings about, distress in practicing our customs, friction with other faiths, admixture of var·πáas, and an infinitude of other worries form our fate. How then can we pay attention to mok·π£a? Our daily burdens of life are more than enough for us. Can the Gƒ´tƒÅ help us amidst all of this? If so, it might be of value to us.

This is the favour we are eager for. Our minds are in turmoil; we need some fortitude. Our beliefs are shaking and infirm; the mind needs a secure resting place. The future is stuck in doubt; we need a comforting assurance. If the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ were to show us such viveka, such ≈õraddhƒÅ, and such samƒÅdhƒÅna, we would desire to read that work.

The Gƒ´tƒÅ makes it clear in its own words that it can indeed bestow this benefit upon us. Though our ancient commentators gave importance to mok·π£a, they have stated that the Gƒ´tƒÅ is equally applicable to everyone in terms of worldly life.

Dharma is the holistic and sustainable method to enrich worldly [personal and public] life. Dharma and mok·π£a cannot exist without one another. The prerequisite to mok·π£a is dharma and the perfection of dharma is mok·π£a. Hence what was a treatise on mok·π£a to our ancestors is to us a treatise on dharma.

The Declaration of the Work

Any new work on the Gƒ´tƒÅ would have to encounter a fair question: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs so special about this?‚Äù

There is no dearth of treatises on the Gƒ´tƒÅ. ƒÄcƒÅryas ≈öa·πÖkara, RƒÅmƒÅnuja, and Madhva, who were the chief propounders of their respective schools of philosophy have all written commentaries on the Gƒ´tƒÅ. There have been sub-commentaries and glosses written upon those works. There are collections of other compendia and exegeses built around these glosses. There are innumerable translations with explanations of the Gƒ´tƒÅ not just in all Indian languages but also in English and other foreign languages. Why a new work then?

The author of the current work has to say this in response ‚Äì

  1. The Gƒ´tƒÅ is a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra according to ancient commentators. In this work, it is chiefly a jƒ´vana-≈õƒÅstra (scripture of life). While the ancient ones held vairƒÅgya in greater importance, we have to live in this world, finding practical solutions to the problems of life. Applying the teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ to worldly life is our goal. 2. Our ƒÅcƒÅryas have given greater significance to schools of VedƒÅnta ‚Äì dvaita, advaita, and vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaita. In this work, it is considered that it is possible for these sub-schools to not just co-exist without opposition but exist in harmony like brothers. 2 3. Is karma more important in the worship of the Supreme? Or is bhakti more important? Or j√±ƒÅna? Our ancients speculated on this issue. In our view, all these three, along with a·π£·π≠ƒÅ·πága-yoga, are not harmful when practised together but could actually help one another. It is possible for these four practices to co-exist. The proportion of each practice could be set according to the seeker‚Äôs ability and opportunity. But there is no fear of danger even if the proportion is slightly off the mark. 4. Our ancestors held the authority of ≈õruti and sm·πõti to be paramount. Here, an attempt has been made to harmonize the mode of inquiry employed in the modern scientific method with ≈õruti and sm·πõti and satisfy rationalism. 5. Ancient commentators were well-versed in traditional ≈õƒÅstras. They wrote for those who understood the language of the ≈õƒÅstras. They were able scholars in tarka, vyƒÅkara·πáa, and other branches of traditional wisdom. Here, emphasis is placed upon the straightforward meaning of the verses of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The Gƒ´tƒÅ has several paradoxical passages (e.g. ‚ÄúI am not in them; neither are they in me!‚Äù 3) as well as utterances that are epigrams (e.g. ‚ÄúThe one who enjoys is verify a thief!‚Äù 4) The meanings of such passages can be stretched in any direction. In such cases, it is but consistent to interpret those passages according to the meanings of unambiguous passages of the Gƒ´tƒÅ, the Vedas, and Upani·π£ads. 5 A simple and straight path is thus sought after here. 6. Followers of the Veda and those who don‚Äôt follow the Veda are both addressed here. 7. The discourse here attempts to follow the method of a non-scholar, a common man, who could discuss deeply with his friends subjects such as the Divine, jƒ´va, destiny and dharma.

It is in light of these reasons that this teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is termed jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga (the Yoga of the Right Conduct of Life) in this exposition.

[[The Nature of the Gƒ´tƒÅ Source: prekshaa]]

The Nature of the Work

The Gƒ´tƒÅ is simultaneously a simple-difficult work or a difficult-simple work. What does it mean? Words may be simple to understand but the meaning of the sentence is difficult. The part that teaches nƒ´ti is simple; the part that establishes philosophy is not. It is thus easy to fall in the trap of thinking that one has understood the Gƒ´tƒÅ. However, it is hard to realise its essence in one‚Äôs mind.

Though the language style is not that complicated and the figures of speech are clear, the word association is complex in a few places. Though similes and other figures of speech have been used to clarify the purport in a few verses, paradoxes and epigrams have also been employed to impress the seeker‚Äôs mind and stay rooted there as well. Such paradoxical and epigrammatic verses need more considered reflection.

Any work or treatise cannot overcome the time and place of its composition. Though we may accept that the Veda is apauru·π£eya (not of human origin), there are several marks of human influence in that great body of literature. The memory of the Kuru and PƒÅ√±cƒÅla regions, for instance or the names of kings such as Janaka and JƒÅnu≈õruti mark out time and space. Hundreds of ·πõ·π£is are mentioned. The description of the movements of stars and planets are an aid in estimating the time of the manifestation of the Veda. LokamƒÅnya Bal Gangadhar Tilak has used the position of the m·πõga≈õirƒÅ (Orion) and other asterisms to estimate the antiquity of a certain ·πõk that mentions this. It is thus evident that a few geographical and astronomical markers of a certain age can make their way into a work. The author is subject to his era and geography and has not overcome them.

In addition to the physical environment, his social milieu considerably influences an author. The beliefs of his people, their legends and stories, their aspirations, opinions, tastes, and attitudes are things that an author cannot possibly escape from. They would have had some or the other influence upon him. The best of the poets and philosophers cannot completely be immune to the effects of their age, region or social conditions.

A poet, however, has to rise beyond his condition. The more one is beyond time and geography, the greater his importance. We do not want a report of our world around from him. We have that even without his help. The question is of extracting ourselves from our condition and rise beyond it. This is where we need his favour.

But there is a limit to it. If the poet soars greatly beyond his condition, we may not be able fly with him. If there is not even a modicum of relationship between the world of the poet‚Äôs imagination and the world that we know, we will be unable to even understand his words. His tongue might be foreign to us; his world might be from a different planet. There might be no medium for us to comprehend him. If we are to benefit from a poet, we must adhere to a couple of rules ‚Äì

  1. There must be at least an iota of similarity between his world‚Äôs characters and their conversations with our world and our behaviour. 2. There must be some novelty in the dispositions and circumstances of the characters and in the expressions of their feelings that give fresh stimulation to our minds.

We should be able to relate to the theme of the work; but within a limit. If the limit is exceeded, we might not enjoy it or even grasp it.

The goal of the preceding is to impress upon the reader that there is an unavoidable association between a work and its author‚Äôs time, age and circumstances.

The above definition of a literary work holds for the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata as well. That the works of VƒÅlmƒ´ki and VyƒÅsa hold for all ages and regions is our thesis as well. Their main storylines, the expressions of feeling, the discussions on nƒ´ti, and expositions that establish philosophy will apply to all of humankind at all times. However, even those illustrious works mention the social conditions of the eras of VƒÅlmƒ´ki and VyƒÅsa. Included in them are their legends, common idioms and proverbs, their ancient traditions, histories, their beliefs and faith. These ancillary aspects may not be accepted by those of this age. Even if we disregard some parts of the story or some sub-plots, there will be no loss to the comprehension of the main narrative. There might be a loss of uniqueness of narrative here and there. Consider this, ‚ÄúThe earth is flat. Eight elephants bear it. Those elephants stand on the back of a turtle, which is on the hood of the serpent, Adi≈õe·π£a.‚Äù If such descriptions are left unaccepted, a little bit of the story‚Äôs flavour might be found lacking. But there will not be any inadequacy in understanding the story‚Äôs principle.

Such aspects can be found in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The faith that rains and crops stem from the yaj√±a is as old as the Vedas. There is no harm to the main thesis of the Gƒ´tƒÅ whether we accept this belief or not. Another such matter is that of the devayƒÅna (the way of the deities) and the pit·πõyƒÅna (the way of the ancestors). This is another item of Vedic faith. Believing in it is optional. This causes no loss to the main teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ whose thesis is independent of the inquiry behind the yaj√±a and the different ways of ayana (departure).

The Two Stages of Instruction

The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya instructs us in two stages. One is for a normal aspirant, or one of worldly practice. The other is for an exceptional aspirant, or one relating to the Absolute. If Arjuna is a normal aspirant, let him come to the way of sva-dharma through desires for kingdom, fame and heaven. The path of

‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Ç

could be followed. Let him perform yaj√±as, let him depart by the way of the moon. If on the other hand he is an exceptional aspirant, let him transcend the three gu·πáas (sattva, rajas, tamas), be established in the Supreme dharma and work for the welfare of the world from the perspective of the Universal Spirit. Thus the paths differ based on the stature of the aspirants. Differences in path, however, do not matter from the destination‚Äôs view. This is a rule to keep in mind throughout the study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya accepts both the worldly and the Absolute.

[[The Conversation of the Gƒ´tƒÅ Source: prekshaa]]

The Style of a Conversation between Friends

The sequence of the Gƒ´tƒÅ appears jumbled at times. The Gƒ´tƒÅ is referred to as a ≈õƒÅstra. Its theme does make it one. But in the Gƒ´tƒÅ‚Äôs method of instruction, we do not see a systematic division and order in its topics as in a school textbook. There is a chapter-wise division for sure. But the matter apposite to a specific chapter-topic shows up admixed in a different one. Another chapter‚Äôs issue shows up in the current one. There is a reason for this. This work was not authored as a textbook. Neither Arjuna nor K·πõ·π£·πáa set out to write one. The turn of events got them to converse and that flowed as a dialogue between friends.

RƒÅma saw his old friend Bhƒ´ma in the market. Both of them remembered their childhood friend ≈öƒÅma. Then they talked about the story of Soma‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs alliance with ≈öƒÅma‚Äôs son KƒÅma. ≈öƒ´na, Timma‚Äôs lawyer had won the lawsuit. When the lawsuit‚Äôs description ended, the matter of KƒÅma came up again followed by Soma and Bhƒ´ma once again. Then about the latter‚Äôs brother-in-law Boma. A dialogue between friends typically rambles among different topics like this; much like what Bhavabh≈´ti has said ‚Äì

‚Ä¶in the meandering manner of gossipers. 6

The same happens when friends talk about philosophical topics. From the present topic to a PurƒÅ·πáic story; from the purƒÅ·πáa to the condition of the world, from the world to the Absolute, and from that to the current issue ‚Äì the conversation swings back and forth. This can be found in Plato‚Äôs Dialogues wherein the debates between Socrates and others are described.

It can be seen from everybody‚Äôs experience that the subject of a discussion between friends can go hither and thither. This characteristic of a friendly chat has entered the Gƒ´tƒÅ quite naturally. So we have to observe the links of an actual conversation here. Consider a person enquiring his friend ‚Äì ‚ÄúWhen did he come? What happened there?‚Äù Both of them know what is being referred to by ‚Äòhe‚Äô and ‚Äòthere.‚Äô Their opinions can be inferred from their tone of voice and facial expressions. When we read their dialogues without seeing them, their mental states have to be surmised from their backgrounds. In the same manner, the link between one verse and the next and the flow from one idea to the next can be understood through a consideration of the antecedent and precedent verses. This is where traditional bhƒÅ·π£yas help us. Seemingly mysterious links between verses are clarified by these bhƒÅ·π£yas. Once these links are inferred, we can see that the work is indeed logically well connected.

Was there Enough Time for a Dialogue?

Some people ask ‚Äì ‚ÄúCan such an inquiring and deep conversation happen on the battlefield? Is it even possible to have a lengthy dialogue amidst two enemy armies baying for battle?‚Äù Another common suspicion is whether these words really came out of the mouths of K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna. And whether they really spoke in verse. My answer is that such doubts are irrelevant.

Before doubting if there was time for dialogue when everyone around clamoured for war, we should remember the rules of battle conduct of that age. Conflict in that era did not mean anyone killing anyone else in any manner or place. There were rules pertaining to the place of battle, its time and of worthy and unworthy conduct. War in that age was an occasion for dharma; especially of the k·π£atriyas. Its rules were accepted equally by both opposing parties. Fighting would not begin upon sighting either side. There was no fear of harm till both sides decided that it was opportune to fight. There was ample time even after K·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs and Arjuna‚Äôs dialogue.

It was then that DharmarƒÅja alighted from his chariot and approached Bhƒ´·π£ma and his preceptors. His brothers, without knowing his bent of mind, presumed that he was surrendering out of fear and tried to stop him. DharmarƒÅja did not pay heed to them and without uttering a word went to Bhƒ´·π£ma, prostrated at his feet and sought his blessings and permission for war. He did the same with Dro·πáa, K·πõpa, and ≈öalya. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa again tried to bring over Kar·πáa to the PƒÅ·πá·∏çava side. Finally DharmarƒÅja stood in the middle of the battlefield and called out for anyone intending to come over to his side. Yuyutsu, Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra‚Äôs son from a servant girl, came over to the PƒÅ·πá·∏çava side.

It is only after all this the war began. Nobody had the fear that anyone would rush into it. Everything took place in a relaxed, sequential manner. K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna had sufficient time [for a discussion.]

The Authorship of the Work

Now to the authorship of the work. Nobody will opine that all the words of the Gƒ´tƒÅ, including ‚Äòca,‚Äô ‚Äòtu,‚Äô and other filler words, have been uttered by K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna. Sanskrit was natural to them. So it is likely that most of the words in the Gƒ´tƒÅ, which were in vogue those days, were spoken by them. How could it be said that the intent of those verses did not belong to them? All the doubts, clarifications, statements of opinion, and logical inferences definitely belonged to K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna. Such discussions were common in that age. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata has numerous such instances. Viewed thus, it can be established that most of the language used and all of the sentiment belong to K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna and the only the metrical structure came from VyƒÅsa. Maha·πõ·π£i VyƒÅsa has reported a verse form of the dialogue through Sa√±jaya for us.

Anubandha-Catu·π£·π≠aya ‚Äì The Fourfold Connection

It is an ancient and traditional practice to define the four connections during an introduction to a work of ≈õƒÅstra.

AdhikƒÅrƒ´, Vi·π£aya, Sambandha, and Prayojana‚Äîthe four anubandhas‚Äî

[are essential] for the pursuit of a ≈õƒÅstra to bear fruit 7

The four anubandhas or connections are ‚Äì

1. AdhikƒÅrƒ´ ‚Äì the qualified student

2. Vi·π£aya ‚Äì the subject matter of the treatise

3. Prayojana ‚Äì the benefit of studying the work

4. Sambandha ‚Äì the relationship between the vi·π£aya, the adhikƒÅrƒ´, and the prayojana.

1. Who is the adhikƒÅrƒ´ or one qualified for a study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ?

The one who has experienced difficulties, dilemmas, and crises in the world; who is able to control desires for sense-pleasures; who is endowed with empathy towards all people; and is passionately curious about knowing how to lead a life to ensure it is meaningful ‚Äì qualifies to study the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Controlled desire, self-control, and a desire to know the Truth are the internal qualifications for a student of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

2. The Vi·π£aya or the theme of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is the Universal Principle.

‚ÄúWhat is the nature of the jƒ´va? What is the principle of ƒ™≈õvara? What is the character of the world? What is the relationship between the jƒ´va and the world? What is the supreme way for the jƒ´va? What is the position of ƒ™≈õvara in the triad of jagat, jƒ´va and ƒ™≈õvara?‚Äù - are the questions that the Gƒ´tƒÅ can answer. Its subject is the Vision of Universal Life.

3. Sambandha is of three kinds:

a. The relation between the teacher and the taught. The seeker is the taught and the Gƒ´tƒÅ is the teacher.

b. The relation between harmony and the harmoniser. The Gƒ´tƒÅ is to be studied in conjunction with the Vedas, PurƒÅ·πáas, and ItihƒÅsas with the assistance of tarka and vyƒÅkara·πáa while refined by worldly experience, reasoning, and evidence. All of the ≈õƒÅstras and experiences are needed for that.

c. The relation between the purifier and the purified. The instruction of the Gƒ´tƒÅ has to pervade all spheres of human life and make excellent all actions by purifying them. Life has to be refined through an implementation of its teaching and become capable of greater ends.

4. Finally the topic of prayojana or benefit.

A repeated study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ makes light of the soul‚Äôs burden of life. Through philosophical discernment, the mind understands the true value of various worldly things and a forms a value hierarchy. That marks the cessation of delusional error. Questions such as What is the meaning of life? What is the Absolute? What is to be done? What should not be done? are answered and a pure path of dhƒÅrmic life becomes visible. Then comes clarity of mind followed by the solution to life‚Äôs trials and tribulations. This results in tranquility. That [clarity and serenity] is the fruit of the study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

Though a cursory examination of the fourfold connections has been made, there are a couple of items that need further thought. The first one is of the adhikƒÅrƒ´. The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya has several kinds of adhikƒÅrƒ´s in mind.

Four kinds of fortunate people worship me, O Arjuna ‚Äì
the distressed,
the one wants to know,
the one desirous of wealth, and
the wise one 8

All of these [bhaktas] are excellent‚Ä¶ 9

Individuals are at various levels in intellect and tastes, in knowledge, in richness of personal qualities, and in the extent of dispassion according to the karma done in their previous lives. These differences in ability and taste are innate. Therefore instruction and modes of practice differ accordingly. Even though the defining markers of adhikƒÅrƒ´s appear to be the same, they vary in degree from person to person. Thus all forms of life that remember the Supreme have separate paths towards welfare depending on their capabilities.

The above explanation of the connections is of a common type and coarse. There are several points to be pondered upon here. The above explanation might be incomplete if it those points are not examined.

[[Instruction on the Vi·π£aya is According to the AdhikƒÅrƒ´ Source: prekshaa]]

Let us first look at the theme of the work and the qualification to study it. Each of these decides the other. The story of pu·πáyako·π≠i befits a six year old. A study of the Raghu-va·πÅ≈õa, however, is for a student aged sixteen or more.

Thus each one decides the other. The one who is capable of dealing with the vi·π£aya‚Äîsubject of the work‚Äîis the adhikƒÅrƒ´. The instruction has to be tailored to the education and capacity of the seeker. Both of these are thus relative to each other.

The vi·π£aya of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is not of a single kind, when subjected to subtle examination; rather, it is of many kinds. While there is the devotion of common folk on one side, there are logical conundrums that can cause headaches to great pundits. Prav·πõtti-dharma (the mode of action) and niv·πõtti-dharma (the mode of renunciation), atƒ´ta-sthiti (the exalted state), bhakti-yoga (the path of devotion), karma-yoga (the path of selfless work), dhyƒÅna-samƒÅdhi-yoga (the path of meditative concentration), and j√±ƒÅna-yoga (the path of wisdom) ‚Äì is the stepped path of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The intended seekers are correspondingly of different levels. There are several levels of seekers that fall in the purview of the Gƒ´tƒÅ ‚Äì from the ignorant to the illuminated and from family men to ascetic mendicants. Because of the variety in adhikƒÅrƒ´s, the instruction is also varied. From ‚ÄúOffering a leaf, flower, fruit, or water‚Äù 10 to ‚ÄúBe devoid of the three gu·πáas, O Arjuna!‚Äù 11 there are several paths of instruction. The destination is one; but the paths are eight. It won‚Äôt be wise to argue that only one of these eight is right and the rest are not. If the maxim of ‚ÄòAs the student, so the instruction‚Äô is remembered, it can be seen that the controversies of religious doctrine fade away.

The goal of medicine is one; a state of a healthy body is another. But the causes of sickness are many; the forms of diseases are many. Therefore modes of diet and treatment are many. Ginger and pepper do not treat an eye disease; alum cannot treat indigestion. Medicine is prescribed according to the weakness of the body. Instruction is given according to the debility of the jƒ´va.

This now is the most important matter. That the Gƒ´tƒÅ is applicable to all var·πáas, all classes, and to all those in any circumstance or stage, to all women and men, has been clearly stated by the Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya. However, all instructions are not for everyone. Every student has to understand his or her own capability and choose the appropriate teaching after a thorough examination. This has been clarified by the Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya himself ‚Äì

Whatever is the utility of a small reservoir of water
when there is a floor and water is flowing everywhere ‚Äì
that is kind of utility of all the Vedas
for a person who has realised the Brahman! 12

Even if all ponds, streams, wells, and tanks are full of water, a man can use only whatever is necessary for his uses such as his ablution and drinking. Similarly, even if there are a hundred instructions in the Vedas, the judicious man chooses and uses whatever fits him. The same holds for the Gƒ´tƒÅ. A palace befitting a queen holds hundreds of attendants in as many quarters. It is only appropriate for each occupant to reside in the appointed quarters. All floors and all rooms are not for everybody.

Questions such as, ‚ÄúWill not there be discrimination then? Is it proper?‚Äù might arise. The answer lies in the highs and lows of human behaviour. K√≤bbari-mi·π≠hƒÅyi (a sweet dish made with grated copra) is certainly desired by many. Would it then be proper to feed a bagful of that to a two-year-old, citing equality of treatment? What would happen to the child‚Äôs health? Just as there are limits on the food taken in by the body, there must be limits on food for the mind. This limit indicates a healthy respect for the nature of anything. ‚ÄòReality‚Äô is understanding the nature of a thing as it is. Tattva is the same thing. A thing‚Äôs thing-ness is tat-tva. That Tattva, Reality, or Truth is the foundation of dharma. Since, in reality, each jƒ´va differs from one another in innate disposition, it becomes necessary to prescribe different instruction and practice for each. Thence the multifaceted teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. There is no question of inferior or superior here. Is an injection a superior form of medicine or is a mixture inferior? Is a tablet better than medicinal powder? Our disease is one of ignorance. The Gƒ´tƒÅchƒÅrya is the healer. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs answer to Arjuna‚Äôs question about the race between superior and inferior‚Äîin the A≈õvamedhika-parva of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata‚Äîsubsequent to the war can be considered here ‚Äì

All are superior in their own domains
They all help one another‚Äôs domains too! 13

In society, each one is best in his own appointed duty. Just as a brƒÅhma·πáa is the best when it comes to the Veda, a k·π£atriya when it comes to protecting the kingdom, a vai≈õya when it comes to wealth, a g·πõhastha in service of the world, and a sa·πÉnyƒÅsi in tapas, everyone has to help others while being the best in one‚Äôs own duty. In the same vein, the instruction most suitable for the spiritual progress and refinement of every jƒ´va is the best for him or her. The same is declared in the Gƒ´tƒÅ thus ‚Äì

Performing one‚Äôs own dharma, even if imperfect,
is greater than performing another‚Äôs dharma well 14

The reason I emphasise this so much is the inordinate impetuosity shown by people in the matter of mok·π£a. The Gƒ´tƒÅ has received much fame as a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra. People therefore want to unravel the secret as soon as possible and rush towards liberation. Such haste is not just a waste but dangerous as well. Nobody avers that the Gƒ´tƒÅ is not a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra; no one says that the thought of mok·π£a is wrong. But the Gƒ´tƒÅ is as much a dharma-≈õƒÅstra as it is a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra. While the thought of liberation is good, it is good to to reflect upon dharma as a prerequisite. People have to first understand that there is no mok·π£a without dharma. Upon consideration, it is seen that there is no reason to hanker after mok·π£a separately. Mok·π£a follows dharma by itself. A person who earns his livelihood in the day according to his ability and follows a healthy lifestyle does not have to take pills for a good night‚Äôs sleep. He whose food is well-digested falls asleep as soon as he hits the sack. Mok·π£a is set for the discerning one who performs dharma diligently. Let us therefore follow the Gƒ´ta with a focus on the matter of dharma.

The vi·π£aya and the adhikƒÅrƒ´ are not completely separate from the view of our study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ; but are symbiotic. We have seen that dharma is indeed the theme of the Gƒ´tƒÅ if the student is interested in dharma. We have discussed the prayojana of the Gƒ´tƒÅ study cursorily. There is one thing left to be stated about the sambandha (relationship among adhikƒÅrƒ´, vi·π£aya, and prayojana). This is about our attitude. It has been mentioned that the relationship is one between the teacher and taught ‚Äì the Gƒ´tƒÅ is the teacher and we are the taught. Is this not clear? Should it be explicitly stated? The answer is yes. The relationship could be one of a refuter and the refuted. Isn‚Äôt it quite possible that Buddhists, Muslims, and Christians could study the Gƒ´tƒÅ in order to refute it? Our explicit statement is to clarify that there should be mutual faith and respect between the work and the student.

≈öraddhƒÅ is trust that is not blind. It is the trust with which a child eats what its mother gives it; that with which a patient takes his medicine from the doctor. If the child does not relish the food given by the mother, it throws it away and demands something else. If the ailment does not get cured, the patient complains to the doctor who prescribes another medicine. Both the child and the patient have from their experience a freedom to examine the mother and healer respectively. Similarly, the ≈õraddhƒÅ we have in the statements of the ≈õƒÅstras and the gurus is not opposed to independent thought but subject to reason and experience. The way of the world is to examine first and trust later. However, ƒÅtmƒÅ, jƒ´va, and dharma are supranormal subjects. Therefore it is trust that is followed by examination in these matters. The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya himself specifies that what is needed is reflection and not a lack of thought through the following statements ‚Äì

Understand that‚Ä¶ from inquiry 15

‚Ä¶having analyzed all of this‚Ä¶ 16

and so forth.

There is yet another thing that has to be said here. That is related to the difference between the nature of worldly or physical sciences and this subject [i.e., the Gƒ´tƒÅ]. Mathematics, Physics, and Chemistry can be grasped only via the intellect. Physical objects can be grasped by the senses. Therefore, they are available through the pramƒÅ·πáas (means of knowing) of pratyak·π£a (direct perception) and anumƒÅna (inference). The ƒÅtman is suprasensory. It cannot be grasped by our hands or measurements. To obtain it therefore, we have to rely upon the Veda-≈õƒÅstra, which is the testimony of ƒÅptavƒÅkya (trusted source). If we don‚Äôt place our trust in it, there is no way out.

The other preparation we need in addition to ƒÅptavƒÅkya is the purification of our inner being or a clean disposition of mind. Those in hasty pursuit of mok·π£a tend to forget this.

It is an error, a dangerous one, to think it possible to unravel the secrets of VedƒÅnta through a sleight of mind. It is possible to win at a game of cards through a trick. A machine can be operated through a shortcut. A math problem can be solved through a stratagem. It is also possible to shut up an opponent with wit. We think it possible to storm the city of mok·π£a using an easy manoeuvre. But Brahman is not something attainable merely through intellectual artifice.

[[SƒÅdhana-catu·π£·π≠aya - The Four Prerequisites Source: prekshaa]]

It is indicated above that the buddhi is a power that works with the manas. The buddhi is under the influence of the manas. Therefore, to purify the buddhi, it is imperative to purify the manas. Buddhi is an implement that enables reflection. Manas experiences the product of the buddhi. In VedƒÅnta, j√±ƒÅna (wisdom) is the same as anubhava (experience). Knowledge of Brahman is the experience of Brahman. Mind is the arena of experience. Unless the mind is ready, there can be no true experience of reality. Hence a purified mind is inevitable for the study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ-≈õƒÅstra. The method of purification of the mind is termed sƒÅdhana-catu·π£·π≠aya (the fourfold attainment) comprising the following ‚Äì

1. NityƒÅnitya-viveka (Discernment between the real and the unreal)

What things of the world exist at all times? What are those that live for a short duration? The mind must repeatedly reflect upon and practise discrimination between the great and the trivial, the fixed and the unsteady, and the eternal and the transient.

2. IhƒÅmutrƒÅrtha-phala-bhoga-virƒÅga (Renouncing the desire for enjoyment in this world and beyond)

Gradually renouncing the desire for bodily pleasures in this world or in other heavenly abodes; being unruffled by sense pleasures.

3. ≈öamƒÅdi-·π£a·π≠ka-sampatti (The sixfold wealth of quietude &c.)

a. ≈öama is the absence of other thoughts while in control of inner senses; keeping the mind established in itself.

b. Dama is the control of external senses.

c. Uparati is the withdrawal of the mind from external happenings and being established in itself.

d. Titik·π£hƒÅ is forbearance; to be equanimous while being unruffled by the duals of profit and loss, joy and sorrow, love and hate, or hot and cold.

e. ≈öraddhƒÅ is implicit faith in the words of the ≈õƒÅstras and the learned.

f. SamƒÅdhƒÅna is establishing the mind in its object while not allowing it to wander.

4. Mumuk·π£utva (The intense desire to be liberated)

Curiosity about mok·π£a. Mok·π£a is the experience of Bliss devoid of any trace of sorrow, beyond duality, that is a result of release from bondage.

To summarise, the student of the Gƒ´tƒÅ, having seen the limitations of earthly wealth and pleasures and controlling Desire, Anger, and Envy, realises the existence of the ƒÅtman beyond bodily existence and considers that Supreme Essence to be the best amidst all transactional reality. This is the foremost prerequisite for the student of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

A Couple of Precautions

It is important to understand how the essence of an important work should be comprehended. A couple of precautions are pertinent here ‚Äì

1. To temporarily let go of one‚Äôs skepticism in the narrative (‚Äú‚Ä¶willing suspension of disbelief for the moment‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äì Coleridge)

2. To focus on the purport of the work in its narrative.

1. Willing suspension of disbelief.

To suspend questions about characters and events that arise during a story for resolution at a later time. ‚ÄúDid RƒÅva·πáa of the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa really have ten heads? Was he able to assume a form at will? How did MƒÅrƒ´ca become a golden deer?‚Äù ‚Äì such are the items of doubt. ‚ÄúWas the potency of the mantras the reason for the birth of the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas? Was the number of damsels that ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa brought from NarakƒÅsura‚Äôs town exactly sixteen thousand? Were they all of the same age or were there old women among them?‚Äù ‚Äì Such questions are irrelevant from the perspective of the story‚Äôs essence. These incredible incidents are essential for the poet-world‚Äôs reality. These are the bricks of the poetic monument. We need to believe in the solidity of these bricks if we want the tale. We need to be able to believe in the story and nod our heads with a, ‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù much like children who do so. Instead if we were to ask questions at every stage of the story, the poetic edifice falls apart and we derive no use from it. This is a rule relevant only to the story aspect of a work.

2. Focus on the purport of the work amidst the flow of words.

By purport we refer to that meaning which resonates with the intent of the work or the sentence. For example, if during a meal a person is asked to bring saindhava, one should infer it to be ‚Äòrock salt‚Äô rather than ‚Äòa horse.‚Äô Meaning stems from context. In the sentence, ‚ÄòCome over to my house while visiting the temple,‚Äô the phrase ‚Äòcome over‚Äô does not mean ‚Äòarrive on top of,‚Äô but ‚Äòto casually visit.‚Äô In ≈õƒÅstra, this is referred to as lak·π£a·πáƒÅ-v·πõtti (using the secondary sense of meaning when the primary word meaning is not apt). It should be remembered that the intent of the speaker is more important than the word.

If intent is more important, should not only those words appropriate to the intent be chosen? Why the superfluity? This raises a question on the innate capability of a language or the lack of it. That is an area to ponder. Can language exactly convey the intent of the mind and intellect? In several works is seen the inability of language to precisely express the author‚Äôs intent. To make up for that, we must resort to several figures of speech such as upamƒÅna-upameya (simile), utprek·π£ƒÅ (hyperbole), and punarukti (repetition). Our daily language is filled with such figures of speech as well. ‚ÄúI polished off ten dosas,‚Äù ‚ÄúI gave a couple to the mischief monger,‚Äù ‚ÄúThat baby is like a flower,‚Äù etc. are examples for that. Words are not enough to convey our emotional states or our experiences. We say that ‚ÄúHe was fuming with rage‚Äù or ‚ÄúEverything has cooled down.‚Äù We exclaim, ‚ÄúIt was like seeing God,‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt was like drinking am·πõta,‚Äù or ‚ÄúI remembered KƒÅmadhenu!‚Äù Thus, even common folk cannot converse without figures of speech even for a moment. Seeing that normal words do not completely convey delight or pain in those sentences, uncommon or special words or comparisons are employed. Those comparisons fill in the gap left by words. That indeed is ‚Äòala·πÉ‚Äô (enough) ‚ÄòkƒÅra‚Äô (make) ‚Äìala·πÖkƒÅra = making it enough; filling any gaps or shortcomings. Ala·πÖkƒÅra is used to fill in those gaps created by normal word usage. It is a kind of lak·π£a·πáƒÅ-v·πõtti. The same consideration is used in all art forms. What does a young lady do when she does ‚Äòala·πÖkƒÅra‚Äô (make up) to herself? She does two things. The first is to amplify or accentuate the beauty of her own bodily features. A small dark dot on her beautiful golden cheeks brings out the attraction in the cheeks. A single white jasmine flower on her dark tresses renders the entire hairdo gorgeous. How? The seer is able to appreciate beauty of the same thing faster and with more vividity. This is a kind of ala·πÖkƒÅra or decoration. The other kind of ala·πÖkara·πáa is to make any deficiency or ugliness invisible. Applying face powder to a faded face, filling gaps between teeth with gold, using wax to smoothen out any pockmarks ‚Äì are all examples for this. Even here, ala·πÖkara·πáa or decoration is used to resolve any gaps in beauty and project the product as real. This is indeed artificial. When something artificial is used for good i.e., when its effect is pleasurable, we call it ala·πÖkƒÅra.

More words are thus used in a language for either clarifying the meaning or amplifying it. The sentiment conveyed by the statement ‚ÄòRƒÅma is good‚Äô is also conveyed by ‚ÄòRƒÅma is exemplary‚Äô but the sentiment is amplified in the latter.

[[Repetitions and Reiterations in the Gƒ´tƒÅ Source: prekshaa]]

Let us get back to the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. There are so many punaruktis (repetitions); upamƒÅna-upameyas (comparisons in a simile) and paradoxes. Our attention should be on their purport. When prosaic speech does not suffice and figurative expressions are resorted to even while describing commonplace incidents and worldly experiences, how else could the mind of the philosopher expressing thoughts about the supernatural reveal itself to us without figurative language? Consequently, there is quite a bit of symbolism in the Veda especially in the matter of the ƒÄtman (Self).

The puru·π£a-s≈´kta is a large allegory. When such language is encountered, the mind must not focus on the literal meaning but on the purport. In the statement

sahasra≈õƒ´r·π£ƒÅ puru·π£a·∏•

does not mean that the virƒÅ·π≠-puru·π£a (the Cosmic Being) has one head more than 999 or one head less than 1001. ‚ÄòSahasra‚Äô just signifies innumerable. That is the substance.

The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ has the same words repeated. The same matter is conveyed in different words.

nitya·∏• sarvagata·∏• sthƒÅ·πáu·∏• acalo‚Äôya·πÉ sanƒÅtana·∏• ‡•§

Here both sthƒÅ·πáu and acala mean the same. What does nitya and sanƒÅtana mean? Both mean the same. Is it not a fault when the text is repetitive to express the same thing in three different words? It is not so here. It is rather advantageous here and much needed from our perspective. For, when the instruction does not come in a flood of words but in subtle and terse letters, it might not catch the mind of a dull or a careless learner. If, however, it is repeated in many words, the fear of such a loss is lessened. The effectiveness of a sentence is not only gained from its inner strength but also from its external size. Experienced teachers know that in a school, children are taught the same concepts ‚Äì even easy ones ‚Äì by revising it multiple times. While dealing with an extremely subtle and deep topic, the instruction might not be understood or even misunderstood if terse language is used. Therefore a little repetition is not a defect but a blessing. Names of trees occur as if in a catalogue during descriptions of forests in the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. The names of a hundred persons are encountered when an ƒÅ≈õrama is being described. Are we botanists or anthropologists that we need these catalogues? The answer is that this description of a multitude has an impact on our mind. It is required for increased impact in the depiction of the object.

Descriptions of such collections are encountered in the tenth and eleventh chapters of the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. We have to comprehend the meaning of the flow there. A significant opinion or instruction flows out in multiple streams. In the vibh≈´ti-yoga, for instance.

An economical word arrangement in which no word required to elucidate its meaning is left out, no superfluous word is added, and in which any movement or transposition of letters results in a greater, lesser or completely different meaning is known as a s≈´tra. The Brahma-s≈´tra conveys in four words what the Upani·π£ad takes fifteen words to do. The presence of the conjunction ‚Äòca‚Äô conveys a special meaning in the s≈´tra; the absence of it conveys yet another meaning; similarly with ‚Äòtu.‚Äô The style of the s≈´tra befits experienced scholars; and gives an opportunity for their logic and arguments. The author of the Gƒ´tƒÅ did not follow the rule of aphorism. His style is one of poetry. His admirable goal is to explain uncommon subjects with common words. Therefore we do not have to sift through every letter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The holistic vision is appropriate here. Our goal is not the word to word meaning of an instruction but the essence of the flow of thoughts ‚Äì the general drift or tenor of the words used. This, if remembered, will bring several controversies about the teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ to rest.

The story aspect of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is in a poetic form. Poetry attempts to convey the subject matter in a way that is impactful to the mind. That kind of an attempt makes imperative several figures of speech such as the hyperbole. This is something even we are aware of. During the education of children, we use exclamations like ‚ÄúBravo!‚Äù whenever a child solves a problem correctly. When it is two ‚Äì we use expressions like ‚ÄúAwesome!‚Äù If there are a couple of children there, we begin to think on how it would be possible to convey a unique phrase of encouragement. For one, we may use ‚ÄúSmooth!‚Äù and for the other, we may use ‚ÄúIncredible!‚Äù We might use ‚ÄúUnbelievable!‚Äù for the third one. We do not use the literal meanings of these words when we convey our appreciation. We do not weigh the implications of the usage of such words. Such an examination of exact word meaning is unnecessary for our use and may even be detrimental. Encouraging students is our only goal. If we weigh our words carefully much like an apothecary weighing his medicines, and try to state the exact intended meaning, the effect on the students might be more discouraging than encouraging. Therefore it is proper to grasp the meaning of God‚Äôs words after considering His intent.

Arjuna was crestfallen. He was out of his wits. The intent of the Lord was to infuse enthusiasm and confidence in him and make him surge forward.

The poet uses a few extra words to ensure that the meaning sticks to the mind. This is a literary device that is seen employed even in the Veda.

The Veda‚Äôs chief goal is one of vidhi (injunction); to decide dharma. Are then all those Vedic passages injunctions? No. Should not the propitiated deity be invoked during the yaj√±a? There are mantras for those known as stƒÅvakas (hymns of praise). These praise Deities thus ‚Äì ‚ÄúYou are the greatest among the great! You created all of us! You are the one who existed before us!‚Äù ‚Äì in a variety of ways. It is but natural to use many words when praising anybody. We see that even in the world. Can a minister be praised with the words, ‚ÄúYou have an LLB degree! You have two ears!‚Äù and so forth? Does that even count as praise? If, however, the minister is praised with words like: ‚ÄúYou are the avatƒÅra of B·πõhaspati!‚Äù &c., there is a good chance of getting our work done. When it is so in the mundane world, can Yaj√±e≈õvara (Lord Agni) be propitiated with ‚ÄúYou burn!‚Äù, ‚ÄúIf you are controlled, you give us happiness. Please restrict yourself!‚Äù and so forth? Will Agni give us what we desire? Therefore a plethora of stƒÅvakas are necessary. The pragmatic view is that this is a device to get the favour of the deity. The Absolute or philosophical perspective is that since Para-brahman is the final destination, we arrogate all its qualities on all the devatƒÅs.

There is another class of Vedic passages known as arthavƒÅda. The arthavƒÅda informs us that one would get certain fruits on the completion of certain rites. In everyday language, this could be termed an advertisement.

There are several such Vedic passages included to stimulate (prarocana). The stimulation is for the performance of certain rites and subsequently achieve interest in them and prosperity.

prajayƒÅ pa≈õubhirbrahmavarcasena‡•§
mahƒÅn kƒ´rtyƒÅ‡••

The above is the praise of food. Food has to be acquired in plenty. The one with food eats abundantly. He becomes great. He begets progeny, bovine wealth, BrƒÅhmic effulgence, and extensive fame. What is the intent behind such praise? For man to work and earn his living. To work for a living is not something debased but the best among duties. It is needed even to realise Brahman. By stating all this, the mahar·π£is desire to infuse a sense of importance with faith and enthusiasm even during common everyday tasks. When the Veda says, ‚ÄúMahƒÅn bhavati,‚Äù the intent is not to convey that the one eating will put on weight and become a wrestler but to insist that such a person would become great in quality and influence.

Similarly in the Gƒ´tƒÅ, one finds enough passages of upade≈õa (instruction) as well as for clarification. There are even more passages to generate interest. So, it would be instructive for the reader to observe how certain passages convey the overall meaning of the Gƒ´tƒÅ and in what way. When this is done, the harmony among various parts of the text becomes evident.

[[Importance of Realizing the Meaning Source: prekshaa]]

The Importance of Contemplation

The Gƒ´tƒÅ has two intertwined streams of instruction. One is theoretical whereas the other is practical. The theoretical part is especially intellectual with an ascertaining of the truth using an analytical mindset. The practical aspect or sƒÅdhana pertains to the emotional mind. The mind when active is known as the citta ‚Äì ‚ÄòAnusandhƒÅnƒÅtmaka-v·πõttimad-anta·∏•kara·πáam cittam‚Äô (‚ÄòThe citta is the contemplative mind.‚Äô) The buddhi has to be followed by citta. But the citta is slower than the buddhi. Hence there is always a difference between the buddhi and the citta.

It is seen that in the world, there is always a gap between words and deeds. It is not that only dishonesty is the reason for this. Spoken words might not match what is in one‚Äôs mind on half the occasions. But during the other instances, the reason is impossibility and not dishonesty. The citta is not ready to follow what the buddhi deems appropriate. The citta is not as careful as the buddhi. The more difficult the buddhi‚Äôs instruction gets, the more unprepared the citta is for it.

Man‚Äôs mind is like a sheet of paper. It remains flat and smooth when not folded layer by layer or rolled into a tube. Once folded, however, it is a struggle to make it smooth. The same goes for a bar of metal. Once bent in a certain way, it is not easy to make it straight. The same happens with a cane stick. The citta too, similarly, yields to habit. To let go of an old habit and take on a new habit takes time, patience, and firmness. This is its nature.

Thence is BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs statement.

asa·πÉ≈õaya·πÉ mahƒÅbaho mano durnigraha·πÉ calam‡•§
abhyƒÅsena tu kaunteya vairƒÅgyena ca g·πõhyate‡•• (6.35)

abhyƒÅsa-yoga-yuktena‡•§ (8.8)

abhyƒÅsa-yogena tato mƒÅm-icchƒÅptu·πÉ dhana√±jaya‡•§ (12.9)

Deep is the gap between the citta and the buddhi.

This is why the practical aspect of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is harder than the philosophical aspect. Practice of the gƒ´tƒÅ requires a long-standing firmness of the mind and constant effort. It should not be thought that mere hearing of the instruction is attaining the goal. Even if the principles are well-understood intellectually, it is not the same as attaining the final fruit. The gƒ´tƒÅ-≈õƒÅstra was not created for argumentation but for practice.

Experience is Knowledge

We can go a step further and state that one who lacks practice will be found lacking in the realization of the truth, for j√±ƒÅna is not a mere comprehension of an idea but a method of work. In other words, j√±ƒÅna is not akin to a point but to a line. There are several stages in j√±ƒÅna. The peak, however, is experience. The one who has scaled a mountain peak can claim to have seen the entire mountain. The one who has experienced the truth completely knows what it is. The j√±ƒÅna of an inexperienced person is insufficient and hence not trustworthy. It is as dangerous as confusion. Therefore those are honest students of the Gƒ´tƒÅ who take the effort to practice and consequently realise it in their experience.

Experience is becoming that which we contemplate upon ‚Äì through an effort of the mind. The mind is like lac or beeswax, capable of assuming any form. It has to be melted, cast in the shape of the contemplated object, and then hardened. That is experience ‚Äì becoming the object. The gopikƒÅs meditating constantly upon ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa had their minds passionately absorbed in him, consequently attained his form, and experienced Bliss. That is experience.

Such an experience of the Supreme can happen only through significant effort and prolonged practice. Therefore people like us who have read the words of the Gƒ´tƒÅ and have slightly understood its literal meaning have not attained much. Our efforts and practice are important. For this, we need to understand by ourselves the modes of instruction and practice that match our ability and competence. Theoretical philosophy is not unimportant. But its importance is for intellectual inquiry. That inquiry bears fruit during actual experience. Practice is imperative for experience. And experience is not something that happens intellectually. Along with the buddhi (intellect), the manas (psyche), the citta (the unconscious storehouse of all impressions), sm·πõti (memory), comprehension, inference, and intuition as well as other powers of the internal organs should converge. If all of life‚Äôs energies were to be engaged, the fruition of that effort and its ripening is the experience of the Supreme.

Let us therefore focus on applying the teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

Mere Reading is Insufficient

Several students of the Gƒ´tƒÅ religiously read the work even if they do not understand it, in the ardent belief that the act yields religious merit. That is a good thing, no doubt. But there is a danger in that. They might get the false assurance that just uttering the letters of the Gƒ´tƒÅ can destroy all their pƒÅpas. Repetition and remembrance of BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs holy names have been greatly extolled in our tradition. However, remembrance of the name and reading the work are but the means. Towards what? Means to ensure that our minds are focused on the Divine. Utterance of the names of the Divine with the mind elsewhere is fruitless. It is a mistake to think that repeating the letters of the Gƒ´tƒÅ will remove pƒÅpa accruing from performing bad deeds. The benefit of repeating the Gƒ´tƒÅ text is in memorizing it. Once memorized, it becomes easy to recall the text again and again. With repetition, the meaning of the text becomes clear to the mind. Reflection on the meaning of the text becomes easier with the meaning clarified. Reflection on the essence of the text enables contemplation. Hence the pƒÅrƒÅya·πáa or ritual reading of the text is sequentially beneficial rather than as a complete solution by itself. For the complete benefit of the Gƒ´tƒÅ, the focus must be on its meaning. The practice of parroting the text has increased of late. The desire of proclaiming to the world that they have read the Gƒ´tƒÅ has spread a lot. What of mere reading? What of understanding the meanings of sentences? Only after harmonizing the meaning across different parts of the Gƒ´tƒÅ, seeing its meaning holistically and an extended practice might the essence of the Gƒ´tƒÅ flash in the mind. The same is said about the Vedas as well.

sthƒÅ·πáur-aya·πÉ bhƒÅrahƒÅra·∏• kilƒÅ‚Äôbh≈´tbr>adhƒ´tya veda·πÉ na vijƒÅnƒÅti yo‚Äôrtham

The study of the Gƒ´tƒÅ should not be like the burden of the washerman‚Äôs vehicle.

yathƒÅ khara≈õ-candana-bhƒÅravƒÅhƒ´
bhƒÅrasya vettƒÅ na tu candanasya

What if a donkey bears the weight of sandalwood logs on his back? It experiences only the burden and not the fragrance of the sandal.

Therefore, the pƒÅrƒÅya·πáa bears fruit only through contemplation on the work‚Äôs meaning.

The path of contemplation has been divided into three stages by our ancients ‚Äì

≈õrotavyo mantavyo nididhyƒÅsitavya·∏•‡•§
tarati ≈õokam-ƒÅtmavit‡•§

The three stages are ≈õrava·πáa, manana, and nididhyƒÅsana.

≈örava·πáa is listening, which means reading or performing a ritual study.

Manana is thinking about the meaning. Manana is the reflection on the meaning of the work by the union of the refined manas and the well-trained buddhi.

NididhyƒÅsana is the constant considered observance in one‚Äôs own deeds of the principle understood through manana.

Of these three, the first one is not hard. The other two are achievable through great difficulty. If manana has proceeded well, nididhyƒÅsana should not be difficult.

Thus manana is the most crucial part of contemplation.

[[Contemplation and Reasoning Source: prekshaa]]

Manana

There is an element of truth that escapes words and can be discerned only through inner experience. That is the secret. Contemplation via considered reflection is the only way to unravel the secret of Brahman. If the study has to be beneficial, it must follow the path of reflection.

There is an anecdote in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka-upani·π£ad. In the court of King Janaka, GƒÅrgƒ´ asks the ·πõ·π£i YƒÅj√±avalkya about the structure of the earth and the structure of its warp and woof. YƒÅj√±avalkya, in turn, describes the structure of the worlds from here to Brahma-loka stage by stage. At that time, GƒÅrgƒ´ questions him about the structure of Brahma-loka, who then cautions her with:

MƒÅtiprƒÅk·π£ƒ´·∏•‡••
‚ÄúDo not over question!‚Äù

Questions and answers are fine until a point, after which they become meaningless. This is because what exists beyond a certain point is beyond words as well. Experience is the only way out after that. Thence the path through reflection and meditation.

Reflection is primarily an intellectual activity. One could call it the maturation of ≈õraddhƒÅ or faith. Faith in instruction has been ordained for the disciple. Faith is belief. If belief already exists, the question arises as to what the need for the intellect would be. The rule of manana shows that a need for the intellect co-exists with the presence of ≈õraddhƒÅ. Manana clarifies the word-meaning of the instruction, analyses its purport, validates the message, and firms up our conviction. What we have in the beginning is incomplete knowledge or j√±ƒÅnƒÅbhƒÅsa ‚Äì a semblance of knowledge. This apparent meaning is refined through manana to get the accurate import. Thus the role of the intellect is critical in the study of the scriptures. ≈örava·πáa‚Äîlistening or reading‚Äîis the first stage in knowledge acquisition. NididhyƒÅsana‚Äîmeditation‚Äîis the last. The bridge between the two stages is manana‚Äîreflection‚Äîwhich requires a meticulous use of the intellect.

The Nature of Dharma

Constantly paying attention to the principle and adhering to it during various activities of life is the application or practice of dharma. The four main indicators of dharma are as follows ‚Äì

  1. The remembrance of the greatness of the Divine. 2. Renouncing one‚Äôs ego. 3. Reducing the feeling of ‚Äòme‚Äô and ‚Äòmine.‚Äô 4. Applying one‚Äôs own capabilities for the benefit of others.

Such a dharma takes multiple forms such as ku·π≠umba-dharma (dharma towards one‚Äôs family), kula-dharma, (dharma towards one‚Äôs clan), janapada-dharma (dharma towards one‚Äôs nation), and others. Only if the practice of the Gƒ´tƒÅ-principles occurs across these dharmas can a faraway glimpse of the Divine be achieved. That is experience. The three main methods of dharma has been delineated by the Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya himself.

tad-ity-abhisandhƒÅya
phala·πÉ yaj√±a tapa·∏•-kriyƒÅ·∏•‡•§
dƒÅna-kriyƒÅ≈õ-ca vividhƒÅ·∏•
kriyante mok·π£a-kƒÅ·πÖk·π£ibhi·∏•‡••
Yaj√±a, dƒÅna, and tapas are the three paths to attain Divine experience. Yaj√±a is worship of the Divine. DƒÅna is service to society. Tapas is educating or refining oneself. These three form the path to elevate one‚Äôs life.

The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ expounds upon dharma as much as it instructs about mok·π£a.

≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya clarifies this in his introduction to the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

dvi-vidho hi vedokto dharma·∏•, prav·πõtti-lak·π£a·πáo niv·πõtti-lak·π£a·πáa≈õ-ca, jagata·∏• sthiti-kƒÅra·πáam‡•§ prƒÅ·πáinƒÅ·πÉ sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd-abhyudaya-ni·∏•≈õreyasa-hetur-ya·∏• sa dharmo brƒÅhma·πáƒÅdyair-var·πáibhir-ƒÅ≈õramibhi≈õ-ca ≈õreyorthibhi·∏• anu·π£·π≠hƒ´yamƒÅna·∏•‡•§ ‚Ä¶
Vedic dharma is two-fold ‚Äì one of activity (prav·πõtti) and the other of renunciation (niv·πõtti) ‚Äì and is responsible for the maintenance of order in the world. This dharma, which gives both worldly welfare as well as mok·π£a, has been practised by the brƒÅhma·πáas and other var·πáas who are desirous of welfare.

abhyudayƒÅrtho‚Äôpi ya·∏• prav·πõtti-lak·π£a·πáo dharmo var·πáƒÅn-ƒÅ≈õramƒÅ·πÉ≈õ-coddi≈õya vihita·∏•, sa devƒÅdi-sthƒÅna-prƒÅpti-hetur-api san, ƒ´≈õvarƒÅrpa·πáa-buddhyƒÅ anu·π£·π≠hƒ´yamƒÅna·∏• sattva-≈õuddhaye bhavati phalƒÅbhisandhi-varjita·∏•‡•§ ‚Ä¶
Although this dharma of action is a means to worldly prosperity and is prescribed for different var·πáas, and is capable of achieving the regions of the devas, if practised with submission to the Supreme with no regard towards the results of the work, it is conducive to the purification of the mind.

The opinions of RƒÅmƒÅnujƒÅcƒÅrya and MadhvƒÅcƒÅrya are not different in this matter. All the three ƒÅcƒÅryas say the same.

No Distinction of Religious Doctrine in Dharma

The difference of opinion amongst the ƒÅcƒÅryas is not with respect to the dharma portion of the work but with the aspects pertaining to philosophy or tattva ‚Äì the nature of reality. The reason is that the philosophical aspects deal with the final questions about the nature of mok·π£a. The ƒÅcƒÅryas greatly developed the topic of philosophical inquiry and extensively discussed the exalted condition or state of the jƒ´va. This resulted in the Gƒ´tƒÅ being thought of as mainly dealing with mok·π£a and that the question of dharma was subsidiary to it. That is not quite correct. For common people, practice or the application of dharma is primary.

There is yet another reason. ≈öruti (Vedas), Sm·πõti, PurƒÅ·πáas, and ItihƒÅsas as well as long-standing traditions have the same opinion about dharma. Dharma is principally an external practice. Therefore, authority or testimony, conclusion, what is right and what is not ‚Äì are all topics available to most people. It is easier to achieve unanimity in this regard. Because it is clearly observable in the world, there is not much dissent in the matter. Mok·π£a, however, is an internal state wherein external testimony is insufficient. While the opinions of the world have achieved near unanimity vis-√†-vis dharma, the same has not been achievable when it comes to jƒ´vƒÅtman and paramƒÅtman. It is not possible either. There is scope for debate and analysis in this regard. It is possible for one to analyse or critique another‚Äôs theory. With the growth of polemical works, the focus has been more on tattva and mok·π£a, which has distracted people from the practice of dharma.

The Position of Tarka (Logical Reasoning)

There are hundreds of commentaries and glosses on the Bhagavad-Gƒ´tƒÅ. As far as we know, it is the commentary of ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya that is the oldest. He gave more attention to tattva and so his adversaries had to follow suit. We need to understand why ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya gave more importance to the philosophical portion.

≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya set forth to establish pristine VedƒÅnta by showing the defects in the philosophical schools of his day. The three main rival schools were ‚Äì 1. Buddhism, 2. The Doctrine of Karma, and 3. SƒÅ·πÖkhya.

Buddhism was non-Vedic and had four sub-schools. We don‚Äôt need to delve into their details now. Suffice it to say that they did not accept the Divine principle.

The Doctrine of Karma, propounded by KumƒÅrila and others of the P≈´rva-mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ school, holds that the karma portion of the Vedas is the primary one and that yaj√±as and other Vedic rituals comprised dharma, which resulted in the final human goal. The third group‚ÄîSƒÅ·πÖkhya‚Äîis also a Vedic philosophy. They held that there were numerous fundamental constituents of the universe and the relation between cause and effect is established via two principles known as prak·πõti and puru·π£a.

These three schools of philosophy were in vogue during ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara‚Äôs time. All the three were philosophical in nature. It was then the duty of ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara to refute these three schools and establish his own school of philosophy of the One Self through testimony and reasoning. Therefore we find analyses of philosophy and examinations and refutations of reasoning in his works. As a result, those that came after him had to further develop dialectical approaches in their works. Due to historical factors and development of various philosophical schools, commentaries on the Gƒ´tƒÅ have concentrated more on tarka while the aspect of dharma was sidelined. I feel that an abundance of tarka is unnecessary in our times and that the benefit from hashing out the same issues repeatedly is probably less than looking at the work from a contemporary perspective. I do not deny the commentaries of our ancient teachers. Those commentaries show us the way. We need them. Without them, we might lose our way. But we need a present-day viewpoint as well. There will not be any contradiction to existing schools of thought. Our thought has to be harmonised with that of our ancients. That is the way of progress. The history of man has to flow unimpeded and unbroken like the flow of the Ga·πÖgƒÅ and other great rivers. Our new thoughts and interpretations have to similarly continue from that of our predecessors.
