[[The Puru·π£ƒÅrthas and the Self Source: prekshaa]]

Puru·π£ƒÅrtha

Man is a bag of desires. His life is a river of ceaseless likes and dislikes. Whatever he desires and whatever goals he attempts to attain have all together been termed by our ancestors as puru·π£ƒÅrthas.

There are four puru·π£ƒÅrthas ‚Äì

1. Dharma (good works, virtue, sustenance, global ethic)

2. Artha (wealth, means to fulfill desires)

3. KƒÅma (desire, enjoyment)

4. Mok·π£a (liberation).

KƒÅma and Artha are first desired by all. Both of these are born of an impulse from Nature. Dharma, however, is achievable through the individual‚Äôs discernment.

The uses of artha are twofold ‚Äì 1. Dharma and 2. KƒÅma. Wealth has to be earned without violating dharma and has to be used for giving to the deserving and to help society. Artha then becomes a means to attain dharma.

Dharma has to partially follow Nature as well as oppose it. But mok·π£a has to be achieved by completely transcending Nature. One end of human life is kƒÅma that is completely subservient to Nature. The other end is mok·π£a that is beyond Nature. Dharma then is the human endeavour to ascend from the bottom to the top. Dharma is special in that it is good work that yields double results. One is the fruit of pleasure the other is that of well-being. Dharma can pull us out of the web of Nature for a moment, bring down our selfishness and ego, turn our minds towards the Supreme, and prepare us for the world. This refinement of the jƒ´va is the fruit of well-being. While dharma can take us on the path to progress, it could cause regress as well. Yaj√±a, dƒÅna, tapas, and others are ways of worshipping the devas. Pleased with us, the devatƒÅs give us what we desire. That is the fruit of pleasure. There is intoxication in the wine of this fruit. Just as tasty food eaten without considerations of limit can cause indigestion and thereby disease, the boons we desire can delude us and pull us down to error. Is this not the story of RƒÅva·πáa and other rƒÅk·π£asas? They obtained boons from their tapas and misused them. It is not easy to find one who, by means of thought, knows what befits him, what benefits his nature. When we attain desired pleasures, we forget ourselves in the intoxication of their enjoyment. That can make us negligent. We begin to hanker after another pleasure when what we have is not enough. It could motivate us to do wrong. When that pleasure ends, we covet after yet another. It could lead us astray. Thus, the fruit of pleasure from the practice of dharma could be enjoyable at first but end in sorrow; which means that dharma, by its giving of fruit, could enable its rival puru·π£ƒÅrtha through a flourish of kƒÅma and coveting after artha.

The Composition of Human Nature

An important consideration here is the composition of human nature. The three gu·πáas of sattva, rajas, and tamas are found mixed in unequal proportions. The results of dharma are dependent upon the doer‚Äôs proportion of these gu·πáas. For what goal does man perform dharma? To what specific dharma among the numerous forms of dharma is he attracted? The fruit of dharma depends on the answers to these questions.

Man‚Äôs inclination towards artha or kƒÅma stems from different proportions of these three gu·πáas. From those inclinations arise dharma and its opposite, adharma. From dharma and adharma emerge the fruits of the activity or otherwise. From the fruits again arise avarice and delusion, which result in the increase or decrease of the gu·πáa-proportions. A shift in *gu·πáa-*proportions further causes a change in human nature, dharma, adharma, and the succession of results and the cycle continues. This is sa·πÉsƒÅra or worldly existence.

The Means to Attain the Supreme Self

Mok·π£a is beyond this causal chain of transformation. It is the transcendence of activity by being rid of desire. The activity of the liberated one is known as adhi-dharma, which is beyond the fruits of dharma and adharma. Sa·πÉsƒÅra is not a burden to the liberated but rather a lƒ´lƒÅ, an effortless pastime, which implies that sa·πÉsƒÅra becomes light, as if it does not exist.

When the practice of dharma becomes easy, when dharma happens without exertion, and when it occurs as naturally and involuntarily as breathing ‚Äì thence begins the conduct of adhi-dharma. That is the liberated state. Therefore all our effort has to be in the performance of dharma. The riddle of life is completely embedded in the question of dharma.

ki·πÉ karma kim-akarmeti kavayo‚Äôpy-atra mohitƒÅ·∏•‡•§ (BG 4.16)

‚ÄúEven the most intelligent become foolish when it comes to what is to be done and what is not to be done,‚Äù declares ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa himself. Dharma has to nourish the attachment to desire and wealth as well as restrain it. When should the nourishment stop? When should the restraint begin? Our difficulty is in determining this boundary.

Nature stands behind attachment to desire and wealth as support. She excites the sense organs, causes a preponderance of selfish desire, and erases discernment. There is yet another power of confusion that joins her ‚Äì our past karma. There is no guarantee of a result regardless of how bravely we fight without losing our sense of discrimination, no guarantee of absolute freedom from danger either. Waves of accidents hit so many lives. Obstacles and dangers occur unexpectedly like typhoons and earthquakes. Just as pre-ordained favourable karma envelops us with the fuzzy lustre of delusion, ill-luck covers us with a shroud of darkness. How can we glimpse dharma when our eyes are hazy with sorrows and crises?

Just as there is no limit to the creative faculty of Nature, there is no limit to human misfortune either. She conjures up dainty delicacies and new games. But man is tortured by ever new hungers and pains. On one side are fresh desires while on the other side are old deeds. Enmeshed between the two, the jƒ´va finds it necessary to concentrate on an entirely different means towards well-being. Dharma has to nourish fresh desires, educate, stand up human effort and uplift the jƒ´va. By stating

gahanƒÅ karma·πáo gati·∏• ‡•• (BG 4.17)

BhagavƒÅn illustrates the knotty nature of the dharma-riddle. The duty of dharma is to reconcile a jƒ´va‚Äôs ancient residue of karma with its current desires and future well-being. Among these three, the one that must gain the upper hand is future well-being, which is the way of attaining the Divine.

[[The Great Instruction of the Gƒ´tƒÅ Source: prekshaa]]

The Yoga of Life

The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ establishes and illustrates these three problems of life on a philosophical foundation. There is a place for kƒÅma, a place for artha, a place for dharma, and a place for mok·π£a. How is it possible to establish the suitability of attaining one of these four? What are the rules for each of the four puru·π£ƒÅrthas? How are those four courses to be adjusted to ensure that they do not hamper one another? Indicating the answers to these questions through an elucidation of the nature of worldly life and core principles is the scripture of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. It shows the path for men and women to elevate their lives according to their mental preparations, their intellectual capabilities, and their circumstances. Therefore it is but apt to call the Gƒ´tƒÅ a ‚ÄòSamyag-jƒ´vana-≈õƒÅstra‚Äô (‚ÄòScripture of a Good Life‚Äô) or ‚ÄòJƒ´vana-yoga-≈õƒÅstra‚Äô (‚ÄòScripture of Life-Yoga‚Äô).

The Great Instruction

The great teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is Respect for Life. Life is a play of Brahman, the Supreme Consciousness. Be it any animal, its inner state has an element of the power of the Supreme Brahman. It is our duty to realize this and perform our life‚Äôs work with faith and efficiency. We should not belittle Life by deeming it insignificant. Life is an opportunity to obtain the best. It is a great duty and therefore worthy of our worship and service. One should engage in one‚Äôs own dharma with a pure mind and a faith for the Absolute. A life well-led is a life spent in the worship of the Divine.

The Yoga of the Full Life

It is an article of belief of our ancestors that the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ is the essence of all the Vedas and VedƒÅnta. That the Gƒ´tƒÅ too is an Upani·π£ad is an object of faith and tradition.

‚Äú≈örƒ´mad-bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅsu upani·π£atsu…‚Äù goes the description.

‚ÄúSarvopani·π£ado gƒÅva·∏•… dugdha·πÉ gƒ´tƒÅm·πõtam mahat…‚Äù is another description that states that the Gƒ´tƒÅ is an Upani·π£ad.

It seems proper to say that the Vedas and the Upani·π£ads (known as VedƒÅnta) have found reconcilement in the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ. The non-Upani·π£ad portions of the Vedas ‚Äì i.e., the Sa·πÉhitƒÅ and the BrƒÅhma·πáa portions deal especially with the worship of devatƒÅs. The Upani·π£ads focus on the principle of ƒÅtman or the Self. The Gƒ´tƒÅ integrates the path of worship of the Vedic karma portion with the philosophical inquiry that is found in the j√±ƒÅna portions of the Veda. The Good Life is not a ‚Äòpoint‚Äô-like concept; it is like a ‚Äòline‚Äô that comprises a multitude of points. It is not of a ‚Äòpoint in time‚Äô or a single moment but of a ‚Äòperiod of time‚Äô comprising innumerable moments. There is scope in it for worship of devatƒÅs through yaj√±a, dƒÅna, and tapas. There is opportunity for worldly duty in the form of personal as well as societal works. There is room for philosophical contemplation via meditation on the Self.

The Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ demonstrates that each of the following three ‚Äì 1. Worship of devatƒÅs, 2. Life in the world, and 3. Meditation on the nature of the Self ‚Äì are connected to one another, and that each of them have a definite position in the Good Life and that they have to be comprehended in an integrated, holistic form.

Thus a great benefit for us from the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ is the vision of an Integrated Good Life for all of humankind except perhaps the pure atheist. The vision of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is such that it is acceptable to not just those Hindus who believe in the testimony of ≈õruti and sm·πõti but also to those Parsis, Muslims, Christians, and those of other faiths without religious contradiction. 17 Its teaching is not against rationality in any portion. There is no religious dogmatism or heterodoxy or intolerance towards other opinions in the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

tad-viddhi… paripra≈õnena‚Ä¶‡•• (BG 4.34)
[Learn that… by sincere questioning and enquiry…]

vim·πõ≈õyaitad-a≈õe·π£e·πáa…‡•• (BG 18.63)
[Having reflected upon this without leaving anything unexamined…]

Thus the Gƒ´tƒÅ does require reasoning. It is reliant upon the Veda only when it comes to supra-sensory reality. For the Truth that is not available via direct perception or the Truth that although experienced as one‚Äôs own Self is inconceivable, there is no other resort for us than the Veda. In such an unavoidable situation, though the Gƒ´tƒÅ quotes from the Veda, it could still be considered a hypothesis that needs further reasoning.

Logic or reasoning is about something known. There is no ground for logic in a void that is bereft of any experienced object. A statement about something that provides matter for logical reasoning is a ‚Äòhypothesis.‚Äô It could be a positive or negative statement but should convey a definite opinion. When we encounter such a hypothesis, we consider it from different perspectives and ask different questions. We discuss it with our experience and reasoning. If that statement stands scrutiny of all these examinations, it becomes a principle. The Gƒ´tƒÅ‚Äôs statements about Reality stand unshaken even after many such analyses. That is why the Gƒ´tƒÅ is considered an authority. All those questions that are born either of the intellect or out of experience can be answered by the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

The statement of the scholar Theodore Goldstucker that Hinduism is like an ocean can be applied to the Gƒ´tƒÅ as well. Young children feel happy when they look at the ocean. They play with the sand on its beaches. They dance with joy when they see the variegated conches and shells. They are amazed by the ceaseless play of the waves. Adults experience pleasure by splashing waves on one another. They expand their sight to the horizon and become contemplative. They desire to voyage on it in boats and ships. They stretch their bodies to take in the ocean breeze. This is about common people. Brave seafarers immerse in the mass of water and bring up pearls, jade, and jewels. SanƒÅtana-dharma is also like that. From the devotees of village deities such as MƒÅramma and Ga·πÖgamma, from those that sacrifice chicken and male buffaloes to those savants who realize the Impersonal and Formless Truth, people of all classes, all kinds, and all levels of capabilities are provided‚Äîby the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ‚Äîthe satisfaction of bettering their self according to their mental and intellectual capabilities.

The Gƒ´tƒÅ offers a meaningful and holistic vision of life. It has considered every aspect of human life without ignoring anything. It has analysed every facet of human nature without overlooking it. It has addressed the welfare of human beings of all possible levels of worth without giving up on them. It is an all-round, all-capable set of principles. It is harmonious in its essence without any inconsistency. None should feel disheartened if he could not find an answer to his question. He should reflect upon the statements of the Gƒ´tƒÅ again and again. This becomes possible when the entire text is in his memory. The problem that arises in one part of the text finds a solution in another part. Any deficiency seen is not in the work but in one‚Äôs study of it. He must reflect upon it repeatedly. Reflection with patience and mindfulness is required. As he discusses the work within himself, and resolves every issue that arises, facets that were not apparent from the beginning become manifest and solve his doubts. Such constant contemplation is possible only for someone endowed with ≈õraddhƒÅ.

≈õraddhƒÅvƒÅn labhate j√±ƒÅnam‡•• (BG 4.39)
[The sincere one endowed with dedication attains wisdom]

yo yacchraddha·∏• sa eva sa·∏•‡•• (BG 17.3)
[A man is what his ≈õraddhƒÅ is]

≈õraddhƒÅ hi paramƒÅ gati·∏•‡••
[Dedication‚Äî≈õraddhƒÅ‚Äîis the highest state]

The one without ≈õraddhƒÅ cannot escape mental delusion. The Gƒ´tƒÅ is an elucidation of the philosophy of jagat, jƒ´va, and ƒ´≈õvara that is complete, consistent, and harmonious all over. Venturing near the Gƒ´tƒÅ without ≈õraddhƒÅ is like entering a temple when unclean ‚Äì it is an effort in vain.

If the essence of the Gƒ´tƒÅ has to be conveyed to a person of faith, it could be done so through this proclamation of the ƒ™≈õopani·π£ad ‚Äì

kurvann-eveha karmƒÅ·πái jijƒ´vi·π£ecchatag·πÉ samƒÅ·∏•‡••
[Doing your karma here, desire to live for a hundred years!]

Which means that life is not evil. One should not wish to abandon it but face the difficulties in it and fight them bravely. This is the teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

tasmƒÅd-yudhyasva bhƒÅrata‡•• (BG 2.18)
[Therefore, fight, O descendent of Bharata!]

Gist

‡≤≠‡≤∞‡≤§‡≤ï‡≥Å‡≤≤‡≤¶‡≥Å‡≤≠‡≤Ø‡≤µ‡≤æ‡≤π‡≤ø‡≤®‡≤ø

Substance

When the armies of the Kauravas and PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas gathered at Kuruk·π£etra, known as dharma-k·π£etra‚Äîthe abode of dharma‚ÄîArjuna beheld his elders and relatives in front of him and was overcome with pity. He said that he did not want to enjoy the kingdom that he would obtain by killing his near and dear ones. Thus he became ‚Äò≈õoka-sa·πÉvigna-mƒÅnasa·∏•‚Äô ‚Äì i.e., his mind was agitated by sorrow. He threw his bow and quiver down and told K·πõ·π£·πáa that he would not fight.

Chapter One

Arjuna-vi·π£ƒÅda-yoga (The Yoga of Arjuna’s Distress)

or PrƒÅk·πõta-kƒÅru·πáya-yoga (The Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion)

The first chapter of the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ is a story, not instruction. This story relates the reason for the Gƒ´topade≈õa. Since the purport of this work can be easily discerned from its commencement, even though this chapter does not have any teaching, it is portentous of the nature of the instruction that follows. This story is in two parts ‚Äì

1. The description of the preparation for war and

2. Arjuna‚Äôs aversion for fighting.

1. Preparation for War

Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra, the king of HastinƒÅpura*,* asks Sa√±jaya what his children‚Äîthe Kauravas‚Äîand his brother‚Äôs children‚Äîthe PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas‚Äîdid.

Replying to that*,* Sa√±jaya said, ‚ÄúO king, your son Duryodhana saw the preparation of the army of the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas. He came to Dro·πáƒÅcƒÅrya and requested him thus ‚Äì ‚ÄòVenerable Sir, there are many mighty heroes on both sides. Still, the force under Bhƒ´·π£ma‚Äôs command is not enough; the army of the enemy led by Bhƒ´ma is adequate. Therefore, you and the heroes on our side may please protect Bhƒ´·π£ma from all sides.‚Äô‚Äù

aparyƒÅpta·πÉ tad-asmƒÅka·πÉ bala·πÉ bhƒ´·π£mƒÅbhirak·π£ita·πÉ‡•§
paryƒÅpta·πÉ tv-idam-ete·π£ƒÅ·πÉ bala·πÉ bhƒ´mƒÅbhirak·π£ita·πÉ‡•• (BG 1.10)

…bhƒ´·π£mam-evƒÅbhirak·π£antu bhavanta·∏• sarva eva hi‡•• (BG 1.11)

Hadn‚Äôt Duryodhana, in the beginning, designated Bhƒ´·π£ma as the commander of the army? Why did he go to Dro·πáa instead of Bhƒ´·π£ma? From his words, it appears that Duryodhana had some doubt in his mind. (1) Did he believe that Bhƒ´·π£ma was partial towards the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas, and therefore he might not fight with his full might in the battle? (2) Did he think that Bhƒ´·π£ma was old and lacked physical strength? (3) Did he consider Bhƒ´ma to be more competent, even though Bhƒ´·π£ma was a mighty warrior? (4) Or, if the above three were not the reasons, did he think that Dro·πáa was beleaguered by jealousy or anger that he was not chosen to be the commander-in-chief of the army, and try to allay that by flattery? (5) Alternatively, did he deem it profitable to have Dro·πáƒÅcƒÅrya‚Äôs pride stirred up by indicating that deep inside, his own respect and reliance were more in him, even though he had designated Bhƒ´·π£ma as the commander-in-chief as a mere formality? Thus, we can think of five or six reasons for this supplication of Dro·πáƒÅ by Duryodhana. Let the reasons be as they may, it is clear that Duryodhana was not without doubt. His mind was wandering because of fear and apprehension. This conjecture becomes established later, in the 19^(th) verse.

sa gho·π£o dhƒÅrtarƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒÅ·πáƒÅ·πÉ h·πõdayƒÅni vyadƒÅrayat‡•§ (BG 1.19)

The sound from the conches of the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas tore the hearts of the Kauravas.

As if he guessed at the misgivings in Duryodhana‚Äôs mind, Bhƒ´·π£ma blew his conch loudly with a mighty roar like that of a lion. That was a sign that they were ready for battle. In reply to that, all the commanders sounded their conches.

…≈õa·πÖkhƒÅn dadhmu·∏• p·πõthak p·πõthak‡•• (BG 1.18)

This invitation to battle is the first stage of the story.

2. Arjuna‚Äôs Reluctance to Fight

When the time to use his weapons had finally arrived, Arjuna requested K·πõ·π£·πáa ‚Äì

senayor-ubhayor-madhye ratha·πÉ sthƒÅpaya me‚Äôcyuta‡•• (BG 1.21)

‚ÄúO Imperishable One! Please park my chariot between the two armies. With my own eyes, let me see whom I have to fight with ‚Äì those who are backing the vile Duryodhana!‚Äù K·πõ·π£·πáa parked the chariot as requested and asked Arjuna to look at the Kaurava army. When Arjuna did so, he saw that all the warriors on the Kaurava side were his near and dear ones. Men whom he regarded as he did his own father, his preceptors, uncles, brothers, nephews, grandchildren, friends and relatives; they were all his own people. As soon as he saw them, Arjuna felt the gush of affection and attachment specially reserved for one‚Äôs own relatives. As soon as the realization that they were worthy of his respect, love, and affection dawned on him, Arjuna‚Äôs heart melted. He became limp and broke down; his face fell, his bow slipped from his unsteady hands and his willpower gave way.

etƒÅn-na hantum-icchƒÅmi ghnato‚Äôpi madhus≈´dana‡•§ (BG 1.35)

‚ÄúO slayer of Madhu, let them kill me if they want to, I do not want to slay them!‚Äù ‚Äì thus decided Arjuna.

This conduct of Arjuna was unexpected. Arjuna was no fledgling in battle; that was certainly not the first time he saw huge armies. He was a renowned warrior and had won hundreds of wars. He was familiar with the brutality and horrors of battle. Secondly, he also knew that his opponents were his own people. He had not forgotten that elders such as ≈öalya were deserving of respect and that Duryodhana, Du≈õ≈õƒÅsana, and others were his cousins. The pity that had not surfaced in him until then arose in him at that very moment. How did that happen?

We must ponder upon this. Our mental speculations about a far-off object, based only on our imagination and hearsay, will all undergo an abrupt sea-change when it comes nearer. We may hear and consider the bereavement of a friend and may think that we have understood its nature; but when we experience the same thing, we think of it as a new calamity and suffer. This is the power of direct experience. The mind is more agitated and frenzied with direct experience, rather than hearing in detail about the same thing. Thus, Arjuna‚Äôs experience in the battlefield of Kuruk·π£etra is an unfamiliar experience for him, in a way.

…hatvƒÅ sva-janam-ƒÅhave‡•• (BG 1.31)

The feeling of ‚Äòsva‚Äô in ‚Äòsva-jana‚Äô (1.28, 31, 37, and 45) became intense when Arjuna saw his elders and relatives. That is the extreme result of his cognizance of the fact that he, himself was now about to fight them. The grim spectacle of his kindred geared up for battle at Kuruk·π£etra excited the passionate proprietorship of Arjuna.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

At this point, as an example of the severity of the result of one‚Äôs own experience, we can recollect the episode of the blind king Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra. VyƒÅsa offered to give him the capability to witness the scenes in the battlefield.

yadi tv-icchasi sa·πÖgrƒÅme dra·π£·π≠um-ena·πÉ vi≈õƒÅmpate‡•§
cak·π£ur-dadƒÅni te hanta yuddham-etan-ni≈õamaya‡••
(Bhƒ´·π£ma-parva 2.6)

Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra replied ‚Äì

na rocaye j√±ƒÅti-vadha·πÉ dra·π£·π≠u·πÉ brahmar·π£i-sattama‡•§
yuddham-etat-tv-a≈õe·π£e·πáa ≈õ·πõ·πáuyƒÅ·πÉ tava tejasƒÅ‡••
(Bhƒ´·π£ma-parva 2.7)

I do not want to watch the massacre of kinsmen with my own eyes but I am interested in the war. Therefore, grace me so that I can hear about the occurrences in the war. Acceding to this request, VyƒÅsa bestowed upon Sa√±jaya the capability to view the battle from afar and arranged for him to narrate it to Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra.

Dh·πõtarƒÅ·π£·π≠ra was Arjuna‚Äôs senior. He was older and more experienced. Therefore, he did not want to witness the horrors of the battle with his own eyes. The effect of sight on the mind is more acute than that of hearing. The eyes cannot bear as much as the ears do.

The reasons that Arjuna gave to justify his aversion for war are required to be pondered upon by all those who are desirous of knowing about dharma ‚Äì

  1. It is not good to kill one‚Äôs own relatives. 2. ‚ÄúNa kƒÅ·πÖk·π£e vijayam‚Äù ‚Äì I do not desire to win. 3. ‚ÄúKi·πÉ no rƒÅjyena ki·πÉ bhogai·∏•‚Äù ‚Äì What is the use of kingdom and enjoyment? 4. ‚ÄúKi·πÉ jƒ´vitena‚Äù ‚Äì What is the use of living? 5. ‚ÄúPƒÅpam-evƒÅ≈õrayedasmƒÅn‚Äù ‚Äì We will only accrue sin by this battle. 6. ‚ÄúLobhopahata-cetasa·∏•‚Äù ‚Äì Should we become afflicted by avarice? 7. ‚ÄúKula-k·π£aya-k·πõta·πÉ do≈õa·πÉ‚Äù ‚Äì Corruption that causes the annihilation of the entire clan. 8. ‚ÄúMitra-drohe ca pƒÅtakam‚Äù ‚Äì The pƒÅpa of betraying friends. 9. ‚ÄúKula-dharmƒÅ·∏• pra·πáa≈õyanti‚Äù ‚Äì The dharma of the entire race will be destroyed. 10. ‚ÄúDharme na·π£·π≠e adharmo‚Äôbhibhavati‚Äù ‚Äì When dharma is destroyed, adharma will dominate. 11. ‚ÄúPradu·π£yanti kula-striya·∏•‚Äù ‚Äì Virtuous women will also debase themselves. 12. ‚ÄúJƒÅyate var·πáa-sa·πÖkara·∏•‚Äù ‚Äì Different var·πáas will mix together. 13. ‚ÄúSa·πÖkaro narakƒÅyaiva‚Äù ‚Äì This inter-mingling will pave the way to naraka. 14. ‚ÄúPatanti pitara·∏•‚Äù ‚Äì The pit·πõs will be dragged down. 15. ‚ÄúUtsƒÅdyante jƒÅti-dharmƒÅ·∏• kula-dharmƒÅ≈õ-ca‚Äù ‚Äì The individual dharmas of different jƒÅtis and clans will be ruined.

And so on and so forth.

In this list of the evils of war, there is no mention of mok·π£a; there is no thirst to know oneself; nor is there a dialogue about human nature. This is what we have to always keep in mind because the Gƒ´tƒÅ discusses these three key points. Why did they appear in K·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs answer although they were not present in Arjuna‚Äôs question? To know this, we have to completely understand the fundamental parts of Arjuna‚Äôs question. The feelings hidden in the above list of Arjuna’s arguments may be divided into four groups ‚Äì

  1. The necessity of pity 2. Being scared of pƒÅpa 3. Being detached from worldly enjoyment 4. Being rooted in dharma, having deep ≈õraddhƒÅ in it

Which of these four can we reject? Haven‚Äôt we always been taught that we should practise the above four qualities? What is the deficiency in Arjuna’s argument then? Why did K·πõ·π£·πáa not agree to it?

The first chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ has always been called the ‚ÄòYoga of Arjuna‚Äôs despondency.‚Äô True, there is despondency here. But is it the sole subject this chapter deals with? There is a reason behind Arjuna‚Äôs despair. There is also a direction to it. We should understand both.

The outcome of Arjuna‚Äôs excessive pity was his reluctance to fight. By killing, he would not only lose his loved ones but also invite pƒÅpa. Arjuna also wanted to escape from this pƒÅpa. Is this endorsed by dharma? In a righteous war, is killing adharma? Is there any situation where killing a living being becomes dharma? This has to be deliberated upon. Had Arjuna understood the nature of dharma? Were the doubts he had about the duties of a k·π£atriya correct? What is dharma? It becomes necessary to contemplate upon this.

Distress can be caused by anything. It can be caused by the feeling of inadequacy of strength, or by a hesitation that the gods may not be pleased; or by the hopelessness that he may not be a partner to profit in future; or the fear that he himself may be injured or even die. None of these were the reasons for Arjuna‚Äôs despair; it was caused by excessive love. Sa√±jaya describes him thus ‚Äì

ta·πÉ tathƒÅ k·πõpayƒÅvi·π£·π≠am… (BG 2.1)

Arjuna is completely controlled by his love and pity. K·πõ·π£·πáa’s answer is that his pity is unfounded there. There is no doubt that mercy is a fine quality. But it is acceptable if it is exercised upon a worthy object in a worthy manner, not otherwise.

Pity is a kind of mental alteration. It has to be born, by itself, within us. It does not need outside force or even any influence. As Bhavabh≈´ti said,

vyati·π£ajati padƒÅrthƒÅn-ƒÅntara·∏• ko‚Äôpi hetur-
na khalu bahir-upƒÅdhƒ´n prƒ´taya·∏• sa·πÉ≈õrayante‡•§
(Uttara-rƒÅma-carita 6.12)

The thread that binds people together is something that is within their hearts. Love is not based on outward support. That inward object is brought into being by Nature. Just because it is natural, it cannot be concluded that such pity is acceptable or beneficial. Whether something is beneficial or hurtful should be decided only after due contemplation. Arjuna’s pity, in that sense, is not brought about by deliberation. It was an impulse of the moment. Impulse is hasty and is not enough to cultivate belief. Proper consideration and reflection should eliminate the improprieties of the emotion. Emotion thus justified by discrimination becomes acceptable.

Probably with this in mind, ≈örƒ´ YƒÅmunƒÅcƒÅrya calls Arjuna‚Äôs pity ‚ÄòasthƒÅna-kƒÅru·πáya‚Äô ‚Äì compassion at a wrong time and wrong place. Arjuna‚Äôs intemperate and inconsiderate pity can be classified as a sentiment. Sentiment is emotion, or even excessive emotion. The heart when it does not submit itself to being examined by the head becomes agitated, it is sentimental. BhagavƒÅn calls this ‚Äòh·πõdaya-daurbalya‚Äô ‚Äì weakness of the heart. The softer the heart, the shallower it is, the weaker it becomes. We can call it the quagmire of tears. It may be said that this kind of flaccidity and unsteadiness is characteristic of our times.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

It is claimed often that ours is an Age of Science, an era of intellectual superiority. On the one hand, the intellect is mighty but on the other hand, the mind is fragile. Our times despise difficulties. Let nothing be difficult, may everything be easy ‚Äì a piece of cake ‚Äì this is today‚Äôs mindset.

This starts in our schools. Indian languages have the letters cha, bha, k·π£a, hra ‚Äì who needs these letters? They weary the children.

Let us not chastise students for anything. They have to be reformed by bribes of candy and sweets. Let us spare the rod even if it spoils the child.

Skin exposed to the sun and wind will become rough. Let us keep it covered always.

It is perturbing to be asked to brush one‚Äôs teeth before breakfast. Let people eat whenever they want, brush their teeth whenever they want.

Thus flows the river of pity in spate!

Why should one obtain forty out of a hundred marks to pass? It is enough if she manages ten!

There should be a manure shop right next to a shop that sells fine musk. That is equality.

Let the man who has never had a bath in his life rub the body of a man who bathes daily. Isn‚Äôt that brotherhood?

If the daughter says that she does not want to marry someone who is not a billionaire, can we ask her to marry a millionaire? If we do force her, what will become of individual freedom?

If there is an unjust conflict between countries, let us prattle about peace and non-violence and not even raise the subject of war. Let our weapons rust even if our hearts simmer.

Why does the Creator give legs to humans? It is because of legs that we have to walk and strain ourselves. Instead of that, let us design a machine in a car that will lift people and seat them within.

Why should the Supreme create horses? Horse-riding is dangerous and fatiguing. Let men fly without the least exertion.

Why do we need snacks like chakli or pu·∏ª·∏ªa·πÖgƒÅyi? They exhaust the teeth. Can we not suck tasty candy instead?

If a debtor does not repay his loans, do not demand that from him! Let him not fear about being jailed. Scaring is torturing. Let us take pity on him and loan him more money.

Let murderers not be afraid of execution. Let us give them asylum with tasty food and warm shelter so that he does not feel any grief.

The police should not incarcerate dacoits and cause them undue hardship. They should beg them to become good citizens.

Workers should forget that they are working and behave as though they are masters. Let the company run into losses, it does not matter. The happiness of the comrades is paramount.

The stone-hearted RƒÅma sent Sƒ´tƒÅ to the forest in a cruel manner. Why should we worship him?

The river of pity flows further. This is the weakness of the soul, the fragility of the mind. It is not manliness.

If a human soul has to become strong, it should be ready to face difficulties.

nƒÅyam-ƒÅtmƒÅ bala-hƒ´nena labhya·∏•…
(Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad 3.2.4)

A coward cannot grasp dharma. It needs courage and intelligence. The bones of a lazy man are soft; he is not capable of taking on challenges or fighting in wars. He cannot protect dharma.

Only the tƒÅmasika and rƒÅjasika qualities of humans cause war, not sƒÅttvika. When sattva is prominent, there is no conflict. Even if there is one, it is resolved quickly. Rajas and tamas do not end like that. They understand the language of the stick, not that of guidance. The predominant trait of Duryodhana and Du≈õ≈õƒÅsana is tƒÅmasika, not sƒÅttvika. For such rulers guided by their baser instincts, any medicine other than war would be useless. Therefore, there was no means to correct them except stringent punishment.

A great man said, ‚ÄúWhat is dharma without mercy?‚Äù A philosopher said, ‚ÄúWhat sort of mercy is it, without dharma?‚Äù Thus, to aid in the goal of establishing dharma, just as there is a place for mercy, there is also a place for punishment. Courage is the first quality needed in a person who wants to protect dharma. A man who flees without fighting on seeing injustice and adharma is not merciful but is actually encouraging adharma.

This, then, is the mental state of Arjuna. His is not compassion bestowed on people worthy of it but pity shown towards people who are entirely undeserving of it. BhagavƒÅn himself proclaims that one should exercise due discretion whether the recipient is worthy of pity.

de≈õe kƒÅle ca pƒÅtre ca tad-dƒÅna·πÉ sƒÅttvika·πÉ sm·πõtam‡•• (BG 17.20)

This philosophy had been forgotten by Arjuna.

Arjuna‚Äôs thought was that of pity but the circumstances were not right. PƒÅyasam is good to eat and digest, not to smear on the body. This discrimination ‚Äì of finding the right place to do the right thing is the basis of dharma.

That Arjuna‚Äôs dejection transformed into pity and detachment shows that his understanding was superior. His dispassion is not that of a coward or a weak person. The dejection of some people transforms itself into rage. In some others, it brings hopelessness and rigidity. Arjuna did not become depressed or angry. His words ‚ÄòKi·πÉ bhogair-jƒ´vitena vƒÅ‚Äô do not have any philosophical curiosity. His mind is uncertain about dharma. That had to be remedied. The reason for the uncertainty was the pity that arose in him.

Like anger, pity is also a mental change. In normal human circumstances, it may be a good sentiment. There is no dharma without mercy, but mercy should not be unrefined. The pity that animals and birds show to their young ones is artless and unrefined. Mother Nature has placed this unthinking inclination in all living organisms. In lower organisms, the purpose of this natural inclination is to nurture the offspring. In humans, if this natural inclination works independently of discrimination it can cause confusion and have adverse consequences. Compassion not tempered by discrimination is unbridled infatuation and delusion ‚Äì that is partiality; that is the confused view; that is the thorn in the way of justice. Therefore, BhagavƒÅn felt that the juice of compassion that swelled in Arjuna out of his natural inclination had to be filtered by viveka. Mental alterations have to be purified by philosophy ‚Äì that is the subject of the next chapter.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

The fault of Arjuna‚Äôs compassion is not just that it was indiscriminate and unexamined. It was mixed with ego. The self-delusion that he was responsible for deciding the nature of his dharma, that the others were fit for compassion, that the decision to fight the war was out of his own free will (see BG 18.58‚Äì59) was included in it.

Among the various forms of human relationship, compassion is indeed great. There are very few people in the world worthy of compassion but dharma applies to the whole world. Therefore, the appropriateness or inappropriateness of compassion has to be examined with due consideration given to dharma. Dharma is a conglomeration of many principles of which compassion is only one. A dhƒÅrmic person should consider other relevant principles during his course of action.

Compassion is natural whereas dharma is established by right judgment. The basis of compassion is nature whereas the basis of dharma is philosophical deliberation. Compassion that negates dharma can be disastrous. Therefore, when compassion manifests itself, it is necessary to examine and purify it in the light of philosophy. Thus, a study of the nature of dharma becomes pertinent.

Summary

‡≤∞‡≤£‡≤Æ‡≤ò‡≤Æ‡≥Ç‡≤≤‡≤Ç ‡≤™‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤Ø‡≤ó‡≥Å‡≤∞‡≥Å ‡•§
‡≤π‡≤®‡≤®‡≤ï‡≤∞‡≤Ç ‡≤≤‡≥ã‡≤ï‡≤ß‡≤∞‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≤ò‡≤æ‡≤§‡≤ï‡≤Æ‡≤¶‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤Ç ‡••

War is the root cause of pƒÅpa, causes elders and loved ones
To be killed, destroys the dharma of the world, therefore
I will not bear my bow, said Arjuna
To the Lord ‚Äì thus finishes the first chapter.

Appendix: Dharma is Multifaceted

Many people think that dharma is a feast of lƒÅ·∏çus and cƒ´ro·π≠is. They do not feel that pepper chutney and ginger pickle are dharma. Arjuna is like them.

He is a good man. His virtues are something we generally praise but we do not know if viveka is part of it. Goodness unaccompanied by viveka cannot yield the intended result. In the feast of a man of discernment, there is a place for pepper rasam, just as there is a place for pƒÅyasam. In the conduct of dharma, just like there is a place for compassion, there is a place for stone-heartedness.

vajrƒÅd-api ka·π≠horƒÅ·πái m·πõd≈´ni kusumƒÅd-api‡•§
(Uttara-rƒÅma-carita 2.7)

Arjuna had forgotten this. Just as nurturing life is dharma, there can be circumstances where killing also becomes dharma. Just as friendship is dharma, there are also circumstances where war becomes dharma. In the case of Sugrƒ´va and Vibhƒ´·π£a·πáa, friendship became dharma for ≈örƒ´rƒÅma. In the case of VƒÅlƒ´ and RƒÅva·πáa, killing became his dharma.

The essence of dharma is the elevation of the soul. By following dharma, the soul should get trained and should elevate itself to at least a little higher state. The souls of Sugrƒ´va and Vibhƒ´·π£a·πáa were in a slightly more elevated state than those of Vali and Ravana. The training that they had to undergo had to be done through friendship. VƒÅlƒ´ and RƒÅva·πáa lacked the qualifications to be trained through friendship in their current birth, so it was necessary for them to be reborn to acquire them. Some dirty clothes can be washed and cleaned. Some other dirty clothes cannot even be touched by water ‚Äì fire is their refuge. The same can be said about bodies. This is the essence of the art and dharma of war.

After Hira·πáyaka≈õipu was killed, his son PrahlƒÅda beseeched Narasi·πÉha to grant him salvation. The Supreme One replied ‚Äì

tri·∏•-saptabhi·∏• pitƒÅ p≈´ta·∏• pit·πõbhi·∏• saha te‚Äônagha‡•§ (BhƒÅgavata-purƒÅ·πáa 7.10.18)

…pitu·∏• p≈´tasya sarva≈õa·∏•‡•§
mada·πÖga-spar≈õanenƒÅ·πÖga-lokƒÅn yƒÅsyati suprajƒÅ·∏•‡•• (BhƒÅgavata-purƒÅ·πáa 7.10.22)

The touch of the Supreme‚Äôs limbs is the panacea that cures the pƒÅpƒ´. Therefore, BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs avatƒÅra kills the pƒÅpƒ´, thereby freeing the soul from the prison of vice. This sort of killing, even though it looks cruel at the superficial level, it is not cruelty but compassion when examined subtly. It is the compassion of a wise man ‚Äì like that of a surgeon.

Dharma has to occasionally take fierce forms ‚Äì just as the hands of the father who feeds sweets might also have to give a slap. Just as a spank from the father is affection, just as the bitter medicine from the physician is compassion, so also is the war that is waged for the sake of dharma.

Dharma is not just the sound of festive bells, it is also the sound of lions‚Äô roar. The call of dharma is not just for feminine affection but also for masculine brave-hearts. Our people should understand this well. After pepper has finished its job, black gram can take its place. After war has finished its work, compassion and affection can find their places. After the stick of the teacher has worked its magic, the disciple will win prizes. BhagavƒÅn himself has indicated this ‚Äì

yat-tad-agre vi·π£am-iva pari·πáƒÅme‚Äôm·πõtopamam‡•§ (BG 18.37)

Neem always comes before jaggery.

du·∏•kham-ity-eva yat-karma kƒÅya-kle≈õa-bhayƒÅt tyajet‡•§ (BG 18.8)

na dve·π£·π≠y-aku≈õala·πÉ karma ku≈õale nƒÅnu·π£ajvate‡•§ (BG 18.10)

We should not give up a job because it is tedious. It should not be avoided just because it is difficult for the body. An activity should not be shunned because it is difficult or disagreeable; neither should it be adhered to because it is delightful.

It is enough if a job is dharma. Whatever it is, it has to be finished ‚Äì that is the purport of this chapter. It is not right to eye the results, whether they are good or bad, attained or not attained.

Like the PitƒÅmaha BrahmƒÅ, dharma can also be visualized as having four faces. It is said that BrahmƒÅ recites the four Vedas through his four mouths. Dharma, with its four mouths, will teach these four duties ‚Äì (1) nurturing of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, (2) purification of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, (3) understanding the true nature of Self, and (4) benevolence towards the world. Among the above, purification of the ƒÅtmƒÅ is tapas. It cannot be achieved by short-cuts. Like ≈öiva, it has a terrific form; it performs the fearsome tƒÅ·πá·∏çava dance; it drinks the hƒÅlƒÅhala. Arjuna‚Äôs eyes beheld this fierce form of dharma in front of him at Kuruk·π£etra. It needed a courageous heart not feminine yearning. It needed virility. That is why BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs advice was replete with instructions to be valorous and heroic.

‡≤Æ‡≥É‡≤¶‡≤≤‡≤Ç ‡≤™‡≥Å‡≤∑‡≥ç‡≤™‡≤¶‡≤µ‡≥ã‡≤≤‡≤¶‡≥ä‡≤Æ‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≥Ü ‡≤∂‡≤ø‡≤≤‡≥Ü‡≤µ‡≥ã‡≤≤‡≥ç ‡≤á‡≤®‡≥ç‡≤®‡≥ä‡≤Æ‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≥Ü ‡≤§‡≤æ‡≤Ç ‡≤®‡≤ø‡≤∑‡≥ç‡≤†‡≥Å‡≤∞‡≤Ç ‡•§

Soft as a flower now, hard as a rock then, rigid at another time
Flowing continuously like a river now, meandering then, and then hidden
Sweet as honey now, pungent as ginger then, behold thus, dharma takes
A hundred forms in this world, suited for various souls.

One who is cognizant of human experiences, his eyes moist with sympathy

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Gist

‡≤∏‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≤ø‡≤§‡≤¶‡≤ø‡≤Ç ‡≤∏‡≥å‡≤π‡≥É‡≤¶‡≤µ‡≥Ä‡≤ï‡≥ç‡≤∑‡≤æ-

With a smile and a nectar-like glance of friendship,
the world-teacher, K·πõ·π£·πáa, sang the essence of life,
curing Phalgu·πáa‚Äôs (Arjuna‚Äôs) mind delusion

What is compassion that lacks reflection?
What is faith in dharma without the basis of analysis?
What is renunciation if accompanied by sorrow?
Does a pit hidden by a spread of fresh flowers count as pleasure?

Elucidating the nature of reality
from sƒÅ·πÖkhya and other ancient sciences,
BhagavƒÅn expounded upon the indestructibility of
the eternal and omnipresent Self in detail and
rid Arjuna of his fear.

Substance

Arjuna was unaware of exceptional circumstances wherein violence became imperative and compassion became inappropriate. He did not realize that a limited personal perspective or common public opinion was insufficient to arrive at the right conclusion. He was ignorant of the idea that the determination of one‚Äôs dharma required discernment between the Real and the Unreal.

Karma (action) depends upon the performer whereas the fruit of action is dependent on Providence. Excellence or kau≈õala (skill) is that by which one does not accumulate detriment while performing one‚Äôs dharma.

Chapter Two

SƒÅ·πÖkhya-yoga (The Yoga of Knowledge)

or Tattva-viveka-yoga (The Yoga of Discernment of Reality)

Terminology

There are several words of ≈õƒÅstric terminology in the Gƒ´tƒÅ such as ƒÅtmƒÅ, brahman, and prak·πõti, which have not been defined or explained. Such words had been in common parlance for ages prior to the Gƒ´tƒÅ. These terms have come to us from the Vedas and Upani·π£ads that are thousands of years older than the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Therefore, it might not have been necessary for either VyƒÅsa, K·πõ·π£·πáa, or Arjuna to explain these terms. However, an understanding of these terms is a necessary prerequisite for our study. Let us now comprehend, albeit in brief, some of the most important terms.

1. Adhi-dharma ‚Äì This word is not found in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. I do not know if this term has been used in any ancient work. As I deem it to be a necessary term, it has been used in this work.

Dharma can be deliberated upon through six different perspectives:

A. Dharma is the body of obligatory works‚Äîboth worldly and Vedic‚Äîcomprising ritual practices, conduct, and restrictions that enables one‚Äôs own welfare as well as that of the others.

B. Svadharma is dharma based upon a person‚Äôs circumstances, clan, and society. In other words, it is one‚Äôs own dharma.

C. Adharma ‚Äì (i) Something that is not dharma or (ii) Something that is against dharma.

D. Vidharma ‚Äì (i) Something that is not one‚Äôs own dharma or (ii) The dharma of the others.

E. Ubhaya-tƒÅ·π≠asthya (indifference to both) ‚Äì Being indifferent to both dharma and adharma.

F. Adhi-dharma is one who, though beyond dharma and adharma, follows dhƒÅrmic behaviour in society. As he sees his own Self everywhere, he has no friends or foes; or likes and dislikes; and hence free from the touch of pƒÅpa and pu·πáya. Therefore the adhi-dharma has no need for rules and prohibitions. However, he acts as if he is subject to societal rules and norms and performs worldly activities while free from the fruitful or unfruitful rewards of those actions.

tyaja dharmam-adharma·πÉ ca ‡••
(Renounce both dharma and adharma)
yena tyajasi tat-tyaja ‡••
(Renounce that by which you renounce)
Sa·πÉnyƒÅsopani·π£ad 2.17

2. AvidyƒÅ ‚Äì This word is not found in the Gƒ´tƒÅ but is found in ≈õƒÅstra. AvidyƒÅ is the deficiency in human knowledge, not the absence of it. The illumination of the Self is obstructed by the impurities from previous lives. Therefore one is unable to see an illusion as an illusion. This lack of knowledge and its insufficiency is avidyƒÅ.

3. ƒÄtmƒÅ ‚Äì This word has several meanings. Let us note a few of them here:

(i) Consciousness accompanying the body ‚Äì The entity being alluded to when man refers to the word ‚ÄúI‚Äù in his mind. This ƒÅtmƒÅ, referring to itself as ‚ÄúI‚Äù (‚Äúaham‚Äù), ‚ÄúI‚Äù, separates itself from the world. This can be referred to as dehƒÅtmƒÅ or embodied self. The body or deha includes sensory and motor organs, mind, intellect and the vital airs.

(ii) Manas ‚Äì ƒÄtmƒÅ also refers to the mind that is distinct from the body. ‚ÄúMahƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù (great soul), ‚Äúdu·π£·π≠ƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù (evil soul) and ‚ÄúpƒÅpƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù (sinful soul) refer to this definition of the ƒÅtmƒÅ.

(iii) Jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äì The entity that, while different from the body and mind, illumines and enlivens both. This is referred to as the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ. The word ‚Äújƒ´va‚Äù refers to pure consciousness coupled with the body and a few other elements.

(iv) AntarƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äì Pure consciousness without any upƒÅdhis (adjuncts). This is also referred to as the k≈´·π≠ƒÅtmƒÅ or s≈´trƒÅtmƒÅ. The name s≈´trƒÅtmƒÅ denotes the consciousness that is like the string in a necklace of pearls that is unseen and untouched. It is the inner essence of all beings.

The previous definitions pertained to the individual being.

(v) ParamƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äì Collective existence of the individual consciousness found in all beings. This pervades all creation and gives energy to every being. This is an aspect of para-brahman.

4. ƒ™≈õvara ‚Äì State of brahman related to creation, preservation, destruction, and other activities pertaining to the created universe.

5. ·πöta ‚Äì Natural order in the world. This is seen in the movements of the earth, the planets, the sun, the moon, and other celestial objects as well as in the change of seasons and in the production of offspring. The special distinguishing quality seen in each individual substance is ·πõta. Seen this way, ·πõta is the seed of dharma. ·πöta is Truth contemplated upon internally, or Reality. It is also the power that makes available the appropriate fruit for karma.

6. Karma or transmigratory karma is of three kinds:

(i) Sa√±cita ‚Äì This is the collective set of merits and demerits produced by actions performed across several lives. These are waiting to yield results.

(ii) ƒÄgƒÅmi ‚Äì Karma that has not yet yielded fruit and will yield fruit later.

(iii) PrƒÅrabdha ‚Äì is a part of the sa√±cita karma that has begun to yield fruit. In a pile of grain, a few grains would have begun to sprout; prƒÅrabdha is such. This prƒÅrabdha can be exhausted only by experiencing and enduring it.

Has not the beginningless jƒ´va lived across so many births? The mass of karma that remains after experiencing its fruits is akin to today‚Äôs leftover food that came from yesterday‚Äôs cooking. This is of three kinds‚Äîsa√±cita, ƒÅgƒÅmi, prƒÅrabdha‚Äîas explained before.

When grains of ragi (or any cereal) are moistened, a few of those grains sprout sooner. Other grains sprout in time. The sprouted ones constitute prƒÅrabdha. There are other distinctions in prƒÅrabdha ‚Äì but those are not relevant here.

Terminology

[Continued]

7. KƒÅla-De≈õa ‚Äì See De≈õa-KƒÅla.

8. De≈õa-KƒÅla (Space-time) ‚Äì The ideas of size and duration that emerge in our minds through the experience of various objects and actions. Both de≈õa and kƒÅla are expressions of the existence of the world. The world is an aggregate of things and actions. The word de≈õa (or dik - direction) indicates the shape and size of objects in the world and their mutual relationships. The word kƒÅla denotes the actions of the world, the extent of their influence, and the intervals between them. The feeling of de≈õa-kƒÅla exists wherever the world exists. Where there is no world, de≈õa-kƒÅla does not exist or it is beyond the Universe. That is Infinite Existence; that is pure existence. De≈õa and kƒÅla are but markers of the experience of existence. This topic is extended in the Appendix.

9. Daiva-vidhi (Fate/Destiny) ‚Äì The Divine order that controls the experience of a jƒ´va. That is the law of ·πõta. This is the yarn woven from two threads. One of those threads is the existing individual karma of the jƒ´va. The other is the Universal law for ensuring order in collective existence. These two threads come together to form daiva.

10. Dharma ‚Äì What sustains i.e., saves and protects, is dharma. The set of activities, worldly actions, and rules that nourishes and exalts life is dharma.

The above ten aspects belong to this world. The mode of living by which a human jƒ´va gives up its adjuncts of body and bodily organs, subsequently attains Divine experience, and goes beyond the world is known as dharma. The system of the world that ensures deliverance for the jƒ´va is dharma, which is applicable to the jƒ´va as long as it is in contact with the three kinds of bodies. Once beyond the jƒ´va state, there is no bond of dharma. (See adhi-dharma)

11. Prak·πõti ‚Äì The power of brahman and is its expressed state, i.e., its external form.

12. Brahman ‚Äì The root meaning of brahman is big. In the ≈õƒÅstras, it means limitless. That is Infinity. The bounds of time or space do not limit brahman. That is of the form of consciousness. It is impossible to define it completely with words because words belong to the material world. Brahman-consciousness is not just omnipresent in the Universe but is also beyond it. It is even beyond human imagination. This brahman is parabrahman (Supreme brahman). It is also known in human conversation as ParamƒÅtmƒÅ and ƒ™≈õvara. (Look at the earlier definition of the word ‚ÄòƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äô). The source of the Universe is brahman and when expressed in the world, it is known as ≈õabala-brahman (brahman endowed with variety) or kƒÅrya-brahman (brahman as effect). The manifest brahman is also known as parame≈õvara (Supreme Lord) because in this state as ƒ™≈õvara, brahman causes creation, sustenance, and dissolution of the universe. When beyond the world, brahman is referred to as ≈õuddha-brahman (pure brahman), kƒÅra·πáa-brahman (cause brahman) or Para-brahman (Supreme brahman).

These explanations are of a coarse nature. The subtleties in meaning will become clearer as we proceed.

13. MƒÅyƒÅ ‚Äì The thing that, as a result of the incessant interaction amongst the components of the world, rises as a cloud-like layer between the seer [one who is seeing] and the seen [that which is being seen by the seer]. It makes existent objects appear as non-existent and vice-versa. That which masks an existing object is known as ƒÅvara·πáa. Making a non-existent thing appear is known as vik·π£epa.

The word mƒÅyƒÅ with its various shades of meaning will be seen in this work.

14. M≈´rta-Am≈´rta (with form-without form) ‚Äì Of the five primordial elements (Earth, Air, Water, Ether and Light), Earth, Water, and Light are considered to be with form and hence m≈´rta. Air and Ether do not have a form and are hence am≈´rta.

M≈´rta and am≈´rta are also used in the sense of sa-deha (with body) and a-deha (without body).

15. Vyakta-Avyakta (manifest-unmanifest) ‚Äì Vyakta refers to the state in which a thing‚Äôs inner qualities are expressed or manifested externally. The world is a manifestation of brahman‚Äôs power. Avyakta is the state wherein a thing‚Äôs qualities lie unexpressed like a sprout latent within a seed. This is the state of prak·πõti before creation.

16. Vya·π£·π≠i-Sama·π£·π≠i (individual-collective) ‚Äì Vya·π£·π≠i refers to the individual level; and is something that can be counted one by one or separately.

When we say ‚Äòrupee‚Äô, its hundred different paisas are counted together. The paisas individually count as vya·π£·π≠i. Sama·π£·π≠i is the integration of different things together. A collection of all vya·π£·π≠i is known as sama·π£·π≠i. Putting together a hundred different paise to form one rupee is sama·π£·π≠i.

17. VyƒÅk·πõta-AvyƒÅk·πõta (divided-undivided) ‚Äì VyƒÅk·πõta is the state when different parts are seen in a single mass of objects. The state when something is divided or classified into genera (plural of genus) and classes is vyƒÅk·πõta. VyƒÅkara·πáa (Grammar) means the same. Classifying a whole language into nouns, adjectives, verbs, indeclinables, suffixes, and prefixes and defining the relationships amongst them is vyƒÅkara·πáa.

AvyƒÅk·πõta is the state when a mass remains undifferentiated or undivided.

M≈´rta-Am≈´rta, Vyakta-Avyakta and VyƒÅk·πõta-AvyƒÅk·πõta are three sets of terms used for explaining the process of creation.

18. Sat-Asat (real-unreal) ‚Äì These words have two or three meanings.

The first meaning.

Sat ‚Äì Existent, what is created, Truth.

Asat ‚Äì Non-existent, one without a ‚Äúreal‚Äù existence, falsehood.

In this sense of meaning, asat also means mere appearance. Whatever does not exist in reality, i.e., cannot exist by itself and is dependent on something else to be perceived by the eyes, ears, and other organs, however fleetingly, is asat.

A tree is sat; its shadow is asat. Man is sat; his reflection in the mirror is asat. Similarly, brahman is sat, the world is asat. MithyƒÅ (error) is asat. Sat is Truth, reality.

Asat or mithyƒÅ (error) does not refer to a void; or complete non-existence; or something imaginary like the horns of a hare. It means that it is an appearance, dream-like.

The second meaning.

Sat ‚Äì Something that is perceivable. What we know as existent is sat.

Asat ‚Äì Something that is not perceivable. Whatever is not available to us, even if it exists.

asadvƒÅ idamagra ƒÅsƒ´t
Aitareyopani·π£ad 2.7
(Wasn‚Äôt it asat that existed before?)

Asat is imperceptible. In this meaning, asat is also avyakta (unmanifest).

The third meaning.

Sat ‚Äì What is good; beneficial.

Asat ‚Äì Not good; bad.

The Beginning of the Instruction

The second chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ has four main aspects.

  1. The remainder of the first chapter‚Äôs topic, i.e. Arjuna‚Äôs words of abandoning battle. 2. Propounding the eternal nature of the Self (ƒÅtmƒÅ) 3. The necessity of performing one‚Äôs own dharma 4. The nature of the knower of reality

Let us look at this one by one.

Arjuna‚Äôs Wish to Give Up

The story of Arjuna‚Äôs depression continues in the first nine verses. When Arjuna dropped his bow and arrows and sat immersed in sorrow, ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa objected. He said, ‚ÄúArjuna, how did this mental impurity come upon you? This does not befit an ƒÅrya. This is not conducive to attain higher realms. This causes infamy. Discard this cowardice. Cast off this lowly weakness of the heart and rise for battle!‚Äù

Arjuna replied, ‚ÄúO K·πõ·π£·πáa, how can I bring myself shoot the worshipful Bhƒ´·π£ma and Dro·πáa with my arrows? If we, by not killing preceptors, have to subsist on alms, even then, such food obtained from begging is far better than food mixed with their blood. Should we win over our enemies or be won over by them? Which path is better for us? K·πõ·π£·πáa, who are our enemies? Those upon killing whom we do not wish to live! My nature has been overcome by the taint of selfish pity that is the nature of compassion for ‚Äúme and mine‚Äù (kƒÅrpa·πáya-d≈ç·π£≈çpahata-svabhƒÅva·∏•). I have become confused about what dharma is owing to this self-love. What of a kingdom on earth or the position of Indra in svarga? I do not see anything that can cure me of my sorrow that is drying up all my senses.‚Äù He then said,

na yotsye! (BG 2.9)
‚ÄúI will not fight!‚Äù

and sat silently. The first part of the second chapter ends here.

Now, BhagavƒÅn again set forth to give instruction.

a≈õ≈çcyƒÅn-anva≈õ≈çcas-tvam (BG 2.11)
‚ÄúYou grieve for those who should not be grieved for!‚Äù

What does this mean? Should one not grieve for his preceptors and relatives? Should one become stony-hearted?

It is natural for the heart to melt with compassion. However, in some instances, one should harden his heart. The battle for dharma is such an instance.

War is an occasion that involves several groups of people. Floods, fire accidents, earthquakes, and epidemics are disasters that the Divine imposes to punish groups of people. A single person‚Äôs action also affects people other than the doer when it yields results.

ka·πõtƒÅ kƒÅrayitƒÅ caiva preraka≈õ-cƒÅnumodaka·∏•
(Nitya-nƒ´ti 30)
The performer of the action,
one who causes the action to be performer,
the one who urges it, and
the one who approves of it,
[all share equal responsibility
in good and bad deeds]

Individual karma (actions) bear individual fruit; group actions yield group results. Though Duryodhana and his brothers were the main actors in the war, Bhƒ´·π£ma, Dro·πáa, Kar·πáa, ≈öalya, and others joined forces with them regardless of whether they liked it. The same happened in their rival camp. While a few joined for the cause of dharma, there were others who joined either side for revenge, glory, or other reasons. Death was perilously close to both sides. In this episode of dharma, who were the ≈õocyas (ones to grieve for)? Who were the a≈õocyas (those who should not be grieved for)? Who? None were to be grieved for. Those who died there were not to be grieved for. Why? Death comes for a few as deliverance from their demerits. For others death results in a better path. Duryodhana, Du≈õ≈õƒÅsana and others would have continued to commit sinful actions as long as they lived. The seed of impurity had existed in them across lives. They had to be divested of their armour (body) to help them get rid of their pƒÅpa. Death became a means for this. Death in battle was the only way for them to redeem themselves from this situation of pƒÅpa.

Thus death redeems the evil from the clutches of evilness. Therefore it is not necessary to grieve for it.

Even for those who are virtuous, death is helpful. Bhƒ´·π£ma and Dro·πáa were great souls and deserved higher worlds. But they had to inhabit earth due to a residue of their karma of previous lives. Once they had exhausted their karma, they would once again become eligible for those higher worlds. Hence for those righteous, death obtained in a war of dharma helps attain heaven and better worlds. Hence sorrow is not proper even in this situation.

When is grieving appropriate, when is it proper? The answer is: Never. It is of course another matter that it cannot be avoided. It cannot be argued that all things that are natural are correct as well. There are so many bodily actions that are natural but undesirable. It is the same with mental actions too. All things natural cannot be accepted. Sorrow upon bereavement is natural. But it is wise to mitigate one‚Äôs sorrow after considering the progression of a jƒ´va and the law of nature. BhagavƒÅn now teaches this wisdom through a description of the ƒÅtmƒÅ that is the essence of the jƒ´va.

The Eternality of the ƒÄtmƒÅ

The instruction now begins. Arjuna asks four important questions:

  1. Isn‚Äôt violence or killing beings a misdeed? 2. Isn‚Äôt compassion our dharma? 3. Shouldn‚Äôt selfish desires be discarded? 4. Isn‚Äôt dharma the biggest value?

≈örƒ´-k·πõ·π£·πáa had to answer these questions.

Arjuna had all the following mental qualities: fear of doing evil, compassion towards beings, selflessness, and faith in dharma, which are accepted by all to be the best of qualities. Did such a man, endowed with such admirable qualities, need instruction? Yes. Because Arjuna possessed those qualities not as results of his own deliberations but because he was impelled by his own natural condition and also by imitating others. All of us are mostly like that. There are a few naturally friendly tendencies within us. We normally refer to that as a ‚Äútug at one‚Äôs heartstrings.‚Äù While that behaviour is devoid of any pretense, we should not consider that feeling to be completely pure. There is quite likely an iota of selfishness or a particle of pride or a piece of egotism that is non-obvious and latent in such behaviour. Friendship becomes pure and wholesome only after this aspect of self-interest is removed after a thorough examination. We learn several behaviours from those around us. We form our opinions through others. Any action or habit or opinion or belief should not be construed as pure or as being conducive to welfare just because it follows popular convention. We should have independently analysed it and understood its good aspects. Thus our behaviours and opinions must be a result of a proper examination.

It may be apt to recall the maxim of the English philosopher John Stuart Mill. It is not enough if one person forms an opinion or follows a certain set of actions because of faith in the words of others‚Äô words. One should yearn to understand the exact reasons why a certain thing is good through one‚Äôs own analysis. Then the thing becomes truly beneficial. A belief that arises from blind faith may not be as fruitful.

The same words are stated by the Vedas that are thousands of years old ‚Äì

yad-eva vidyayƒÅ karoti‚Ä¶
tad-eva vƒ´ryavattara·πÉ bhavati‡••
ChƒÅndogyopani·π£at 1.1.10
(Whatever one does with knowledge, that becomes efficacious)

vij√±ƒÅna·πÉ yaj√±a·πÉ tanute‡••
Taittirƒ´yopani·π£at 2.5
(Knowledge from analysis accomplishes an activity)

VidyƒÅ refers to knowledge ‚Äì the knowledge of a thing, knowledge that rises from deliberation on cause and effect. The knowledge that is produced from analysis is vij√±ƒÅna. Action becomes meaningful only when accompanied by knowledge borne out of reasoning and discernment. Arjuna did not possess that clarity of thought. His fear of pƒÅpa was not the result of his own analysis. It was based on what others said. His compassion was because of unrefined mental impressions and it lacked the refinement of analysis. It belonged to the feeling heart, not to the thinking mind. His dispassion similarly lacked consideration. It came from momentary distress and not as a result of discernment between the eternal and the ephemeral. The householder, encountering some disorderly conduct or arrogant behavior in his house, laments, ‚ÄúI will exit all of this and go elsewhere,‚Äù or bawls, ‚ÄúWho cares if something happens to me? I can‚Äôt deal with all this!‚Äù In the next moment, he tries to fix the problem. Arjuna‚Äôs feeling of renunciation was like that ‚Äì a renunciation that was not hardened by discretion but one assumed in a hurry. His tendency towards virtue was of the same kind ‚Äì one that came from worldly convention and not from a fundamental knowledge of dharma. He agreed that he did not comprehend the true nature of dharma.

p·πõcchƒÅmi tvƒÅ·πÉ dharma-samm≈´·∏çha-cetƒÅ·∏•‡•• (BG 2.7)
(With a mind confused about dharma, I ask you)

When K·πõ·π£·πáa began answering Arjuna‚Äôs questions it is evident from the following words that the latter was ridiculed ‚Äì ‚Äòprahasanniva‚Äô (as if laughing), ‚Äòpraj√±ƒÅvƒÅdƒÅ·πÉ≈õca bhƒÅ·π£ase‚Äô (you seem to speak words of wisdom). Arjuna‚Äôs knowledge was born out of confusion and not true wisdom. He uttered weighty words of wisdom such as pƒÅpa, pu·πáya, vairƒÅgya, dharma ‚Äì like a scholar. He did not understand anything about the origin of these wise words or their inner meaning or the depth of its meaning. That was what was derided by BhagavƒÅn as ‚Äòseeming words of wisdom.‚Äô BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs duty, then, was to disabuse Arjuna of this confusion.

‚ÄúArjuna, you are endowed with a keen faith towards dharma. Saying ‚ÄòutsƒÅdyante jƒÅti-dharmƒÅ·∏• kula-dharmƒÅ≈õ-ca ≈õƒÅ≈õvatƒÅ·∏•‚Äô (transgressed are the age-old ways of the clans and jƒÅtis) ‚Äì you expressed anxiety and sorrow. Do you, however, know what the duty of your class is? Recall it! Is parroting ‚ÄòDharma, dharma‚Äô the same as knowing its true nature?‚Äù

The crux of all of Arjuna‚Äôs questions was the matter of the ƒÅtmƒÅ (the Self). The relationship with the world, compassion, pu·πáya, pƒÅpa, and dharma ‚Äì are all matters pertaining to the jƒ´va. As the jƒ´va is a manifestation of the Self, the answers to all other questions become evident only after having known the true nature of the Self. Thus it is imperative to know what the Self is.

Dharma and adharma cannot be determined merely by our natural impulses or by worldly convention. The compassion in Arjuna‚Äôs mind was a transformation of the mind that happened naturally rather than arising out of an examined consideration. The opinions he had of pu·πáya and pƒÅpa were created by what people spoke of and lacked any solid proof or testimony. dharma has to be decided based upon the nature of reality. The nature of reality has to be determined from ≈õƒÅstra (scriptural exposition). The nature of reality is something beyond the empirical and unavailable to the senses. Hence it has to be determined only by the Vedas and other scriptural testimony. Therefore, BhagavƒÅn has declared in the sixteenth chapter ‚Äì

tasmƒÅccƒÅstra·πÉ pramƒÅ·πáa·πÉ te‡•• (BG 16.24)
(Therefore, ≈õƒÅstra is your means to knowledge.)

Dharma can be determined only by understanding the nature of reality, which in turn is determined from the ≈õƒÅstras.

NityƒÅnityaviveka ‚Äì Discernment between Eternal and Non-eternal

We see two kinds of objects in our experiential world.

A few objects constantly change and undergo growth, decline, and other modifications. These are non-eternal. This constitutes the majority of the experienced world. But doesn‚Äôt the experienced world exist at least for a little while? From where does its ephemeral existence arise? Doesn‚Äôt this experienced world act even in its limited condition? From where does its power of animation arise? Who gave it its form? Who changes it? The root of this power of the world is eternal ‚Äì Brahman. The sentience that acts behind and inside all objects is Brahman. Thus the experienced universe comprises two substances ‚Äì the impermanent world and the eternal Brahman.

The world is asat ‚Äì i.e., lacks an independent existence. Brahman has existence and it is this existence that is the basis of this world.

Now, BhagavƒÅn expounds on the relationship between these two substances because the answer to Arjuna‚Äôs question had to originate from this bifurcation of the world into the eternal and the non-eternal. The act of war is related to the non-eternal.

From these words,

nƒÅsato vidyate bhƒÅvo nƒÅbhƒÅvo vidyate satahÃ£ ‡•§
ubhayor-api drÃ£sÃ£tÃ£o‚Äôntas-tv-anayos-tattva-dar≈õibhihÃ£ ‡•• (BG 2.16)
‚ÄúSat (existence) is not born from Asat (non-existence). What does not exist is not born from what exists. (i.e., the non-existent is never born and the existent never dies). They are the wise who have realized the essence of the existent and the non-existent.‚Äù

Did not Arjuna‚Äôs doubt arise from his concern over killing sentient beings? Killing is that which makes something non-existent. What is ‚Äòbeing‚Äô or ‚Äònon-being‚Äô? Let us first understand their nature ‚Äì says K·πõ·π£·πáa. What things are apt to be denoted as ‚Äòexistent‚Äô or by the verb ‚Äòis‚Äô? Whatever cannot be destroyed and whatever remains unchanged is aptly denoted by the words ‚Äì ‚Äòsat,‚Äô ‚ÄòsattƒÅ,‚Äô or ‚Äòsatya.‚Äô Such an unchanged and undestroyed thing is Brahman.

avinƒÅ≈õi tu tad-viddhi yena sarvam-ida·πÉ tatam ‡•§
vinƒÅ≈õam-avyayasyƒÅsya na ka≈õcit kartum-arhati ‡•• (BG 2.17)
‚ÄúWhatever permeates all of this ‚Äì understand that to be indestructible. None can destroy this, which has no decline.‚Äù
antavanta ime dehƒÅhÃ£ nityasyoktƒÅhÃ£ ≈õarƒ´rinÃ£ahÃ£ ‡•§
anƒÅ≈õino‚Äôprameyasya tasmƒÅd-yudhyasva bhƒÅrata ‡•• (BG 2.18)
‚ÄúThese bodies you see are perishable; however the Principle that nourishes them is eternal; imperishable; and beyond all measure. Arjuna, your arrow and sword cannot harm It. Therefore, arise and fight!‚Äù

When the reality is thus, if anyone said that you were a killer and another is killed, that person would be ignorant of reality. There is none killed here and no one is the killer. The Self has no birth or death. It does not have any divisions of time such as the past, present or the future. That is forever immutable.

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

The Self Cannot be Destroyed

Arjuna, there are two substances in this world ‚Äì the body and the embodied. The body is a thing that is known directly to everyone. It comprises not only physical organs but also inner organs such as the mind and intellect and also the remnants of karma and vƒÅsanas (latent impressions) that have been accumulated over several lives. These are the characteristics of a jƒ´va. All subtle ingredients other than the Self are aspects of the body. The embodied is the consciousness within the body. That is the Pure Self. The body belongs to the Self. The Self is the Master of the body. The thing to be noted here is that while the body is subject to change, the Self is not. The body can be destroyed but the Self cannot be.

‚ÄúArjuna, isn‚Äôt your sorrow because you have to kill in battle? What is it that is destroyed when killed? The body or the Self? It is not the embodied Self.‚Äù

nƒÅya·πÉ hanti na hanyate‡•• (BG 2.19)
(He neither kills nor is he killed)
dehƒ´ nityam-avadhyo‚Äôyam‡•• (BG 2.30)
(The embodied one is Eternal and cannot be killed)

‚ÄúThen whatever is left is the body. Do you weep for that? The body will not survive just because you weep for that. That is bound to die regardless of whatever anyone does.‚Äù

jƒÅtasya hi dhruvo m·πõtyu·∏•‡•• (BG 2.27)br>(Death is certain for the one who is born)

‚ÄúJust as we cast off old clothes and don new ones, the Self that is in jƒ´va-hood discards a body to inhabit another one. Just as man cannot escape the stages of childhood, youth and old age, obtaining a new body through death is an inescapable occurrence.‚Äù

tasmƒÅd-aparihƒÅrye‚Äôrthe na tva·πÉ ≈õocitum-arhasi‡•• (BG 2.27)
(Therefore these two (birth and death) are inevitable. You should not grieve)

‚ÄúWhat will result from pining over something that is inevitable? Death will definitely visit all one day without fail. It cannot be avoided through lamentation‚Äù.

BhagavƒÅn uses the simile of old garments for the body ‚Äì ‚ÄòvƒÅsƒÅ·πÉsi jƒ´r·πáƒÅni.‚Äô This comparison is interesting. The fabric of wearing out garments cannot be strengthened by any means. Discarding them is the only way of dealing with them. Similarly, it is impossible for anybody to clean and purify a decadent body associated with evil qualities, immense greed, and despicable habits. Just as malodour cannot be removed without getting rid of smelly clothes, just as a head with lice-infested hair cannot be cleaned without shaving the head completely, the embodied jƒ´va cannot hope for purity without death freeing it from the body that has been an abode of iniquity for a long time. Therefore, for a jƒ´va inhabiting a body given long to vice, death might be a blessing. For the bearer of a sinful body, demise is release. Hence, death occurring during battle need not be considered wrongful. A diseased person might, out of laziness or lack of strength, insist on remaining in dirty unwashed clothes. His caretakers would compel such a person to get up, clean him, and get him to put on new clothes. Similarly, War releases people from their bodies. Those slain get better vestments upon departure.

Arjuna could ask another question. Let death come when it is inevitable. Why should I be the reason for it? Why should I bear the sin of killing another? The solution is as follows.

Performing One‚Äôs Dharma

Every being has a body and a spirit. The ƒÅtmƒÅ in that state is known as jƒ´va. The jƒ´va has two sides to it. One is the inert body. The other is the conscious Self. Due to its embodied nature, the jƒ´va suffers many hardships in the mundane world. Amidst the push and pull of Nature, karma, and Destiny, the jƒ´va forgets its Self and suffers. When it goes beyond its *jƒ´va-*hood and experiences its own Self, it experiences true bliss. That is mok·π£a. If the jƒ´va has to experience its own Self, it has to equip itself with some instructive means. The Self (ƒÅtmƒÅ) is:

nitya·∏• sarvagata·∏• sthƒÅ·πáu·∏• acalo‚Äôya·πÉ sanƒÅtana·∏•‡•§ (BG 2.24)
avyakto‚Äôyamacintyo‚Äôya·πÉ avikƒÅryo‚Äôyamucyate‡•• (BG 2.25)

Thus the ƒÅtmƒÅ is beyond the universe, different from the universe, beyond comparison and impossible to describe. To see and experience it, the layers of the body and the world have to be stripped and thrown away. Dharma is the means for that.

What is Dharma?

Let us now understand the meaning of the word ‚Äòdharma‚Äô to some extent ‚Äì this should be helpful in our further study. We have seen this word used several times and this word will be used again in this work. The *Gƒ´tƒÅ-*treatise (Gƒ´tƒÅ-≈õƒÅstra) has been described as ‚ÄòJƒ´vana-dharma-≈õƒÅstra‚Äô (The science of the dharma of life) already. BhagavƒÅn himself has clarified that dharma is the topic of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

ya ima·πÉ dharmya·πÉ sa·πÉvƒÅdam-ƒÅvayo·∏•‡•• (BG 18.20)

All interpretations of the Gƒ´tƒÅ are dependent on the meaning of the word dharma. Therefore it is essential to reflect on the meaning of dharma.

First, the meaning of the word. Dharma is something that sustains. ‚ÄòDhƒÅra·πáƒÅt dharma ityƒÅhu·∏•.‚Äô The discipline that protects everything suitably is dharma. ‚ÄòDharmo rak·π£ati rak·π£ita·∏•‚Äô ‚Äì the set of rules that protects us upon following it is dharma.

In practice, dharma is of three kinds: 1. Characteristic 2. Systemic 3. Compassionate.

1. By characteristic dharma is meant a thing‚Äôs natural state of being. Whatever quality makes a thing itself, the expansion of that quality is dharma. Burning is the dharma of fire. To blow is the dharma of the wind. To fly is the dharma of the bird. The dharma of water is to dissipate heat and cool anything it comes in contact with. The dharma of the body is to grow old and decrepit. Likewise are age related rules (vayo-dharma) and seasonal practices (·πõtu-dharma). Whatever ability or quality of a person is useful to society at large, that group of qualities and abilities is that person‚Äôs dharma. This can be termed a ‚Äúvalue‚Äù in English. Whatever quality or characteristic brings value to a certain thing is that thing‚Äôs dharma. Thus preserving a thing‚Äôs characteristic is dharma.

2. Systemic dharma is that set of rules by following which the natural expression of a being does not hinder another being‚Äôs existence or natural expression. The law of mutual non-detriment is justice. It is dharma.

3. Compassionate dharma is love towards other beings. The flowering of the self is developing one‚Äôs own life to help all. Affection towards the world is a means towards this. This is what is termed ‚ÄòƒÅtmaupamya‚Äô (self-identification) later in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. That is dharma.
