[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

Dharma is a word not used just by the vaidikas but also employed reverently by the Buddhists and Jains. The vaidikas have employed this term in different ≈õƒÅstras and as part of different terminologies. ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara gives the following meaning:

jagata·∏• sthiti-kƒÅra·πáam‡•§ prƒÅ·πáinƒÅ·πÉ sƒÅk·π£ƒÅd-abhyudaya-ni·∏•≈õreyasa hetu·∏• ya·∏• sa dharma·∏•…
≈öƒÅ·πÖkara-gƒ´tƒÅ-bhƒÅ·π£ya upodghƒÅta

The system and set of acts that bestows

(i) Welfare upon beings in the world now and

(ii) Salvation in the hereafter

is dharma.

Dharma sustains not only the jƒ´vas but also the universe. The jƒ´va and the world have a mutual relationship. Hence, the body of practices, qualities, rules, and regulations that

1. Suitably ensure that the **jƒ´va‚Äôs abilities and qualities do not degrade in contact with the Universe, but on the other hand ensure that they flower and help the world and

2. Also ensure that the Universe is unhindered by its contact with jƒ´vas and benefits the jƒ´va

constitutes dharma.

This is an ancient explanation. The vai≈õe·π£ika-s≈´tra states thus:

yato‚Äôbhyudaya-ni·∏•≈õreyasa-siddhi·∏• sa dharma·∏• ‡••
(Vai≈õe·π£ika-s≈´tra 1.1.2)

Ni·∏•≈õreyasa refers to the best among the best, the supreme good. What is it that is good? What is well-being? The great sage ƒÄpastamba conveys the quintessence of the Veda and VedƒÅnta in the following words:

ƒÅtmƒÅ-lƒÅbhƒÅn-na para·πÉ vidyate‡••
(ƒÄpastamba-dharma-s≈´tra 1.8.22)

There is no greater benefit than attaining one‚Äôs own Self. This is the highest of all welfare. It was the considered view of our ancients that being established in one‚Äôs own Self after experiencing it constituted mok·π£a (absolute deliverance).

The B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£at [and ChƒÅndogyopani·π£at] states it as follows:

ƒÅtmƒÅ vƒÅ are ≈õrotavya·∏•‡••
B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£at 2.4.5
(The ƒÅtmƒÅ has to be heard about)
tarati ≈õokam a ƒÅtmƒÅvit‡••
ChƒÅndogyopani·π£at 7.1.3
(The knower of the ƒÅtmƒÅ crosses sorrow)

The ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsyopani·π£at states:

tatra ko moha·∏• ka·∏• ≈õoka ekatvam-anupa≈õyata·∏• ‡••
ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsyopani·π£at 7
(Whence delusion? Whence sorrow for the one who sees Unity everywhere?)

All Upani·π£ads state the same.

The jƒ´va, enmeshed in the web of mƒÅyƒÅ (delusion) cast by prak·πõti (the primordial power) forgets the Supreme Self in him, and believes that things other than the ƒÅtman bring happiness and hankers after those ingredients of pleasure. This hankering after pleasure is sa·πÉsƒÅra. Confusion stems from a desire for the world. Going beyond this error and delusion, experiencing the Self ‚Äì and the Divine ‚Äì is a bliss higher than any other external pleasure. The set of qualities and behaviours that ready the jƒ´va for such supreme benefits is dharma. The same has been stated by YƒÅj√±avalkya.

aya·πÉ tu paramo dharmo yadyogenƒÅtmadar≈õanam ‡••
(YƒÅj√±avalkyasm·πõti 1.8)

All of the above can be collectively stated as follows. There are three main benefits from dharma:

1. Sustenance of the world.
2. Bliss for the jƒ´va
3. Welfare for the jƒ´va.

Beings normally yearn for pleasure at every instant. Pleasure is attainment of the desirable and cessation of the undesirable. But all pleasure is not welfare. All that yields pleasure may not be beneficial. Many dishes are enjoyable whilst on the palate but are otherwise when they are in the stomach. The kind of food that does not cause displeasure to the digestive system while still yielding pleasure to the tongue is wholesome (or hita). Wholesomeness originates from limiting one‚Äôs pleasures or moderation. Pleasure is wholesome (or hita) when associated with a method and moderation. The welfare of a jƒ´va is in restraining one‚Äôs enjoyment of pleasures while pursuing his desire in such a way that his future course towards the Beyond is unimpeded. The set of rituals, practices and rules that are needed for the welfare of the jƒ´va form the essence of dharma.

The above defines dharma from the perspective of its results. From the perspective of its internal structure, dharma can be defined as the practical observance of objective truth. By truth is meant reality, a situation as is. ‚ÄòTattva‚Äô refers to the same. Tat-tva is a thing‚Äôs thingness. Dharma is the adaptation of our behaviour to current circumstances after understanding the true nature of the circumstances.

There is yet another explanation. Dharma is the set of our actions performed with the Supreme Self as witness. The set of actions performed with the conviction that one is answerable to ƒ™≈õvara for every action done or not done is dharma.

Thus dharma is an essential training or refinement for the jƒ´va. War is another such training ground. For a few kinds of jƒ´vas, because of the bodies they inhabit, death in the battlefield is an essential purification, just as surgery for a few kinds of ailments.

Dharma is therefore the set of behaviours that is based on one‚Äôs own self, follows the Truth, and keeps the good of all in view.

Having briefly noted the inner essence of dharma, we need to understand that it assumes myriad forms in action. Just as a blob of gold assumes different forms such as coins or ornaments, the singular principle of dharma functions in different forms according to the capabilities of the individual jƒ´vas and their varied circumstances. Such dharmas can be classified into four main groups:

1. SƒÅdhƒÅra·πáa-dharma or nitya-dharma (common or ordinary dharma)
2. Vi≈õe·π£a-dharma (dharma in special circumstances)
3. Naimittika-dharma (dharma befitting specific occasions)
4. ƒÄpad-dharma (dharma in extreme situations)

1. SƒÅdhƒÅra·πáa-dharma or nitya-dharma - This is decreed for all of humanity. The main characteristics have been enumerated by Manu as follows:

dh·πõti·∏• k·π£amƒÅ damo‚Äôsteya·πÉ ≈õaucamindriyanigraha·∏•
dhƒ´rvidyƒÅ satyamakrodha·∏• da≈õaka·πÉ dharmalak·π£a·πáam‡••
(Manusm·πõti 6.92)

1. Dh·πõti - Courage or steadfastness, 2. K·π£amƒÅ - Forgiveness, 3. Dama - Controlling the mind, 4. Asteya - Not coveting others‚Äô wealth, 5. ≈öauca - Purity, 6. Indriyanigraha - Controlling sense organs, 7. Dhƒ´ - Intellect, 8. VidyƒÅ - Knowledge, especially that of philosophy, 9. Satyam - Being truthful, 10. Akrodha - Being free of anger.

The above ten are characteristics of dharma. It is imperative for all human beings to cultivate or possess these qualities at all times.

2. Vi≈õe·π£a-dharma (Dharma under special circumstances) is of two kinds:

a. JƒÅti-dharma - is dharma belonging to one‚Äôs clan or var·πáa or region. Arjuna referred to these when he said, ‚ÄúutsƒÅdyante jƒÅti-dharmƒÅ·∏• kula-dharmƒÅ≈õ-ca ≈õƒÅ≈õvatƒÅ·∏•‚Äù - Dharmas belonging to society and one‚Äôs own clan, that have existed for time immemorial, will get destroyed.

b. ƒÄ≈õrama-dharma - pe·πõtains to the initiation, conduct, and rituals pe·πõtaining to the ƒÅ≈õramas of brahmacharya (studenthood), g·πõhastha (householderhood), vƒÅnaprastha (forest-dweller) and sa·πÉnyƒÅsa (renunciate).

3. Naimittika-dharma is dharma pe·πõtaining to a goal relevant for a specific duration of time. That is of two kinds:

a. KƒÅmya - the works (p≈´jas, vratas, yaj√±as) performed to achieve one‚Äôs personal desires.

b. ≈öuddhi - are the rites to purify oneself of any impurity or expiation for pƒÅpas committed.

4. ƒÄpad-dharma - When it is not possible to perform any of the above mentioned dharmas due to disease, drought or other calamity, a token of that dharma is maintained. The actions performed to maintain such a token dharma constitute ƒÅpad-dharma. Mantra-snƒÅna (ritual bath using mantras) during fever, a brƒÅhma·πáa following agriculture and other occupations during the age of Kali are the common examples. Dro·πáƒÅcharya‚Äôs foray into battle can thus be termed ƒÅpad-dharma or vi≈õe·π£a-dharma. In a story in the ChƒÅndogyopani·π£at, the brƒÅhma·πáa named U·π£asti had become emaciated due to a drought. To maintain his life, U·π£asti took half-eaten cereals from an elephant-driver. For U·π£asti, this became ƒÅpad-dharma.

To summarize, the rule of conduct placed upon oneself to neither mar one‚Äôs own progress nor be an impediment to others‚Äô pursuits of pleasure and actually help others while achieving one‚Äôs own happiness is dharma.

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 7) Source: prekshaa]]

Every jƒ´va‚Äôs characteristics and circumstances differ from one another. Therefore every one‚Äôs dharma is different. Thus everyone has his or her own svadharma.

For a k·π£atriya, fighting a war for dharma becomes dharma. Therefore, it was Arjuna‚Äôs duty. Not VyƒÅsa‚Äôs. Accepting five husbands became dharma for Draupadƒ´; not for any other woman. It became dharma for AmbikƒÅ and AmbƒÅlikƒÅ to seek offspring from their own brother-in-law; not for other women. Therefore, dharma takes varied forms based on class, capabilities and circumstances of an individual. Hence

dharmasya tattva·πÉ nihita·πÉ guhƒÅyƒÅm ‚Äî MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, Vanaparva 314.119
(The essence of dharma is hidden in secret)

The ascertainment of dharma is possible only via an analysis of reality.

yastarke·πáƒÅnusandhatte sa dharma·πÉ veda netara·∏• ‡•§ (Manusm·πõti 12.106)
itikartavyatƒÅbhƒÅga·πÉ mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ p≈´rayi·π£yati ‡•§ (KumƒÅrila‚Äôs B·πõha·π≠·π≠ƒ´kƒÅ)

It is pƒÅpa to slip from one‚Äôs own dharma. It is not a pƒÅpa for a k·π£atriya to kill during battle; but running away from battle is. What is pƒÅpa? The descent of the jƒ´va towards a worse state. It is thus that BhagavƒÅn said - ‚ÄúArjuna, look at it from the perspective of a jƒ´va‚Äôs welfare. This war is an opportunity for you to fulfill your dharma. Therefore there will be no loss or failure of dharma.

After stating the dharma of one‚Äôs own duty, BhagavƒÅn with a doubt as to whether Arjuna understood this deep and Supreme philosophy or with an intention to test Arjuna‚Äôs mind states other exhortations for war.

1.The death of kinsmen causes sorrow. However, in this world, the dualities of sorrow/happiness and profit/loss come and go just as winter and summer. They have to be forborne. One should not abandon dharma out of fear for them.

2. This war has happened by chance. Not because you wished for it. Therefore you will not beget any pƒÅpa.

3. Not fighting this war will bring sin upon you.

4. Fleeing from this war will cause infamy.

5. The world will deride you as a coward and bring you disrespect.

6. You will achieve heaven if you die.

7. You will achieve your kingdom if you win. Thus does ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa show many allurements as well as fears. In the Ka·π≠hopani≈õad, when Naciketas prays to Lord Yama for Self-knowledge, the latter tests him by offering him enticements much lower than Self-knowledge such as ‚ÄúI will give you palaces; a wife; a long life-span and riches‚Äù. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa similarly tested Arjuna. In addition to these seven arguments, ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa added these three in another part of the work.

8. The tendency for war is innate to you. You cannot overcome it. Even if you try to control it, it will get you to fight.

9. If you do not desire to fight for your own selfish desires, do it for the welfare of the world.

10. This war is due to the will of the Divine. It will not stop if you do not participate in it. It will definitely happen. Those that you refuse to kill will not stop dying. They have already entered the jaws of death. It will be your loss if you do not fight.

The inevitability of war and the importance of the duty of fighting in one are stated first. Then are expounded the Universality of the Self, steadiness in samƒÅdhi and the mental makeup the seeker needs to have while discharging one‚Äôs duty.

The Vision of the Universality of the Self

‚ÄúArjuna, what you just said are the words you heard from the people of the world. Those are useless. Why don‚Äôt you reflect upon the principle of reality with your own intellect? I have told you what the Supreme Principle is - it is of the nature of the Self. That indeed is sƒÅ·πÖkhya (knowledge). Keeping the Self as your foundation, reflect upon the conundrums of life by yourself. When that is done, your fetters of pƒÅpa and pu·πáya will fall away.

buddhyƒÅ yukto yayƒÅ pƒÅrtha karmabandha·πÉ prahƒÅsyasi ‡•§ (BG 2.39)

As long as one is embodied, action is inevitable. dharma too is a karma (action/work) that leads one towards the Self. The natural qualities of sattva, rajas and tamas are mixed into every karma. These three qualities might be present in dharma-related work too. Perform your dharma while going beyond these three qualities i.e., while others do their dharma keeping heaven and other desires in mind, do your dharma without any desire. Your objection that ≈õruti (revealed ≈õƒÅstra) and sm·πõti (remembered ≈õƒÅstra) teach works with specific results in mind is valid. However, such works are prescribed for those who qualify only for that and cannot reach the next level. The intention of such prescriptions by the ≈õruti is to initially motivate the lower category of seekers to eventually turn them towards the Divine.

yƒÅvƒÅnartha udapƒÅne sarvata·∏• samplutodake ‡•§
tƒÅvƒÅn sarve·π£u vede·π£u brƒÅhma·πáasya vijƒÅnata·∏• ‡•• (BG 2.46)

Even if there are multitudes of wells, ponds, and tanks in a town, and all of them are full of water, we take only what we need for our cooking, ablutions, drinking or other needs. Not all of it. The same is the case with the teachings of the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras. There are hundreds of teachings. We can choose only those befitting our eligibility. The ≈õƒÅstric terminology for this eligibility is ‚ÄòadhikƒÅra‚Äô. The instruction befits one‚Äôs adhikƒÅra. All instructions do not apply to all. Of the ten reasons I have stated, act according to the reason that fits you or if they do not suit you, do so from the perspective of the Universal Self that is beyond all desires. Remember the following rule regardless of how you act. You have the right only to perform your duty, not to its results. Effort is under your control; victory and defeat are left to the Divine. (See 18.14). If your mind is not attached to results, the merit or demerit of that work will not attach itself to you. That is Yoga.

karma·πáyevƒÅdhikƒÅraste mƒÅ phale·π£u kadƒÅcana ‡•§
mƒÅ karmaphalaheturbh≈´·∏• mƒÅ te sa·πÖgo‚Äôstvakarma·πái ‡•• (BG 2.42)
‚ÄúYou have adhikƒÅra only in performing the work prescribed to you. You have no adhikƒÅra over the results of the work. Do not examine the work‚Äôs results and think - ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs in it for me?‚Äù. Do not give up work.‚Äù

This is a highly celebrated verse. It is natural for anyone to think about the results whenever they begin work. This question is quite the norm in the case of one‚Äôs duty as a citizen. The government is powerful. It could be performing actions that are unjust or dangerous. What is the benefit in opposing it? The government will not swerve from its decision whereas protests and protestors will earn only its ire. Such is the usual argument that most have heard. But this is not what the Gƒ´tƒÅ teaches. Duty lies in opposing injustice and adharma under all circumstances. Even if the one opposed to evil has to fight all alone without any assistance, he must stand firm to protect that which his Inner self holds to be dharma and destroy that which is opposed to it.

They are slaves who dare not be
In the right with two or three.
“Stanzas on Freedom”, James Russell Lowell

Defeat is not rare for the one who fought for dharma. That is sometimes a daily occurrence. He must not consider external defeats and victories but rejoice in an inner feeling of contentment. It is not possible to deduce how dharmic a certain work is from its result. Dharma does not rest upon results but is independent. Its origin is in the energy of Consciousness in the Self; in the discernment between the Self and the non-Self; in the ardent desire for the elevated state of the Self. Dharma is solely for the betterment of life, not for external achievements. BhagavƒÅn again confirms it thus.

yogastha·∏• kuru karmƒÅ·πái sa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ dhana√±jaya ‡•§
siddhyasiddhyo·∏• samo bh≈´tvƒÅ samatva·πÉ yoga ucyate ‡•• (BG 2.48)

Not giving any attention towards the results of a work after performing it is yoga. Appearing effortless even during effort, not fatigued even after sweating, being of a contented mind is yoga. That is karma-kau≈õala or excellence in works.

There are several tiers of instruction in the Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ from the level of “patra·πÉ pu·π£pa·πÉ phala·πÉ toyam” (offering a leaf, flower, fruit or water) to the level of nistraigu·πáya (being beyond the three qualities). Not all of us can follow these teachings at all times. It is like a library wherein we select what we need. Though there are hundreds of lessons, it is up to us to choose what fits us. One‚Äôs itch cannot be relieved by another person. Only the experiencer knows what and where the itch is.

We have to find our respective actions and dharma by ourselves. The objective of karma is cleansing pƒÅpa (sin/effect of evil actions). One should not inquire after its fruits. The fruit is to prepare one‚Äôs mind. What comes from doing good work? What accrues from serving one‚Äôs parents or loving one‚Äôs children? The resultant happiness is its fruit. Karma (action) is dependent on the individual; the results on Providence. Where is our excellence then? It lies in not incurring results - good or evil - even after performing one‚Äôs duty. For this to happen, one must be indifferent towards the results. That is yoga and the purport of the statement ‚Äúyoga·∏• karmasu kau≈õalam." The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ (the enlightened one) does not think that he is performing good acts. Good naturally flows from him. Only fragrance emanates from a ball of musk. What is good or bad there? Is it possible to spoil it?

The Self is Non-attached

The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is beyond duals. He is of one form of undivided goodness. Results accrue from actions which in turn happen because of a restriction of Nature or a prescription of dharma. The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ reckons thus - ‚ÄúWhat had to be done has been done. Its fruits will occur accordingly. What if they are sweet? Or bitter? My palate is ready for both‚Äù. Those are regarded as ‚Äúbuddhi-yukta‚Äù (endowed with wisdom); those who have seen reality in its entirety; those for whom there is no effort of anxiety or curiosity towards good and evil.

buddhi-yukto jahƒÅtƒ´ha ubhe suk·πõta-du·π£k·πõte ‡•§
tasmƒÅd-yogƒÅya yujyasva yoga·∏• karmasu kau≈õalam ‡•• (BG 2.50)

The Self is Actioness

Natural instinct and one‚Äôs former deeds impel one to perform activity. As long as one feels that he is performing an action and that the results of the said action are his and feels bound to the work, the fruits of activity exist for an individual. If one is of the strong resolve that one‚Äôs life is because of the results of former deeds (prƒÅrabdha-karma) and that one‚Äôs Self is actionless and pure and any activity that will be done will be done solely for dharma and not for its fruit, the noose of karma will not bind him.

…nƒÅya·πÉ hanti na hanyate ‡•§
…ka·πÉ ghƒÅtayati hanti kam ‡•• (BG 2.19)
‚ÄúThe Self does not kill; Nor is It killed. Whom does It maim or kill?‚Äù

The Self does not do anything. Whatever is done is by the modifications of the mind and intellect. These changes are impelled by Nature or by the past of the individual. Man‚Äôs intellect can establish limits for these. Man‚Äôs golden opportunity is in the independence of discernment.

‚ÄúDid I not say that all works comprise the three qualities of sattva, rajas and tamas? These activities could conform to dharma or not. Any activity done without touching these three qualities will not bind you and cause Universal welfare‚Äù

traigu·πáya-vi·π£ayƒÅ vedƒÅ nistraigu·πáyo bhavƒÅrjuna ‡•• (BG 2.45)

The actions prescribed by the Vedas yield results or fruits. Those desirous of heaven and other rewards perform these works. You perform the same without any desire. Then it becomes ‚Äúadhi-dharma‚Äù (performing dhƒÅrmic works even when beyond the dual of dharma and adharma). There are several who might purify their jƒ´va through desireful actions. Others are beyond the prescriptions and proscriptions of ≈õruti and sm·πõti. Be like those who go beyond the three gu·πáas. If that is not possible, follow the regular path of the rest and attain the Supreme Goal.

‚ÄúArjuna, the need for instruction will cease when your mind goes beyond agitations of infatuation. Which means that the purpose of any instruction is to remove mental confusion and desires. Uttered words are of various kinds. They stir and scatter the mind. If you are not swayed by these words and stay firm, being of one resolve - you will not touched by pu·πáya and pƒÅpa. It will be possible for you to uncover the secret of Art of Yogic Living: ‚Äúyoga·∏• karmasu kau≈õalam."

samƒÅdhƒÅvacalƒÅ buddhi·∏• tadƒÅ yogam-avƒÅpsyasi ‡•• (BG 2.53)

SamƒÅdhi is contemplation: keeping the mind equanimous and focusing on the object of meditation. In other words, it is the unwavering mind established in one-pointed concentration.

The Characteristics of a Knower

The teaching must have affected Arjuna a wee bit. He asks, ‚ÄúYou mentioned about the state of being in samƒÅdhi and talked about a sthitapraj√±a (one of steady wisdom). What are his characteristics? How does he speak?‚Äù BhagavƒÅn enumerates the marks of a knower which forms the education of a seeker. The nineteen ≈õlokas from the 54^(th) to 72^(nd) were apparently Mahatma Gandhi‚Äôs favourites. These ≈õlokas are useful for contemplation and practice.

Arjuna asks, ‚ÄúO Ke≈õava! How does a person of established wisdom speak? What is the behaviour of one who has his mind in equanimity? What does one of a firm intellect speak about? How is such a person? What does he desire?‚Äù (54)

≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa replies, ‚ÄúO Arjuna! When a person, renouncing all mental desires, is content in contemplation upon the Self and Self-experience by and within oneself, he is known as a sthitapraj√±a.‚Äù (55)

‚ÄúHe is not agitated by sorrow and does not hanker after pleasure. Beyond desire, fear and anger, he of a firm mind, is known as a muni.‚Äù (56)

‚ÄúOne who is uniformly devoid of desires and is impartial under all circumstances, and is steady without grief or mirth in the face of fortune or misfortune, such a person‚Äôs wisdom is said to be firmly established.‚Äù (57)

‚ÄúOne who retracts his sense organs from objects that excite them like a tortoise that withdraws its limbs and is able to live without attachment to sense objects, his wisdom is said to be firmly established.‚Äù (58)

‚ÄúIf asked, ‚ÄúAs the seeker limits his food intake, sense objects move farther from him. Isn‚Äôt the taste for objects within the mind?‚Äù, the reply is, ‚ÄúYes. But when the intellect experiences something higher than itself, the taste for sense objects disappears.‚Äù [Which means that as the desire to know about the Supreme Self grows, the appetite for sense pleasures wears out] (59)

‚ÄúArjuna, even if the intelligent seeker strives to restrain his mind, the sense organs agitate him and forcibly carry away his mind [as it is the nature of the mind to be externally engaged]. These sense organs have to be tamed and the mind should be established in the Supreme Self. He whose sense organs are controlled, his wisdom is said to be firmly established.‚Äù (60-61)

‚ÄúWhen man remembers sense objects, a relationship between the mind and sense objects is formed. Desire for those objects arises from this memory relationship. [When those desires are opposed] anger is born. From anger arises infatuation that destroys discrimination. Infatuation overturns understanding. Hampered understanding destroys the intellect. The destruction of the intellect ruins the person‚Äù (62-63)

‚ÄúThe one who gives up attachment and aversion, separates sense objects from sense organs and controls them while restraining the mind is able to attain tranquillity of the mind i.e., a firm and pure state‚Äù (64)

‚ÄúWhen his mind attains tranquillity, all of the seeker‚Äôs sorrows end. In such a tranquil mind, the intellect is firmly established.‚Äù (65)

‚ÄúThe intellect of the one who has not united one‚Äôs mind with the Self does not function well. Realisation does not come to such a person. The one who is unrealised will not be at peace. How can one without peace attain happiness?‚Äù (66)

‚ÄúHe whose mind is a slave to sense organs will have his intellect snatched away by it just as a boat is carried away by the wind.‚Äù (67)

‚ÄúTherefore, O one with mighty arms! One whose sense organs are separated from sense objects and are restrained has his knowledge well-established.‚Äù (68)

‚ÄúThe knower stays awake when it is night for the world. [The knower is careful and conscious of the principle that is unseen by the ignorant ones engaged in worldly pleasures]. When it is day for the beings of the world, it is night for the knower. [i.e., The knower has no interest in those areas that immensely interest mundane people] (69)

‚ÄúJust as the ocean remains (un)disturbed even after taking in new waters that join it incessantly, desires enter the realised sage. [He, whom desires do not enter thus, attains peace]. The one desirous of more desires does not attain peace.‚Äù (70)

‚ÄúThe sage who abandons all desires, does not hanker after pleasures and acts without ego and selfishness, attains peace.‚Äù (71)

‚ÄúO Partha. This is indeed the BrƒÅhmƒ´ state i.e., the state of those whose minds experience brahman. Your confusions and delusions will be dispelled if you reach this state. One who is in this state even at the time of death, attains brahmanirvƒÅ·πáa [unity with brahman]. (72)

Nobody would have thought that attaining the aforesaid qualities is easy by any stretch of the imagination. These qualities are noble and can be attained only after great effort. Such qualities are necessary not just for the Yogi but everyone else as well. It will be good for everyone to remember these qualities frequently. Equanimity, abandoning desire, anger etc., treating fortune and misfortune the same, restraining the sense organs - such qualities ought to be fostered.

This chapter is known as SƒÅ·πÖkhya-yogaby convention. SƒÅ·πÖkhya refers to the discernment of the principle of reality. ‚ÄúKhyƒÅ prakathane‚Äù [khyƒÅ refers to description] is the DhƒÅtupƒÅ·π≠ha for the root - khyƒÅ. Sa·πÖkhyƒÅ, khyƒÅti, khyƒÅpana are words from the same root. The one that enumerates reality well is sƒÅ·πÖkhya. The one who has attained the knowledge of reality is known as a Sa·πÖkhyƒÅvƒÅn. There is a branch of philosophy propounded by Mahar·π£i Kapila known as SƒÅ·πÖkhya. The word meaning of sƒÅ·πÖkhya is the same there as well.

samyag-vivicya khyƒÅyante arthƒÅt praka·π≠ƒ´kriyante tattvƒÅni prak·πõti-puru·π£a-padƒÅrtha-r≈´pƒÅ·πái yasminstat‡••
Gƒ´tƒÅ-bhƒÅ·π£yam by ≈örƒ´-nƒ´laka·πá·π≠ha 18.13

According to this sƒÅ·πÖkhya school, the Universe is constituted by prak·πõti, puru·π£a and thirty-two other principles. Since this school differs from vedƒÅnta, we will not worry about it here. In our case, sƒÅ·πÖkhya refers to that knowledge that expounds upon the Self - made distinct from the body, jƒ´va (the transmigratory self), jagat (the world) and ƒ™≈õvara (the Supreme Controller). That is the knowledge of reality. Arjuna‚Äôs unrefined mindset had to be refined by this discerned knowledge of reality.

As this intended meaning of sƒÅ·πÖkhya is not currently well-known, it appears that we can rename this chapter ‚Äútattva-viveka-yoga‚Äù (The Yoga of Discernment of Reality). The gist of the chapter might become clearer to the mind with these words.

The principle of the Self decides everything

The teaching of the Gƒ´tƒÅ begins from the second chapter in which BhagavƒÅn classifies the entire Universe into the body and the embodied, and explains that while the body is subject to modification and destruction, the embodied Self consciousness is immutable, eternal, of one form and without any divisions.

The Self is eternal, omnipresent, immutable, without beginning and end. What is the reason behind delving deep into this principle right at the beginning of the teaching? The answer is that all questions of life can be decided only from the perspective of the Self.

Several aspects have come together into forming a human being - organs of action such as hands and legs; sensory organs such as the eyes, ears, nose, skin and tongue; the mental apparatus comprising the psyche, intellect and other components; the remnants of karma that come from previous births, and the debts and relations therein as well as tendencies towards specific activities with merits and demerits; the jƒ´va who experiences pain and pleasure in this multifarious vessel and finally - the Self who is untouched by all this. In this complex of myriad parts, the Self is the only permanent thing while others are subject to growth, contraction, modifications. Therefore, it is our first duty to discern the Self from the non-Self. The Gƒ´tƒÅ‚Äôs essence is that all goals of life and suitability or otherwise of any action in life should be decided from the Self‚Äôs perspective. With this it becomes possible to know what results in welfare and what does not. Arjuna‚Äôs question was about dharma

p·πõcchƒÅmi tvƒÅ·πÉ dharmasamm≈´·∏çhacetƒÅ·∏• ‡•• (BG 2.7)

BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs answer was mostly about mok·π£a. This is consistent with the teaching.

‚ÄúA tree is known by its fruit‚Äù - goes the English proverb. Dharma and mok·π£a are two parts of the same tree. While dharma is its root, mok·π£a is its fruit. So, if a question were to arise whether an act was in consonance with dharma or not, the answer would be to check if it helped attain mok·π£a or not. The thoughts we think, the words we utter, and our behaviours constitute dharma only if they help lead us to mok·π£a now or later. If not, it is adharma. As such is the relationship between dharma and mok·π£a, it became necessary to demonstrate that the instruction given to Arjuna was in fact conducive to the attainment of mok·π£a and not unfavourable to it. Therefore, reflection upon the nature of mok·π£a became imperative. From this reflection came deliberation upon the Self, jƒ´va, prak·πõti, the Supreme Self and the way of worship.

Arjuna needed to understand this distinction. Though his natural unrefined qualities were ‚Äúgood‚Äù, his mind underwent delusion as it was not refined by an analysis of reality. He could not come to a firm conclusion. The knowledge of reality is the root of knowledge of dharma. Thence the greatness of this treatise.

Appendix 1. What is tattva (Reality) ?

We stated earlier that the determination of what is dharma and what is adharma i.e., deciding what should be done and what should not be done has to be made based on an understanding of tattva (Reality or Truth (lit. the essence of Reality) and not based on our prejudices or existing beliefs. Tattva is the foundation of dharma. What then is tattva?

Tattva (tat + tva) is literally the state of a thing being itself. The quality or characteristic by which a thing is that thing and not something else is the thing‚Äôs tattva. The true nature of a thing or a thing‚Äôs own innate form is its tattva.

There are two forms of anything in this world. One is its innate or true form. The other is what is seen. The true form is reality or tattva. The appearance is known as pratƒ´ti (phenomenal appearance).

The earth is a thing. We see it in various forms as mud, sand, or rocks. This is perception. The earth is seen in pits, mounds, buildings, canals, and other forms. This is perception that is apprehended or experienced by our eyes, hands, and other sensory organs. The state of the earth as-is when sensory perception is excluded is its tattva or reality.

The world and the jƒ´va are objects seen or experienced by our eyes, ears, tongue in myriad ways. This is appearance, not reality. The capacity for knowledge of our sense organs is limited. Therefore, all aspects of a thing may not be felt or known by our eyes and other sense organs. Only a little of it might have been comprehended. Our sense organs might be confused because of disease. It is not uncommon for appearance to be accompanied by such lacunae. Therefore, experience only through sense organs might not constitute the complete truth. Tattva or reality is the complete truth about the thing in question.

The question or tattva under inquiry in the Gƒ´tƒÅ is that of dharma and adharma. In other words - what kind of relation between the individual (jƒ´va) and the world (jagat) is conducive to welfare? To decide upon this, it becomes imperative to reflect upon the true nature of the world and the individual jƒ´va. Are the world and the individual two different things? What is their relationship? When this is analysed, the answer should include both the individual and the world. This quote from the Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad defines tattva as follows.

kasminnu vij√±ƒÅte sarvamida·πÉ vij√±ƒÅta·πÉ bhavati? Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad 1.1.3
‚ÄúWhat is it upon knowing which all this becomes known?‚Äù

A statement expounding a thing‚Äôs tattva should be able to answer all questions about the thing.

The one thing knowing which all of what we need to know becomes known is Brahma or ParaBrahma (Supreme Brahma). If we were to understand a bit of the nature of Brahma, it would be possible to satisfactorily answer several questions about the world, ƒ™≈õvara, jƒ´va and dharma. The fount of knowledge that gives us understanding of Brahma, the origin of everything, is the Veda that states the following about Brahma.

sarva·πÉ khalvida·πÉ brahma ‡•• ChƒÅndogya Upani·π£ad, 3.14.1 (All this is Brahma)
satya·πÉ j√±ƒÅnamananta·πÉ brahma ‡•• Taittirƒ´ya Upani·π£ad 2.1.1
(Truth, Knowledge and Infinity are Brahma)
ayamƒÅtmƒÅ brahma ‡•• MƒÅ·πá·∏ç≈´kya Upani·π£ad 2
(This Self is Brahma)
ƒÅtmaivedag·πÉ sarvam ‡•• ChƒÅndogya Upani·π£ad, 7.25.2 (All of this is the Self)

The votaries of the Veda take the above statements to be self-evident truths. It would be beneficial even for those who do not believe in the Veda to accept the above as hypotheses. When accepting a few statements (theorems) as truths makes it possible to get consistent and satisfactory answers to the problems under question, and not accepting them leads to no such answers, such statements form a hypothesis.

If Vedic and VedƒÅntic statements on Brahma were to be accepted, it becomes possible to find sound solutions to all our questions about the jagat, jƒ´va and other topics. Therefore we can accept the Veda as the Great Hypothesis. This is why the Supreme Brahma becomes the fundamental tattva for all inquiries.

What then are the topics relevant to the discussion between K·πõ·π£·πáa and Arjuna?

1. Jƒ´va (the individual)

2. ƒÄtmƒÅ (the Self)

3. Jagat (the world)

4. ƒ™≈õvara (the Supreme Ruler/Master)

5. Dharma and adharma.

6. Svarga and naraka

7. Transmigratory existence (JanmƒÅntarya)

8. Mok·π£a (final liberation)

The foundational field to answer questions and sub-questions about the preceding eight topics is Brahma. These eight aspects are lessons that expand upon the greatness of Brahma. By knowing the nature, form, intelligence, and greatness of Brahma, it becomes possible to understand the true nature of the world, the individual and dharma. Thus Brahma is the ultimate tattva.

kasminnu vij√±ƒÅte sarvamida·πÉ vij√±ƒÅta·πÉ bhavati? - Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad 1.1.3

Appendix 2. What do we do with our sense organs?

The havoc created by the sense organs repeatedly comes up for discussion. There is no life without sense organs; but no peace of mind with them. How do we deal with them?

indriyƒÅ·πái pramƒÅthƒ´ni haranti prasabha·πÉ mana·∏• ‡•§ (BG 2.60)

The sense organs disturb the mind, scatter it and take it away. Therefore the sense organs have to be restrained. What does this mean? Should the organs be prevented from functioning? Or since they create a lot of trouble, shouldn‚Äôt the sense organs be suppressed and killed?

Not so. Neither is it possible nor is it wise to do that. The sense organs must be won over, not killed. Sense organs must exist but function within limits. Sense organs must function but within bounds. That is exactly what the great ·πõ·π£is prayed for.

bhadra·πÉ kar·πáebhi·∏• ≈õ·πõ·πáuyƒÅma devƒÅ·∏•
bhadra·πÉ pa≈õyemƒÅk·π£abhiryajatrƒÅ·∏•
sthiraira·πÖgaistu·π£·π≠uvƒÅg·πÉ sastan≈´bhi·∏• ‡•• ≈öƒÅntipƒÅ·π≠ha
O Devas! May we listen to the auspicious with our ears!
O those deserving adoration! May we see the auspicious with our eyes!
May we please them with bodies and firm organs!

ƒÅpyƒÅyantu mamƒÅ·πÖgƒÅni vƒÅkprƒÅ·πáa≈õcak·π£u≈õ≈õrotramatho
balamindriyƒÅ·πái sarvƒÅ·πái ca ‡•• ≈öƒÅntipƒÅ·π≠ha
May my limbs, speech, vital airs, eyes and ears and all my organs gain in strength.

It does not befit a rider to dismount his horse because the horse runs hither and thither. He should be seated firmly on his mount. He should be able to rein in the horse and go where he wants to go. The one who knows the use of the reins and the stirrup can keep any horse in his control. The one who has won over his organs is not the same as one whose organs are dead or non-functional. (A jitendriya is not the same as a m·πõtendriya). Winning over the senses is not killing them. The senses should endure and be capable but must not yield to evil.

What is the merit in one whose senses are not working? A destitute is a renunciate; A toothless one eats healthy food as he has no choice; a mute observes silence; a weak person has good conduct. These varied innocences are not sound qualities in reality; but are handicaps. It is called restraint when a strong one reins in his strength. It is mercy only when a person capable of delivering punishment restrains himself from doing so. It is virtue, likewise, when capable senses do not hanker after evil.

The sense organs must not lose their ability to grasp and appreciate beauty. They must continue to perceive the finest of details but we must not come under their spell. A sweet-meat vendor knows the finer details and tastes of his own culinary creations quite well. Without this ability, his products will not be able to attract discerning customers. Thus, though being a connoisseur of tastes, he will not succumb to them. If he is infatuated by his own creations, he would have to close shop after eating all of his dishes. A refined palate is imperative for his business; but not dangerous to him.

Similar rules need to apply to our sense organs as well. We should have power over them and not the other way around.

yuktƒÅhƒÅravihƒÅrasya ‡•• (BG 6.17)

All must exist in moderation.

Appendix 3. The yoga of buddhi

buddhyƒÅ yukto‚Ä¶..karmabandha·πÉ prahƒÅsyasi (BG 2.39)
buddhau ≈õara·πáamanviccha (BG 2.49)
buddhiyukto jahƒÅtƒ´ha ubhe suk·πõta-du·π£k·πõte (BG 2.50)

The term buddhi has been used in a special sense in this chapter. Here buddhi does not refer to one of the constituents of the internal organ such as mind, citta, the ego, memory, steadiness (dh·πõti) and intention (ƒÅk≈´ti). Here buddhi refers to the action of the intellect. It is the discernment of or investigation into reality. The knowledge that results at the end of this discernment is also indicated as buddhi.

Thus, ‚ÄúbuddhiyogamupƒÅ≈õritya‚Äù means taking recourse to the discernment or investigation into truth. If a seeker has this wisdom, karma performed by him will not bind him as he performs karma only from a transcendental perspective devoid of any selfish desires. There is no ‚Äòme‚Äô or ‚Äòmine‚Äô for a knower of Truth. Where there is no selfishness, there is no touch of pƒÅpa or demerit.

Similarly, there is no pu·πáya or pƒÅpa incurred for one who, having taken refuge in the Truth, witnesses the Self everywhere, and is free of selfish desires. He is the adhi-dharmi whose characteristics are as follows.

buddhiyukto jahƒÅtƒ´ha ubhe suk·πõta-du·π£k·πõte (BG 2.50)
Whoever is buddhiyukta i.e., is yoked with the buddhi - or has comprehended and experienced the Supreme Principle - such a person, being unselfish, is free of both pu·πáya and pƒÅpa.

This has to be related with the 18th chapter, in the famous verse fragment ‚ÄúsarvadharmƒÅn parityajya‚Äù (18-66). The dharmas (right actions) are counted among meritorious acts. Such works have associated motives and are accompanied by at least a tinge of self-interest. The knower, having realised the Supreme truth, has no ‚ÄôI‚Äô. The one who has no ‚ÄôI‚Äô does not pa·πõtake of any merit or demerit. ‚ÄújahƒÅtƒ´ha ubhe suk·πõta-du·π£k·πõte‚Äù - is free of both good and bad deeds. It is about him that the following is said.

tyaja dharmamadharma·πÉ ca‚Ä¶
(Renounce dharma and adharma)
yena tyajasi tattyaja ‡••
(Renounce that by which you renounce‚Ä¶)
SannyƒÅsopani·π£ad 2.12

Appendix 4. Titik·π£ƒÅ (Forbearance)

Titik·π£ƒÅ is forbearance or patience or endurance. It is a quality that is much needed in a seeker. If the end goal of human life is the realization of Brahma or the experience of Supreme Godhead, the path towards the goal is of crucial impo·πõtance. The practice of seeing the Divine everywhere is the path. Imagine how our behaviour would be if we knew that we were always in the presence of the Divine and that he would constantly be watching us without batting an eyelid. Our lives should be led with such behaviour.

We are models of good behaviour and humility when we meet an important government official or an influential person. What good behaviour and politeness would we exhibit if the Supreme Himself were in front of us! In that situation, there should be no scolding or threatening others, or angry shouting reactions. Our arrogance and ego must be kept in check. That is titik·π£ƒÅ.

mƒÅtrƒÅspar≈õƒÅstu kaunteya ≈õƒ´to·π£·πáasukhadu·∏•khadƒÅ·∏• ‡•§ (BG 2.14)
The world associates and dissociates from us. Sense experiences come and go. Our minds should not be swayed by them.

What do we do during sultry summers, wet monsoons, or dew or cold winters? We accept those as seasonal changes and endure them. We do not try to change Nature but adjust to her system. Why do we not have the same attitude with our worldly relationships? Bodily nourishment, growing thin, elation, pain, opulence and poverty, triumph - all of these appear randomly and leave subsequently. They are transient and impermanent. We should not give in to worry for those.

The rival of titik·π£ƒÅ is egotism. ‚ÄòMy‚Äô convenience, ‚Äòmy‚Äô profit, ‚Äòmy‚Äô desire, ‚Äòmy‚Äô pride - when these ‚Äòme‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô are on the ascendant, forbearance becomes impossible. ‚ÄúAlas! My work got hampered! My ego is hurt! I did not get what I wanted in time!‚Äù - are all examples of the ego in action. These are destructive to the practice of living in Divine Presence.

Titik·π£ƒÅ comes from an understanding of the eternal and the transient.

ƒÅgamƒÅpƒÅyino‚ÄônityƒÅs tans-titik·π£hasva bhƒÅrata (2-14)

Cold, heat, pain, mirth, debt, money, anxiety and excitement - all of these do not last long. They exist for a while and then disappear. Once wisdom dawns about these ephemeral entities, enduring them becomes easier.

The understanding of this difference between the eternal and the transient is known as a ‚Äúsense of proportion‚Äù which refers to the relative importance of different aspects of a circumstance or an object. It would not be in the fitness of things to pay four or two rupees for something worth three rupees. It would not be prudent to devote a day‚Äôs attention to an occurrence of momentary impo·πõtance. All of our daily vexations and irritations are caused because of a lack of this ‚Äúsense of proportion‚Äù. We make mountains of molehills; disturb ourselves and others as well.

vivekabhra·π£·π≠ƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ bhavati vinipƒÅta·∏• ≈õatamukha·∏• ‡•§ (Bhart·πõhari nƒ´ti≈õataka 10)

The fall of those lacking wisdom proceeds in a hundred ways.

Titik·π£ƒÅ enables peace of mind. There is no experience of reality without mental peace. Just as it is not possible to see an object clearly in the light of a lamp whose flame is swayed by wind, a disturbed mind is unable to comprehend the truth. Therefore titik·π£ƒÅ is an imperative prerequisite for the seeker of Truth.

Appendix 5. VyavasƒÅya (Sustained effort)

vyavasƒÅyƒÅtmikƒÅ buddhirekeha kurunandana ‡•• (2.41)

Here vyavasƒÅya refers to sustained effort or continuous industry focused on a single goal. That is penance (tapas). A person needs to be of a single-pointed mind to satisfy any immense objective. If, on the other hand, his mind were to vacillate from one side to another every moment, none of his efforts would go very far.

80 or 90 percent of us need to learn this lesson. Multiple objects of this world attract them. But they get fascinated by each one of those attractions and end up without satisfaction in any of them.

When a teacher listens to exquisite music, he thinks - ‚ÄúAh! What a wretched job I have! If only I were a musician‚Äù. The musician longs after the legal profession. The lawyer is interested in medicine. The doctor on the other hand wants to try his hand at business. The same person when listening to the radio in the morning feels - ‚ÄúAha! If I had learnt music!‚Äù. When he sees a civil servant in a cavalcade of cars, he exclaims - ‚ÄúI should have done my IAS!‚Äù. When, in the afternoon, he sees rich lawyers depositing money in the bank, he greedily admires the legal profession. When he sees the interminable queue and the fans in a movie theatre the yearning becomes - ‚ÄúHad I been an actor!‚Äù. This is the fate of many. They lack respect for what they have but regard what they do not possess very highly. This is a sure path towards spoiling one‚Äôs life.

The one who is desirous of leading a meaningful life must first fix up a goal in his mind. With the goal decided, he must pursue it without letting go. He should not get fascinated by everything he sees and lose his mind.

Good in this world is of many a kind. Pleasures are myriad. Tastes are teeming. Attractions are endless. All of them cannot be enjoyed by a single person. He might get to enjoy but a few of them. But he should not give up on his goal because of them. When he gets a whiff of fried snacks from a neighbouring house while on a walk, he must not forget that food must be cooked in his own kitchen. He should not forget that he has his own family when he listens to a pleasant melody from someone‚Äôs dwelling. He must forever keep his goal in his sights and constantly strive towards it. Arjuna was a k·π£atriya. His chief goal was to protect dharma. If he set that goal aside and thought - ‚ÄúI will be a mendicant. I will campaign for animal welfare. I will be a nurse in a hospital. I will do bhajan in a temple‚Äù, it would not be dharma; but a deficiency in it.

When a person wants to set a considered goal, those around him say different things and confuse him. ‚ÄúOh! What‚Äôs in a BA?‚Äù - exclaim the neighbours of a family wanting their boy to study for a BA. ‚ÄúWhy? Can‚Äôt they afford to make him a B.E.?‚Äù - object the other neighbours. ‚ÄúYou should go in for at least a B.Sc.‚Äù - avers the third set of neighbours. The mind dithers.

My friend was building a house. Five or six of us used to walk every morning in front of the construction site. Someone amongst us would proffer a suggestion every single day. One day I said, ‚ÄúThe window should have been bigger‚Äù. The next day another opined, ‚ÄúThe door now looks smaller in proportion to the window‚Äù. The third averred, ‚ÄúYou should probably tile the roof‚Äù. Another continued on another day, ‚ÄúA concrete roofing is better for such a house‚Äù. The owner of the house would listen to all these suggestions with a smile. We went there after twenty such days. No suggestion would come forth that day. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have any suggestions today?‚Äù he asked us beaming. ‚ÄúWhose suggestion should I have followed? If I had followed all your suggestions, even the walls of the house would not have risen‚Äù - he finally declared.

bahu-≈õhƒÅkhƒÅ hyanantƒÅ≈õhcha buddhayo‚ÄôvyavasƒÅyinƒÅm ‡•§ (BG 2.41)
The intellects of the faltering are many-branched and endless.

This is the fate of those who do not know their own mind. The individual firms up when the goal is known. This brings repose to the mind. Such a mind becomes capable of achieving the goal. Therefore, if life has to become meaningful, the first undertaking is deciding upon the goal. Once the goal is decided, one must not change directions frequently. One must not give his ears to those on this side and that. Arjuna had done so. He was taken in by others‚Äô words and became confused. Therefore, BhagavƒÅn chided him

‚Äúpraj√±ƒÅvƒÅdƒÅ·πÉ≈õca bhƒÅ·π£ase ‡•• (BG 2.11) - You utter these words of ‚Äòwisdom‚Äô!
≈õrutivipratipannƒÅ te ‡••‚Äù (BG 2.53) - When your intellect is uncertain because of the words of the ≈õruti that show multiple possibilities.

and corrected him. ‚ÄúYour intellect has lost faith by listening to others words and is agitated‚Äù. This is a caution to all of us.

Summary

In a sense, karma has not spared anyone. When we say karma here, only the actions that we perform after due deliberation are to be considered and not natural bodily functions such as breathing. In such actions where a person exerts himself, there is a possibility of pƒÅpa. What is its root cause? Karma is inanimate. Any quality ‚Äì good or bad ‚Äì that is attributed to it, is from the doer. A sword is just a lifeless form of iron. Merit or demerit from the sword is accrued because of the mindset of the person who wields it.

Water acquires the colour, smell, and taste of the land on which it flows. Like water, karma is independent, without colour or quality. It is a part of the universal mechanism of life. The more elevated the doer becomes, the purer his karma becomes. Based on who the doer is, the same karma could be virtuous or sinful; or it could be beyond these two, being just a sport of the Self.

Chapter 3 / Section 4

The Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Svadharma-yoga) or Karma-yoga

This chapter deals with the following six topics -

  1. Unavoidability of karma 2. Cooperation amongst all beings 3. Karma without attachment 4. Distinction between karma of the wise and that of an ordinary person 5. Relationship between j√±ƒÅna and karma 6. Necessity of performing one‚Äôs own dharma

Arjuna‚Äôs heart mainly harboured these feelings:

  1. Love for his kinsmen 2. Fear of sin 3. Indifference for his own self-interests 4. Reflection on dharma

We feel that these are virtues to be found in good people, not vices. However, ≈örƒ´K·πõ·π£·πáa derided Arjuna‚Äôs words as base, ignoble, and indicative of his weakness. The reason for this acerbic statement was that Arjuna‚Äôs argument was praj√±ƒÅvƒÅda ‚Äì mere words of wisdom. K·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs objection to it was that Arjuna was parroting the words of the wise and not substantiating them by applying his own intellect to any philosophical reasoning. What, then, is the basis for philosophical reflection? For all deliberation about dharma and adharma, the fundamental concept is the study of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Therefore it is imperative to understand the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Thinking along those lines, ƒÅtmƒÅ is indestructible; whereas the body is going to definitely perish. Therefore, K·πõ·π£·πáa said ‚ÄúO Arjuna, what is destroyed if you fight? Only that for which destruction is a natural end. You should not bemoan that. If you ask why you have to fight ‚Äì fight for kingdom, glory, enjoyment and for a place in svarga. If you feel that you don‚Äôt need them, fight for dharma. Take part in this fight for dharma with the spiritual view that it is your sacred duty. Karma that is performed without desire for its fruit and with the attitude of a yogi who has transcended both virtue and vice, will not shackle you‚Äù. Hearing BhagavƒÅn speak thus, Arjuna asked ‚ÄúWho is a spiritual yogi? How does he behave in this world?‚Äù BhagavƒÅn then described the signs of a sthitapraj√±a ‚Äì the calm and equanimous yogi. The sthitapraj√±a has mastered his sense organs. He is beyond the dualities of love and hate, happiness and sorrow. He does not hanker for anything and is unselfish; his mind is placid ‚Äì thus Lord K·πõ·π£·πáa described the brƒÅhmƒ´-sthiti ‚Äì the state of where the mind is firmly established in Brahma.

Then Arjuna said ‚Äì ‚ÄúWell, K·πõ·π£·πáa, you said that the means to attain brƒÅhmƒ´-sthiti is true knowledge of the Self. If the yoga of the intellect, sƒÅ·πÖkhya-yoga can itself gain me that excellent state, can I not follow that path? Why are dharma and karma required?‚Äù The answer to this question is given in the third and fourth chapters.

At this point, it is necessary to clearly understand the meaning of karma. Karma means work. Words in Indian languages such as karma, kƒÅrya, k·πõti, k·πõtya, kartavya, kara·πáa, kƒÅra·πáa, kriyƒÅ, ƒÅkƒÅra, vikƒÅra, and prakƒÅra - all spring from the same root. Of these words, the word karma is more prevalent in the terminology of the ≈õƒÅstras. The meanings of this word are many. Let us examine those meanings that are of interest to us.

Firstly, karma is of two kinds: 1. PrƒÅk·πõta (involuntary or natural) and 2. Svak·πõta (voluntary or wilful)

PrƒÅk·πõta karma is unknowingly performed by an animal without it expending any effort: breathing, blinking, yawning, burping, hunger, sleep, excreting and egesting waste from the body ‚Äì these bodily functions are natural. Even a j√±ƒÅni has to go through them. Together, they can be called prƒÅ·πáa-kriyƒÅs, or bodily actions essential to sustain life.

Svak·πõta karmas are those that humans perform knowingly. They are of two types ‚Äì 1. sat-karma (good karma) and 2.du·π£-karma (bad karma). We shall see their detailed descriptions later, in the next sections. For now, let us just have this in mind: karma that uplifts the jƒ´va is satkarma, karma that pushes it down is du·π£karma.

All karma can be classified into three kinds.

1.Karma ‚Äì Performing what is prescribed

2.Akarma ‚Äì Not performing what is prescribed, or performing it and behaving as if one has not performed it.

3.Vikarma ‚Äì Performing what is prescribed in a way it is not supposed to be done.

This classification can be seen in prƒÅk·πõta karmas also; breathing through the mouth instead of the nose, for instance. But they are not because of human volition.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

Sat-karma itself is dharma. It is of three kinds:

  1. Laukika (pertaining to the world) 2. Vaidika (pertaining to the Vedas) 3. PƒÅramƒÅrthika (pertaining to the ultimate truth)

Laukika dharma is what we commonly follow in the world ‚Äì bh≈´tadayƒÅ (compassion towards all creatures), sadƒÅcƒÅra (virtuous conduct), satya(truth), ahi·πÉsƒÅ(nonviolence), ≈õauca(purity), k·π£amƒÅ(mercy), dƒ´navƒÅtsalya (tenderness towards the wretched), para-hita-cintana (thinking of others‚Äô well-being), paura-rƒÅ·π£·π≠raka-kartavyas (the duties of citizenry) ‚Äì all these virtuous behaviours and noble qualities are expected of all and accepted by all.

Vaidika dharma is mainly of two types: one is in the form of sa·πÉskƒÅras and the other is in the form of sƒÅdhana (performing actions). Sa·πÉskƒÅra refers to rituals such as jƒÅtakarma (rituals performed soon after birth), nƒÅmakarana (naming ceremony), upanayana (the ritual that marks the entry into student-hood), vedƒÅdhyayana (the study of the Vedas*)*, vivƒÅha (wedding), etc. They purify the jƒ´va by means of mantras and rites sanctioned by the ≈õƒÅstras. Bathing in holy rivers and going on pilgrimages belong in this category.

The Gƒ´tƒÅ says that sƒÅdhana rituals are of three kinds ‚Äì yaj√±a, dƒÅna, and tapas. All meritorious undertakings can be added here. Under yaj√±a, we can include actions such as worship of deities, devoted service to gurus and elders, and studying the ≈õƒÅstras. In the Gƒ´tƒÅ, there is the mention of yaj√±as like dravya-yaj√±a (yaj√±a performed by offering ƒÅhuti into the sacred fire), j√±ƒÅna-yaj√±a (learning something deeply), svƒÅdhyƒÅya-yaj√±a (studying something deeply by oneself), dhyƒÅna-yaj√±a (meditation) and so on. Yaj√±a is worship. All work that we do to make others happy is yaj√±a.

DƒÅna is giving away something that belongs to us to someone who is deserving. There are many kinds of dƒÅna. Before dƒÅna, there should be a feeling of belongingness about the asset that is going to be given away. Later, when the object is given away willingly, when we say ‚Äúna mama ‚Äì not mine‚Äù, then it is dƒÅna.

Tapas means penance or intense meditation. Being moderate with respect to food and enjoyment; to control the mind and the senses by prayer and study of sacred texts; to teach the mind to understand and practise profound topics: to repeatedly remember, meditate upon and practise a great ideal, a great quality, a great virtue; to constantly strive towards a noble cause ‚Äì all this is tapas.

Thus, yaj√±a, dƒÅna, and tapas ‚Äì all three are the instruments to attain something higher. The aforementioned sa·πÉskƒÅras and these instruments follow tradition, according to ≈õƒÅstras. Believers follow the rules laid out for them by their religious sanctions. Fasting during Ramzan for Muslims, penance during Lent for Christians ‚Äì all these are duties stipulated by their scriptures. Followers of the Veda believe that they yield benefit not only in this world and this life but in other births and other worlds. Indeed, for many acts of worship, the benefit obtained is more in the other world than in this world.

The third is pƒÅramƒÅrthika karma. Both laukika and vaidika karmas have associated fruits. PƒÅramƒÅrthika karma does not desire fruit. It is performed without any hunger for reward, with the single view that it is one‚Äôs duty, the duty performed to please ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. PƒÅramƒÅrthika karma is dhƒÅrmika and is beyond it as well. From the point of view of usefulness to the world, it is dharma. From the point of view of the doer, it is beyond dharma. Therefore it can be called ‚Äòadhi-dharma‚Äô ‚Äì something that is over and above and beyond dharma. When BhagavƒÅn said ‚Äònis-trai-gu·πáyo bhavƒÅrjuna‚Äô this is what he meant. This is how an equanimous person behaves in this world. He performs his dhƒÅrmika duties without expecting any reward. Ordinary people perform virtuous deeds out of a desire for worldly pleasures and wealth, or dread of naraka, or longing to attain a place in svarga. In contrast, a pƒÅramƒÅrthika person, without any desire or fear or longing, conducts himself with everyone mindful that he is one with the entire universe ‚Äì ƒÅtmaupamyena sarvatra. Sat-karma is natural to him ‚Äì just as perfume is natural to sandalwood or coolness is natural to the moon. It does not need any effort or exertion; this is the best of best states ‚Äì the BrƒÅhmƒ´ state.

Karma in common parlance can also mean ‚Äôthe fruit of karma.‚Äô When we say: ‚ÄúHe is experiencing his karma,‚Äù we imply that he is experiencing the good and bad results of his deeds. PrƒÅcƒ´na, prƒÅrabdha, prƒÅpti ‚Äì all these are synonyms for the karma of the past. In the fourth, seventh, and fourteenth chapters, the word karma is used to mean prior deeds, including actions performed during previous births. We shall analyse this interpretation later, as we look at those contexts. The meaning of karma as the fruit of prior deeds is not relevant to us for now.

Arjuna had his doubts. K·πõ·π£·πáa once advised him thus ‚Äì ‚ÄôYuddhƒÅya yujyasva‚Äô ‚Äì engage in battle for the sake of battle, ‚ÄôKarma·πáy-evƒÅdhikƒÅras-te‚Äô ‚Äì your right is only to perform karma and ‚ÄôKuru karmƒÅ·πái‚Äô ‚Äì perform your karmas. Again he said ‚ÄôAvara·πÉ karma‚Äô ‚Äì karma is inferior, ‚ÄôBuddhau ≈õara·πáamanviccha‚Äô ‚Äì find refuge in buddhi, ‚ÄôYogƒÅya yujyasva ‚Äì be engaged in yoga‚Äô. Thus K·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs instruction was a mixture of two seemingly mutually exclusive things; it looked absurd. Arjuna‚Äôs mind was therefore perplexed. He asked Krishna ‚Äì ‚ÄùKarma and j√±ƒÅna ‚Äì which of these two should I pursue? Please tell me with certainty.‚Äù

K·πõ·π£·πáa says: Arjuna, j√±ƒÅna and karma are not contradictory to each other, they complement each other. Initially, karma is the means for knowledge. Once knowledge is acquired, karma becomes its result. Karma is, anyway, ever present. The jƒ´va cannot escape the stain of karma by only giving up action. Just assuming the state of an ascetic does not bring you knowledge. Then what is meant by ‚Äúleaving karma‚Äù?

na hi ka≈õcit k·π£a·πáamapi jƒÅtu ti·π£·π≠hatyakarmak·πõt‡•§
kƒÅryate hyava≈õa·∏• karma sarva·∏• prak·πõtijairgu·πáai·∏•‡•• BG 3.5

‚ÄúNo one can exist for even a second without performing any kind of karma. Nature herself pushes intrinsic qualities out into the world, holds our hands, and gets work done. When senses are being rankled by worldly objects and are inflaming the mind, hiding this agony inside and showing off a stiff exterior is just hypocrisy. On the contrary, one who controls his senses and makes his limbs perform karma only for the sake of dharma, without caring for any benefit for himself, is a Karma-yogi.‚Äù

karmendriyƒÅ·πái sa·πÉyamya ya ƒÅste manasƒÅ smaran‡•§
indriyƒÅrthƒÅn vim≈´·∏çhƒÅtmƒÅ mithyƒÅcƒÅra·∏• sa ucyate‡•• BG 3.6

One who subdues his outward senses but dwells on carnal pleasures in his mind is a hypocrite. He does not know what has to be purified. There is no use of restraining external organs and giving up karma. BhagavƒÅn says:

niyata·πÉ kuru karma tva·πÉ karma jyƒÅyo hyakarma·πáa·∏•‡•§ BG 3.8

‚ÄúPerform the karma that is designated for you (niyata-karma). Do whatever has to be done. Performing such karma is better than giving it up altogether.‚Äù

Here, the distinction between niyata-karma and aniyata-karma (designated and undesignated karma) is the key. Suppose a family member, old or young, is bedridden at home. Then, suppose there is a bhajan programme in the neighbour‚Äôs house, is it niyatam‚Äìdesignated‚Äìkarma to go and ensconce oneself there? A lot of good deeds are seen in this world. Are they all prescribed for everyone and appropriate for everyone? Is India‚Äôs dash to Korea or elsewhere to resolve a dispute justified when the Chinese are marching against us? No. Is there anything to be achieved in your neighbourhood? Where does your responsibility lie? Reflect upon that. It is essential to fulfil duties enjoined by the ≈õƒÅstras after careful thought.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

If we consider the verses between the ninth verse ‚Äì ‚Äúyaj√±ƒÅrthƒÅt…‚Äù and the sixteenth verse ‚Äì ‚Äúmogha·πÉ pƒÅrtha sa jƒ´vati‚Äù as one single meaningful portion, the meaning might be clearer. The style of the text here is a little complex. Two or three metaphors are combined thus: KƒÅmadhenu (the milch-cow of desire), jƒ´va-cakra (the cycle of jƒ´vas), brahma-cakra (the cycle of brahma). The topics too are knotty. Food, rain, crops, yaj√±ƒÅ, distribution of the fruit of labour ‚Äî thus many ideas are intertwined here. To understand the meaning of this part clearly, the entire section has to be read as a whole.

Here, we should comprehend the word yaj√±a as the act of worship; that act has three aspects. The first is the acceptance of the greatness of that which is going to be worshipped (i.e., a deity). The second is surrendering oneself to the deity as the result of the acceptance of its greatness. The third aspect is sharing the fruit of worship with others. Unless these three perspectives are clearly etched in our minds, it may be difficult to understand the collective meaning of these verses.

Now let us examine the meaning of these verses.

yaj√±ƒÅrthƒÅt karma·πáo‚Äônyatra loko‚Äôya·πÉ karma-bandhana·∏• ‡•§
tadartha·πÉ karma kaunteya mukta-sa·πÖga·∏• samƒÅcara ‡•• (BG 3.9)

‚ÄúO Arjuna, karma that is not performed with a view that it is a yaj√±a, without completely offering it to the divine binds us to this world. The stratagem to escape this binding is not giving up karma, but performing karma with the feeling that it is a yaj√±a.‚Äù

Therefore, perform your prescribed duties without any touch of selfishness; that is, with the view that it is a yaj√±a.

sahayaj√±ƒÅ·∏• prajƒÅ·∏• s·πõ·π£·π≠vƒÅ parovƒÅca prajƒÅpati·∏• ‡•§
anena prasavi·π£yadhvame·π£a vo‚Äôstvi·π£·π≠akƒÅmadhuk ‡•• (BG 3.10)

‚ÄúPrajapƒÅti created people with the sense of yaj√±a embedded in their hearts, and commanded them thus:
O people, bring out and employ the feeling of yaj√±a which is inherent in your hearts and obtain all you want from it. Yaj√±a is a veritable kƒÅmadhenu (divine cow) bestowed on you.‚Äù

devƒÅn bhƒÅvayatƒÅnena te devƒÅ bhƒÅvayantu va·∏• ‡•§
paraspara·πÉ bhƒÅvayanta·∏• ≈õreya·∏• paramavƒÅpsyatha ‡•• (BG 3.11)

Please the deities of the universe with this yaj√±a. They will please you. Thus may divinities and humans gladden each other and gain supreme welfare.‚Äù

[This has been said on behalf of Para-brahma. It is said that there is something greater (para·πÉ) than materialistic things that can be granted by deities in this world. The world of Para-brahma is not just more distinguished than this world, but also beyond the worlds of Indra and S≈´rya. The deities of the universe are all subservient to Parabrahma.]

i·π£·π≠ƒÅn bhogƒÅn hi vo devƒÅ dƒÅsyante yaj√±abhƒÅvitƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
tairdattƒÅn apradƒÅyaibhyo yo bhu·πÖkte stena eva sa·∏• ‡•• (BG 3.12)

‚ÄúThe devas, satisfied by your yaj√±as, will grant you all you desire. One who does not return their gifts to them by means of dƒÅna, dharma, and benevolent charity and enjoys them alone, is a thief.‚Äù

yaj√±a≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅ≈õina·∏• santo mucyante sarvakilbi·π£ai·∏• ‡•§
bhu√±jate te tvagha·πÉ pƒÅpƒÅ ye pacantyƒÅtmakƒÅra·πáƒÅt ‡•• (BG 3.13)

Those who enjoy the fruit of yaj√±a, considering it a remnant of the yaj√±a, as a gift from the divine, and treat it as prasƒÅda, will be emancipated from all pƒÅpas. (Within the term bhagavat-prasƒÅda is embedded the indication that it should be shared with others. This meaning becomes clear here). Those who consume it for their own, selfish sake without sharing with others will be eating pƒÅpa. Such a person cooks to fill his own stomach.

Now Jƒ´va-cakra:

annƒÅdbhavanti bh≈´tƒÅni parjanyƒÅdannasa·πÉbhava·∏• ‡•§
yaj√±ƒÅdbhavati parjanyo yaj√±a·∏• karmasamudbhava·∏• ‡•• (BG 3.14)

All living beings in the world are born of food. Food is the origin of life. Food is generated by the benevolence of the deity Parjanya. Parjanya becomes benevolent because of yaj√±a, or propitiation of the divine.

Propitiation of divinities is in the form of many laukika and vaidika karmas.

karma brahmodbhava·πÉ viddhi brahmƒÅk·π£arasamudbhavam ‡•§
tasmƒÅt sarvagata·πÉ brahma nitya·πÉ yaj√±e prati·π£·π≠hitam ‡•• (BG 3.15)

‚ÄúThat karma is fundamentally inspired by Brahma. (We just saw that the inclination to perform karma is present in beings by birth).
That Brahma (here it means Veda) is created by the eternal substance called Para-brahma. Para-brahma is omnipresent. Therefore Brahma is present in the performance of a yaj√±a‚Äù. (15)

eva·πÉ pravartita·πÉ cakra·πÉ nƒÅnuvartayatƒ´ha ya·∏• ‡•§
aghƒÅyuri·πÉdriyƒÅrƒÅmo mogha·πÉ pƒÅrtha sa jƒ´vati ‡•• (BG 3.16)

‚ÄúThus rotates the cycle of Life. The life of one who does not revere it‚Äî one who does not follow activities related to the cycle of life starting from the growing of food to realising Para-brahma through worship‚Äîis in vain.

It can be said that these eight verses contain the essence of what ordinary people learn from the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Let us keep the important parts of this teaching in mind.

  1. The universe is not worthless. It is created by Brahma. Therefore, it deserves our devotion and respect. 2. Devas are the powers of Nature that are moving the machine of the universe ‚Äì Indra, Agni, Varu·πáa, VƒÅyu, S≈´rya, P·πõthvƒ´, Candra, Parjanya, etc. 3. Yaj√±a is the worship of all these divinities. The worship comprises three emotions ‚Äì (i) Obedience and respect (ii) Partaking of the results as prasƒÅda, (iii) Distributing the results to the world 4. Obedience here means understanding the laws of Nature and acting according to them, and not attempting to perform deeds that are against nature. The hairs on the body, by nature, hang down. That is its natural direction, anuloma. An attempt to make it stand up is against Nature. That is called pratiloma. 5. Whatever is the fruit obtained from Nature, from the activity of the powers of the universe, however it is, should be accepted with equanimity as a boon from the divine. One should not think ‚Äì ‚ÄúI earned this‚Äù, ‚ÄúThis is the fruit of my intellectual prowess‚Äù, or ‚ÄúThis is self-acquired‚Äù. Instead, one should think, ‚ÄúThis is not my effort, it is a gift from above.‚Äô‚Äô 6. Whatever is thus obtained should be shared with other people of the world. The three meritorious works ‚Äì tapas, yaj√±a, and dƒÅna are present in the daily tasks of our lives. It is possible for everyone to practise. Tapas is accepting ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs greatness and giving up one‚Äôs ego. Performing wordly tasks using the powers of the universe is yaj√±a. (See the Puru·π£a-s≈´ktam.) Not consuming the fruit of the beneficial action oneself, but sharing it with others around him and experiencing happiness by mingling it with their happiness, is dƒÅna.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Thus, one who leads life in the form of tapas, yaj√±a, and dƒÅna, does not have to hanker after mok·π£a. It is readily available. By leading a life that is dedicated to the divine, he climbs above the duality caused by lust and anger. Gradually he will realize that there is something beyond worldly enjoyment and becomes eligible to see the abode of paramƒÅtmƒÅ. Then is freedom from karmic shackles.

yastvƒÅtmaratirƒìva syƒÅdƒÅtmat·πõpta≈õca mƒÅnava·∏• ‡•§
ƒÅtmanyƒìva ca santu·π£·π≠astasya kƒÅrya·πÖ na vidyatƒì ‡•• BG 3.17

K·πõ·π£·πáa says, ‚Äúsahayaj√±ƒÅh prajƒÅh sr·π£·π≠vƒÅ‚Äù (It appears that there is a pƒÅ·π≠hƒÅntara, ‚Äúsahayaj√±aih‚Äù). It is probably necessary to make sense of this verse by explaining and understanding the inner meanings of expositions of the earlier ƒÅcƒÅryas.

  1. It should be noted that there is no mention of division on the basis of region, caste, or clan. By the words ‚ÄúprajƒÅh sr·π£·π≠vƒÅ‚Äù, it is clear that it refers to all humankind. Therefore, this instruction applie to all humans, irrespective of caste or position in life. 2. The temperament of yaj√±a is inherent in the makeup of human nature. It has not entered man from outside. It is not created by someone else‚Äôs influence. The inclination towards yaj√±a is one of the innate qualities of humanity. 3. Yaj√±a is worship. An important part of worship is naivedya or oblation. It is also called ƒÅhuti or havirbhƒÅga; that itself is upƒÅyana or gift. The common English translation of the word yaj√±a is sacrifice. In essence, ‚Äôsacrifice‚Äô also means proper conduct of oneself towards something sacred ‚Äì that is, start with worship and make an offering. Giving up something that belongs to us for an object worthy of worship ‚Äì giving up one‚Äôs ownership with a sense of reverence is yaj√±a. 4. Is not the purport of the earlier verse that Yaj√±a is inborn in man? What does it mean? Does it not imply that giving up ownership is inborn and natural in him? Is it real, though? Our experience tells us otherwise. Man is by nature selfish. Giving up something selflessly is usually unnatural to him. (See #7 below). 5. Let us explore the experience in greater depth and breadth. In every human, there is surely some generosity in something. Even the most parsimonious man will show some affection and concern towards his wife and children ‚Äì at least sometimes. He might loosen up, at least to reach his own selfish ends. He might draw someone close to him and help him. The seed of selflessness is thus sown. DƒÅna and yaj√±a are the workings of sattva-gu·πáa. There is no human without at least some goodness in him. Just as there cannot be a person who is completely sƒÅttvika, there is no one completely devoid of goodness. In some people, the quality of sattva-gu·πáa and the tendency towards yaj√±a are quite minimal and feeble. By associating with the world, these feelings gradually grow and become more intense. Lust becomes love. Love transforms into attachment. Attachment moulds into fellowship. Fellowship trains one to give up selfishness, at least a little. This is the instruction of nƒ´ti acquired by acquaintance with the world. This teaching is possible because there is at least an iota of sattva in all humans. The germination of this tiny seed of sattva is the initial manifestation of yaj√±a. Matthew Arnold‚Äôs opinion is nearly the same ‚Äì ‚Äú… the enduring Power, not ourselves, which makes for righteousness.‚Äù (Literature and Dogma). 6. Initially, natural selfishness itself expects others‚Äô help. No one can lead a life in this world without at least some help from other people. Thinking thus objectively, a solitary life is not a full life. No man is completely independent. Everyone is dependent on others. As humans are necessary for one another‚Äôs survival, they have established families, societies, and states. Plato the philosopher affirms the same. Thus, interdependence among humans is a natural state. 7. Even though the seed of yaj√±a is naturally present within us, our difficulty is that it is dormant (See 5. above). As we will later see in the sixteenth chapter, daivƒ´ and ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities are both mixed in our nature. Selfishness and friendship with others co-exist. A sense of ownership exists alongside indifference. The object of dhƒÅrmika rituals is to sift through this mixture, separate out the virtuous qualities and reinforce them. Among all dharmas, the first one is the intention to help others, the will to think of others‚Äô welfare. Even if it is born out of a desire for one‚Äôs own welfare, it is not a flaw. It is enough if from within arises the realisation that there is someone other than oneself and that their companionship is valuable. This wisdom paves the way for further lessons in moral instruction. When man progresses from egotism to affection ‚Äì when ego expands from self-centredness into a sense of ‚Äòmine‚Äô and ‚Äòmy people‚Äô ‚Äì it can be said that the progress of nƒ´ti has begun. The second step is moving from the sense of ‚Äúonly these are mine‚Äù to the feeling that ‚Äúall are mine‚Äù. Due to the organisation and mechanics of creation, natural self-love and self-regard themselves desire the company of others and help practise giving up selfishness. 8. ‚Äúparaspara·πÉ bhƒÅvayanta·∏•‚Äù: is the golden maxim of life in the world taught by BhagavƒÅn. That indeed is friendship with the world. It is a yaj√±a where one‚Äôs selfishness is offered as an ƒÅhuti. Bonding with family is its preliminary form. The husband has to give up something for the happiness of his wife. She, in turn, has to do the same for him. This mutual giving up for the other‚Äôs sake itself is yaj√±a which leads to a rise in matrimonial bliss. In fact, love itself is preparation for giving up oneself. Without the yaj√±a of the offering of one‚Äôs ego, there cannot be family or friendship or society, or any human relationship at all. 9. As the fluid of ‚Äòme‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô gradually spreads from one‚Äôs home to the extended family, to society and then to the country, it goes deeper and becomes thinned and diluted. As ego thins out, the practice of likening oneself with the whole world increases. As the practice of ƒÅtmaupamya (the feeling that the whole world is like us) increases, the universe is seen and experienced as an extension of oneself. When the sense of belonging breaks out of the embankments of worldly attachment and rushes into the sea of paramƒÅtmƒÅ, mok·π£a or salvation is gained.
