[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

‚ÄúWhen devas are worshipped and satisfied, they give rain and good crops.‚Äù

It is easy to misconstrue this statement. Will rains cease, or will crops die because worship is stopped? Are rains and crops dependent on human effort? Then, does it not mean that man is more powerful than nature? This is a frivolous argument. If a father says to his scallywag of a son, ‚ÄúIf you study well, I will buy you a wristwatch. If you listen to your mother she will give you tasty snacks,‚Äù what does it mean? Does he imply that he will not feed his son or throw him out of the house if he does not pass his exams? We are familiar with such behaviour of fathers and sons. Even if the son is a rogue and fails all his exams, his parents tell him to try, try, and try again. BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs promises of rains and crops and fulfilment of other wishes are not injunctions, but incentives and means of encouragement. It is an instruction to an individual. Mother Nature does not stop rains and crops that are due to the whole world, just because an individual or a thousand people stop their worship and yaj√±as.

At this point, the symbiosis that is alluded to in ‚Äúparaspara·πÉ bhƒÅvayanta·∏•‚Äù seems like it should be between humans and the divine. However, we should understand that a similar relationship with the motive of mutual benefit should be present between humans and lesser animals as well. It is also clear that humans should also have similar conduct with one another.

The statute of symbiosis is applicable to the whole world. What is its fundamental tenet?

sarva-bh≈´tastham-ƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni cƒÅtmani ‡•§
ƒ´k·π£ate yoga-yuktƒÅtmƒÅ sarvatra sama-dar≈õana·∏• ‡•• BG 6.29

The inspiration for such conduct‚Äîa feeling of brotherhood‚Äîis natural in all beings. Goodness is present in everyone to at least a small extent, but it is hidden deep inside. It has to be brought out and made to express itself. That is the intention of ≈õƒÅstras and traditions.

Yaj√±a is performed for the benefit of the entire world. It is a form of worship performed for the abnegation of one‚Äôs selfishness and the welfare of the world.

The universe thrives on the symbiosis between the devas and humans. Yaj√±a is a means to establish that relationship. Such activity that cements the bond between the devas and humans is dharma. That is what the ≈õruti says ‚Äì

yaj√±ena yaj√±am-ayajanta devƒÅh ‡•§ tƒÅni dharmƒÅ·πái prathamƒÅny-ƒÅsan ‡•• (Puru·π£a-s≈´kta, ·πögveda 10.90.16)

At the beginning of creation, various devas employed the five primordial elements (pa√±ca-mahƒÅ-bh≈´tas) in appropriate activities, and thus worshipped ƒ™≈õvara. That was the first yaj√±a and the beginning of dharma. Dharma is the subservience of the forces of nature to the rule of the divine without transgressing it in any way. Dharma is performing acts that are ordained. This is what our great poets have praised. VƒÅlmƒ´ki and VyƒÅsa are of the same opinion. They do not consider the devas to be completely separate from humans, or that there is no connection between their world and ours. Devas, humans and other animals belong to the same world.

yatra vi≈õvam bhavatyekanƒ´·∏çam‡•• (MahƒÅnƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-Upani·π£ad 1.14)

The entire universe is embedded in the nest of the Supreme Brahma. In the ≈öƒÅkuntala, KƒÅlidƒÅsa says,

tava bhavatu bi·∏çaujƒÅ·∏• prƒÅjyav·πõ·π£·π≠i·∏• prajƒÅsu‡•§
tvamapi vitatayaj√±o vajri·πáa·πÉ prƒ´·πáayasva ‡•• (Abhij√±ƒÅna-≈õƒÅkuntalam 7.34)

‚ÄúMay Indra send abundant rain for the benefit of your subjects; may you please him with many yaj√±as.‚Äù

We have to grasp the meaning of these lines of the Gƒ´tƒÅ (6-29) carefully. The universe is created by ƒ™≈õvara. Many energies come together in this great and continuous endeavour. By the ordinance of ƒ™≈õvara, man has the unique opportunity to collaborate with them, by becoming one of them. That is dharma. Satkarma is that which makes use of this opportunity.

Karma is like water, without its own form, taste or colour. Water takes the colour, taste, and form of the ground on which it flows. Similarly, depending on the person performing it, karma can be pu·πáya or pƒÅpa. Karma that is beyond these may be a mere sport of ƒÅtmƒÅ. The nobler the karmi (doer) becomes, the purer the karma gets. Karma is, anyway, an integral part of the universe. When that is so, when it satisfies the governing deities of the universe, they grant good rain and bountiful crops in return. Living beings thus enjoy bliss and bounty.

There is a question here. What is the relation between yaj√±a performed by humans and rains and crops? If men stopped performing yaj√±a, would nature‚Äôs work cease? Does it not rain, don‚Äôt crops grow in countries where people do not even know the concept of yaj√±a? Here are five points to ponder upon:

  1. All religions espouse the belief that there is a relationship between human merit and divine grace. Similarly, there is a relationship between human pƒÅpa and the wrath of the deities. When they are angry, natural calamities such as drought, flood, earthquakes, and pandemics plague the earth. This belief can be observed in the texts of Islam as well as in Christian religion. 2. Similarly, we cannot accept that in countries outside India - countries that do not know the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras- rain and crops are obtained without yaj√±a. Yaj√±a is essentially the worship of the divine. In this broad sense, there is no community that does not perform yaj√±a. Even the most primitive African tribe firmly believes in a supernatural power, fears its wrath, and craves for its blessing. Probably such faith is more entrenched in them than in modern city dwellers. There is no human without religion; and no religion without yaj√±a. Therefore we cannot use the example of religions outside the umbrella of the Vedas to prove that there is no relationship between rain, crops, and yaj√±a. 3. Just as it is difficult to prove that human karma and nature are related, it is difficult to prove that they are unrelated. Similar are the claims about the afterlife and the otherworld. If rebirth is possible and the afterworld exists, pu·πáya and pƒÅpa as well as drought and plenty are inter-related. ‚ÄúAs in the physical world, so in the world of spirit, nothing ever goes without producing results ‚Äì results of one kind or of another kind‚Äù [A line DVG probably made in English.] We believe in karma; we believe in rebirth; we believe that the future is influenced by the past. Therefore, we also believe that human karma is definitely related to divine intervention. 4. If nature‚Äôs working is not a result of human actions, what can be the rationale for it? Does nature‚Äòs activity proceed without any rules? Is it random? Is it mad exuberance? When we observe natural phenomena like the movements of the sun, moon, and earth, it does not seem so. We see order there. We have already seen that the warps of the thread of time find a place in the working of nature. Then, how do natural events sometimes occur without any apparent reason? Effect always has a cause. We reason that a part of those causes is human karma ‚Äì good or bad. Nature follows the dicta of ƒ™≈õvara. That karma should have appropriate consequences is *ƒ™≈õvara‚Äô*s law. 5. The universe is a glorious mega machine. Divine beings, humans, lesser animals, and inanimate objects are its gears, wheels, handles, ramrods, and ribbons. The machine works only if all these components are doing their allocated jobs. Suppose the screw on the mudguard of a car is loosened by coming into contact with a shaft, it should be repaired immediately. If it remains loose, it starts making a sound, the vibrations of which loosen other parts of the car. Gradually, the entire machinery of the car might fail. It is the same with the machinery of the universe. Transgression committed by a human today will touch the deities, the powers of nature and will anger them. Man is not isolated from the universal machine. Whatever happens to it, happens to him also. Whatever he does affects it as well. Thus, celestial beings and humans are parts of the same machine.

This has been explained in other places.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

Who are devas? Various pictures of divine beings holding a trident, staff, rope, or discus might arise in our minds. These pictures are useful elsewhere; they can assist in meditation. When we are studying philosophy, devas are the powers of creation and nature ‚Äì great powers of various kinds. The relationship between humans and these superhuman deities may not be directly observable to us. But it cannot be said that they do not exist just because they are not seen. For most of us living in Bangalore, China is unseen. But does China not exist? We do not doubt its existence at all!

BhagavƒÅn has explained the symbiosis between the world of devas and the world of humans ‚Äî that one influences the other, and has presented a philosophy that is more expansive and munificent than today‚Äôs socialism and communism ‚Äì

tair-dattƒÅn-apradƒÅyaibhyo yo bhu·πÖkte stena eva sa·∏•‡•• BG 3.12
‚ÄúOne who consumes alone, the bounty bestowed upon him by the divine overseers, is verily a thief.‚Äù

yajna-≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅ≈õina·∏• santo mucyante sarva-kilbi·π£ai·∏•‡•§
bhu√±jate te tv-agha·πÉ pƒÅpƒÅ ye pacanty-ƒÅtma-kƒÅra·πáƒÅt‡•• BG 3.13
‚ÄúYaj√±a is giving a part of one‚Äôs earnings to others to please the divine. One who consumes the leftovers of this yaj√±a considering it as prasƒÅda from them is virtuous. Cooking only for oneself and partaking of it is a pƒÅpa.‚Äù

Therefore, we have rituals like vai≈õvadeva, bali-hara·πáa, and bh≈´ta-bali, where food is offered to the powers of the universe, performed since ancient times. Behind the rule that one should not partake of meals without guests is the same intent. That is why the Veda declares

‚ÄúOne who eats alone eats only pƒÅpa.‚Äù

Naivedya offered to the divine and hospitality towards guests are also yaj√±as. This is the principle of communal living. This is the path to the elevation of the jƒ´va.

sa·πÉs·πõ·π£·π≠a·πÉ dhanamubhayam samƒÅk·πõtamasmabhyam‡•§ (·πögveda-sa·πÉhitƒÅ 10.84.7)

≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa merely taught Arjuna the technique to expand the nature of his ƒÅtmƒÅ, something that has been expounded by ·πõ·π£is since the times of the ·πögveda. The ƒ™≈õopani≈õat says ‚Äì

tena tyaktena bhu√±jƒ´thƒÅh (ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsya-upani·π£ad 1)
All wealth belongs to ƒ™≈õvara. You enjoy the world thinking of it as his prasƒÅda.

I would like to relate something heartwarming about a family I know well. The head of the family was quite well-to-do; he was a government servant, drawing a salary of about four hundred or five hundred rupees. His wife was the overseer of the house. She would sit for her meals after the whole family and the servants were also fed. When she sat down thus for her meals, she would serve herself whatever she wanted and keep back the remaining food. Then she would gather some food from her plate into her palms ‚Äì rice, curry, ghee, fried food, etc., and stand at the door of her house. Some beggars who knew the hour would come there and accept food from her hands. This was her daily practice. One day, her son asked her the meaning of this. She replied that this was her dƒÅna. The boy asked, ‚ÄúWhy is this dƒÅna required? Hasn‚Äôt Father given you enough money? He performs dƒÅna, doesn‚Äôt he?‚Äù

She replied, ‚ÄúYour father gives me money to run the entire family. DƒÅna that he does is from his own earnings. My earning is only through my cooking. Earning my food through my own hard work, and giving away a part of that as charity is pu·πáya for me. What is the use if I give dƒÅna from your father‚Äôs money and your money? That doesn‚Äôt have my tyƒÅga. DƒÅna without tyƒÅga is only in name.

Karma is necessary for everyone because of their relationship with the whole universe.

When we say ‚Äòeveryone‚Äô, is it implied that those who are already self-realised are included? Yes. Those who read ‚Äútasya kƒÅryam na vidyate‚Äù from the seventeenth verse and close the book might think that the self-realised do not have to perform karma. That is a delusion because the sentence that starts in that verse ends in the nineteenth verse ‚Äì

tasmƒÅdasakta·∏• satata·πÉ kƒÅrya·πÉ karma samƒÅcara (BG 3.19)
‚ÄúTherefore without attachment, you should always perform action which should be done‚Äù.

An ƒÄtma-j√±ƒÅni just does not have the desire to gain anything for himself. He willingly performs his duties for the benefit of the world without desiring any fruits of labour, not because of other stipulations. Everywhere, BhagavƒÅn says ‚ÄúkƒÅrya·πÉ karma,‚Äù ‚Äúniyata·πÉ karma.‚Äù ‚ÄúDo your duty.‚Äù It is indeed said that one should perform dƒÅna but it does not mean that one should take a loan for it. One should not steal in order to do charity. Duties such as taking care of one‚Äôs own family are to be performed by the returns earned by one‚Äôs own karma.

One who experiences the ƒÅtmƒÅ will not have selfish desires or indigence. Karma performed by such a person is bereft of pƒÅpa and is beneficial to the whole world as well. Such a man has the complete authority to perform karma for the sake of the universe. The one about whom it is said ‚Äútasya kƒÅryam na vidyate‚Äù, one who performs his duties without anyone‚Äôs obligation, without greed, with a feeling of being one with the universal soul ‚Äì his karma alone is beneficial to the world.

Purification of the soul and obtaining an object of desire are the two natural uses of karma. An ƒÅtma-j√±ƒÅni does not need either of these. He is already pure; he doesn‚Äôt desire anything either. Then why does he still work? For the benefit of the world‚Äîfor *loka-sa·πÖgraha‚Äî*is BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs reply. The establishment and maintenance of the order of the universe is his responsibility. ≈örƒ´ VidyƒÅra·πáya says the same thing ‚Äì

j√±ƒÅninƒÅ caritu·πÉ ≈õakya·πÉ samyag-rƒÅjyƒÅdi-laukikam (Pa√±cada≈õƒ´ 9.114)
“It is possible for a j√±ƒÅni to engage in polity and other worldly matters.”

Plato‚Äôs opinion is the same. Affairs of the state impact many; therefore one who wants to practise statecraft should not be selfish. Bhƒ´·π£ma too says the same thing in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. ‚ÄúYou are possibly not interested in the pleasures of svarga or kingship. Should you not, however, take the circumstances of the world into account? Perform your duty diligently to please the owner of the house in which you live.‚Äù

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 7) Source: prekshaa]]

There is another thing to consider. Illustrious people such as Janaka, who are greater than you have all performed karma much before you.

‚ÄúJanaka and others attained fulfilment by karma only; You should also perform your duty keeping the welfare of the world in mind‚Äù.

Janaka was a great and elevated soul. Many ·πõ·π£is would send seekers desirous of initiation into brahma-vidyƒÅ to him. His story appears in many places ‚Äì in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, BhƒÅgavata, Yoga-vƒÅsi·π£·π≠ha, and above all in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad where it appears as a conversation between him and YƒÅj√±avalkya. Just as Janaka was distinguished in his lifetime, so are you now. The ordinary imitate the eminent.

yadyadƒÅcarati ≈õre·π£·π≠ha·∏• tattadevetaro jana·∏• ‡•§

‚ÄúWhatever a great man does, the other men also do; The world follows whatever he sets up as a standard‚Äù.

‚ÄúLet us say that Janaka is not in front of us now. Am I not there? You have seen me since childhood. You know my basic nature. “Whenever there is decline of dharma and rise of adharma, I manifest myself. For the protection of the virtuous, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of dharma, I am born in every yuga.”

paritrƒÅ·πáƒÅya sƒÅdh≈´nƒÅ·πÉ vinƒÅ≈õƒÅya ca du·π£k·πõtƒÅ·πÉ ‡•§

How affectionate BhagavƒÅn is towards the universe! We should never forget this. We should diligently and devoutly discharge the duties that have been allotted to us by his divine arrangement. In the story of K·πõ·π£·πáa in the BhƒÅgavata, the gopikƒÅs ask him: ‚ÄúIn this world, we see that some people love only those who love them. Some others love those who do not love them in return. ‚ÄúJust as ignorant men perform their duties being attached to them, the wise should perform their duties for the welfare of the world, without attachment‚Äù.

This is the essence of karma yoga. It has to be always remembered by those who share their ideals with the Gokhale Institute.

Even though Karma is directly perceived, its root is hidden. When a man‚Äôs inner tendencies flow out through his actions, it becomes karma.

yatpuru·π£o manasƒÅbhigacchati‡•§ tadvƒÅcƒÅ vadati‡•§ tatkarma·πáƒÅ karoti‡•§ (Taittirƒ´ya-ƒÅra·πáyaka PrapƒÅ·π≠haka 1, AnuvƒÅka 23, Mantra 1
‚ÄúWhat a man thinks, he speaks and performs as action‚Äù.

Therefore, the place of origin of good and bad results of karma is the manas (mind). The mind is the kartƒÅ or doer. Karma follows the doer. If he is good, it is good. If he is bad, it is bad. If his intention is improper, it is not virtuous, even if the endeavour is worthy. If the intention is upright, he is worthy; regardless of the nature of his work, it is virtuous.

hatvƒÅ‚Äôpi sa imƒÅ·πÉllokƒÅn na hanti na nibadhyate‡•• BG 18.17

How does a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ differ from an aj√±ƒÅnƒ´? Do not both of them work for the sake of the world? Having said that, there is a characteristic difference. What the aj√±ƒÅnƒ´ performs with an eye for profit, the j√±ƒÅnƒ´ performs without any expectation. The function is the same. Even the j√±ƒÅnƒ´ might think that he is working for the betterment of the world. Is it not selfishness? Does not the seed of selfishness thrive in him to that extent? BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs response is thus: ‚ÄúEven if a tiny bit of egotism is present in one‚Äôs mind, he cannot be called a j√±ƒÅnƒ´. In a worldly sense he may be called a j√±ƒÅnƒ´; he just does not have any realisation of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. However, there is an interesting aspect to consider. ‚ÄúActions are being done in every way by the gu·πáas of prak·πõti (nature). However, a man deluded by ego thinks that he is the doer‚Äù.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 8) Source: prekshaa]]

Human nature is composed of the triad of gu·πáas ‚Äì sattva, rajas, and tamas. It is true of the universe also. A man‚Äôs inner nature influences his outward behaviour and vice-versa. The essence of graha-atigraha mentioned in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka-upani·π£ad is this mutual impulse.

tattvavit-tu mahƒÅbƒÅho gu·πáa-karma-vibhƒÅgayo·∏• ‡•§
gu·πáƒÅ gu·πáe·π£u vartanta iti mattvƒÅ na sajjate ‡•• (BG 3.28)

One who knows the principle of distribution of natural temperaments (gu·πáa) and actions (karma) understands that all the workings in the world are a dialogue between the gu·πáa-triad internal to the jƒ´va and the gu·πáa-triad of the universe. Also he understands that the ƒÅtmƒÅ is unaffected by these transactions and remains an uninvolved outsider.

The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ knows that life in this world is a working of prak·πõti and is not related to the jƒ´va ‚Äì like the sah·πõdayas (connoisseurs) watching a play. Life in this world needs to be only seen from afar and enjoyed. Actors who come on stage perform different actions ‚Äì they laugh, cry out, and scream. The audience, without really being a part of the happenings, remain separate but see, experience, and enjoy the play.

The mental condition of the j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is thus ‚Äì

sƒÅk·π£ƒ´ cetƒÅ kevalo nirgu·πáa≈õ-ca (≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara-upani·π£ad 11)
‚ÄúWitnessing everything, isolated, devoid of all gu·πáas.‚Äù

Prak·πõti seems amuse herself through her manifold activities. That is the lƒ´lƒÅ of BhagavƒÅn and is beyond our control. A j√±ƒÅnƒ´ constantly keeps this in mind. Ordinary people do not differentiate ƒÅtmƒÅ from the body and other upƒÅdhis (attributes). They are of the illusion that the body is the jƒ´va and the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Indeed, the body consists of three aspects ‚Äì 1. Sth≈´la {Gross, tangible form}, 2. S≈´k·π£ma {subtle form}, 3. Li·πÖga or KƒÅra·πáa {The subtle form that is unaffected by transmigration between bodies.} Until body, mind, and notions arising from memories of previous births captivate the jƒ´va, it remains just that ‚Äì a mere jƒ´va. Our mind mistakes jƒ´va to be the supreme ƒÅtmƒÅ and vice versa because that is how it understands the nature of the body. But a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is ‚Äòk·πõtsnavit‚Äô ‚Äì ‚Äòone who knows everything.‚Äô He sees that ordinary people are deluded. But he does not thoughtlessly seek to liberate them from their path. Spiritual attainment is proportional to one‚Äôs intellectual capacity, skill and virtue. People should not be prevented from pursuing the sƒÅdhanƒÅ that they deem fit. If we stop them from doing what is suitable for them, they will lose their sƒÅdhanƒÅ; our instruction will be unsuitable for them and they will not be able to follow it and thus they will deteriorate. When learning to walk, it is not good if one forgets the gait of a crow but cannot learn the gait of a swan. The gƒ´tƒÅ therefore says,

na buddhibheda·πÉ janayet aj√±ƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ karmasa·πÖginƒÅm (BG 3.26)

If people follow what is right for their stage, they will earn the ability to enter higher stages.

This is what our enthusiastic vedƒÅntins should realise. Proclaiming the ultimate truth to lay people might be detrimental to them, rather than being helpful. If a father teaching his young child to walk well pulls him at his speed, the child might lose its motivation, energy or even his life. It is the same in spiritual pursuit. There must not be an undue hurry to make progress in the path of self-realisation.

The initial requirement for the study of VedƒÅnta is to keep the mind under control and to be honest in the work one is doing. We must pay more attention in nurturing this common worldly moral conduct. People are more engaged in disputes‚Äîof ‚ÄúDvaitamu sukhamƒÅ advaitamu sukhamƒÅ‚Äù [A famous kriti by Sri TyƒÅgarƒÅja]‚Äîwhether dvaita is better or advaita is better. It is useless. All interpretations of VedƒÅnta expect purity of the jƒ´va and the six-fold qualities of ≈õama, dama, etc. [≈öamƒÅdi-·π£a·π≠ka-sa·πÉpatti refers to ≈õama, dama, titik·π£ƒÅ, ≈õraddhƒÅ, uparati, and samƒÅdhƒÅna.] We have to give more importance to that.

~

BhagavƒÅn has summarised the relationship between j√±ƒÅna and karma. An ordinary man thinks that he is the one performing karma, from the point of view of the jƒ´va. The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ knows that he is not the doer but prak·πõti is the doer. The distinction between the two of them is not in performing karma; it is common to both. For ordinary people, karma is preparation for j√±ƒÅna. For realised jƒ´vas, karma is the result of j√±ƒÅna. BhagavƒÅn thus set the boundaries of the pervasiveness of karma and said, ‚ÄúArjuna, the result of your karma does not belong to you. Whatever be the result, understand that it belongs to me (that is, to the ParamƒÅtmƒÅ) and fight without desire or egotism.

mayi sarvƒÅ·πái karmƒÅ·πái sa·πÉnyasyƒÅdhyƒÅtmacetasƒÅ ‡•§
nirƒÅ≈õƒ´rnirmamo bh≈´tvƒÅ yudhyasva vigatajvara·∏•‡•• (BG 3:30)
‚ÄúDedicate all your actions to me with your mind intent on the supreme ƒÅtmƒÅ. Break off from your affliction. Do not fear. Fight without anguish!‚Äù

Even a great j√±ƒÅnƒ´ follows the path paved by his own prak·πõti. Then how is j√±ƒÅna useful for him? What is the use of self-realisation when Prak·πõti dictates everything? It is this: when a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ performs karma, his negative mental qualities like desire and hatred are kept in check. Of course, he does perform karma; but it is untainted by love or hate. An ordinary man, on the contrary, is afflicted by desire and hatred. He also works according to the dictum of his nature, but the difference is in the condition of their minds.

prak·πõti·πÉ yƒÅnti bh≈´tƒÅni nigraha·∏• ki·πÉ kari·π£yati (BG 3.33)

Nature is all-powerful in everything. Is it possible for someone born with a voice like that of a beast of burden to sing like the Gandharvas? Natural qualities are always present in their places, without fail. In any situation, nature rushes forth to show herself. This nature is different for different people. In the context of a jƒ´va, it is of the form of unconscious tendencies inherited from previous births. It is the result of past actions and conditioning. Therefore, nature works differently for different people. It then follows that dharma is also different for different people. Dharma follows Nature. The dharma of a being is based on the nature that it houses. That is svadharma. Karma has to be performed, it cannot be avoided. But what kind of karma should it be? The karma is in the form of one‚Äôs svadharma. While performing karma is inevitable, performing it as one‚Äôs svadharma is most excellent.

≈õreyƒÅn-sva-dharmo vigu·πáa·∏• para-dharmƒÅt-sv-anu·π£·π≠hitƒÅt ‡•§
sva-dharme nidhana·πÉ ≈õreya·∏• para-dharmo bhayƒÅvaha·∏•‡•• (BG 3:35)

“Arjuna, you are a k·π£atriya. Your dharma is to fight. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is dharma for brƒÅhma·πáas; indeed only for a few of them, for those in whose minds dispassion has arisen by itself. Indeed, ≈õƒÅstras say that sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is to be avoided in the Kali-yuga. Only those who have been dispassionate and weary for a long time are eligible for sa·πÉnyƒÅsa. It is prescribed only for those who are genuinely disinterested in the pleasures of the world. Renouncing the world is to be done when one is truly disinterested in it. You, however, are a k·π£atriya. Why are you trying to follow a specific dharma prescribed only for a few brƒÅhma·πáas? It is better to perform one‚Äôs own karma even if all its attributes are not palatable. Do not consider Vi≈õvƒÅmitra as your role model. He obstinately persevered and won, and is worthy of our praises and prostrations. However, your nature is different. You have to fight. Fight!”

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of One‚Äôs Own Dharma (Part 9) Source: prekshaa]]

Why only Svadharma?

“One‚Äôs own karma performed diligently, even though it may not be the best thing, is better than others‚Äô karma performed in a most satisfying manner”. What then is svadharma?

Certain qualities, powers, propensities, and enthusiasm come to some people naturally. Using such qualities, that mindset and those internal faculties for the benefit of the world is dharma.

Then, should he be tied to his natural talents? Why should he not adopt something that is superior? How is a seemingly deficient svadharma nobler than a ‚Äòbetter‚Äô dharma that is, albeit, not one‚Äôs own? There are four reasons for this :

  1. Nature helps the doer in svadharma. Whatever she aids him in, is svadharma. Since she is supporting him, his work becomes easy. This ease is the first advantage of following svadharma. 2. When the duty becomes easy, it gets done faster too. The yield is greater too. Thus, the second reason is the plentitude of results. 3. The world will benefit greatly from this work ‚Äî as much as the doer can give, it can take and profit from it. Increased benefit to the world is the third reason. 4. When performing svadharma, at least some known qualities and abilities are solidly established and flourish in the character. If this dharma is given up and another chosen in its place, the existing abilities are weakened; there is no guarantee that new ones are gained. Therefore, the fourth reason is that there is an absolutely undiluted improvement of one‚Äôs skills.

The washerman in our town, Machayya, works till his bones break when there is a wedding in the local wealthy man‚Äôs house. What is the use? The man who is seated on the velvet carpet and garlanded on the wedding day is the musician Rangappa. Machayya became sick and tired of this and made his son Marayya learn music. After learning music for ten years, the boy could sing bhajans on the roadside, but no more. The donkeys commented that the town lost a washerman, but did not gain a musician either.

The Practice of Sattva

Arjuna raised another question. Even if we try to perform an action with the best of intentions, we may accrue pƒÅpa because of it. What should be done about that? BhagavƒÅn answered thus:

kƒÅma e·π£a krodha e·π£a rajo-gu·πáa-samudbhava·∏• ‡•§
mahƒÅ≈õano mahƒÅpƒÅpmƒÅ viddhyenamiha vairi·πáam ‡•• (BG 3.37)

BhagavƒÅn has answered this vividly and clearly. KƒÅma has to be subdued. Senses excite the mind. The manas agitates the buddhi. The agitated intellect loses its vision. Therefore, you have to carefully protect that which is above the intellect ‚Äî the true essence of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. This will preserve the buddhi from being spoiled by external influences. The intellect works well when the senses are under control. Therefore, rouse the quality of sattva within you, hidden behind the veil of the intellect, and let that be your safeguard.

Attributes like kƒÅma and krodha are hereditary. Family, in turn, is chosen based on previous karma and tendencies from past lives. Relatives and friends, society, and surroundings are also based on vƒÅsanas - impressions from past lives. If thus, the qualities of a man depend upon countless lives, how can we hope to change them? The answer is that every jƒ´va has enough internal sattva that can be much stronger than the negative vƒÅsanas accumulated from many births. But it is dormant, or it is shrunk within itself because of external rƒÅjasic and tƒÅmasic influences. We have to remember one characteristic of the jƒ´va here. The sattva of the jƒ´va is unlimited in its source. The K·πõ·π£·πáarƒÅja-sƒÅgar dam is a huge reservoir of water. The water that we get from there into our house in a tap is just a droplet from there. The pipes that carry water from the KRS to our house might be blocked by dirt and block the flow of water. However, we should remember that behind the dripping tap in our house, there is a vast reservoir. This reminiscence gives us courage. This reminiscence is the contemplation of BhagavƒÅn. He is backing us. If we remember that omniscient, omnipotent BhagavƒÅn is behind the strength that is exuded by our bodily organs – that there is an ocean of energy behind us – it becomes possible to subdue kƒÅma and krodha, which are but forms of rajas and tamas. One should constantly practise meditating on the nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ and Brahma. We shall study this later.

The capability of the ƒÅtmƒÅ appears dormant. An awakened man sharpens and hones the strength of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. The intellect then remains conscious and corrects the mind when it errs. The awakened mind quells sensory excitement. When heat from the senses subsides, the viveka to discriminate between right and wrong becomes possible. This viveka decreases the tendency to err. Thus, the first step towards conquering sin is to defeat the foe that is desire.

This chapter is generally called the Karmayoga. In a copy of the ≈öƒÅnkarabhƒÅ·π£ya, it is called karma-pra≈õa·πÉsƒÅ-yoga ‚Äî or the yoga (path) of praise for karma. Karma can be of many kinds. This chapter deals with karma that is of the form of day-to-day work, specifically karma in the form of one‚Äôs own dharma ‚Äî svadharma. Therefore, it has been called sva-dharma-yoga, so that the meaning is easily grasped.

The next chapter deals with the same topic. What was called karma in the form of yaj√±a in this chapter, is said to be karma that will be an offering to the Supreme Brahma, or karma that is performed without getting attached.

Summary

Similar to a peepal tree that has an old trunk and root along with young and tender shoots, there are stages in the history of man. The old should form the basis for the new; only then does the new acquire credibility and authority. Continuity of the new from the old is proof of a healthy society. In his instruction to Arjuna, ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa demonstrated this same continuity to him.

That which internally spurs one to search for goodness in whatever way possible is the door to dharma for that person. Dharma follows the condition of a jƒ´va - its fitness and eligibility. The svadharma of every jƒ´va is in turn determined by its unique characteristics. This means that the contemplation and practice of dharma is possible by viveka and not by blind faith.

Even though we work to fulfill our desires, if we work to serve BhagavƒÅn as a devotional yaj√±a, our ego is subdued and our jƒ´va is purified. As it becomes purer, the jƒ´va becomes capable of grasping the true essence of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. A man who does not perform karma as a yaj√±a will not even obtain its fruits in this world. He alone is worthy whose life-river flows between two banks of ƒ™≈õvarƒÅnugraha (whatever is obtained is ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs blessing) and ƒ™≈õvarƒÅrpa·πáa (whatever is given to others is an offering to ƒ™≈õvara).

Chapter 4 / Section 5

The Yoga (Path) of Unattached Karma (Nirlepa-karma-yoga) or J√±ƒÅna-yoga

This chapter deals with the following seven main topics.

  1. The antiquity of the instruction about karma 2. The divine greatness of dharma 3. Distinction of gu·πáa and karma for dharma 4. Akarma in Karma 5. Different karma-yaj√±as 6. The relationship between karma and j√±ƒÅna 7. The necessity to completely eliminate doubt

Let us recall what K·πõ·π£·πáa said in the previous chapter. He said, “Arjuna, you say that you will not perform your duty. You say that you will not fight ‚Äì fighting that is karma enjoined upon you by virtue of your family and your basic nature. Is karma subordinate to you? No. Nature makes you perform karma. Your innate disposition exhorts you to engage in activities. If you try to repress your intrinsic activities, such repression is also karma. Karma is inescapable in any which way.

na hi ka≈õcit k·π£a·πáam-api jƒÅtu ti·π£·π≠haty-akarmak·πõt ‡•§
kƒÅryate hy-ava≈õa·∏• karma sarva·∏• prak·πõtijair-gu·πáai·∏• ‡•• (BG 3.5)

“No one in this world can remain aloof without performing any activity. Owing to the inevitability of karma, whatever freedom you enjoy is not to abandon karma; it is to deliberate‚Äîin a given circumstance‚Äîwhether a task is good or bad, and to choose that which is aligned to dharma. Even this freedom to critically examine a task is also limited because the mind that is engaged in deliberation is itself largely influenced by past impressions (prƒÅcƒ´na-vƒÅsanƒÅs). The sa·πÉskƒÅras from past lives bind and cloud the mind and intellect. Even so, at an auspicious moment, because of some unseen force, the spark of sattva rises up from within. Real deliberation is then possible. Dharma has to be thought about then, especially svadharma:

≈õreyƒÅn svadharmo vigu·πáa·∏• paradharmƒÅt svanu·π£·π≠hitƒÅt‡•§ (BG 3.35)

‚ÄúYou say you want to give up your svadharma; you say that you wish to become a sa·πÉnyƒÅsi; you want to follow para-dharma [the dharma of others]; you say that you do not want the kingdom. This is not appropriate. There is great merit in adhering to svadharma.

svadharme nidhana·πÉ ≈õreya·∏•‡•§ (BG 3.35)

‚ÄúEven if your sva-dharma causes your death, it is more desirable, because nature helps you in your endeavour. It has three advantages ‚Äî

  1. Your actions will become easier and faster 2. By actions aligned to svadharma, the world will benefit more than it will if you performed para-dharma. 3. Your innate qualities will grow and expand. As they grow and flourish, knowledge of the ƒÅtmƒÅ will spring forth sooner and more easily. Your life will attain fulfilment sooner.

“Right now, your svadharma is to fight the war. Would you say that it involves cruel deeds like killing, and that it is pƒÅpa? If you carry out your actions selflessly it does not become pƒÅpa. When does pƒÅpa happen then? When you are driven by self-benefit ‚Äî even if there is a little bit of selfishness in you ‚Äî it becomes pƒÅpa. When you execute your tasks selflessly, then there is no pƒÅpa. The situation of the world requires war right now. War is needed for the sake of justice. War is needed to sustain dharma in the universe. It is not for your sake. Carry it out as an offering to BhagavƒÅn. Perform that which secures the well-being of the world without any selfish desire for profit. Then the pƒÅpa that is attached to the fight will not affect you. There is an inherent element of impurity attached in every worldly duty,. This is true of all the duties of all people, to at least a little extent. One cannot say no to life because of this. It is necessary to examine how to cleanse this impurity off. Karma is the process of life itself and therefore, it is impossible for it to be devoid of all dirt. How then can it be purified? By removing all traces of selfishness. If karma is performed without any desire for selfish benefit and as an offering to ƒ™≈õvara, it becomes a means for elevation rather than a degrading pƒÅpa. Anything other than satkarma is du·π£karma. Whatever is not your dharma is adharma for you. All karma other than your sva-dharma is adharma for you!” Thus, in the fourth chapter, BhagavƒÅn develops what he had elucidated previously.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Antiquity of Karma-vidyƒÅ

‚ÄúArjuna, what I am explaining to you now is not something new and contemporary. It is something that I had explained to the sun named VivasvƒÅn at the beginning of creation. He, in turn, taught this to Manu, the progenitor of the human race. Manu then gave the same upade≈õa to Ik·π£vƒÅku, the foremost among kings. Thus, this knowledge of karma has been passed on through many generations. Earlier, many king-sages like Janaka and others followed the tenets of this knowledge and became accomplished.”

Why did BhagavƒÅn thus speak of an unbroken guru-≈õi·π£ya tradition? Did he intend that since it was ancient, it had to be accepted? KƒÅlidƒÅsa says,

purƒÅ·πáam-ity-eva na sƒÅdhu sarva·πÉ
na cƒÅpi kƒÅvya·πÉ navam-ity-avadyam‡••
santa·∏• parƒ´k·π£yƒÅnyatarad-bhajante‚Ä¶ (MƒÅlavikƒÅgnimitram Act 1)

All that is ancient is not great because of its antiquity; all that is new is not bad because of its newness. The gu·πáa or do·π£a of something can be determined only after careful reasoning. Nothing should be accepted with blind faith. Still, the fact that many people over hundreds of generations accepted it is proof enough of the probity of the knowledge of karma. We find similar testimony of widespread acceptance by people spanning aeons even with regard to the Vedas. Therefore, the fact that a great many people have accepted the principle of karma is evidence of its efficacy.

This is why BhagavƒÅn praised antiquity and tradition. The people of our times should study this principle carefully. Human history should, like the flow of a mighty river, be unbroken. Only then does it acquire prominence. Otherwise, if it is broken here and there, torn asunder by flaws, inconsistent and incoherent, and absurd, it becomes a meaningless travail. It becomes like the lokƒÅyata refrain “aparaspara-sa·πÉbh≈´tam” (BG 16.8) (born and existing independent of one another). This is why all our social reformers have always averred that they are the followers of their elders. This is the tradition in all countries. If a reformer wants his work to be sustained in future, he always says that he is only reiterating and demonstrating what is already expressed in previous works. Jesus Christ also did the same. He did not claim that he founded a new religion, but that his was an ancient creed that disappeared over time and he was only resurrecting it. Scholars of commerce, law, and other subjects also say that they are only taking naturally established philosophies forward and not creating them anew. The seers of the Vedas said,

“iti ≈õu≈õruma dhƒ´rƒÅ·πáƒÅ·πÉ ye nas-tad-vicacak·π£ire” ‚Äî “This we heard from the wise, who explained it to us.” (ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsya Upani·π£ad 10)
“idam-ƒÅhur-an≈´cƒÅnƒÅ·∏•” ‚Äî “thus said the ancients…” (KumƒÅrasambhava 6.15)
“tade·π£ƒÅbhyuktƒÅ” ‚Äî “this was declared…” (Taittirƒ´ya-upani·π£ad 2.1)
“atraite ≈õlokƒÅ bhavanti” ‚Äî “these are the verses here…” (MaitrƒÅya·πáy-upani·π£ad)

etc., and remembered their ancient masters.

This is not just an act of courtesy. Those who strive for the progress of humankind follow the method of home builders. The very first layer is the foundation, then comes a line of bricks, and then a line above that and so on. A storey is built using the lower storey as support. Thus, it is important that all the levels from the foundation to the topmost floor are connected. A building that has stood strong for a long time itself is proof that it can withstand the impact of rain and sun and wind, and also the thumps and thwacks of people living in it. A religion or custom is venerated because it is time-tested. This is tradition. The plight of a civilisation without tradition is similar to that of a cotton strand that is flitting aimlessly as the wind takes it.

Tradition is not mindless parroting of customs and rules. ‚ÄòTraditional‚Äô does not amount to mere repetition. Saying and doing the same thing over and over again is not progress. True progress blends older aspects of societal life with the new ‚Äî just as old trunk and roots of a peepal tree coexist with and nurture new branches and leaves. The same pattern of progress holds true for human history also. The old should form the basis for the new. Only then does newness gain acceptability and strength. Such continuity from old to new is the sign of a healthy society. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa demonstrated that such continuity existed in his instruction and therefore it was worthy of following. It was accepted by many people across many generations, and therefore it was authoritative. He said, “My good man, this instruction is suited for all times. Don‚Äôt think that you, Arjuna, are the first among the world‚Äôs intelligent people! There were many wise people before you who followed this path. I am only telling you what has been established firmly, by virtue of being accepted across generations by many people. Therefore it is fit to be accepted.”

Why did something that was well-established even in ancient times go missing?

eva·πÉ paramparƒÅ-prƒÅptam-ima·πÉ rƒÅjar·π£ayo vidu·∏•‡•§
sa kƒÅleneha mahatƒÅ yogo na·π£·π≠a·∏• parantapa‡•• (BG 4.2)
(This science that was passed on in an uninterrupted manner, studied by sages among kings, was lost).
“As aeons passed, the conditions of the world changed and this knowledge was lost.‚Äô‚Äô

Coming to think of it, it is not surprising at all. We see many streams of knowledge dying out in front of our eyes.

Divine AvatƒÅras

Arjuna was surprised on hearing BhagavƒÅn praise long-lost ancestors. He said, “Wait a moment, my dear fellow! When was VivasvƒÅn born and when were you born? How were you, my contemporary, able to instruct someone who existed long, long ago?”

This question of Arjuna‚Äôs gave an opportunity to BhagavƒÅn to demonstrate his firm attachment towards his dharma. He said, “Arjuna, you and I do not belong to this era alone; we have always existed. You and I differ in two aspects. Firstly, you have forgotten your previous births; I remember them. Secondly, your births were caused because of your deeds ‚Äî good and bad. My avatƒÅras are for the protection of dharma.‚Äù

yadƒÅ yadƒÅ hi dharmasya glƒÅnirbhavati bhƒÅrata
abhyutthƒÅnam adharmasya tadƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ s·πõjƒÅmyaham ‡•§

(Whenever dharma declines and adharma ascends, I manifest myself.
To protect the virtuous, to destroy the evil and to establish dharma, I am born in every age).

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Why is Dharma Worthy of Worship?

Dharma is established and nurtured by the divine. BhagavƒÅn who needs to have no thought for anything else thinks of dharma alone and of his own volition. This should bring the greatness of dharma to our minds. Dharma is ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs own property. Therefore, it is immensely worthy of our worship. We have to always remember that ƒ™≈õvara is watching us all the time. An American poet says thus:

Though the mills of God grind slowly,
And they grind exceeding small,
Though with patience He stands waiting
With exactness grinds He all.
‚ÄîRetribution, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

Not one human-grain can elude the mill of karma. Sooner or later, they are consumed by it. Those who follow dharma escape it.

svalpam-apy-asya dharmasya trƒÅyate mahato bhayƒÅt (BG 2.40)
(Even following a little of this dharma protects from great fear)

The Need for Viveka

All this is fine, but what is the way to dharma? Whatever approach one‚Äôs heart spurs him to take in his search for goodness ‚Äî is the means of dharma for him. Dharma follows the condition of the jƒ´va, its distinct qualifications and its strengths and weaknesses. A ‚Äòone size fits all‚Äô approach cannot be applied to dharma. The dharma of a jƒ´va is determined by its unique quality. This means that the acceptance of dharma is possible only by clear-headed deliberation and not by blind faith.

dharme pramƒ´yamƒÅ·πáe hi vedena kara·πáƒÅtmanƒÅ
iti kartavyatƒÅ-bhƒÅgam mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ p≈´rayi·π£yati
(When dharma is being comprehended through the Veda,
mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ complements it by providing practical means.)
‚ÄîTƒÅrkika-rak·π£ƒÅ

Mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ means logic, or deliberation on cause and effect. This verse means that one should reflect carefully, to understand the true nature of dharma.

Thus dharma is fundamentally the same for everyone. Its practice differs according to the desires and capabilities of the doer. Just as food conforms to the health of the stomach and the desire of the palate; dharma also conforms to the state of the jƒ´va. It should consider the incapability of the jƒ´va also. Can fasting be prescribed to a person who cannot bear hunger? The dharma of a person is decided based on the natural proclivities of his jƒ´va.

Classification of Guna and Karma (Guna-karma-vibhƒÅga)

People harbour different desires in their heart and to obtain them, they propitiate different deities. They are all travellers on the wide road that leads to BhagavƒÅn. As the innate qualities and propensities of humans are naturally different, they have been broadly classified into four categories to determine their respective dharmas. BhagavƒÅn said, “I incarnate myself in this world again and again to establish dharma, to systematize var·πáas and ƒÅ≈õramas, to codify appropriate fruits for actions. Thereby I am performing my dharma.‚Äù

cƒÅtur-var·πáya·πÉ mayƒÅ s·πõ·π£·π≠ya·πÉ gu·πáa-karma-vibhƒÅga≈õa·∏• (BG 4.13)

There is a peculiar attribute of the system of jƒÅti that needs to be discussed here. The reformers of today argue that it is against the principles of equality and is therefore a blemish upon society. Even though the Gƒ´tƒÅchƒÅrya‚Äôs advice espouses equality, the essential meaning is that this equality should be practical and ultimately result in wholesome benefit to the jƒ´va. The aim of the var·πáa system is that an individual should employ his qualifications by birth in the service of the collective. It is true that the elevation of the individual is important. But if it has to be a genuine ennoblement and not just a fa√ßade, it should result in continuous, perpetual value to the collective. The basic premise of the var·πáa system is that by being of service to the collective, an individual can achieve his own betterment. The qualities, activities, and capabilities of an individual help him to thus be of service.

BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs words describe the existing situation and not the products of human imagination. As this four-fold division of human society is based on natural qualities, it is settled that it is applicable for all humans in all places at all times.

BhagavƒÅn himself has established the var·πáa system considering the various qualities distributed amongst different groups of people, and the several benefits that accrue to the world through them. He has established the dharma of various var·πáas and clans based on the naturally occurring proportions of sattva, rajas and tamas in each person.

The var·πáa system will be studied again in the appendix.

Akarma in Karma

BhagavƒÅn explains to Arjuna that even though he is engaged in karma, he is not tainted by it.

na me karma-phale sp·πõhƒÅ (BG 4.14)
‚ÄúArjuna, it is not wrong for you to fight to win a kingdom, or for glory and renown. It is also acceptable to perform your duty as an offering to BhagavƒÅn, with the sole purpose of dharma.‚Äù

eva·πÉ j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ k·πõta·πÉ karma p≈´rvairapi mumuk·π£ubhi·∏•
kuru karmaiva tasmƒÅt tva·πÉ p≈´rvai·∏• p≈´rvatara·πÉ k·πõtam(BG 4.15)

K·πõ≈õna is not modernist, but traditionalist. He believes in practices that are established over time. That is the meaning of sanƒÅtana as in sanƒÅtana-dharma. Not only those who desired worldly wealth and pleasure, but even people desirous of mok·π£a performed karma. Mok·π£a is ‚Äòrelease‚Äô. Why did those desirous of emancipation shackle themselves in karma? BhagavƒÅn explains.

karma·πáo hyapi boddhavyam boddhavyam ca vikarma·πáa·∏•
akarma·πáa≈õca boddhavya·πÉ gahanƒÅ karma·πáo gati·∏• (BG 4.17)

The ways of karma are mysterious. Therefore, to understand its nature, we have to first understand the three types of karma ‚Äî karma, vikarma and akarma.

  1. vihita-karma ‚Äî one‚Äôs ordained duty, that which has to be performed without fail, which yields results 2. vikarma ‚Äî unfavourable, forbidden karma, that which should not be performed, 3. akarma ‚Äî there are three possible meanings to this word. Therefore the preceding and succeeding contexts have to be examined before the meaning is determined.

i. Giving up all karma, including those that are mandatory or required; doing absolutely nothing at all.

mƒÅ te sa·πÖgos-tv-akarma·πái (BG 2-47)

karma jyƒÅyo hyakarma·πáa·∏•
na prasiddhyedakarma·πáa·∏• (BG 3.8)

ii. Performance of necessary duties, but not getting attached to its results. Perform action but be unconcerned and calm as though no action needs to be performed.

karma·πáy-akarma ya·∏• pa≈õyet (BG 4.18)

karma·πáy-abhiprav·πõtto‚Äôpi naiva ki√±cit karoti sa·∏• (BG 4.20)

kurvannapi na lipyate (BG 5.7)

iii. It could also mean vikarma ‚Äî action that should be avoided, something that should not be done. Even though the Gƒ´tƒÅ doesn‚Äôt have this kind of meaning, it is seen elsewhere.

Thus, the meaning of akarma is to be inferred from the context.

Arjuna is hasty. Initially, he was eager to fight. Then, he was eager to give up fighting. Vikarma is the result of this haste. Therefore, the following is said about those who deduce the nature of dharma -

yuktƒÅ ƒÅyuktƒÅ·∏•

Those who are skillful and experienced, not harsh, and practise dharma constantly, as they behave (during times of doubt), so too you shall.
‚ÄîTaittirƒ´yopani·π£ad, ≈öƒ´k·π£ƒÅvallƒ´, AnuvƒÅka11

(Who is devoid of anger and greed according to the precepts of dharma)
‚ÄîYƒÅj√±avalkya-sm·πõti 2.1

What, then, is the way here?

karma·πáyakarma ya·∏• pa≈õyet akarma·πái ca karma ya·∏•
sa buddhimƒÅn manu·π£ye·π£u sa yukta·∏• k·πõtsnakarmak·πõt (BG 4.18)
(One who sees action in inaction and inaction in action is wise among men, he is a yogi; he performs all actions)

BhagavƒÅn has captured the entire essence of karma in this verse. One who can achieve the detachment and calmness of a non-doer even while performing all actions, and can likewise find the benefit of karma while giving its fruits up, is wise. He is k·πõtsnakarmak·πõt ‚Äî one who is worthy of performing all karmas. Such a man performs all actions but is not influenced by their consequences. Jackfruit should be peeled, but the hands should not become dirty. The hands should therefore be lubricated with oil beforehand ‚Äî that is the trick. BhagavƒÅn says the same thing later through the example of a lotus-leaf in water -

A man should live in this world like a lotus leaf in water. He has to work hard outwardly. Internally, he should not be affected by it. The affliction and perturbation associated with karma should not hassle him while he performs it. The same thought is expressed in the old saying -

alepavƒÅdamƒÅ≈õritya ≈õrƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáajanakƒÅvubhau (Unknown)
The doctrine of non-attachment was employed by both ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa and JanakƒÅ.

Asa·πÖgakarma ‚Äì Karma without Attachment

BhagavƒÅn explains akarma further:

tyaktvƒÅ karmaphalƒÅsa·πÖga·πÉ nityat·πõpto nirƒÅ≈õraya·∏•
karma·πáyabhprav·πõtto‚Äôpi naiva ki√±cit karoti sa·∏• (BG 4.20)
(If one is engaged in karma but abandons the desire for fruits of action, is always content and not subject to the whims of anyone, then it is as though he is not doing anything at all)

How can he “naiva ki√±cit karoti sa·∏• " ‚Äî not do anything, even though he is actively engaged in karma? By being ever-content and completely disinterested.

tattvavit-tu mahƒÅbƒÅho gu·πáakarmavibhƒÅgayo·∏•
gu·πáƒÅ gu·πáe·π£u vartanta iti matvƒÅ na sajjate (BG 3.28)

There are some internal and some external qualities in human nature. They keep agitating one another. This agitation is not related to the ƒÅtmƒÅ, but happens in the domain of prak·πõti. It is not suitable to attach this agitation to the ƒÅtmƒÅ.

A human has freedom only to determine karma, vikarma and akarma. This freedom to deliberate is also quite limited, because even the intellect is shackled by impressions from previous births. Individual discernment is present in everyone at least to some extent. At least an awareness that one is not a j√±ƒÅnƒ´, or the wisdom that he should not proclaim it to the world if he does indeed think that he is one, or the awareness of the dangers of such self-praise ‚Äî these are all present in any person. A man should develop his discerning abilities using the wisdom he already possesses. As discernment (viveka) becomes a habit, detachment can be practised.

There is a phrase that is often used in RƒÅmƒÅyana and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ‚Äî “rƒÅmasya akli·π£·π≠akarma·πáa·∏•”, “rƒÅmam akli·π£·π≠akarmƒÅ·πáam”. The same is said about Yudhi·π£·π≠hira. Those great people perform their duties, but do not become exhausted because of them. This is alepayoga ‚Äî the yoga of performing action without getting attached. This is the formula of tyaktvƒÅ karmaphalƒÅsa·πÖgam. Even if a person actively performs karma, if he does not desire its fruits for himself and is content always, and is not subject to others‚Äô whims, that karma does not make any difference to him; to him, it is as good as doing nothing.

The epithet nityat·πõpta is mentioned above. This is a very important quality. Likewise, nirƒÅshraya. He should not be dependent on anything or anyone. Desiring the society of others is discouraged. The upright and beneficial qualities of a person emerge completely only when he becomes independent. Ni·∏•sp·πõhasya t·πõ·πáa·πÉ jagat ‚Äî the universe is but a trifle for the unattached. A man who does not have any desire, even though he performs action, is naiva ki√±cit-karoti ‚Äî does not do anything. He understands dharma. He does not deem praise or censure, fame or infamy as important. He does not experience mental strain; he does not attach his ƒÅtmƒÅ to any labour. It is said in the second chapter itself -

naina·πÉ chindanti ≈õastrƒÅ·πái naina·πÉ dahati pƒÅvaka·∏•
na caina·πÉ kledayantyƒÅpo na ≈õo·π£ayati mƒÅruta·∏• (BG 2.23)

Responsibility of the Jƒ´va-state

We said that a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ does not get fatigued and does not attach himself to any labour. Does it mean that he has no sense of responsibility?

There is only one fundamental thing - the ƒÅtmƒÅ. It is now in the state of a jƒ´va. In this state, it has certain responsibilities. In its state as pure ƒÅtmƒÅ, it is unstained. However, as a jƒ´va, it has its own responsibilities, pu·πáya and pƒÅpa, dharma and adharma. That is why BhagavƒÅn says that we should have the right judgement. It is difficult to know the path of karma. Knowing our rightful duty (vihitakarma) is difficult, as is performing it without exertion. One should neither be proud of one‚Äôs accomplishments nor feel distressed about not performing action. Wise is he who performs activity with the sole view that it is a duty. We can take the example of doctors. They have neither love nor hate for their patients, but work with the sole intention of bringing the bodies to their normal working state. They never worry if the patient is a criminal or a thief.

The principle is that there should be no desire for the fruit of a task. Our duties should be performed to please BhagavƒÅn and to sustain dharma. Even in the performance of good karma, there are two stages. The first stage is to act to please BhagavƒÅn, whereas the second stage is to act with self-knowledge. Self-knowledge is hard to obtain; it has to develop within us, by itself. For this to happen, the impurities that cover the mind have to be removed. These impurities can only be removed when dhƒÅrmic duties are performed.

Selfless Karma

Who should follow the principle of not wanting results for one‚Äôs duties? Those who are seeking mok·π£a. How many of us are wishing for mok·π£a? Surely, the number of people wishing for material things vastly exceeds that. We all desire something or the other. They may all be noble desires. For instance, those indulging in wrongdoing must be destroyed; we as a country should grow our own food; we have to establish ourselves well in the world; attain glory and so on. We perform‚Äîindeed we have to perform our duties to attain these desires. A man desirous of mok·π£a can also carry out all these duties, but he does them independently. This is the meaning of nirƒÅ≈õraya·∏•.

We work towards one or the other goal. K·πõpa·πáƒÅ·∏• phalahetava·∏• ‚Äî wretched are they who work only with the motive of results. What did our ·πö·π£is pray for? Asmin de≈õe ≈õ≈´ro jƒÅyatƒÅmityƒÅha ‚Äî “May brave people be born in this country, may strong horses be born; may youth capable of discussing in assemblies be born; may they discuss and argue in august assemblies‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî all this is selfishness from a certain perspective. It might be beneficial, but it is still selfishness. BhagavƒÅn assures Arjuna that pƒÅpa will not attach to him if he performs his duties just for the sake of dharma, to sustain the world.

yad·πõcchƒÅlƒÅbhasantu·π£·π≠o dvandvƒÅtƒ´to vimatsara·∏•
sama·∏• siddhƒÅvasiddhau ca k·πõtvƒÅpi na nibaddhyate (BG 4.22)
(He who is content with what comes to him unasked, transcending dualities, free of jealousy, who remains equanimous during attainment or nonattainment of the desired object, will remain free even when he performs worldly duties.)

Duties do not shackle a man who, without fatiguing oneself, is content with what he has, has a state of mind that has risen above worldly love and hate, shunning jealousy, is single-minded, and is of equanimous disposition towards success or failure. Yad·πõcchƒÅ is something has come to us, as it is our lot; let it be. DvandvƒÅtƒ´ta·∏• ‚Äî pƒÅpa and pu·πáya also constitute duality ‚Äî but let us not go so far. The duality that we see commonly is that of love and hate. Vimatsara·∏• ‚Äî without jealousy. BhagavƒÅn says this word again and again. By all accounts, practising it is very difficult; being free of jealousy ‚Äî anas≈´yƒÅ is hard in this world. Sama·∏• siddhƒÅvasiddhau ca ‚Äî we should not give up activity because the results of our work were not what we expected. We have to try again and again to perform our dharma. He, who carries out his duties with such a mindset, is ‚Äî k·πõtvƒÅpi na nibaddhyate” ‚Äî not bound by karma.

Karma-yaj√±a

gatasa·πÖgasya muktasya j√±ƒÅnƒÅvasthita-cetasa·∏•

One who is unattached and is liberated, with his mind established in true knowledge, acts in the spirit of yaj√±ƒÅ. All his actions are indeed absolved.

The activity performed by a knower of truth, who is neither anxious for the results nor is excessively passionate, is no different from yaj√±a. All karma, carried out with such a view does not influence the performer of the action in any way and dissolves away completely.

Each and every one of our duties must be carried out in the spirit of the yaj√±a. This is the instruction of the ≈õruti as well ‚Äî to live with the spirit of yaj√±a. Whenever the word yaj√±a is mentioned, a picture of homa, the sacrificial fire, purohitas chanting mantras and ghee for the oblation comes to mind. That is not just it. All worship is yaj√±a. Grammar dictates the same ‚Äî “yaj p≈´jƒÅyƒÅm” ‚Äî the root yaj is used in the context of worship. In practice, yaj√±a usually refers to oblation through fire or an offering. Giving up something we love in order to please another is yaj√±a.

It has been said earlier one should give up the desire for the fruit of an action. However, this feeling‚Äîgiving up something for a loved one‚Äîis easier to grasp. The following verse is well-known.

All karma carried out by a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is yaj√±a. All parts of this yaj√±a, all its instruments are manifestations of the Supreme Brahma. The very process of yaj√±a is dedicated to It. Thus, the profit gained by a man who is engrossed in selfless, divine duties ‚Äî brahma-karma, is Brahma itself. The doer, the work and the object are all one with Brahma. All activities of life are, indeed, worship of Parabrahma. ≈öruti says the same -

Once we say that it is not wrong but only fit and proper to experience pleasure, we have to make all arrangements to obtain it. Sustaining the family, earning a salary for their comfort, taking loans in case there are emergencies and repaying them, giving and taking help, struggling thus in many ways become the duty of a householder.

In the Presence of the Divine

Whatever one can think of, whatever one‚Äôs mind likes, whatever one is capable of doing, whatever one likes to do, - if one thinks, ‚Äú≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa prasƒ´da (≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa*,* be pleased)‚Äù while doing any of this or praying for any of this - it becomes a yaj√±a. ‚Äî≈öiva-mƒÅnasa-p≈´ja

The essence of the earlier upani·π£at quote ‚Äî “tasyaiva·πÉ vidu·π£o yaj√±asyƒÅtmƒÅ yajamƒÅna·∏•” is also the same. “≈õarƒ´ra·πÉ g·πõha·πÉ” ‚Äî the body is the house of Para≈õiva, and the enjoyment of worldly pleasures is “te p≈´jƒÅ” ‚Äî his worship. ≈örƒ´ KanakadƒÅsa says “eveyikkade no·∏çuva no·π≠a ninnadayya” ‚Äî the sight that stares (at beautiful maidens) without blinking is yours, “·π£a·∏çurasadannakke nalidƒÅ·∏çuva jihve ninnadu” ‚Äî the tongue that is gladdened by tasty food with all six flavours is yours. Life should be led in this manner, with a mind to yaj√±a. “Yanmara·πáa·πÉ tadavabh·πõtha·∏•” ‚Äî death is also a part of the yaj√±a of life. The word yaj√±a has a wide range of meanings. By the word j√±ƒÅna in j√±ƒÅnayaj√±a should be understood philosophy, biology or mathematics and all other branches of learning. Physics, biological and social sciences and all other scientific pursuits too are j√±ƒÅna, which implies that even scientists are established in yaj√±a. All studies, all art, and all knowledge are harmonised in the realm of self-welfare.

Our ancestors followed a meaningful vrata, “kavale kavale Govinda·πÉ” ‚Äî at mealtime, they would take BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs name with each morsel of food they partook instead of chatting with others. This is the same as reciting verses during meals. Today‚Äôs city life is not conducive for remembering the names of the divine often. Gandhiji tried to bring back this practice. Singing divine names is a kind of training for some minds. For people with such a mindset, even chanting divine names is a yaj√±a. There are two kinds of results for all yaj√±as ‚Äî obtaining what one wishes for, and gradual elevation of the jƒ´va.

We perform our activities with a desire to accomplish something. However, if we perform karma with a view that it is a yaj√±a or that it is a service to the divine, our minds will gradually turn towards the Supreme; our ego will gradually diminish as the jƒ´va becomes purer. And as the jƒ´va becomes purer, it becomes capable of grasping the principle of reality.

People work according to their capabilities. What did Kucela have? A handful of rice! How did that become inexhaustible? Because he said K·πõ·π£·πáƒÅrpa·πáa. Everything should be seen as an offering to K·πõ·π£·πáa. Whatever we obtain must always be seen as a boon from K·πõ·π£·πáa. An elderly person in my family would recite a Telugu verse at mealtime ‚Äî “Not a grain of rice more, not a grain less; not a minute earlier, not a minute later; not a drop of water more, not a drop less. BhagƒÅvan, only the quantity that you determine will enter my stomach”. After chanting the pre-meal mantras, he would recite this verse and take ƒÅpo≈õana(ritual drinking of a spoon of water before meals). The meaning of the mantras chanted by vaidikas at meals ‚Äî “≈õraddhƒÅyƒÅ·πÉ prƒÅ·πáe nivi≈õya ‚Ä¶ prƒÅ·πáƒÅya svƒÅhƒÅ …” ‚Äî is the same, it is the constant remembrance of the presence of the divine. It is “practising the presence of the Supreme”. It is the feeling that we are always under the watch of the divine. The feeling of this proximity of the divine does not arise from a thousand campaka flowers or ten thousand jasmines. If the feeling first exists, only then does worship with this large heap of flowers carry any meaning. Maturity of mind is paramount. This is what BhagavƒÅn implies when he says “patra·πÉ pu·π£pa·πÉ phala·πÉ toya·πÉ”.

yaj√±a-≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅm·πõta-bhujo yƒÅnti brahma sanƒÅtanam

O great scion of the Kurus! Those who partake of the am·πõta that is the remnant of yaj√±a attains the eternal abode of Brahma. One who does not perform yaj√±a is not even fit for this world, what then to say of other, higher worlds?

A person who carries out his duties without considering it an offering, will not even gain the good in this world. Then, how can he obtain a good state in other worlds? Mok·π£a is the best among the four cardinal aims of human life. Karma helps achieve dharma, artha and kƒÅma (dharma, wealth, and enjoyment). Even so, karma is the necessary first step for mok·π£a. Mok·π£a is liberation from the burden of the universe. Since we do not know the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, mƒÅyƒÅ (illusion of the world) and moha (attachment to the world) cover and shackle us, and make life miserable and burdensome. To get rid of the burden, we should know the true nature of jƒ´va, ƒ™≈õvara and ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. That is tattvaj√±ƒÅna or the knowledge of reality. The way to this knowledge is training the mind by performing our duties.

≈õreyƒÅn dravyamayƒÅt yaj√±ƒÅt j√±ƒÅnayaj√±a·∏• parantapa
sarva·πÉ karmƒÅkhila·πÉ pƒÅrtha j√±ƒÅne parisamƒÅpyate (BG 4.33)
(O scorcher of foes, J√±ƒÅnayaj√±a is better than yaj√±a performed with physical objects. All karma culminates in j√±ƒÅna. )

A man who feels that he is performing a yaj√±a, will be content with what he obtains. What he gains is a blessing from ƒ™≈õvara, what he gives away is an offering to ƒ™≈õvara ‚Äî indeed, blessed is the man whose life-stream flows thus between the banks of blessings and offerings. He reaches the ocean of Brahma quickly. By constant recollection of ƒ™≈õvara, he will understand the nature of BhagavƒÅn ‚Äî “j√±ƒÅne parisamƒÅpyate” ‚Äî it culminates in j√±ƒÅna.

The Benefit of Satkarma

Thus, there are four uses of performing satkarma ‚Äî

  1. Obtaining what one desires, like in the stories of Gajendra and Dhruva. 2. Practice of bhakti: the experience that there is something above us, the understanding that it deserves our love, worship, service, and obedience. This gives us serenity and courage. 3. Diminished ego: the illusion of “I”, the constant feeling that there is an ocean of energy behind us. 4. Preparing the mind to grasp the knowledge of reality.

The intellect can, probably to a certain extent, understand the nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. To understand it fully, it has to be experienced. If it has to be experienced, all our internal faculties must work together as one. The severity and rigidity of the ego must be annihilated. All this priming will ready it for self-realisation. “buddhigrƒÅhyamatƒ´ndriyam” (BG 6.21) ‚Äî it can be grasped by the intellect, even though it is suprasensory. Belief should rise from inside. The mind, akin to a mirror, must become pure.

dh≈´men-ƒÅvriyate vahnir-yathƒÅdar≈õo malena ca (BG 3.38)
(Just as fire is enveloped by smoke, and a mirror by dirt).

Karma is that which wipes this mirror clean.

Obtaining J√±ƒÅna

Well then, is knowledge gained by just performing our duties? That is not enough; there must be other effort too. What is that?

tadviddhi pra·πáipƒÅtena paripra≈õnena sevayƒÅ
upadek·π£yanti te j√±ƒÅna·πÉ j√±ƒÅninƒÅtattvadar≈õina·∏• (BG 4.34)
(Learn that knowledge from those who have realized the truth. Approach them with a spirit of sincere enquiry and serve them with humility. They will impart that knowledge to you.)

Pra·πáipƒÅta is bowing down, a demonstration of humility. It is a sign that one is interested in learning something of value. It signifies earnestness and receptivity. Readiness to grasp is the first sign of a seeker of knowledge.

The second sign is paripra≈õna ‚Äî Analysing the same thing in various ways and asking pertinent questions, thereby clearing all doubts.

The third sign is sevƒÅ or service. Be with the elderly and knowledgeable always. The guru may expound the theory of the Supreme Brahma in words, but its practice must be learnt by observing his conduct. “kelava·πÉ mƒÅ·∏ªpavarindƒï ka·πá·∏çu” ‚Äî learn some things by observing those who are already doing them. One must wait, watch and observe how gurus deal with challenging and difficult circumstances when the mind is perturbed.

This is the essence of philosophy:

yad j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ na punarmoham eva·πÉ yƒÅsyasi pƒÅ·πá·∏çava
yena bh≈´tƒÅnya≈õe·π£e·πáa drak·π£asyƒÅtmanyatho mayi (BG 4.35)

The supreme principle is that by knowing which the delusion that is clouding your mind will not arise again; after seeing which you will see all creatures of the world within yourself and me also. How can you incur pƒÅpa after understanding this? Harming others is pƒÅpa.

≈õlokƒÅrdhena pravak·π£yƒÅmi yadukta·πÉ granthako·π≠ibhi·∏•
paropakƒÅra·∏• pu·πáyƒÅya pƒÅpƒÅya parapƒ´·∏çanam
(In half a verse, I will convey what has been expounded at length by millions of books. It is pu·πáya to help others, and pƒÅpa to hurt others.)

Who is para ‚Äî other ‚Äî when there is nothing in the universe other than oneself? For an ƒÄtmaj√±ƒÅnƒ´, there is nothing or no one other than him in the universe. How, then, can he hurt anyone else? Or, how can he even help anyone else? It is just self-conceit to say that one has helped another. One who sees himself in everyone doesn‚Äôt see “other”. Therefore, he is not even touched by pu·πáya or pƒÅpa.

aya·πÉ nija·∏• paro veti ga·πáanƒÅ laghucetasƒÅ·πÉ
udƒÅracaritƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ tu vasudhaiva ku·π≠umbakam
‚ÄîHitopade≈õa 1.71

Ordinary people have the feeling that one is his own, or that another is alien. Therefore he has the concepts of pu·πáya or pƒÅpa. But the generous man who has comprehended the Supreme principle considers the whole world is an extension of himself. Therefore, understanding the true nature of the Supreme will erase the differences in the world, their derivatives such as greed and delusion, and their derivatives such as hatred and jealousy.

j√±ƒÅna·πÉ labdhvƒÅ parƒÅ·πÉ ≈õƒÅntim acire·πáƒÅdhigacchati (BG 4.39)
(Having obtained knowledge, he will quickly attain great peace).

The Necessity of Firm Decision

Arjuna, if we analyse from the perspective of the supreme principle, it becomes clear that your doubts are baseless. Be firm about the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Do not entertain doubts in your mind.

aj√±a≈õcƒÅ≈õraddhadhƒÅna≈õca sa·πÉ≈õayƒÅtmƒÅ vina≈õyati
nƒÅya·πÉ loko‚Äôsti na para·πÉ na sukha·πÉ sa·πÉ≈õayƒÅtmana·∏• (BG 4.40)
(One who does not know, doesn‚Äôt have faith or is filled with doubts in his mind, perishes. A doubtful man can neither live in this world nor the otherworld. He is never happy.)

Do not keep swinging between karma, j√±ƒÅna, dharma or sannyƒÅsa. You will be ruined from all sides if you do that. Trust something completely. Only then will you attain a better state.

Let us suppose a man has been invited to a banquet at a big restaurant. We can imagine the conflict in a traditional man‚Äôs mind if he comes to know that that day is an ekƒÅda≈õi[eleventh day of the lunar fortnight; traditional Hindus fast on this day.] If he stays back at home, he will be thinking about the good time his friends are having. If he does go, he will be worrying that he is eating outside food on an ekƒÅda≈õi. Both are doubtful ‚Äî sa·πÉ≈õayƒÅtmƒÅs. One did not enjoy the banquet, the other did not think of BhagavƒÅn on ekƒÅda≈õi.

We have to believe in one thing ‚Äî either karma or j√±ƒÅna. Only then can we be peaceful. Belief is courage, and courage is happiness. There are thousands, even countless philosophies in today‚Äôs world. But it cannot be said that any one of them can really build faith. Many of them can, however, shake existing beliefs. The poverty of our times is that we do not have strong belief ‚Äî the belief ‚ÄòI am living for a specific purpose, I will be delivered from our sorrows from this‚Äô. Amongst the various kinds of poverty that afflict us, lack of belief (≈õraddhƒÅdƒÅridrya) is the greatest.

‚ÄúArjuna, doubt born of ignorance is housed in your heart. Cut it with the power of the knowledge of the self, and establish yourself in the yoga of performing your duty for the Divine. Get up and fight‚Äù. This is ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs instruction.

Nirlepa-yoga

This chapter seems to have got its name, j√±ƒÅna-karma-sa·πÉnyƒÅsa-yoga, from the words ‚Äúyoga-sa·πÉnyasta karmƒÅ·πáa·πÉ‚Äù. This chapter is called brahma-yaj√±a-pra≈õa·πÉsƒÅ in the ≈öƒÅ·πÖkara-bhƒÅ·π£ya. The important takeaway here from the view of the common people is karma·πáyakarma yah pa≈õyet. We should perform karma, but in such a way that its dirt does not stick to us. Therefore, it is quite apt if we name this chapter nirlepa-karma-yoga.

Alepa or nirlepa is a negative form. It means that something is not there, and not that something good is present instead. If something or some work has to be useful, there should be a positive ‚Äôas‚Äô (present) quality associated with it. Just because something bad went away, it does not mean that something good came by. Just because a banana leaf is cleaned well with water, it does not mean that the tongue tasted good food and the stomach became full. A banana leaf becomes useful if and only if there are various palatable eatables on it. Similarly, an unattached mind should attain yoga. Yoga means one thing joining another. When a jƒ´va joins the Supreme ƒÅtmƒÅ, it becomes yoga. Nirlepa-karma-yoga is that by which an unattached mind or a purified mind that has washed off all attachments, performs its ordained duties and gradually merges the jƒ´va with paramƒÅtmƒÅ.
