APPENDIX 1

*ƒ™≈õvara‚Äô*s Governance

yadƒÅ yadƒÅ hi dharmasya glƒÅnirbhavati bhƒÅrata
abhyutthƒÅnam adharmasya tadƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ s·πõjƒÅmyaham (BG 4.7)
(Whenever dharma decreases and adharma becomes more prominent, I take birth).

paritrƒÅ·πáƒÅya sƒÅdh≈´nƒÅ·πÉ vinƒÅ≈õƒÅya ca du·π£k·πõtƒÅ·πÉ
dharmasa·πÉ≈õthƒÅpanƒÅrthƒÅya sambavƒÅmi yuge yuge (BG 4.8)
(I am born again and again to protect the good, to destroy the evil and to establish dharma).

ananyƒÅ≈õcintayanto mƒÅ·πÉ ye janƒÅ·∏• paryupƒÅsate
te·π£ƒÅ·πÉ nityƒÅbhiyuktƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ yogak·π£ema·πÉ vahƒÅmyahm (BG 9.22)
(I will take complete care of those who think of me always with no other thought and worship me, and are fully occupied in me).

Anything that exists (sat) can be thought of in four ways -

  1. Parabrahma ‚Äî this is shapeless, changeless, still, and not subject to expansion. 2. ƒ™≈õvara or Jagadƒ´≈õvara ‚Äî is an entity related to Brahma that has shape, can change and has activity. It is the energy that rules the universe. 3. Prak·πõti ‚Äî this is the universe, with name, form and activity. It is under the control of ƒ™≈õvara. 4. Jƒ´va ‚Äî this is of the form of many living beings of the universe, the individual element of the universe.

Of the above four, the first one does not have any activity. Therefore, we will examine the relationship among the other three.

It is already said that ƒ™≈õvara is related to the universe in the same way as a king is related to a subject in a constitutional monarchy, such as England. Constitutional monarchy is a system of governance where the king and all his subjects are subservient to a known set of rules and arrangements. In such a system, just as common people agree to abide by a set of rules (the constitution, for instance), the king is also bound by the same rules. The king here is not at complete liberty to do as he pleases. Though it does not tie up his hands fully, it sets a limit to his freedom. His official duties are carried out within this limit, and he accepts it.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 9) Source: prekshaa]]

When they ascend the throne, England‚Äôs Kings (or Queens) take an oath in front of their subjects that they will follow, preserve, and protect the traditional methods and rules of governance. In India, the President who is in place of the King, takes this oath while swearing in ‚Äî ‚ÄúI will, to the best of my ability, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law.‚Äù (Art. 60) Thus, even the highest official of the state is subject to the arrangement accepted by the common people.

In VedƒÅnta, ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs sovereignty over the universe is similar. The system of governance accepted by the all the people is dharma. Dharma is the constitution of the kingdom. ƒ™≈õvara has taken the responsibility of sustaining and maintaining it. In the constitution of dharma, the important sentence is that ƒ™≈õvara is its protector. Thus, in the sustenance of dharma, he is not just an officer, but also the supreme authority. The constitution of dharma gives four responsibilities to ƒ™≈õvara.

  1. Protecting those who follow dharma 2. Punish those who harm dharma 3. Re-establishment of dharma, whenever the situation demands it 4. Protection of the distressed.

To perform the first two of the above tasks ‚Äî that is protection of dhƒÅrmics and punishing the adhƒÅrmics, ƒ™≈õvara has appointed other functionaries. They are deities such as Indra, Agni, Yama, Varu·πáa, and VƒÅyu. The deities of different karmas, deities of different directions, planets and stars are such officers. Generally, they protect the dharma of the world. They protect and encourage the dhƒÅrmics of the world, and punish adhƒÅrmics appropriately. ƒ™≈õvara, the overlord of the universe, supervises their work. Thus, ƒ™≈õvara does not have to get into the daily activities of the world. For day-to-day activities, dharma-≈õƒÅstra is the law. Various deities take the responsibility of maintaining law and order. ƒ™≈õvara is just the supervising head in relation to them. Ordinarily, ƒ™≈õvara himself is actionless.

Similarly, even in our current system of governance, the king is a neutral entity. Walter Bagehot, an English political scientist avers that the most excellent quality of an English king is his wise inaction. The fundamental concept here is that the King can do no wrong. This does not mean that there are no mistakes in polity. Mistakes may happen; their responsibility does not rest with the king but with the minister whose duty it is to advise the king on various political matters. That is, the minister becomes responsible for all political damage; this is the peculiarity of the English political setup. This is the meaning behind the phrase “responsible government”.

Thus, even though much of the day-to-day administration is the responsibility of the minister, the system leaves some special rights and offices ‚Äî prerogatives ‚Äî to the King. Inviting the parliament and dismissing it, taking up the reins of administration during conflict, pardoning those who have been condemned to severe punishment ‚Äì all these are the king‚Äôs prerogatives.

The same applies to the rule of ƒ™≈õvara. Among the above four dhƒÅrmic duties of a king, punishing the evil and protecting the good generally fall under the umbrella of the duties of various other deities of the world. The other two ‚Äî re-establishing dharma and being compassionate towards the weak ‚Äî are the prerogatives of ƒ™≈õvara. In this world and the otherworld, various deities of the karmas mete out rewards and punishments to humans for their deeds ‚Äì meritorious or otherwise.

However, the good may become weak and evil may become all-powerful at certain times. When evil reigns, the powers of the lesser deities will not be enough to sustain the world. Such times call for the direct descent of ƒ™≈õvara himself. The below lines proclaim this.

yadƒÅ yadƒÅ hi dharmasya glƒÅnirbhavati bhƒÅrata
abhyutthƒÅnam adharmasya tadƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ s·πõjƒÅmyaham (BG 4.7)

Keeping this in mind, Arjuna praised BhagavƒÅn as “≈õƒÅ≈õvata-dharma-goptƒÅ” (BG 11.18)

Terrible actions such as wars become necessary to re-establish sanƒÅtana dharma and to destroy evil in the world. ƒ™≈õvara arranges, harmonizes and arbitrates such occasions. Thus, protecting dharma by multifarious means falls in the field of the rightful duties of ƒ™≈õvara.

In the same way, giving succour to the distressed, showing affection to the miserable, the protection of those who are seeking it are all the charge of ƒ™≈õvara. In our world, in a political setup like that of England (even in India), it is the authority of the throne to discuss with ministers and grant amnesty if a citizen sentenced to harsh punishment repents and begs for it. In a similar way, it is ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs duty to show compassion to the devotees who are begging for protection, so that there is no laxity in the rule of dharma, and in a way that encourages dharma. This mercy of the divine cannot be construed as partiality and criticised as haughtiness. The divine is not merciless and unjust. Instead, it has kindness and affection that fosters dharma. This is why BhagavƒÅn is

gatirbhartƒÅ prabhu·∏• sƒÅk·π£ƒ´ nivƒÅsa·∏• ≈õara·πáa·πÉ suh·πõt (BG 9.18)
(The resource, provider, Lord, witness, abode, refuge and friend)

APPENDIX 2

Distinction between karma and akarma

karma·πáo hy-api boddhavyam boddhavyam ca vikarma·πáa·∏•
akarma·πáa≈õ-ca boddhavya·πÉ gahanƒÅ karma·πáo gati·∏• (BG 4.17)

The discussion on karma and akarma is so deep that it baffles even the wise, says BhagavƒÅn. What does that imply? Simply that the responsibility of a man is great and that it should translate into sad-asad-viveka – discernment between right and wrong, truth and falsehood. Thus it becomes one‚Äôs duty to use his viveka and independently undertake due consideration. We have to keep this in mind carefully.

Akarma is that action which is not ordained for us. Karma that is beyond our capability and propriety is akarma for us. BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs opinion is that this should be examined carefully.

akarma·πáa≈õca boddhavya·πÉ

The inference is that we should also know the karma that we should not perform. This is the subtle precept in the theory of karma.

A particular karma may be highly valued in the world; it may be recommended to us by society and the learned. It is left for us to decide whether it is right for us to perform it.

Going on a pilgrimage to Kedarnath and Badrinath has been believed to be a great virtuous accomplishment for aeons. But eighty or ninety- year old men and women should decide whether it is karma or akarma for them. Deciding it for them is difficult for others.

Suppose the head of a family is suffering from a terrible disease. Someone then instructs his wife to observe certain austerities for two weeks in a far off pilgrim centre to propitiate the divine and to gain longevity for her husband. Whether it is karma for her to stay with her husband during this time or travel to a far-off place is something she has to decide for herself.

Thus, karma for Rama may become akarma for Bhima. And something that is akarma for Shyama may be karma for Soma. Here, it is impossible to have one rule that holds for all circumstances. Therefore, individual responsibility plays a major role. No one can escape responsibility by disregarding viveka and arguing, “I did it because he told me,” “I trusted BhagavƒÅn and did it,” and “I believed my guru‚Äôs blessings and did it.” Devotees who follow the bhakti tradition should be careful about this. They usually say, “BhagavƒÅn will take care of everything; we do not have any responsibility”. These are not the words of those who have understood the distinction between karma and akarma.

BhagavƒÅn gives results. Humans put forth the effort. Is the effort right? Is it adequate? These are the questions that are in front of us. We should always have this sense of personal responsibility.

karma·πáy-akarma ya·∏• pa≈õyet akarma·πái ca karma ya·∏•
sa buddhimƒÅn manu·π£ye·π£u sa yukta·∏• k·πõtsna-karma-k·πõt (BG 4.18)

This means that we have to see karma in akarma and akarma in karma, and that this is the mark of a wise man. What is akarma? Akarma may mean two things ‚Äî

  1. Not performing any activity implying karmalopa or delinquency in one‚Äôs duty 2. Performing activities but remaining aloof from it, as though no activity is being performed ‚Äî karma-phala-virakti ‚Äî disinterested in the fruits (results) of karma.

The second meaning is implied here, not the first. BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs opinion is never to give up karma. This is made clear in many other verses ‚Äî

mƒÅ te sa·πÖgos-tv-akarma·πái (BG 2.47)

yaj√±a-dƒÅna-tapa·∏•-karma na tyƒÅjya·πÉ kƒÅryam-eva tat (BG 18.5)

Therefore, we have to read the meaning of this dictum as giving up the desire for the results of action, as given in (2). PƒÅpa does not affect one who performs all his various ordained, rightful and dhƒÅrmic duties, but does not worry about their results, as though he is not performing them at all. His karma does not shackle him.

j√±ƒÅnƒÅgni·∏• sarva-karmƒÅ·πái bhasmasƒÅt kurute tathƒÅ (BG 4.37)

ƒÅtmavanta·πÉ na karmƒÅ·πái nibadhnanti dhana√±jaya (BG 4.41)

karma·πáy-akarma ya·∏• pa≈õyet akarma·πái ca karma ya·∏• (BG 4.18)

These are some of the greatest and most important words in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Akarma may mean two things, therefore we have to be careful in grasping the meaning.

In ‚ÄúmƒÅ te sa·πÖgos-tv-akarma·πái,‚Äù akarma means giving up karma entirely. This is not right. Another akarma ‚Äî where desire for the fruit of the karma is given up ‚Äî is implied.

“karma·πáy-akarma” means that one has to perform his duties, but remain aloof as though he is not doing anything, meaning that he should remain neutral towards the good or bad consequences of his actions. He should work hard, but not feel that he is tired, or that he did not get to taste the sweet fruit of his labour.

‚ÄúAkarma·πái ca karma‚Äù means that one has to take a giving-up attitude towards the results of action. This is interesting. Doing one‚Äôs duties is karma, akarma namely giving up even the thought of its results is itself another karma.

Desire to perform karma, but disinterestedness in its results ‚Äî that, then, is the prescription. Akarma in the form of giving up the desire for results while performing ordained karma, karma in the form of disinterestedness while giving up the results of karma.

While performing karma, giving up the ownership and desire for the results becomes akarma. While giving up such desire (which is akarma), the act of giving up itself becomes karma. Thus, ‚Äúkarma·πáy-akarma‚Äù and ‚Äúakarma·πái ca karma.‚Äù

A cook in a hotel cooks food for customers, that is his karma. He does not worry about who is eating the food prepared by him. That is akarma. A customer who visits the hotel eats the food. That is his karma. It is akarma for him to inquire about the person who cooked the food. Thus, akarma within karma and karma within akarma ‚Äî perform duties diligently but be unconcerned about the results ‚Äî this is the principle.

APPENDIX 3

Rains, Crops and Deities

annƒÅd-bhavanti bh≈´tƒÅni parjanyƒÅd-anna-sambhava·∏•
yaj√±ƒÅd-bhavati parjanyo yaj√±a·∏• karma-samudbhava·∏• (BG 3.14)

The divinities of the world do not provide rains and crops only to those who perform yaj√±as. They are generous. If one propitiates them, they become helpful to the entire mankind. If there is even one virtuous man in the village, the entire village is benefited by the results of his good deeds.

The implication of this teaching is that one has to enjoy the benefit obtained by the performance of yaj√±a by sharing it with everyone, even though he has earned it alone. What does it really mean? Even though a deity gives some bounty as a boon to someone who has performed various virtuous actions, even others have the right to partake of it. The performer of yaj√±a is not the lone beneficiary of the received boon. Everyone who is with him would have helped him in some or the other way, however small or big. If not in a positive, encouraging way, they would at least have helped him negatively by not harming the venture, by not creating obstacles in his way! Therefore, they also have the right to enjoy the boon received in a yaj√±a.

Thus, the specious argument whether a non-performer of a yaj√±a obtains its benefits or not, falls flat. There must be at least some virtuous people. A part of the fruits of their virtuous actions are obtained by everyone ‚Äî this shows the greatness of virtuous deeds. The good performed by one brings welfare to everyone.

andu nara·πÖgƒï yuddhamukhado·∏ª paratattva·πÉ pe·∏ªdu lokakƒÅ·πÉ
bandapƒïnannƒïyoddhatara du·π£·π≠ara da·πá·∏çisi sƒÅdhuv·πõndakƒÅ-
nandavanittu ≈õƒÅ≈õvatada dharmava sa·πÉsthitagaivenƒï·πÉda go-
vindanƒï nƒ´nada·πÉ marƒïte-yenadaninnumadekƒï bƒÅre bƒ´radi·πÉ?
O Govinda, once upon a time, at the commencement of a fight,
You instructed Nara on the Supreme Principle, and proclaimed
That you will appear in this world to punish the evil,
To gladden the good, and establish dharma.
Have you forgotten that promise?
Why do not you appear now with all your might?

The Essence

Having performed karma, the j√±ƒÅnƒ´ (the knower) gives up its result.

When might a planter of a coconut palm see its fruit? Whoever plants the tree is different from one who takes care of it. Yet another is he who enjoys its fruits. The planter plants the tree for the good of the people. Just as the seed of pƒÅpa is in one‚Äôs nature, so is the seed of pu·πáya. The Gƒ´tƒÅ‚Äôs message is to amplify this virtuous aspect.

Internal equanimity and an external sense of distinction are the two parts of the maxim for world welfare. The care a mother provides at home depends on the age and health of her children. If she insists upon external equality and gives food meant for a sixteen-year old to a sixteen-month old, it would not cause well-being but quite the opposite of it. Those politicians who shout, ‚ÄúEquality, Equality‚Äù till their throats go hoarse would do well to remember that there is an appropriate place for the principle of distinction in our lives.

Chapter 5 / Section 6

Yoga of Harmony of Action and Wisdom (Karma-j√±ƒÅna-sƒÅmarasya-yoga) or Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa-yoga

This is a small chapter but distills the essence of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. It deals mainly with the following five topics ‚Äì

  1. Synergy between steadfastness in action and steadfastness in knowledge 2. The state of mind needed for action 3. The inactivity of the Self 4. Practising the presence of the Self everywhere 5. A yogi‚Äôs adherence to welfare of the world

Arjuna saw an inconsistency in BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs words in the fourth chapter. ‚ÄúK·πõ·π£·πáa, you once extolled the renunciation of action. Then you praised the yoga of action. (This is an indication of mutual opposition between yoga and renunciation).

≈õreyƒÅn dravya-mayƒÅd-yaj√±ƒÅt-j√±ƒÅna-yaj√±a·∏• parantapa
sarva·πÉ karmƒÅkhila·πÉ pƒÅrtha j√±ƒÅne parisamƒÅpyate (BG 4.33)
(More excellent than the yaj√±a of material objects is the yaj√±a of knowledge. All this action, O PƒÅrtha, finds fulfillment in knowledge)

You said on one occasion, ‚ÄúAll action concludes in the knowledge of the Self. On another occasion, you said,

tasmƒÅd-aj√±ƒÅna-sambh≈´ta·πÉ h·πõtstha·πÉ j√±ƒÅnƒÅsinƒÅtmana·∏•
chittvaina·πÉ sa·πÉ≈õaya·πÉ yogam-ƒÅti·π£·π≠hotti·π£·π≠ha bhƒÅrata (BG 4.42)
(Therefore, having rent asunder the doubt arisen out of ignorance with the sword of knowledge, attain yoga, O BhƒÅrata)

This was said earlier ‚Äì ‚ÄúBe steady in the yoga of action; arise for battle!‚Äù

Both of these are your own statements. What is your conclusion in this matter? If the knowledge of reality is the supreme benefit of action and actions have to be performed to attain this knowledge, is it not established that there is no need for action after attaining knowledge? In other words, renunciates do not have to perform any action, right? Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa or renunciation is without karma or action. Karma-yoga has karma in it. So which one is greater ‚Äì karma or sa·πÉnyƒÅsa?‚Äù This was the question to which the fifth chapter proceeded as an answer.

sa·πÉnyƒÅsa·∏• karma-yoga≈õ-ca ni·∏•≈õreyasakarƒÅvubhau
tayostu karma-sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒÅt-karma-yogo vi≈õi·π£yate (BG 5.2)
(Both karma-yoga and sa·πÉnyƒÅsa yield supreme welfare. Of them, however, the yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action)

This was BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs answer: ‚ÄúBoth the yoga of renunciation and the yoga of action yield the best of benefits. However, the yoga of action is special.‚Äù

Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is renunciation or giving up. Yoga is joining one object to another. What does it mean to give up action? What does the ‚Äújoining‚Äù or the ‚Äúyoga‚Äù of giving up mean? It is clear from the word-meanings that both do not refer to the same thing. BhagavƒÅn clarifies that sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is different from yoga not just by sound, but even by meaning ‚Äì ‚Äúkarma-yogo vi≈õi·π£yate‚Äù. The uniqueness of karma-yoga is that it is a prerequisite to sƒÅ·πÖkhya or the knowledge of reality, which is the ultimate goal of sa·πÉnyƒÅsa as well.

sa·πÉnyƒÅsas-tu mahƒÅbƒÅho du·∏•kham-ƒÅptum-ayogata·∏•
yoga-yukto munir-brahma na cire·πáƒÅdhigacchati (BG 5.6)

Here yoga refers to karma-yoga. Without karma-yoga, it is nigh impossible to attain renunciation. O strong-armed one! With karma-yoga, however, it will not take long for the seeker to attain the knowledge of Brahman.

Who is a Sa·πÉnyƒÅsin?

Are all those who wear saffron robes, shave their heads, and give up rituals sa·πÉnyƒÅsins? It has been said earlier (3.6) that it is not so. If one renounces out of haste, not only does one become ineligible to perform action but will also not automatically qualify for knowledge.

na karma·πáƒÅm-anƒÅrambhƒÅn-nai·π£karmya·πÉ puru·π£o‚Äô≈õnute
na ca sa·πÉnyasanƒÅd-eva siddhi·πÉ samadhigacchati (BG 3.4)

The same is repeated later as well.

‚Ä¶.sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´‚Ä¶.na niragnirna cƒÅkriya·∏•
(One does not become a sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´ just by giving up agnihotra and other rituals).

The characteristic of a true sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´ is this

j√±eya·∏• sa nitya-sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´ yo na dve·π£·π≠i na kƒÅ≈àk·π£ati (BG 5.3)

‚ÄúHe, who neither hates nor desires, is known always as a sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´‚Äù. The feeling of indifference that is implied in the phrase ‚Äì ‚Äúna dve·π£·π≠i na kƒÅ≈àk·π£ati‚Äô‚Äô is not one of mere co-existence. Consider a couple of bus or train passengers who do not know each other. Their mutual co-existence is indicative of ‚Äúna dve·π£·π≠i na kƒÅ≈àk·π£ati‚Äù ‚Äì a negative feeling. BhagavƒÅn shows how to add a positive dimension to it of the root form ‚Äòas.‚Äô

labhante brahma-nirvƒÅ·πáam-·πõ·π£aya·∏• k·π£ƒ´·πáa-kalma·π£ƒÅ·∏•
chinna-dvaidhƒÅ yatƒÅtmƒÅna·∏• sarva-bh≈´ta-hite ratƒÅ·∏• (BG 5.25)

The ·πõ·π£is, being cleansed of all impurities, having extinguished all doubts, and endowed with definite knowledge, are engaged in the welfare of all beings.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J√±ƒÅna (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The phrase hita-nirata (engaged in welfare) does not involve merely uttering homilies. It means those who internally resolve to act towards universal welfare and ensure that those resolutions are acted upon externally. It is thus not necessary for a sa·πÉnyƒÅsin to give up activity that yields in the well-being of the world. But such activities have to be performed with an extraordinary mindset. The activity referred to here is interacting with the world ‚Äì taking from the world and giving back to it. It is but natural for mental modifications such as desire and anger and greed and delusion to creep in during such activities. The one who performs activities free of these mental agitations is the true sa·πÉnyƒÅsin.

It is important to keenly examine the words used in this verse. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsins are chinna-dvaidhƒÅ, they whose dvaidhƒÅ or doubt is torn asunder. When asked, ‚ÄúDoes the divine exist?‚Äù, a few answer in the words of a famous agnostic [Joseph Ernest Renan] ‚Äì ‚ÄúO God, (if there is a God), save my soul (if I have a soul).‚Äù This is doubt. There is no desire to believe but no courage to give up belief as well. This dvaidhƒ´bhƒÅva (feeling of doubt) is like a pendulum oscillating between belief and disbelief. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsins are devoid of these feelings of uncertainty. What answer did Ramakrishna Paramahamsa give Swami Vivekananda in his pre-monastic state when asked if God existed? ‚ÄúYes‚Äù. When again asked, ‚ÄúCan you show me‚Äù?, the Paramahamsa replied, ‚ÄúYes, certainly!‚Äù Sa·πÉnyƒÅsins thus possess definite knowledge. Moreover, they are ‚ÄòyatƒÅtmƒÅna·∏•‚Äô - those who have their minds under control. Will not arrogance arise with definite knowledge? Sa·πÉnyƒÅsins do not just have control over themselves but are also sarvabh≈´tahite ratƒÅ·∏• (engaged in the welfare of all beings). They do not sit idle twiddling their thumbs but strive for the welfare of all. One should take note of the word hita (welfare) here. The word sukha (pleasure) could have been used, but it was not. All that is pleasing does not result in well-being. The purport is to engage in activities that ultimately result in well-being.

Sarva-bh≈´tƒÅtma-bh≈´tatva (Being the Self of all Beings)

Sa·πÉnyƒÅsins engage in action for the welfare of the world. They are not bound by it because they are without ego and are indifferent to opposites such as pleasure and pain.

yogayukto vi≈õuddhƒÅtmƒÅ vijitƒÅtmƒÅ jitendriya·∏•
sarvabh≈´tƒÅtmabh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ kurvannapi na lipyate (BG 5.7)

His self is the Self of all beings. He considers the sorrow and happiness of all beings as his own. Such a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ desires for the rest of the world the same contentment that he pursues. The jƒ´va must be elevated. Remember the pleasure we get when we lazily stretch our limbs. That pleasure does not necessarily indicate hita (well-being). However, the sound sleep that we get after a day‚Äôs hard work is not just sukha (pleasure) but also indicates hita (well-being). The work of uplifting a jƒ´va is hita. The sa·πÉnyƒÅsin experiences the Self of all beings within himself. Who can be a rival or enemy to him who is all? The Self is uniform and is everywhere. Therefore there is no room for partiality, affection or for envy and infatuation. But how does this ‚Äúbeing the Self of all beings‚Äù come to our mind? How can our intellect understand it? How can we experience it every moment? Experience is greater than knowledge. Our contemplation should be such that we should become one with the object of our contemplation. The eight siddhis[a·πáimƒÅ, laghimƒÅ, mahimƒÅ, garimƒÅ, prƒÅpti, prƒÅkƒÅmya, ƒ´≈õitva, and va≈õitva] or attainments such as a·πáimƒÅ (the ability to become atomic in size) are achievable by means of ha·π≠ha-yoga. But this state of sarva-bh≈´tƒÅtma-bh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ (being the Self of all beings) is beyond all such siddhis and is possible only through much refinement.

Asa·πÖgakarma (Action without Attachment)

kƒÅyena manasƒÅ buddhyƒÅ kevalairindriyairapi
yogina·∏• karma kurvanti sa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅtma≈õuddhaye (BG 5.11)

Yogis perform action through their body, mind, intellect, the sensory and motor organs. How? ‚ÄúSa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ‚Äù (by giving up attachment). Two points are important here ‚Äì

  1. If an action has to be performed well, the performer has to be a j√±ƒÅnƒ´. 2. All the faculties of knowledge and action must unite during an action.

It is only then that the body becomes capable. Not even a single organ must slacken. All organs must be effective, attentive, and firm. It was therefore that ≈örƒ´-VidyƒÅra·πáya said,

j√±ƒÅninƒÅ caritu·πÉ ≈õakya·πÉ samyagrƒÅjyƒÅdilaukikam
‚ÄîPa√±cada≈õƒ´ 9.114
(It is possible for a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ to effectively discharge worldly actions such as administering a kingdom).

As the knower of the Self is not selfish, all the actions he performs are effective. Why do yogis act? ‚ÄúƒÄtma≈õuddhaye‚Äù ‚Äì for the purification of the mind. The same idea is conveyed in the tenth verse.

brahma·πáyƒÅdhƒÅya karmƒÅ·πái sa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ karoti ya·∏•
lipyate na sa pƒÅpena padmapatramivƒÅmbhasƒÅ (BG 5.10)

Action must be performed, but should be offered to Brahma. There must be no expectations such as ‚Äì ‚ÄúThis work will yield me profit or bring me fame.‚Äù Demerit will not bind him who has no such expectations and calculations during action. It might be asked, ‚ÄúAny activity is naturally associated with selfishness. How could that not affect a j√±ƒÅnƒ´?‚Äù The answer is ‚ÄúpadmapatramivƒÅmbhasƒÅ‚Äù (like a lotus leaf in water). A cloth gets wet when dipped in water. Even though a lotus leaf originates, sustains itself, and falls away in water, moisture never sticks to it. A j√±ƒÅnƒ´ lives in the world just like the lotus leaf in water. He participates in all of its pleasures and sorrows but is internally unchanged.

yo‚Äônta·∏•sukho‚ÄôntarƒÅrƒÅmas-tathƒÅntarjyotireva ya·∏•
sa yogƒ´ brahmairvƒÅ·πáa·πÉ brahmabh≈´to‚Äôdhigacchati (BG 5.24)

A j√±ƒÅnƒ´ resolves thus ‚Äì ‚ÄúPrak·πõti causes everything. It does not affect me.‚Äù

The poet Lucretius observed ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe bystander on the sea-shore is happy when he sees fishermen struggle to catch fish. On the one hand, he is entertained by witnessing their adventures. On the other, he is relieved that he is not undergoing that hardship.‚Äù The j√±ƒÅnƒ´, much like this bystander, witnesses the actions of the world without any anxiety.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J√±ƒÅna (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

The Steadfastness in Yoga of a J√±ƒÅnƒ´

yukta·∏• karmaphala·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ ≈õƒÅntimƒÅpnoti nai·π£·π≠hikƒ´m
ayukta·∏• kƒÅmakƒÅre·πáa phale sakto nibadhyate (BG 5.12)

The word ‚Äúyukta‚Äù here means yoked or harnessed to yoga or being steadfast in yoga. A j√±ƒÅnƒ´, having performed action, gives up its fruit. We realise quite soon that it is not easy to do so. But it is not that rare either. When can a planter of a coconut palm see its fruit? The planter of the tree is different from the caretaker who is again other than the enjoyer of the fruit. The planter plants the tree for the good of the people. Just as the seed of pƒÅpa is in our nature, the seed of pu·πáya too is within us. The intent of the Gƒ´tƒÅ is in amplifying this tendency for good in us. The goodness within us must be expanded. The one who does that obtains peace from being steadfast (‚Äú≈õƒÅntimƒÅpnoti nai·π£·π≠hikƒ´m‚Äù). ‚ÄúNai·π£·π≠hikƒ´m‚Äù refers to that which results from ni·π£·π≠hƒÅ (being established in something). Just as it is said elsewhere ‚Äì

tanni·π£·π≠hasya mok·π£opade≈õƒÅt
‚ÄîBrahma-s≈´tra 1.1.7
(Mok·π£a or final liberation is declared for one who is established in It).

Tranquillity results from being fully established in something. One has to be devoted or be established in at least one thing. Partial trust in ƒÄyurveda, and believing a little in Unani or allopathy is how our belief is usually spread across different things. The one who is not established in yoga ‚ÄúkƒÅmakƒÅre·πáa phale sakto nibadhyate‚Äù is bound because he is attached to the fruit of acting according to his desire. Such a person acts differently in every moment according to his whims. ‚ÄòKƒÅmakƒÅra‚Äô (acting according to one‚Äôs whims) is the opposite of being established in yoga. That indeed is deviating from the right path. One who acts according to his caprices cannot attain tranquillity. His interest is only in the fruit of the moment. His ‚Äòni·π£·π≠hƒÅ‚Äô or steadiness is in a flux and he thus attains no peace. He is then ‚Äònibadhyate‚Äô ‚Äì bound by his actions.

The Meaning of the Word Karma

The word ‚Äòkarma‚Äô has multiple meanings. There is no reason to single out sat-karma (good karma) here. The phrase ‚Äúbrahma·πáyƒÅdhƒÅya‚Äù (surrendering in Brahma) is used here. There can be no ‚Äúdu·π£karma‚Äù (bad karma) during the remembrance of Brahma. Good karma can be of two kinds ‚Äì scriptural or ≈õƒÅstrƒ´ya works and worldly works. ≈öƒÅstrƒ´ya works pertain to those rituals such as yaj√±as and yƒÅgas that are prescribed in the ≈õruti or sm·πõti. Both ≈õƒÅstrƒ´ya and worldly actions are referred to by the word karma. All of this karma has to be surrendered to Brahma. The remembrance of Brahma must pervade all these works. There must be no trace of personal desire. The one who does that - lipyate na sa pƒÅpena - is not tainted by demerit. Demerit accrues in the presence of ego. Therefore ‚Äúsa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ‚Äù (abandoning attachment) has been used to qualify the performance of action - specifically, abandoning attachment to ‚Äòme‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô. Who then is responsible for the action? ‚ÄúBrahma·πái ƒÅdhƒÅya‚Äù ‚Äì the j√±ƒÅnƒ´ delegates all responsibility to BrahmƒÅ.

The same is expressed in the statement ‚Äì ‚Äúyukta·∏• karmaphala·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ‚Äù (the one in Yoga having given up the fruit of action). Here ‚Äúayukta·∏•‚Äù means the one who has not yoked his mind to BhagavƒÅn. ‚ÄòKƒÅmakƒÅre·πáa‚Äô ‚Äì the one who acts capriciously. Such a person is phale sakta·∏• ‚Äì interested in the result. He is nibadhyate ‚Äì bound. What else but bondage can happen to such a person?

Internal Detachment

The thought continues here.

sarvakarmƒÅ·πái manasƒÅ sa·πÉnyasyƒÅste sukha·πÉ va≈õƒ´
navadvƒÅre pure dehƒ´ naiva kurvanna kƒÅrayan (BG 5.13)

By va≈õƒ´ is meant one who has control over himself. Such a person is happy. Why? ‚ÄúsarvakarmƒÅ·πái manasƒÅ sa·πÉnyasya‚Äù ‚Äì having mentally given up all actions. Works have to be performed externally but they have to be renounced internally. This indeed is the essence of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. However, such renunciation should not result in any lapse in the performance of external action. The non-attachment referred to here is internal. BhagavƒÅn says that it is possible to renounce actions internally without any impact on external action.

We have experienced on occasion that while action happens externally there is no equivalent internal impact. The change of the yaj√±opavƒ´ta (sacred thread) is such an activity for many of us. During the commencement of a meal, activities such as pari·π£ecana (purifying food by sprinkling water around one‚Äôs food) are similar in nature. Though it is an external activity, it is quite rare for the mind to be involved in such activities. Cyclists routinely putting their feet to pedal is an external activity that, however, does not touch the mind. We should perform action without experiencing mental anguish. We have to practise internal detachment. TƒÅ·π≠hastya (detachment) refers to standing on the shore. The one on the shore does not get wet. Neither is he concerned with who is bathing or drowning in the waters. Even if he watches it, he has no selfish interest in those. Similarly, external actions do not impact a j√±ƒÅnƒ´.

Man should divide himself into two ‚Äì the doer and the seer. He should think, ‚ÄúI am the witness. The doer is someone else.‚Äù There are no mental disturbances then. Ego & selfish desires cause mental disturbances.

naiva ki·πÉcitkaromƒ´ti yukto manyeta tattvavit
pa≈õya√± ≈õru·πávan sp·πõ≈õa√±-jighrann- a≈õnan-gacchan svapan ≈õvasan (BG 5.8)
pralapan-vis·πõjan-g·πõh·πáann-unmi·π£an-nimi·π£annapi
indriyƒÅ·πáƒ´ndriyƒÅrthe·π£u vartanta iti dhƒÅrayan (BG 5.9)

The knower of reality believes that he is not doing anything; but he watches; he listens; he touches various objects; smells different things; walks about, eats, sleeps; attends calls of nature, blinks his eyes and yet does not feel that he is doing anything. But all of these are not Vedic rituals! Are not all of these worldly activities? IndriyƒÅ·πáƒ´ndriyƒÅrthe·π£u ‚Äì sensory organs indulge in what they desire. His mind is not those sense organs. Thinking thus, he surrenders his actions to Brahma (brahma·πáyƒÅdhƒÅya). He resolves in his mind that he does not do anything.

The Behaviour of the Gu·πáas

But aren‚Äôt all of these world activities happening? Who then is performing all these? We saw it in the third chapter.

tattvavittu mahƒÅbƒÅho gu·πáakarmavibhƒÅgayo·∏•
gu·πáƒÅ gu·πáe·π£u vartanta iti matvƒÅ na sajjate (BG 3.28)

The gu·πáas of the organs engage in the gu·πáas of the objects. The sensory organs engage in the objects of the external world. The same principle is stated more extensively in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad 14.6.2.

jihvƒÅ vai graha·∏•‡•§ sa rasenƒÅtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´to jihvayƒÅ hi rasƒÅnvijƒÅnƒÅti ‡•§
vƒÅgvai graha·∏•‡•§ sa nƒÅmnƒÅ‚Äôtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´to vƒÅcƒÅ hi nƒÅmƒÅnyabhivadati ‡•§
cak·π£urvai graha·∏•‡•§ sa r≈´pe·πáƒÅtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´ta≈õcak·π£u·π£ƒÅ hi r≈´pƒÅ·πái pa≈õyati ‡•§
≈õrotra·πÉ vai graha·∏•‡•§ sa ≈õabdenƒÅtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´ta·∏• ≈õrotre·πáa hi ≈õabdƒÅ√±ch·πõ·πáoti ‡•§
mano vai graha·∏•‡•§ sa kƒÅmenƒÅtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´to manasƒÅ hi kƒÅmƒÅnkƒÅmayate ‡•§

tvagvai graha·∏•‡•§ sa spar≈õenƒÅtigrahe·πáa g·πõhƒ´tastvacƒÅ hi spar≈õƒÅnvedayata itya·π£·π≠au grahƒÅ‚Äôa·π£·π≠ƒÅvatigrahƒÅ·∏•‡•§

The Vedic seers divided the world into grahas and atigrahas. Whatever grasps is known as a graha and whatever is grasped is known as an atigraha. The tongue is a graha; taste is an atigraha. The ear is a graha; sound, music etc. are atigrahas. The ear, eye, and even the mind that controls these are all classified as grahas. All of them captured by kƒÅma (desire) that is an atigraha. All sense organs are grahas. The sensations of taste, smell etc., that attract these grahas are atigrahas. Thus the categories graha and atigraha naturally exist in the world, as the products of the primordial prak·πõti. Prak·πõti is Parabrahma‚Äôs power of action. Prak·πõti cannot exist without Brahma. These categories of graha & atigraha are the products of prak·πõti, the power of Brahma. These two engage as well as excite each other. This is our life. The lives of all beings can be summed up as harmony and disharmony between the graha and atigraha. This is our perennial struggle.

The ActionlessƒÄtmƒÅ

The whole of creation is thus created from Brahma‚Äôs power, Brahma‚Äôs lƒ´lƒÅ. It is enjoying ƒÅnanda (bliss) causing all these actions. Why do we call it ƒÅnanda? ƒÄnanda is the nature of Brahma. Difficulty or pain is not in its nature. Even when we experience distress or sorrow, there is definitely an aspect of its lƒ´lƒÅ in them. To the divine, our laughter and tears are like the laughter and tears of children to adults. Therefore in the RudrƒÅdhyƒÅya the Supreme is praised as ‚Äúnama ƒÅkkhidate ca prakkhidate ca‚Äù (Salutations to the one who causes minor as well as major troubles).

na kart·πõtva·πÉ na karmƒÅ·πái lokasya s·πõjati prabhu·∏•
na karmaphalasa·πÉyoga·πÉ svabhƒÅvastu pravartate (BG 5.14)

It cannot be said that since ƒ™≈õvara has created this world, it is better to let him experience it. None of these affect ƒ™≈õvara because he is ƒ™≈õvara (the supreme ruler). The engagements of the world do not affect the Self (ƒÅtmƒÅ) who is the indweller of the jƒ´va, as the former is an aspect of ƒ™≈õvara. However, they affect the jƒ´va which is the embodied Self. Even the jƒ´va is the same as the Self, but enveloped by a shroud. The jƒ´va cries out, ‚ÄúMy shroud is heavy! It‚Äôs heavy!‚Äù When experiencing the ‚Äòheaviness‚Äô of the shroud, the Self is known as the jƒ´va. But it becomes light when a knower casts off the covering shroud. This state of the jƒ´va is natural. However, the Self is beyond Nature. ƒ™≈õvara is neither the doer of worldly activities nor is he the one who established this system of causality. But all fundamental components and energies of these universal laws are but minor aspects of his limitless power. It is their actions that constitute worldly events. The relationship between action and their results does not belong to ƒ™≈õvara. Doership, enjoyership, creatorship, and cause ‚Äì are all in the realm of Prak·πõti (Primordial Nature). It is prak·πõti that makes jƒ´vas dependent upon her to perform their actions. The state of the jƒ´va is something that can be remedied; it is not permanent. Mok·π£a is release from the state of the jƒ´va. When something that is not the Self envelops the Self, it becomes a jƒ´va. The non-Self is subject to destruction. It can be removed. We saw in the second chapter:

vƒÅsƒÅ·πÉsi jƒ´r·πáƒÅni yathƒÅ vihƒÅya
navƒÅni g·πõh·πáƒÅti naro‚ÄôparƒÅ·πái
tathƒÅ ≈õarƒ´rƒÅ·πái vihƒÅya jƒ´r·πáƒÅni
anyƒÅni sa·πÉyƒÅti navƒÅni dehƒ´ (BG 2.22)

Thus, the non-Self can be cast off. The Self, that is the internal sentience of the jƒ´va, has to be released from this shell of the non-Self. The true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ is revealed when this shell is removed. It is thus that BhagavƒÅn said:

navadvƒÅre pure dehƒ´ naiva kurvanna kƒÅrayan (BG 5.13)

The two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, the mouth, the two nether orifices - together constitute the nine gates (navadvƒÅra). Our body is the city with these nine gates. The lord of the city is seated inside these gates. He does not do anything and is much like the constitutional monarch who has delegated all work to ministers and officials. They conduct all the activities under his rule.

The Extent of Arjuna‚Äôs Question

We might think that the topic of this chapter is far removed from Arjuna‚Äôs question. Arjuna‚Äôs question was whether he should fight or not. In the guise of answering his question, BhagavƒÅn instructed him on various topics such as what Prak·πõti is, what Brahma is, what it means to perform action, who the doer is and who the enjoyer is. We feel that this is a digression. When asked about war, BhagavƒÅn talked about the Self and non-Self. How are these even related? The reply is that this particular problem can only be dealt with in this way. There is no foundation other than the discernment between the Self and the non-Self to effectively determine what dharma and adharma are. Arjuna‚Äôs question was this ‚Äì ‚ÄúIs this dharma or adharma? I think this is adharma.‚Äù Krishna replied that this was dharma. On what basis could this question have been settled? What is the testimony? The discernment between the Self and the non-Self is the sole testimony. Arjuna somehow asked this question. But he did not realise the root of this query and how far it reached. His query came in the heat of the discussion. The knowledge of the Self is needed to decide what duty is and is not. We have to then accept the verdict of those who are able to discern between the Self and the non-Self.

The Cessation of Ignorance

J√±ƒÅna or knowledge is not something extraneous to a jƒ´va but intrinsic to it. The nature of the Self is three-fold ‚Äì Existence, Knowledge, and Bliss (sat, cit, ƒÅnanda respectively). This cit is the seed of knowledge. Cit is knowledge, the process of comprehension, and the action that is inspired. All of these are latent in the jƒ´va from time immemorial. Ignorance masks this knowledge like a wicker-basket (masks a lamp). Because of this, we see the wicker basket and not Brahma.

aj√±ƒÅnenƒÅv·πõta·πÉ j√±ƒÅna·πÉ tena muhyanti jantava·∏• (BG 5.15)

When the cover of ignorance is removed, knowledge arises spontaneously. That is why BhagavƒÅn asks Arjuna to conquer Anger and Desire. The rest happens on its own.

dh≈´menƒÅvriyate vahnir-yathƒÅdar≈õo malena ca
yatholbenƒÅv·πõto garbhas-tathƒÅ tenedamƒÅv·πõtam (BG 3.38)

Just as smoke covers burning coal, just as dirt covers a mirror does the natural state of ignorance conceal knowledge. How can we get rid of this ignorance? By practising the presence of the Self (ƒÅtma-samak·π£atƒÅ), which is also the same as practising the presence of the divine.

Samak·π£atƒÅ refers to something in front of our eyes - presence. We have to experience the presence of the divine by practising it.

Those that have attained the practice of the presence of the Self have been described thus.

tadbuddhayas-tadƒÅtmƒÅnas-tanni·π£·π≠hƒÅs-tatparƒÅya·πáƒÅ·∏•
gacchanty-apunarƒÅv·πõtti·πÉ j√±ƒÅnanirdh≈´takalma·π£ƒÅ·∏• (BG 5.17)

Have we experienced divine presence or not? We can find this out for ourselves. When someone derided as vile or cheap by society comes and sits next to us, what expression does our face take? What does our mind tell us when a person who has wronged us sits next to us? How do we behave when a person of power or fame moves near us? Our mind values all these external distinctions such as status, rank, and prestige. But on the other hand, if all of these persons ‚Äì who are non-different from the Self ‚Äì are viewed with the same measure of self-love, we would be practising equality.

All differences must be eschewed. The mind is full of such differences. Whoever realises the presence of the divine has no such differences.

vidyƒÅvinayasa·πÉpanne brƒÅhma·πáe gavi hastini
≈õuni caiva ≈õvapƒÅke ca pa·πá·∏çitƒÅ·∏• samadar≈õina·∏• (BG 5.18)
(The knowers of the Self view with equanimity a Brahmin endowed with learning and humility, a cow, an elephant, a dog and him who eats dog flesh.)

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J√±ƒÅna (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

The Vision of Equality (Sama-dar≈õana)

This is a famous ≈õloka. What does ‚Äì sama-dar≈õana - the vision of equality mean? Does equality imply that both the elephant and the cow be offered the same food? The word ‚Äúequal‚Äù is one of the most misused words of our times. Politicians use this word ad nauseam. It is not uncommon for this word to be used without knowing its actual meaning or with an erroneous understanding. Equality is giving to each being what is best for it. A feast for a Brahmaa and grass for the cow ‚Äì showing the same love across beings is viewing all equally. Teachers might rebuke a student and reward another with a sweet. This too is equality from the perspective of the students‚Äô needs and abilities.

The vision of equality requires two things ‚Äì the seer and the seen. The well-being of the seen has to result from the seer‚Äôs vision of equality. The vision of equality has to conclude in a consideration of the welfare of the seen. A uniform perspective of benefiting all is the vision of equality. This instruction pertains to the sameness of love for all. The same love for all beings finds different expressions based on the needs of its recipients.

What is the relation of equality to this instruction about knowledge? The mark of true knowledge is seeing all with equanimity. The chief characteristic of the seer of the Self is equanimity. He does not hate anybody and has the same love for all. He constantly thinks about the well-being of all, not just about the pleasure of a few. In spiritual matters, well-being is more important than pleasure. It is all fine to help others find pleasure as long as it is not in opposition to their eventual well-being. Pleasure and well-being need to be separated out.

Knowledge and humility together are described as the characteristics of a BrƒÅhma·πáa. Seldom are these fine qualities seen together. There are many knowledgeable people but not all of them are humble. Similarly, not all humble persons are scholars. It is rare for knowledge and humility to combine. Arrogance and egoism have to be rooted out from us. The first words of ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara‚Äôs prayer are ‚Äì

avinayam apanaya vi·π£·πáo
‚Äî·π¢a·π≠padƒ´-stotram
(O Vi·π£·πáu, take away arrogance)

Humility is ‚ÄúamƒÅnitvam-adambhitvam‚Äù (not being arrogant, not being deceitful). Humility is something of a rare quality in a democracy. A humble person gets nothing there. The one desirous of thriving in a democracy has to constantly be a rabble rouser. The squeaky wheel gets the grease. The one without a voice suits a ruined well. If one desirous of living a good life waits for recognition and an invitation from others, he might as well wait forever. Even when nobody wants to listen, hustlers rush forward to claim, ‚ÄúHear me. Don‚Äôt listen to others. I‚Äôm the only one who can redeem the country; others will despoil it. I‚Äôm your only confidante. All others are your enemies. I‚Äôm the only truthful one; others are cheats,‚Äù and manage to get good positions. Where is the encouragement for humility in such an environment? The Gƒ´tƒÅ quoted by politicians and RƒÅva·πáa‚Äôs renunciation are the same.

Equanimity is stated in another way.

ihaiva tairjita·∏• sargo ye·π£ƒÅ·πÉ sƒÅmye sthita·πÉ mana·∏•
nirdo·π£a·πÉ hi sama·πÉ brahma tasmƒÅd brahma·πái te sthitƒÅ·∏• (BG 5.19)

They, whose minds are steadfast in the experience of Brahma that is uniform everywhere, obtain mok·π£a (or liberation) ihaiva (in this world only). The statement that Brahma is uniform everywhere just means that it is impartial. Not that it appears the same to everybody. Just as the sky is uniform everywhere, Brahma is uniformly omnipresent. It does not have any inequality or cruelty. This is the purport of the statement ‚Äú≈õuni caiva ≈õvapƒÅke ca‚Äù (in a dog and in a dog-eating ca·πá·∏çƒÅla). The intent of a j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is to do whatever it takes to uplift any jƒ´va. The intent of upliftment is the same across all beings. What is equality from a judge‚Äôs viewpoint? To give everyone their just due according to the law. We need practice for such a temperament to reside in our minds. Our selfish desires and infatuation must go. As long as these exist within us, this practice of equanimity will not be possible.

≈õaknotƒ´haiva ya·∏• so·∏çhu·πÉ prƒÅk·π£arƒ´ravimok·π£a·πáƒÅt
kƒÅmakrodhodbhava·πÉ vega·πÉ sa yukta·∏• sa sukhƒ´ nara·∏• (BG 5.23)
(One must face the onslaught of Desire and Anger here, while alive. The one who can bear it and win over them is a yogi. He indeed is happy.)

In this chapter, yoga refers to karma-yoga. Yogis are sarvabh≈´tahiteratƒÅ·∏• (engaged in the welfare of all beings). They experience their own Self everywhere and thus everyone is non-different from their own Self. The practice of welfare for all is an expression of the love for the Self. The practice of omni-welfare is an action too. That action is performed to please BhagavƒÅn.

bhoktƒÅra·πÉ yaj√±atapasƒÅ·πÉ sarvalokamahe≈õvaram
suh·πõda·πÉ sarvabh≈´tƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ mƒÅ·πÉ ≈õƒÅntim·πõcchati (BG 5.29)

This is one of the most beautiful statements that ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa has made about himself. ‚ÄúI am the friend of all beings. I am the protector of all. Perform your duties knowing that I am there‚Äù. Whom do all our yaj√±as and other meritorious works and austerities reach? It reaches BhagavƒÅn. Whoever constantly experiences this divine greatness attains tranquility. This statement enables the contemplation of the divine Incarnation.

Reflection upon the Principle of Equality

The Gƒ´tƒÅ has numerous mentions referring to equality ‚Äì sama, samatƒÅ, sƒÅmya, samƒÅna, samadar≈õi ‚Äì which have been used in two kinds of meanings that are not opposed to each other but are closely related.

  1. The first meaning is seen in phrases such as ‚Äúsama-du·∏•kha-sukha·πÉ dhƒ´ram‚Äù and ‚Äúsamatva·πÉ yoga ucyate‚Äù. In these situations, equality refers to an attitude of indifference to opposites such as profit-loss, like-dislike, and friends-enemies. 2. The second meaning can be seen in statements such as ‚Äúsama·πÉ sarve·π£u bh≈´te·π£u‚Äù and ‚Äúpa·πá·∏çitƒÅ·∏• samadar≈õina·∏•‚Äù. The purport here is that the Self uniformly exists in all beings.

Both of these meanings have to be considered according to the context.

Tilak‚Äôs Argument

As ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya had criticised the path of action, Bal Gangadhar Tilak endeavoured to establish the primacy of action. Tilak was not interested in re-establishing the a≈õvamedha and the vƒÅjapeya rituals. He was more concerned with action in this world. ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya was not opposed to that either. In fact, ≈öa·πÖkara was least interested in it. From his perspective, nothing needed to be said about worldly action as it was self-evident that everyday action was imperative. Manu‚Äôs testimony, that was considered to be of prime importance by ≈öa·πÖkara, is relevant here. ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya quotes profusely from Manu. ‚Äú·πö·πáƒÅni triƒ´·πái apƒÅk·πõtya mano mok·π£e nive≈õayet‚Äù (Having paid the three-fold debt, the mind must be engaged in liberation), and others are relevant quotes here. Buddha‚Äôs chief instruction was about moral action. ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya insists on fulfilling all these moral prerequisites before holding a VedƒÅnta treatise in one‚Äôs hands. Only those endowed with the wealth of the ≈õama-sextet [ ≈õama, dama, uparati, ≈õraddhƒÅ, titik·π£ƒÅ, samƒÅdhƒÅna] are qualified for the knowledge of VedƒÅnta . Only those are fit to even touch the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Therefore ≈öa·πÖkara implicitly agrees that worldly dharma is essential. His issue is only about the rituals of the ≈õruti and sm·πõti. For us in this era, due to the influence of the times, this is completely irrelevant. Our pa·πá·∏çitas repeatedly debate about ‚Äòkarma‚Äô. Due to this irrelevant debate, this already complicated matter becomes even more complicated. Neither ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya nor the other ƒÅcharyas have any issue with the fact that worldly dharma has be performed. Even if ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya forbids them, those actions will not stop as BhagavƒÅn Kr·π£·πáa himself has extolled the performance of karma.

≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya is chronologically the first amongst the ƒÅcƒÅryas of the three schools (Advaita, Dvaita and Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaita). When he could raise an issue, how could the teachers of the other schools remain quiet without having a say on it? Thus grew this literature of disputation. We can keep that aside.

What is relevant to us is not the question of ≈õrauta rituals but that of everyday worldly actions. There are dos and don‚Äôts as well as dharma and adharma and virtue and vice in everyday life. Is the Gƒ´tƒÅ relevant for the issues of everyday life that are out of the pale of Vedic eligibility? If not, the Gƒ´tƒÅ is a work that stands to become irrelevant with the passage of time and is not worthy of our respect and submission.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J√±ƒÅna (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

The Three Maxims of the Yoga of Action

If we consider the instruction of the Gƒ´tƒÅ as valuable in all places and at all times, the principles of karmayoga apply to all of us. Why? By karma here is meant not just scriptural and traditional rituals connected to devatƒÅs but also all life related activity. Whatever needs to be done to sustain the family ‚Äì loans and receipts, searches for brides and grooms, squabbles with the in-laws, the good and bad of our neighbourhoods, national and international affairs ‚Äì all of these are actions as well as duties.

First of all, the decision of what to do and what not to do has to be decided from the vantage point of the inner Self. Secondly, auspicious action is that which leads to the jƒ´va‚Äôs progress. Thirdly, egoism and hankering after results must be given up in any activity and all actions must be performed as service to BhagavƒÅn. These three rules form the instruction of the fifth chapter.

We discussed the topics of knowledge and liberation. Activity or karma is needed as a prerequisite for j√±ƒÅna. Karma persists after the dawn of knowledge, however, as the play of the Self. The jnƒÅnƒ´ sees his own Self or divine presence everywhere. Therefore he is able to effortlessly perform any action as a service to BhagavƒÅn. Thus action exists as a prerequisite prior to the dawn of knowledge. Action persists later too. The only difference is that while the former kind is mandatory and of the type of an injunction, the latter is a play and is effortless. Thus action exists both before and after the rise of knowledge.

Usually, faith in the efficacy of action as well as a curiosity for knowledge exist among ƒÅstikas*. As knowledge ripens, action recedes. The milk we drink is mixed with water. Even milk directly from a cow‚Äôs udder has water content in it. As the milk is heated, however, the proportion of water keeps decreasing while the proportion of milk solids keeps increasing. In khova and such milk products used for making sweets, water content is almost non-existent and milk solids comprise the entire substance. The interaction between karma and j√±ƒÅna is similar. As the knowledge of reality matures, the craving for the results of the action reduces. Age and worldly experience could be the reason for this. A mental state where karma is seen solely as external activity might arise. Thus, the hankering after karma gradually reduces while j√±ƒÅna, the inner essence of karma, becomes brighter. One fine day, action might be seen as completely unnecessary once knowledge has matured. Karma then automatically falls off. The jnƒÅnƒ´ does not voluntarily give up karma, but it leaves him by itself. We are reading a novel lying down. After sometime, sleep overtakes us and we close our eyes. The book in our hands falls off by itself.

suptahastasthapu·π£pavat..
(Like a flower in the hands of a sleepy person)

What happened then? It is not that faith in karma was lost but that it became unnecessary. When do we need the book? Till we are able to memorize it. Once we know it by heart and are able to recite its contents on demand, what is the need for the book? The performance of karma is like the book. Karma is for the attainment of j√±ƒÅna. The book is also for attaining knowledge. As more knowledge is acquired, the book and karma become irrelevant.

A note of caution, however. Have we really attained j√±ƒÅna? Let us first ensure that. It is safer to perform karma assuming that we have not attained knowledge rather than renouncing it with the assumption that we have attained knowledge.

APPENDIX

Controversy with Schools of Philosophy

The following verses from the fifth chapter are worth remembering.

sƒÅ·πÖkhyayogau p·πõthagbƒÅlƒÅ·∏• pravadanti na pa·πá·∏çitƒÅ·∏•
ekamapyƒÅsthita·∏• samyagubhayorvindate phalam (BG 5.4)

BhagavƒÅn opines that the distinction between the followers of sƒÅ·πÖkhya and yoga is not worth consideration for a seeker.

‚ÄúOnly the childish think of sƒÅ·πÖkhya and yoga as different. The knowers do not differentiate between them. Following either one well ensures that the fruit of both is attained.

‚ÄúWhatever position is attained by the sƒÅ·πÖkhya is attained by the yogis as well. He who sees sƒÅ·πÖkhya and yoga as one is the one who really sees reality.‚Äù

This point is crucial for our country in these times. The poisonous element in our society is inter-religious and sectarian strife. The above verses show that sectarianism is bad and harmful.

The above words are good advice not just for dvaitƒÅdvaita controversies but for conflicts between the votaries of ≈öiva, Vi·π£·πáu, ≈öakti and other deities as well.

Not just that. The rivalries seen between Hinduism, Christianity, Islam and other local and foreign religions can also be answered well by the above verses.

The destination is one but the paths are many. The wayfarer chooses his path according to his aptitude and strength.

The contention amongst Dvaita, Advaita and other schools of philosophy will be discussed in detail in the appendix of the book.

Summary

Not having any desire for one‚Äôs own profit is Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa. Working in a righteous way for riches, wishing for pleasure and coveting success are all suitable for householders. Even if one‚Äôs duties are performed with intended personal benefit, they can eventually bring about selflessness. Whether this is a worldly karma or a religious one, whether it is selfish or not ‚Äî it turns the mind towards the divine if it does not violate dharma. Various experiences gained during the course of life because of constant contact with the world shake and jolt the jƒ´va, make it wander about, and exhaust it. Finally they bring about the realisation about the limited value of the world, the plight of pleasures, and the bounds of human effort.

The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya does not prescribe severe austerities that affect bodily functions. He says that all activities should be within permissible limits. SƒÅdhanƒÅ should not affect efficiency in action and peace of mind.

DhyƒÅna-yoga is fixing the mind upon the principle of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. It is impossible to understand the Bhagavad-Gƒ´tƒÅ without dhyƒÅna. Knowledge gained from mere study of books is incomplete. Complete knowledge is gained from one‚Äôs own experience and the practice of ƒÅtmaupamya.

Different births of a jƒ´va are just like chapters in a single novel. One who wants to study the progression of a jƒ´va should see the various accounts of different births as the uninterrupted flow of a river. Different streams join this river ‚Äî clear and pure streams as well as waters turbid with sewage. The river becomes cleaner and clearer as it progresses. Thus, the flow of small streams also becomes meaningful. Similarly, even a little effort in the right direction will not go waste.

Chapter 6. DhyƒÅna-yoga or DhyƒÅnabhyƒÅsa-yoga

In the previous chapter was enunciated karma-j√±ƒÅna-sƒÅmarasya ‚Äî that karma and j√±ƒÅna are harmonious n with each other. In this chapter will be described dhyƒÅna, an activity that, with satkarma, helps in attaining j√±ƒÅna.

There are ten important points discussed in this chapter:

  1. Relationship between sa·πÉnyƒÅsa and yoga 2. Importance of human self-effort 3. How j√±ƒÅna (knowledge) and vij√±ƒÅna (experiential wisdom) are essential to each other 4. The method of dhyƒÅna 5. The proper limit for food and enjoyment 6. Tranquility 7. The practice of ƒÄtmaupamya or considering the universe as an extension of one‚Äôs own self 8. Accomplishment by practice 9. Even a little practice does not go waste 10. The excellence of performing dhyƒÅna

The Relationship between Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa and Yoga

We might remember that earlier we examined the question of the nature of a sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´n. The answer to that is now given with certainty.

anƒÅ≈õrita·∏• karma-phala·πÉ kƒÅrya·πÉ karma karoti ya·∏•
sa sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´ ca yogƒ´ ca na niragnir-na cƒÅkriya·∏• (BG 6.1)

Who is a sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´ ? Not one who has given up yaj√±a and other fire sacrifices^(^([1])) and other dhƒÅrmic activities like dƒÅna, but one who performs his duties without any desire for selfish benefit. He alone is a yogi.

Among the mahƒÅvƒÅkyas (great declarations) in the Gƒ´tƒÅ, this is one of the most important. Yoga here could mean either karmayoga or j√±ƒÅnayoga. Ultimately, sa·πÉnyƒÅsa and yoga are complementary to each other and are not mutually detrimental. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa, sƒÅ·πÉkhya and j√±ƒÅna are all treated as synonyms in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Similarly, the words dharma, niyata karma and kartavya are all synonymous. The performance of karma yields citta≈õuddhi (purification of the mind) that is a prerequisite to attain j√±ƒÅna. It is impossible to obtain j√±ƒÅna without purifying the mind. The mind must be equanimous and composed to receive j√±ƒÅna. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa becomes a tool to calm and compose the mind. Thus, both karma and sa·πÉnyƒÅsa become one in j√±ƒÅnayoga. They are complementary to each other. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa makes this clear when he says,

ƒÅruruk·π£or-muner-yoga·πÉ karma kƒÅra·πáam-ucyate
yogƒÅr≈´·∏çhasya tasyaiva ≈õama·∏• kƒÅra·πáam-ucyate (BG 6.3)

The readiness for the practice of yoga is obtained by karma, before the actual practice of yoga is begun. Yoga then becomes complete by the practice of ≈õama (tranquillity).

The necessary first step is to perform one‚Äôs ordained duties and then give up the fruit of labour. This is the practice of egolessness. Love and hatred are thence transcended, thus achieving tranquillity of mind. This leads to the complete experience of the Self.

ya·πÉ sa·πÉnyƒÅsam-iti prƒÅhur-yoga·πÉ ta·πÉ viddhi pƒÅ·πá·∏çava
na hyasa·πÉnyƒÅsta-sa·πÖkalpo yogƒ´ bhavati ka≈õcana (BG 6.2)

The first step to prepare for yoga is to give up purpose (sa·πÖkalpa). In other words, desire and want. Thoughts about the outcome ‚Äî that something should result out of an action, or that something should take place in a specific way only and not in any other way ‚Äî are all sa·πÖkalpa. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is the absence of desire for personal fulfilment.

Giving up Desire for Selfish Ends

There is a question here. Should we not have many sa·πÖkalpas such as the upliftment of the nation and so forth? Sa·πÖkalpa is planning. Can there be development in the world without planning? Such questions may arise. Sa·πÖkalpa is the mark of human will; should human effort or will be given up? Has not BhagavƒÅn himself said ‚Äúpauru·π£a·πÉ n·πõ·π£u‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúI am agency or will in humans‚Äù? It has been amply said in the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa and the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata that pauru·π£a is required. Without sa·πÖkalpa, pauru·π£a is impossible.

The answer to this question is thus: Firstly, the intent here is not to give up desire for the progress of the world but to give up selfish desires. The desire for profit, enjoyment, and fame should be given up. However, there is no harm in desires that please BhagavƒÅn. Secondly, selfish desires are prohibited for sa·πÉnyƒÅsƒ´s and people desirous of the knowledge of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, not for everyone. Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is for those who deem worldly pleasures as worthless. Giving up all desires is not expected of people whose minds are firmly and truly attached to the world. The sa·πÖkalpa of such people is ‚Äúcaturvidha-phala-puru·π£ƒÅrtha-siddhyartha·πÉ‚Äù ‚Äî to gain the four-fold achievements in life. Even a selfish desire can be acceptable as dharma. Are not karmas like agni·π£·π≠oma and a≈õvamedha similar to this? Working for pleasure, riches, and success in a righteous manner is not proper for sa·πÉnyƒÅsa but is acceptable for the g·πõhastha. This sa·πÖkalpa of a householder belongs to the millions of objects to be achieved by human beings, the foremost of which is dharma.

A student in a gurukula is prohibited from using perfume, flowers, and tƒÅmb≈´la^(^([2])). However, these enjoyments are not forbidden for householders, and even encouraged. If we say that a man suffering from fever should not be served fatty foods, it doesn‚Äôt mean that his guests should also be deprived of ghee. Let there be selfishness; but it should be subservient to dharma. However, when the highest spiritual knowledge is aspired for, this selfishness should go away.
