[[Ch. 6 The Practice of DhyƒÅna (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Advantage of Performing Karma

The idea that the mind becomes pure by performing karma should be examined before acceptance. Even if one is selfish while performing an ordained duty (vihita-karma), its performance by itself can gradually bring about selflessness. Whether it is a spiritual or worldly duty, even if it is done out of selfishness ‚Äî if it adheres to dharma, its results are two-fold. Firstly, it turns our minds towards the divine; the second is the fulfilment of our objective. Meditation upon the divine does not need any explanation. However, there is one thing to be said about obtaining desires. Performing satkarma is required for everything ‚Äî whether to procure something desirable or to get rid of something undesirable. More importantly, karma means being in contact with the world. Being in constant contact with the world trains the jƒ´va spiritually or changes it in some way. Even such changes can benefit the jƒ´va. Karmas, akarmas, haste, lack of judgment, profit, loss, passion, hatred, jealousy, obstinacy, separation, disease, and sorrow ‚Äî these various experiences shake and jolt the jƒ´va, make it drift about, tire it, and finally bring about the realisation of the meagre extent of the value of the world, of the plight of worldly enjoyment, and of human endeavour. We recall Bhart·πõhari‚Äôs words here ‚Äî

mƒÅtar-medini tƒÅta mƒÅruta sakhe tejas-suba·πÉdho jala
bhrƒÅtar-vyoma nibaddha eva bhavatƒÅm antya·∏• pra·πáƒÅmƒÅ√±jali·∏•‡•§
yu·π£mat-sa·πÉga-va≈õopajƒÅta-suk·πõta-sphƒÅra-sphuran-nirmala-
j√±ƒÅnƒÅpƒÅsta-samasta-moha-mahimƒÅ lƒ´ye para-brahma·πái‡••
VairƒÅgya-≈õataka, 100

Bhart·πõhari probably realised that his life on earth was coming to an end. He then folded his hands and prayed ‚Äî “O mother Earth, father Air, friend Fire, cousin Water, O Sky, who protects me like a brother, this is the last prostration to you from me”. Why? “Because of your association, I was able to gain pu·πáya, and because of the pu·πáya I was able to gain pure, vast and self-effulgent knowledge of the Self.‚Äù As we come more and more in contact with the world, our delusions and infatuations are removed. Contact with the world gives us a sense of the true value of different things. Thus, we become detached from our infatuations, one by one. This is the supreme benefit of experience of association with the world. Connection with the world is one of the exercises required for the jƒ´va. The purity of mind that is achieved by this relationship with the world is greater than that obtained by the sixteen sa·πÉskƒÅras. Therefore, karma is a vital instrument. Indeed, karma is synonymous with man.

Thus, a limit to selfishness is itself set by enjoying the fruit of one‚Äôs self-centered actions. Experiencing pleasure is required for the jƒ´va, as is experiencing sorrow. Therefore, the jƒ´va is ripened even by selfish satkarma, performed out of selfish desire. Remembering the divine and new refinement for the jƒ´va ‚Äî these are the auspicious results of satkarma. The jƒ´va gradually ascends to higher planes of existence through multiple lives by experiencing the fruits of its actions.

Aneka-janma-sa·πÉsiddhas-tato yƒÅti parƒÅ·πÉ gati·πÉ‡••BG 6.45
‚ÄúThus perfected by many lives, he attains the supreme state.‚Äù

One cannot jump to the highest plane, it has to be ascended like a staircase.

Sa·πÉnyƒÅsa is not easy; giving up one‚Äôs interests is not easy; giving up sa·πÖkalpa is not easy either. Performing vihita-karma and enjoying worldly experiences through them ‚Äî this is how one can earn the capacity to experience the supreme reality.

Thus, not just ≈õrauta and smƒÅrta karmas, but all worldly duties, all transactions of life, all friendships and relationships, all physical and spiritual lending and borrowing are training for the jƒ´va. Therefore, we can say that karma itself is life.

Atha khalu kratumaya·∏• puru·π£a·∏•‡••
puru·π£o vƒÅvayaj‚Äôa·∏•‡••
krato smara k·πõtagg·πÉ smara
ChƒÅndogyopani·π£ad 3.14.1

The above sentences from the Upani·π£ads also mean the same. The jƒ´va is karma itself. Karma gives spiritual training to the jƒ´va.

Who can Perform Karma?

Every human being has the freedom to choose the karma that has to be performed, according to his capability and circumstances.

uddhared-ƒÅtmanƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ nƒÅtmƒÅnam-avasƒÅdayet‡•§
ƒÅtmaiva hy-ƒÅtmano bandhur-ƒÅtmaiva ripur-ƒÅtmana·∏•‡••BG 6.5

If man did not have the above freedom, this saying would have been meaningless. The jƒ´va has the freedom to elevate itself, and the freedom to choose whether or not to perform a certain karma.

Why is a person in this state now? Because he acted in a certain way in the past. One exists because of his karma, the karma that he performed in his past. The certainty that one is responsible for his future is embedded in the statement that one exists because of his karma. If a man deliberates today on what he has to do and not do, and performs only the beneficial duties prudently, his circumstances tomorrow will be excellent. In the eyes of westerners, karma is ad·πõ·π£·π≠a ‚Äî unseen ‚Äî some kind of predetermined fatalism about which one can do nothing. They opine that this is a drawback of VedƒÅnta. But we say that it is not a drawback, but a blessing. Who is the master of your life now? You ‚Äî that is, what you did yesterday. Who will be the master of your life tomorrow? You ‚Äî that is, what you do today. If yesterday is the master of today, today will be the master of tomorrow. Thus, past, present, and future are continuously and wholly woven together. Therefore, whatever you have to do today, do it right. This is the essence of the statement ‚Äúuddhared-ƒÅtmanƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ‚Äù. A man is the master of his future. This is the main takeaway from this chapter.

Then can we not jump once and jump hard, and take control of our future? That is not possible. Why is this? This is because the burden from the past weighs the jƒ´va down. That burden should first be lightened. The future is endless. Just as the past does not have any beginning, the future does not have any end. The future that you desire will someday be yours. If you work towards being in the presence of the divine, that is also possible.

bah≈´nƒÅ·πÉ janmanƒÅm-ante j√±ƒÅnavƒÅn mƒÅ·πÉ prapadyate‡•§BG 7.19

If we work towards something in each life, we will obtain true knowledge over time. The meaning is this ‚Äî the jƒ´va must be trained. We have to have that goal in mind and perform karma that trains the jƒ´va, in every life.

≈öama

Now we have agreed that karma is the path to spiritual progress. Is that enough? No.

yogƒÅr≈´·∏çhasya tasyaiva ≈õama·∏• kƒÅra·πáam-ucyate‡••BG 6.3
‚Äú≈öama causes the seeker to be established in yoga.‚Äù

≈öama or tranquility should join karma. Tranquility is possible by meditating on the nature of the Supreme tattva. In a nutshell, karma can train the jƒ´va in a good way, but can also perturb it. The possibility of mental disturbance cannot be escaped even when one is engaged in worship. ‚ÄúYou have brought only red flowers today!‚Äù, ‚ÄúThere is not enough oil for the lamp‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhat have you prepared for the naivedya?‚Äù ‚Äî thus there are many agitations in the mind.

We agreed that karma is transacting with the world. The world does not listen to our words. In a family, a wife may not be able to adjust with the nature of her husband; the husband may not follow his wife‚Äôs whims; the children may not listen to both of them; the old men are irritated by everyone. The employer does not care about the difficulties of his employee; the employee does not worry about the employer. Patient colleagues may not be capable; capable colleagues may not be patient. A man who tries to perform karma in such a world faces anxiety and mental anguish at every step. How can we keep the mind content and resolute in such circumstances?

yogastha·∏• kuru karmƒÅ·πái sa·πÉga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ dhana·πÉjaya‡•§
siddhya-siddhyo·∏• samo bh≈´tvƒÅ samatva·πÉ yoga ucyate‡••BG 2.48

How can equanimity be possible when the surroundings are chaotic? The means for that is meditation upon the divine. If the remembrance of the divine is etched firmly in the mind, mental anguish ceases; conflict vanishes; the work we do becomes meaningful. Therefore, the majesty and glory of the divine should always be meditated upon. Then any work done will be completed to perfection. Thus for spiritual upliftment, dhyƒÅna is also as important a means as karma.

J√±ƒÅna-vij√±ƒÅna

j√±ƒÅna-vij√±ƒÅna-t·πõptƒÅtmƒÅ k≈´·π≠astho vijitendriya·∏•‡•§
ukta ity-ucyate yogƒ´ sama-lo·π£·π≠ƒÅ≈õma-kƒÅ√±cana·∏•‡••BG 6.8

The mind needs two kinds of intellectual wealth to be content. One is j√±ƒÅna, the other is vij√±ƒÅna. J√±ƒÅna here means the knowledge of the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ (tattva-j√±ƒÅna). It is knowledge gained by persistent effort of the intellect ‚Äî knowledge obtained from reading books and listening to discourses. Vij√±ƒÅna is experiencing the knowledge gained thus. Vij√±ƒÅna is the experience of j√±ƒÅna. One is theory ‚Äî intellectual pursuit, whereas the other is practice ‚Äî experiential pursuit. One has to obtain both of these and remain unperturbed by the senses. Such a man is ‚Äút·πõptƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù. One who is separate from every attribute of the jƒ´va except the ƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äî such as the body ‚Äî such a man is ‚Äúk≈´·π≠astha·∏• vijitendriya·∏•‚Äù. ‚Äúk≈´·π≠astha·∏•‚Äù means existing separately, and changeless like the firm anvil of a blacksmith. As William Wordsworth said about John Milton ‚Äî

Thy soul was like a star and dwelt apart
London, 1802

The light should mingle with others like that of a star, but the person should stay aloof. As said previously, ‚Äúpadma-patram-ivƒÅmbhasƒÅ‚Äù ‚Äî one should be in the world, and yet not attached to it. That is being k≈´·π≠astha. Such a man is ‚Äúyukta‚Äù ‚Äî he is established in yoga. Gold and stone mean the same to him

The Method of DhyƒÅna

A yogi brings his senses under his control, learns to distinguish between ƒÄtma and anƒÅtma and practises it in this world as much as possible, and is at peace.

yogƒ´ yu√±jƒ´ta satatam ƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ rahasi sthita·∏•‡•§
ekƒÅkƒ´ yata-cittƒÅtmƒÅ nirƒÅ≈õƒ´r-aparigraha·∏•‡••BG 6.10

‚ÄúHe always unites his mind with the ƒÅtmƒÅ. He keeps his mind under control. He does not worry about earning or enjoying. He sits alone in a private place and immerses himself in dhyƒÅna, thinking about the nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù.

tatraikƒÅgra·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ yata-cittendriya-kriya·∏•‡•§
upavi≈õyƒÅsane yu√±jyƒÅt yogamƒÅtma-vi≈õuddhaye‡••BG 6.12

DhyƒÅna should be performed in a clean place. The seat should be firm. It should neither be too high nor too low. The flow of light and wind should not agitate but be calming. Sitting in such a place, one should focus his mind.

It is said that yoga should be practised while sitting. Even the Brahmas≈´tra says ‚Äî “ƒÅsƒ´nas-sambhavƒÅt” (Brahmas≈´tra 4.1.7). Why should it not be done while walking? Of course, it can be done while walking if it is possible, but it is not possible! When we are walking, we constantly think about where we step next. If we meditate while lying down, we might fall asleep. We should therefore sit calmly to perform dhyƒÅna. “yatraikƒÅgratƒÅ tatrƒÅvi≈õe·π£ƒÅt” ‚Äî one should sit wherever the mind can concentrate. A place where the mind is calm and unlikely to wander is the right place for dhyƒÅna.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 6 The Practice of DhyƒÅna (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Limiting Pleasures

It is not required for a sƒÅdhaka practising dhyƒÅna to adhere to valiant restrictions on food and other diversions. His sitting posture should not hinder easy breathing and other bodily activities, and should not cause trouble to his limbs. There is a proper measure for eating, sleeping and jƒÅgara·πáa^(^([1])). A yogi is moderate in the above aspects. Here, moderation means just as much as is required for mental balance; neither more, nor less.

nƒÅtya≈õnatas-tu yogo‚Äôsti na caikƒÅntam-ana≈õnata·∏• ‡•§
na cƒÅti-svapna-≈õƒ´lasya jƒÅgrato naiva cƒÅrjuna‡•• BG 6.16
yuktƒÅhƒÅra-vihƒÅrasya yukta-ce·π£·π≠asya karmasu ‡•§
yukta-svapnƒÅvabodhasya yogo bhavati du·∏•khahƒÅ ‡•• BG 6.17

A glutton cannot become a yogi, as also one who seldom eats. Excess sleep is not recommended, as is jƒÅgara·πáa or staying awake for too long. One should be tranquil; there should be no excess of pleasure.

Two Goals

There are two goals here:1) Efficiency in work 2) Peace of mind. When the yak·π£a asked^(^([2])) what was the main characteristic of the practice of Dharma, DharmarƒÅja said, ‚ÄúdƒÅk·π£yam-ekapada·πÉ dharmya·πÉ‚Äù (MBh. 3-314-72) ‚Äî ‚ÄúEfficiency is one-quarter of dharma‚Äù. Dharma is possible when one is efficient. JƒÅgara·πáa, oversleeping, starving, and stuffing one‚Äôs stomach with food ‚Äî all these affect the peace of mind.

Enjoyment of and attachment to pleasure should be present in such a way that progress towards the two aforementioned goals is not impeded. Just as ‚Äònot impeding‚Äô is important, it is also important that they be ‚Äòpresent‚Äô. The body and the senses should be controlled, not killed. They become obedient only if they are humoured for some time. If we try to suppress in a strict manner, they might revolt and break the mind into pieces. DhyƒÅna then becomes impossible; worldly work becomes impossible. Viveka deserts the mind that is not peaceful.

Efficiency and peace of mind are required not only for a seeker of knowledge and not just for a yogi but are required qualities even for us, who are not quite so inclined in this direction. The plight of humans is like this because these qualities are not present in our day-to-day dealings. DhyƒÅna-yoga can be practised when the mind is healthy and content.

yatroparamate citta·πÉ niruddha·πÉ yoga-sevayƒÅBG 6.20
sa·πÖkalpa-prabhavƒÅn kƒÅmƒÅn tyaktvƒÅ sarvƒÅn-a≈õe·π£ata·∏•‡•§
manasaivendriya-grƒÅma·πÉ viniyamya samantata·∏•‡•• BG 6.24
≈õanai·∏• ≈õanair-uparamet buddhyƒÅ dh·πõti-g·πõhƒ´tayƒÅ‡•§
ƒÅtma-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ na ki√±cidapi cintayet‡••BG 6.25

The qualification for yoga is said to be acquired when the mind stops roving here and there, and can focus without getting agitated. Until then we do not qualify for yoga. Completely giving up all desires that are the root cause of various sa·πÖkalpas, controlling all senses and subjugating them, attaining tranquility little by little at a time with a steady mind, firmly establishing the mind in the ƒÅtmƒÅ, one desiring to practise dhyƒÅna should not think of anything else. This is paramƒÅtma-dhyƒÅna-yoga or the yoga of meditating upon the Supreme.

Different Types of DhyƒÅna-yoga

For many among us, paramƒÅtmƒÅ is a distant thing. It is not easy for us to even imagine it. But we also possess a desire to understand its nature. Therefore, we also need a method of dhyƒÅna that might gradually lead us on the path to true knowledge. In the statement

*ƒÅtma-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ…*BG 6.25

We can replace ƒÄtma with a deity of our choice ‚Äî one that we love and can grasp. “Deva-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “≈õambhu-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “rƒÅma-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “vƒÅ·πáƒ´-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “k·πõ·π£·πáa-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “lak·π£mƒ´-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, “gaurƒ´-sa·πÉstha·πÉ mana·∏• k·πõtvƒÅ”, etc ‚Äî thus fixing the mind upon our i·π£·π≠adevatƒÅ. Usually, during all vratas like VinƒÅyaka-caturthƒ´, during all japas like that of the GƒÅyatrƒ´-mantra, it is an established tradition to recite the dhyƒÅna-shloka first. The intention is to bring the Divine image to mind ‚Äî and in the process, fix the mind on the greatness of the deity, its wonderful power and glory. “muktƒÅvidruma‚Ä¶” in gƒÅyatrƒ´-dhyƒÅna, “dhyeya·∏• sadƒÅ savit·πõ-ma·πá·∏çala-madhyavarti·∏•”, etc.

This is the first lesson in dhyƒÅnayoga.

The method of dhyƒÅna has to be learnt from experienced people only. It is not possible to learn it by listening to speeches and explanations. The secret of dhyƒÅna is the mechanism to temper the mind. This mechanism differs from jƒ´va to jƒ´va. Some children can be cajoled with candies; others might need to see a cane before they oblige. There is no single rule that works for all minds. If experienced people share their experiences, some guidance can be obtained from it. I am not experienced^(^([3])). I will just say a few words that I have merely heard from others.

Means for DhyƒÅna

As far as possible, those who want to practise dhyƒÅna should decide on the following four first.

  1. A designated place 2. A specific time 3. The m≈´rti of a deity 4. A mantra or a mahƒÅvƒÅkya

Out of the twenty-four hours available in a day, at least fifteen minutes should be earmarked for this purpose. Early morning is the best time. If that is not possible, even night time is fine. It is of utmost importance that the mind should be at peace. If there is a specific time and place, the mind can easily take the requisite mood or attitude. It might be difficult to achieve the same in a different place or at a different time. One should sit there in silence, where there is no animated activity of others. One should sit with a clean mind and body in such a place, and fix the concentration on the icon of the i·π£·π≠adaiva. Once should recall the stories, the wonderful qualities and splendour of the deity, and keep thinking about it. If he feels like it, he can perform p≈´jƒÅ, but the mind should not wander away in the hullabaloo of flowers and naivedya. Japa should not even be performed loudly, because sound pulls the mind outward towards the world. Among all dhyƒÅnas, silent dhyƒÅna is the best. That is why yogis are called maunis (those who are silent).

Then, are bhajanas and kƒ´rtanas wrong? No, they are also useful. However, their use is limited. Bhajanas and kƒ´rtanas bring elevated emotions to the mind. These emotions are fructified only by performing dhyƒÅna solitarily.

I feel that the practice of dhyƒÅna is possible at least to a certain extent for everyone ‚Äî including women^(^([4])). There is no one who is so busy that he or she is not free for a few minutes before sleeping at night, or in the early morning‚Äîjust beside the bed‚Äîbefore one sets out for their daily routine. If those five minutes are used for dhyƒÅna, it will not only bring much-needed peace and calm during the entire day, but also firmly establishes a practice routine.

Yogis can engage themselves in deep dhyƒÅna of their deity for a very long time. It is very difficult for us to achieve such deep concentration for a long time. It is a great fortune if our minds can fix themselves upon the divine even for a second. One of my elders would say ‚Äî “I can wash a buffalo with ease, washing a sƒÅligrƒÅma is difficult”. Another elder would say, “I can focus for hours on worldly matters; whereas my mind is not focused for half a minute in the half hour I spend for p≈´jƒÅ”. Worldly things excite our temper or desire, and trap us with them. There is no such outward attraction for devotion to the divine. It happens inside us. Our firm and persevering effort is required for it. “Uddhared-ƒÅtmanƒÅtmƒÅnam”. That is why it is difficult. SƒÅdhanƒÅ is when something difficult is achieved. What is great in achieving something that is easy?

Without such dhyƒÅna, it is difficult for anyone to understand the Bhagavad-Gƒ´tƒÅ. Experience is knowledge. Here, by experience, we mean our own experience. The knowledge obtained from books is incomplete. Bookish knowledge is only a poor imitation of the knowledge gained by experience, whereas experience gives complete knowledge. When such experience has to be gained, the mind has to ripen. Both karma and j√±ƒÅna are ways to ripen the mind. Both of them are needed.

“yƒÅvad-yƒÅvat karmabhya uparamate tƒÅvat tƒÅvat nirƒÅyƒÅsasya jitendriyasya citta·πÉ samƒÅdhƒ´yate‡•§”
(As it recuses itself from activity, the mind of the one who is at ease and whose sense organs are controlled attains focus.)
≈öƒÅ·πÖkara-gƒ´tƒÅbhƒÅ·π£ya 6.3

naitƒÅd·πõ≈õa·πÉ brƒÅhma·πáasyƒÅsti vitta·πÉ
yathaikatƒÅ samatƒÅ satyatƒÅ ca.
≈õƒ´la·πÉ sthitirda·πá·∏çanidhƒÅnamƒÅrjava·πÉ
tatastata≈õcoparama·∏• kriyƒÅbhya·∏•
(There is no other wealth of a brƒÅhma·πáa
than unity, equanimity, truth,
character, firmness, the cessation of punishment, sincerity
and gradual cessation from activity)
MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, 12.169.35^(^([5]))

They say that the mind should desist from sensual enjoyment; the meaning here is to get rid of the cares, scares and fuss of karma. Karma should be performed, but we should also extricate ourselves from it. Both are required ‚Äî there are different requirements for different situations.

Mark of an ƒÄtma-j√±ƒÅnƒ´

≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa describes the mark of a meditator who has successfully accomplished ƒÄtmadhyƒÅna.

sarva-bh≈´tastham-ƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ sarvabh≈´tƒÅni cƒÅtmani‡•§
ƒ´k·π£ate yoga-yuktƒÅtmƒÅ sarvatra sama-dar≈õana·∏•‡••BG 6.29
yo mƒÅ·πÉ pa≈õyati sarvatra sarva·πÉ ca mayi pa≈õyati‡•§
tasyƒÅha·πÉ na pra·πáa≈õyƒÅmi sa ca me na pra·πáa≈õyati‡••BG 6.30
sarvathƒÅ vartamƒÅno‚Äôpi sa yogƒ´ mayi vartateBG 6.31
ƒÅtmaupamyena sarvatra sama·πÉ pa≈õyati yo‚Äôrjuna‡•§
sukha·πÉ vƒÅ yadi vƒÅ du·∏•kha·πÉ sa yogƒ´ paramo mata·∏•‡••BG 6.32

All living beings are within the expanse of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. A yogi internalises this experience and behaves in the same way towards everything and everyone. We have seen the meaning of samabhƒÅva earlier: it means having clear distinction between proper and improper in external behavior and equal love for all internally. Everything is a manifestation of the divine, and the divine pervades everything uniformly. It cannot be said that it manifests densely in some and sparsely in others. The love that a yogi feels internally is equal and common for all. Wherever he is, whatever state he is in, he always interacts with the divine at all times. ƒÄtmaupamya is characteristic of him. ƒÄtmaupamya^(^([6])) means behaving towards someone else as though it was oneself. A great yogi is one who considers others‚Äô happiness and sorrow as his own, at all times and in all places. He is part of all of the world‚Äôs experiences, be it joy or agony. This is what ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa says. He does not abandon the world; but he is engrossed in the welfare of all beings. Internally, he is not attached to worldly activities, but outwardly, he helps in those very activities. Internally, he is firmly established in the true knowledge of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Because of this ‚Äî because his knowledge of the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ is complete, he is able to conduct himself as though the whole world is an extension of himself. Just as it is the innate nature of jasmine to spread fragrance, the quality of ƒÄtmaupamya is thus natural and effortless for a yogi. ƒÄtmaupamya is prescribed dharma for a sƒÅdhaka, and a natural development for a siddha (one who has attained it). Thus, its importance is in both ways. This philosophy of ƒÄtmaupamya is the fundamental thread running through all our worldly morals and traditions. The ≈õƒÅstras expound this in many ways -

ƒÅtmana·∏• pratik≈´lƒÅni pare·π£ƒÅ·πÉ na samƒÅcaret‡••
(One must not do to others what one would find disagreeable)
MBh. 5.15.17, 18

mƒÅt·πõvat para-dƒÅrƒÅ·πÉ≈õca para-dravyƒÅ·πái lo·π£·π≠havat‡•§
ƒÅtmavat sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni ya·∏• pa≈õyati sa pa≈õyati‡••
(One who sees others‚Äô wives as his own mother,
others‚Äô wealth as a lump of earth,
and all beings as one self, indeed sees.)
Hitopade≈õa 1.14

[[Ch. 6 The Practice of DhyƒÅna (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Accomplishment through Practice

It looks as though this principle appealed to Arjuna‚Äôs mind, in the course of teaching of the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. However, he still had doubts regarding the practice.

cancala·πÉ hi mana·∏• k·πõ·π£·πáa pramƒÅthi balavad-d·πõ·∏çham‡•§
tasyƒÅha·πÉ nigraha·πÉ manye vƒÅyor-iva sudu·π£karam‡•• BG 6.34

Arjuna says ‚Äî “K·πõ·π£·πáa, is not the mind fickle? It can impede the path of the jƒ´va and shake it, can it not? Is it possible to bottle up wind?”. BhagavƒÅn says, “indeed, it is difficult; but not impossible”. How, then, is it possible?

asa·πÉ≈õaya·πÉ mahƒÅbƒÅho mano durnigraha·πÉ cala·πÉ‡•§
abhyƒÅsena tu kaunteya vairƒÅgyena ca g·πõhyate‡••BG 6.35

The mind can be taken into control with intelligent effort. Practice of dhyƒÅna and indifference to worldly pleasures are the ways to accomplish that.

The word abhyƒÅsa (practice) should be looked at in a little more detail here. AbhyƒÅsa means doing something again and again. What does this imply? It means that when one sets out to achieve something, it cannot be done by the mental adrenaline rush of one moment, but requires persistent and consistent effort for a long time. A moment is just a point in a long line. Time is the straight line comprising these moments without any gap. Dots are right next to each other in a line, without any gap. DhyƒÅna and vairƒÅgya too should thus be practised continuously, without any gap. How long should the practice last? Till the sattvagu·πáa of the jƒ´va breaks out of the shackles of rajas and tamas and rises above them, and becomes strong enough to put them down. The time required for sattva to become this strong is determined by how large the quanta of rajas and tamas are. Who can measure the quantity of the three gu·πáas hidden in a jƒ´va? There can be no one outside the jƒ´va who can convey this to him. The workings of his innermost mind will not be visible to them. In fact, it is not even necessary for someone outside to convey it to him, because he can himself realise when his sattva becomes stronger. The development of sattvagu·πáa will happen for everyone at some time or the other ‚Äî however evil or uncultured he may be. There is no being without even an iota of sattva. His exact moment of favourable opportunity is when his sattva blooms. That is when he has to be watchful. This is the ‚Äòinner voice‚Äô that he has to heed. It is heard when bodily ears are closed and the inner ones are opened. If it has to become a habit, one has to listen to it carefully, grasp its intent and follow it thenceforth. The mind becomes strong with long-term practice of detachment and dhyƒÅna. It becomes easier to pursue the true knowledge of the ƒÅtmƒÅ when the mind firms up.

Arjuna says ‚Äî ‚ÄúThis is fine, Krishna, I have ≈õraddhƒÅ. However, my attempt to control my mind might not complete and break down halfway. What will then become of me? What will happen if a small speck of cloud gets separated from its parent? Caught in the wind, it will be scattered without even a sign remaining of it. Is not my plight the same? What if the only outcome of running a race is fracturing one‚Äôs foot? I would not have completely left the practice of dhyƒÅna, neither would I have achieved it‚Äù.

Even a little practice will not go waste

≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa replies to this question thus:

pƒÅrtha naiveha nƒÅmutra vinƒÅ≈õas-tasya vidyate‡•§
na hi kalyƒÅ·πáa-k·πõt ka≈õcit durgati·πÉ tƒÅta gacchati‡••BG 6.40

If you try and do not succeed, you will not suffer from it. One who tries to do good will never come to ruin.

A boy might be coaxed by the elders of the family to study for a difficult exam. They are convinced that he is intelligent and studious, and might pass the exam. He might not be so confident, and might ask ‚ÄúWhat if I don‚Äôt pass?‚Äù. The elders will then say, ‚Äúit is okay to not pass this time. What is the harm in studying for it? The preparation for this exam will help you next time, if not this now‚Äù. ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs answer is similar.

He had given a similar assurance to Arjuna earlier:

nehƒÅbhikrama-nƒÅ≈õo‚Äôsti pratyavƒÅyo na vidyate‡•§
svalpam-apyasya dharmasya trƒÅyate mahato bhayƒÅt‡••BG 2.40

Even if this dharma is followed a little, it protects us from great fear.

Sa·πÉskƒÅra from many lives

The above statement is not just one of encouragement. The accomplishment of yoga is possible only through gradual steps. Our efforts might not bear fruit in a single birth. A jƒ´va attains a favourable state in the next birth because of the pu·πáya of this birth. From the pu·πáya of that birth, it attains an even better state in another birth. Thus, the qualification to be in the presence of the divine is accrued from the sa·πÉskƒÅra and effort of many lives.

prƒÅpya pu·πáya-k·πõtƒÅn lokƒÅn u·π£itvƒÅ ≈õƒÅ≈õvatƒ´·∏• samƒÅ·∏•‡•§
≈õucƒ´nƒÅ·πÉ ≈õrƒ´matƒÅ·πÉ gehe yoga-bhra·π£·π≠o‚ÄôbhijƒÅyate‡••BG 6.41
athavƒÅ yoginƒÅm-eva kule bhavati dhƒ´matƒÅ·πÉ‡•§
etaddhi durlabha-tara·πÉ loke janma yad-ƒ´d·πõ·π£am‡•• BG 6.42

A follower of the path of yoga will gain pu·πáya and thus attain better stations even if his effort is not enough to take him to the intended final destination. His incomplete practice of yoga will not harm him in any way. Rather, he will then be born in a virtuous and wealthy family, and becomes capable of performing virtuous deeds again. Or, he might be born in a family of seers and yogis and gain true knowledge of the self. Is it not great fortune to be born in such a good family? It is indeed great pu·πáya to be born in a good household.

tatra ta·πÉ buddhi-sa·πÉyoga·πÉ labhate paurva-dehika·πÉ‡•§

p≈´rvƒÅbhyƒÅsena tenaiva hriyate hyava≈õo‚Äôpi sa·∏•‡•§
jij√±ƒÅsurapi yogasya ≈õabda-brahm-ƒÅtivartate‡••BG 6.44
prayatnƒÅd-yatamƒÅnastu yogƒ´ sa·πÉ≈õuddha-kilbi·π£a·∏•‡•§

One who practises dhyƒÅna-yoga but leaves his body before his efforts fructify, will be born in a noble family in the next life. Because of the excellence in the place and circumstances of his birth, his mind will turn towards his practice of yoga, which he had left half-finished. Due to his previous practice, his mind will be ripe and ready for yoga. Maturity of the mind is because of the influence of his family. Thus, his practice of yoga resumes. Even if he faces obstacles during his practice this second time, he will be capable of overcoming them. Further, he deliberates upon the nature of reality. He gains knowledge and thus transcends all bookish knowledge. The material in his effort to gain knowledge is ≈õabda-brahma ‚Äî or the collection of Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras. When we say that he transcends them, it is implied that he has full possession of the knowledge contained in them, and therefore they are no longer necessary to him. Thus, by repeated efforts he loses the impurities accumulated in him from the actions and desires of his previous births, and acquires true knowledge.

Three points have to be observed in the above discussion:

  1. Rebirth 2. The relationship between family and the eligibility to perform yoga 3. The necessity of continuous and long practice.

Influence of Family

Consideration of familial influence in the conduct of a person is a distinctive feature of sanƒÅtana-dharma. It is respectful to call ≈örƒ´rƒÅma as belonging to the family of Ik·π£vƒÅku, or the family of Raghu. So also, Paurava, BhƒÅrata, YƒÅdava are all names that denote great pride. ·πö·π£i Ka·πáva indicated King Du·π£yanta‚Äôs exalted nature by saying ‚Äúuccai·∏• kula·πÉ catmana·∏•‚Äù (distinguished indeed is his clan). There is a term ‚Äî noblesse oblige ‚Äî which means that with wealth comes great responsibility. Arjuna himself talks about familial dharma in his extensive lament of abandonment. There is a saying in kanna·∏ça ‚Äî ‚Äúkulavannu nƒÅlag√© he·∏ªuttad√©‚Äù ‚Äî the tongue betrays the family. Thus, family and society are of great importance. It comes to a man by his actions in his previous births. When we say that a family is good, it means that they are good-natured and also have good sa·πÉskƒÅra. A sƒÅttvika mind and innate spirituality run naturally in the family and comprise their ancestral wealth. Also, there is more opportunity for contact with good people and education in such a family. Thus, being born in such a family is the fruit of great pu·πáya in itself. Similarly, being born in a base family is the result of pƒÅpa.

Step-by-step improvement of the jƒ´va

Various accounts of different births and rebirths are not different stories but all births are different chapters of a single great story. One who wants to understand the progress of a jƒ´va should examine the different chapters of different births as one unbroken and uninterrupted flow, like that of a river. Streams of clear water join this river, as does village muck. As the river flows further, it loses its filth and becomes clearer and clearer. Thus, the inflow of small but clear streams also finds a favorable outcome. The story of our meagre but sincere effort is similar.

The progress of a jƒ´va happens gradually. Each birth is a step. The eligibility for mok·π£a comes from many sa·πÉskƒÅras. For the jƒ´va to attain a good state (sadgati) various kinds of purification are required, just as various strokes with a hammer are required to create a sculpture out of stone, and various methods of mixing, boiling, and filtering are required to produce medicine out of herbs. Therefore, it is not right to be hasty about mok·π£a. Only constant practice of yoga helps in the attainment of mok·π£a.

The superiority of dhyƒÅna-yoga

Yoga is when a human being employs his divine nature in the service of the world, and thereby unites his inner-self with the paramƒÅtmƒÅ. This means that he should perform the activities of the world without any desire for its fruit: ‚ÄúYoga·∏• karmasu kau≈õalam‚Äù. Such yoga is superior to penance such as vratas and upavƒÅsas, better than the knowledge of many ≈õƒÅstras, and better even than yaj√±as and yƒÅgas. Therefore, O Arjuna, you practise this yoga and become a yogi.

yoginƒÅm-api sarve·π£ƒÅ·πÉ madgatenƒÅ-ntarƒÅtmanƒÅ‡•§

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-Jƒ´va-ƒ™≈õvara (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Summary

Whatever is essential and uniquely great in this world is to be understood as a salient mark of Brahma‚Äôs power. Whatever quality endows a thing with usefulness and value belongs to the power of Brahma.

In addition to sattva, the gu·πáas of rajas and tamas are also necessary for the functioning of the world. The agitation amongst these three gu·πáas is vital for the constantly dynamic behaviour of the universe and therefore for its existence. Prak·πõti has thrown man a competitive challenge a- “I have instituted this disparity among gu·πáas. Let man overcome it if he can.”

MƒÅyƒÅ is the appearance that manifests to our mind after concealing or distorting reality. It is the world-controlling power that causes the error due to avidyƒÅ that is seen by the mind‚Äôs eye to appear real.

The one who is free of avidyƒÅ, whose influence spans multiple births, is not affected by mƒÅyƒÅ. The cessation of avidyƒÅ is possible through the practice of the presence of ƒ™≈õvara - with renewed effort towards gaining the knowledge of reality.

He who experiences BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs presence everywhere considers all worldly relations, kith and kin as ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs blessing. As that blessed feeling grows, infatuation and delusions recede. The jƒ´va is purified. The contemplation of reality becomes easier. The knower of reality understands what in his life is owed to the world and what is owed to his inner self. He then works towards the welfare of both and becomes free of worry. Such a state is tranquility.

Section 8 / Chapter 7

J√±ƒÅnƒÅ-vij√±ƒÅna-yoga

known as

The Yoga of Jagat, Jƒ´va and ƒ™≈õvara

Though the seventh chapter has only thirty verses, its matter is complex and not easy to understand. The following nine main points are covered here:

  1. The world - insentient prak·πõti 2. The world - sentient prak·πõti 3. ƒ™≈õvara 4. The essence of Brahma in ƒ™≈õvara 5. The marks (signs) of Brahma 6. MƒÅyƒÅ 7. Crossing over mƒÅyƒÅ 8. The worship of ƒ™≈õvara 9. The cessation of infatuation

This chapter covers these nine great topics in its small compass. The last chapter discussed meditation. Karma resulting in the purification of the mind is a negative attainment^(^([1])). DhyƒÅna (meditation) on the other hand is a positive attainment. PƒÅpa is destroyed by karma while new well-being is gained by dhyƒÅna. This has already been stated in the sixth chapter. ‚ÄúMental agitation is remedied by means such as “yuktƒÅhƒÅravihƒÅrasya” (of the one with propriety in food and enjoyment). A state of calm is then reached, one should sit in a clean place and meditate” - and such is stated there.

Now, the object to be meditated upon has to be ascertained. DhyƒÅna (meditation) has three aspects - dhyƒÅna (the act of meditation), dhyƒÅt·πõ (the meditator), and dhyeya (the object of meditation). Knowledge, similarly has three aspects - j√±ƒÅna (knowledge), j√±ƒÅt·πõ (the knower), and j√±eya (the known). All those desirous of knowing reality are dhyƒÅt·πõ. BhagavƒÅn now tells us what the dhyeya should be.

asa·πÉ≈õaya·πÉ samagra·πÉ mƒÅ·πÉ yathƒÅ j√±ƒÅsyasi tacch·πõ·πáu
BG 7.1

It is not sufficient to understand the nature of Brahma a little here and a little there. Brahma has to be understood samagram (completely) - from the beginning to the end.

Before proceeding to the next part of the work, it is important to understand a few words and their meanings. It appears that terminology used in this chapter was well known among people during VyƒÅsa‚Äôs time. The same words have been used in the Mok·π£a-dharma-parva and the SanatsujƒÅtƒ´ya. People probably understood terms such as Brahma without any explanation. But all these are new words for us.

The Meaning of the Word Sat

The Supreme Brahma is of the nature of sat (pure existence). Sat originally referred to existence. The meaning “good” came to sat only later. What exists for a long time is sat. The word sat stems from the root ‚àöas = bhuvi (in existence). Words such as satya, asti, come from the same ‚àöas. Whatever exists is sat. Existence here is existing as-is. Whatever exists unbothered and untainted by the past, present, or future, is unchanged at any time, and is of the same form throughout, is known as sat. That is satya (Truth). Sat is that which is unmodified by the distinctions of time, place, season, limitation, or external actions. We saw this at the beginning of the work itself.

acchedyo‚ÄôyamadƒÅhyo‚Äôyamakledyo‚Äô≈õo·π£ya eva ca,
nitya·∏• sarvagata·∏• sthƒÅ·πáuracalo‚Äôya·πÉ sanƒÅtana·∏•.
BG 2.24

The substance of sat is great, very great; greater than anything we can imagine as the greatest; Infinite; Limitless. That is why we call It Omnipresent or Brahma (that stems from the root ‚àöb·πõhi - v·πõddhau (increase). Brahma is sat. This is all we can say about It - It exists. That is the only thing possible. It is foolhardy to venture to say anything beyond it. Our ancestors have added two other characteristics to sat - cit (consciousness) and ƒÅnanda (bliss). Both of these are considered ta·π≠astha-lak·π£a·πáa^(^([2])) rather than svar≈´pa-lak·π£a·πáa^(^([3])). Cit and ƒÄnanda - the li·πÖgas (markers) of Brahma - are like those characteristics of a swimmer visible to one who is standing on the shore (ta·π≠astha). The li·πÖga is a symbol or a marker used to denote the principle behind it. We notice a bit of both cit and ƒÅnanda in practice. But sat is something that is devoid of any markers and is without activity and thus unnoticeable in practice. That can only be experienced - buddhigrƒÅhyam atƒ´ndriyam. It is not possible to establish its existence through reasoning. It is pure being and pure existence, known in Greek and Latin as ousia and esse respectively. In Sa·πÉsk·πõta, it is known as sattƒÅ.

The Two States of Sat

We can contemplate upon two states of Brahma - 1. Vyakta (manifest). This is prak·πõti. This is kƒÅrya-brahma (Brahma as effect) 2. Avyakta (unmanifest) that is also known as kƒÅra·πáa-bra·∏•ma (Brahma as cause). The latter is also known as Pure existence or Parabrahma. The manifest is known as vyakta and the unmanifest is known as avyakta in the eighth chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ.

avyaktƒÅd vyaktaya·∏• sarvƒÅ·∏• prabhavanty-aharƒÅgame
rƒÅtry-ƒÅgame pralƒ´yante tatraiv-ƒÅvyakta-sa·πÉj√±ake
BG 8.18

paras-tasmƒÅttu bhƒÅvo‚Äônyo‚Äôvyakto‚ÄôvyaktƒÅt-sanƒÅtana·∏•
ya·∏• sa sarve·π£u bh≈´te·π£u na≈õyatsu na vina≈õyati
BG 8.20

When does pure existence become manifest? When it becomes visible in the form of the world. The manifest aspect of Brahma is known as jagat (the world). What is the cause of the world? Supreme Brahma. Statements such as “janmƒÅdyasya yata·∏•”^(^([4])), “yato vƒÅ imƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni jƒÅyante”^(^([5])), “sarvam khalvidam brahma tajjalƒÅnityupƒÅsƒ´ta”^(^([6])) convey the same purport. The world is subservient to Brahma and exists on the foundation of Brahma. Prak·πõti is created from the cit aspect of Brahma.

Prak·πõti is prakar·π£ƒÅ k·πõti·∏• - an excellent and vast creation. Whose work is it? The limitless energies that are in Brahma are the matter under consideration now. How limitless is the consciousness of Brahma - Its cicchakti! It is beyond thought! What exists in it and does not exist in it cannot be said. Its capability exceeds imagination. Its expression itself is Prak·πõti - a great action that is the entire Universe! Whatever can be experienced by our eyes, ears and other sense organs, whatever can be imagined or inferred by our intellect - all that is Prak·πõti. All our systems of knowledge, thought, reasoning, and distinction belong to the realm of Prak·πõti. The arena of our everyday life is pervaded by Prak·πõti. The world is the place where we demonstrate the energies of our mind, intellect, and talent. This manifest world then is permeated by ‚Äúunmanifest existence‚Äù within and without.

An iceberg floats in the great ocean of the unmanifest. The iceberg is water too; but with the form of an iceberg. The ocean is the unmanifest; the iceberg is the manifest. The manifest is something that can be recognised. This recognisable universe floats in the ocean of the unrecognisable unmanifest. The unmanifest aspect of Brahma is like air sustaining a floating balloon within and without. Is not that in which something floats greater than the thing itself? This is also what the ≈õruti says - “pƒÅdo‚Äôsya vi≈õvƒÅ bh≈´tƒÅni ‡•§ tripƒÅdasyƒÅm·πõta·πÉ divi”. PƒÅda refers to a quarter. The solar orb, the lunar orb, the earth, the visible universe - all together comprise just a quarter of Brahma. Thrice or many times as big as the manifest world is the unmanifest or the invisible.

Thus Brahma has two aspects - the manifest and unmanifest - or visible and invisible. That is why our ancients said - vyaktƒÅvyakta-svar≈´pƒÅya (of the nature of the manifest and unmanifest) whenever they remembered Brahma. In all things movable and immovable, whatever is seen and felt by us, whatever has movement, is all pervaded by Brahma. It is in this way that It is omnipresent and omniscient. That is the reason for It to be known as Vi·π£·πáu which means all-pervading. As it exists in everybody as their own ƒÅtmƒÅ (self), It is known as paramƒÅtmƒÅ.

ida·πÉ sarvamas·πõjata ‡•§^(^([7]))

tats·πõ·π£·π≠vƒÅ tadevƒÅnuprƒÅvi≈õat ‡••^(^([8]))

Having created the entire universe, the Supreme Brahma entered it. This was expressed by the Vedic seers as a story.

After being created, the creature required food and other things for sustenance. How is it possible to manage all this without an overseer? It was thus that Brahma became ƒ™≈õvara - the controller. The aspect of omnipresence is referenced by the term paramƒÅtmƒÅ whereas parame≈õvara refers to the aspect of the omnipotent ruler of the universe. The same principle thus appears in two forms to our words and thoughts.

What is the ƒÅtmƒÅ?

Whatever a being refers to when he says ‚ÄòI‚Äô, ‚Äòme‚Äô, is the ƒÅtmƒÅ (Self)^(^([9])). (See the second chapter) The object referenced by the word aham (I) is the self. The self is consciousness in its essential state. When this consciousness assumes the body and other instruments of karma, it becomes known as the jƒ´va or jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ. Sometimes, the complete collection of the body, sense organs, mind, and other instruments is referred to as the ƒÅtmƒÅ. This is the normal practice of common people. Even the mind is referred to by the word ƒÅtmƒÅ. The jƒ´va other than the mind and body is also known as the ƒÅtmƒÅ. An old saying goes:

yaccƒÅpnoti yadƒÅdatte yaccƒÅtti vi·π£ayƒÅniha
yaccƒÅsya santato bhƒÅva·∏• tasmƒÅdƒÅtmeti kathyate
Li·πÖgapurƒÅ·πáa 1.70.96

‚ÄúWhatever obtains (what comes), whatever takes (what it wants), whatever experiences the objects of the universe, whatever endures without a gap, is known as the ƒÅtmƒÅ.‚Äù

The jƒ´va is the gross form or at the centre of the individual in the happenings of the world. The inner seed of the jƒ´va is the ƒÅtmƒÅ.

The State of the Jƒ´va

When an upƒÅdhi (limiting adjunct) is applied to the ƒÅtmƒÅ, it becomes known as the jƒ´va. An upƒÅdhi is something - ƒÅdhi - that can be said to be externally added. External events like suffering (vyƒÅdhi) and disease are also upƒÅdhis. The word upƒÅdhi is also used in the sense of a title or a designation. If a pink rose is kept next to a transparent glass marble, the marble appears pink in colour. The colour pink is an upƒÅdhi for the marble. A garland of flowers is strung using a thread. The fragrance of the flowers becomes an upƒÅdhi for the thread that is, the thread acquires a quality that did not belong to it. An aspect that does not belong to a thing but is attached to it externally is an upƒÅdhi. Once the universe is created, it has to be administered and hence the contact with the universe. Therefore, the Supreme Brahma assumes a few upƒÅdhis. When the ƒÅtmƒÅ appears with these upƒÅdhis, it is known as the jƒ´va. When the actionless ƒÅtmƒÅ is seen as an effect, it becomes known as a jƒ´va.

Let us clarify the meanings of a few repeatedly used terms such as jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ, paramƒÅtmƒÅ and ƒ™≈õvara.

We see growth and decline in every living being. Ingestion of food and its egestion are seen in all animals. All living beings - including plants - take in food and extrude something else. Growth comes from intake and decline comes when intake reduces. This is something that the jƒ´va does. It fattens the body for its first twenty years and wears out the body for the rest of its life. Insentient objects work due to human contact. To humans, they are mere implements. Objects that cannot act by themselves and need something else for their movement are termed ja·∏ça (insentient). The Gƒ´tƒÅ refers to such objects as aparƒÅ. It is an inferior grade of creation.

The jƒ´va holds its inner consciousness and external insentient objects together. The ƒÅtmƒÅ assumes various forms to accomplish a variety of tasks. Those forms are upƒÅdhis.

The world exists because of the jƒ´va. It is because of the existence of the jƒ´va that the mind and other organs are functional. We should understand that man comprises two parts - the jƒ´va and the non-jƒ´va. The insentient part is the non-jƒ´va. But it should not be despised as inferior. We are familiar only with the inferior part while the superior part is beyond our senses. We can see the superior aspect only via the inferior part. We must strive to understand the unfamiliar through the familiar.

The seed of consciousness within a jƒ´va is the ƒÅtmƒÅ or the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ. The layer outside it is the body. The jƒ´va is a combination of the inner ƒÅtmƒÅ and the external body. Worldly actions are dependent on external appearances. When a person known to us is dressed in a khaki uniform with ribbons and wears red headgear, he is known as a soldier. If the same person appears to us with his head shaved and donning saffron robes, he is known as a sa·πÉnyƒÅsin. Similarly, the ƒÅtmƒÅ along with the organs of action and the organs of knowledge such as the body is known variously as a jƒ´va, animal, being, and a living thing.

Jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ-ParamƒÅtmƒÅ

In the innumerable mass of living beings in this world, when each being is considered separately, that unique being is known as vya·π£·π≠i. When the entire set of jƒ´vas is considered together, that group is referred to as sama·π£·π≠i according to ≈õƒÅstric terminology. A hundred-rupee note is sama·π£·π≠i. When each rupee coin is counted individually and separately, it is known as vya·π£·π≠i.

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-Jƒ´va-ƒ™≈õvara (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The State of ƒ™≈õvara

From the perspective of the visible world, the invisible and divisionless part of the universe, Supreme Brahman is known as ƒ™≈õvara or Parame≈õvara. When the pure, formless, and actionless Brahman assumes the position of the universal controller, it is known as Parame≈õvara. There are no differences such as the ruler and ruled in the transcendental state of Brahman. When that consciousness exists as part of the world and is seen as the ruler of the universe, it is known as ƒ™≈õvara.

This cursory explanation is a necessary introduction to the following topic. Our subsequent inquiry will become easy if we know at least the broad meaning of terms such as jƒ´va, jagat, ƒ™≈õvara, ƒÅtmƒÅ and Brahman. Let us now return to the treatise.

Insentient Prak·πõti

The thing we know directly is the world. That indeed is Prak·πõti. ≈öƒÅstric deliberation begins with this. Prak·πõti is of two kinds - aparƒÅ or inferior and parƒÅ or superior. The former (and visible aspect) is better known to us. It has eight parts to it.

bh≈´mirƒÅpo‚Äônalo vƒÅyu·∏• kha·πÉ mano buddhireva ca
aha·πÉkƒÅra itƒ´ya·πÉ me bhinnƒÅ prak·πõtira·π£·π≠adhƒÅ
BG 7.4

Earth, water, fire, air, and the sky are the five primordial elements. Their respective qualities - smell, taste, light, touch and sound are experienced by the mind, the intellect and ego - which constitute the anta·∏•kara·πáa. Thus these eight (five sense organs and three mental components) are the components of Prak·πõti which form the functional implements of the power of the Supreme Brahman.

The first five of these elements combine and work with external facing sensory organs - the nose, tongue, eyes, skin and the ear. The mind (manas), intellect (buddhi) and ego (aha·πákƒÅra) are anta·∏•kara·πáa.

There is a school of thought that there are four anta·∏•kara·πáa. This school includes citta (thought, intention) as the fourth organ. But if we were to add something like this, we should add many more components such as memory. Such issues are best dealt with by considering all such components as parts of the manas.

The function of the manas is to know the objects of the world. The buddhi processes the information given by the manas and decides what is suitable or not. Aha·πákƒÅra assigns an objective to the buddhi. Whenever an object is perceived, it is natural to consider the question, “What of it to me?” This natural practice of extending the personal ‚ÄòI‚Äô during the perception of every object with is aha·πákƒÅra. (There is a separate appendix that deals with the topic of aha·πákƒÅra).

Thus the universe comprises the five primordial elements, five organs of sensory perception and the three anta·∏•kara·πáa. Adding the five organs of action (speech, hands, legs and the two nether orifices) to the mentioned makes up the eighteen important parts of human life. This world is thus the arena of action of these eight or eighteen parts.

KƒÅlidƒÅsa describes the eight bodies of the supreme ≈öiva by replacing manas, buddhi and aha·πákƒÅra with the sun, moon and the yajamƒÅna (the performer of a yaj√±a). ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya, like KƒÅlidƒÅsa, praises Lord Dak·π£i·πáƒÅm≈´rti in the following verse.

bh≈´rambhƒÅsyanalo‚Äônilo‚ÄômbaramaharnƒÅtho himƒÅ·πÉ≈õu·∏• pumƒÅn
ityƒÅbhƒÅti carƒÅcarƒÅtmakamida·πÉ yasyaiva m≈´rtya·π£·π≠akam

Amarasimha, the creator of the Amarakosha, accepts the primacy of the eight-fold form of the Supreme ≈öiva.

a·π£·π≠am≈´rtyahirbudhnyo mahƒÅkƒÅlo mahƒÅna·π≠a·∏•

Sentient Prak·πõti

The previous section dealt with the eight parts of the aparƒÅ or inferior prak·πõti that is deemed inferior as it is insentient and not independent. Manas, buddhi and aha·πákƒÅra are also insentient as they are incapable of doing anything without contact with the jƒ´va. They act only when the jƒ´va-consciousness enters them. This is why the jƒ´va is regarded as belonging to the parƒÅ category or superior prak·πõti.

apareyam-itas-tvanyƒÅ·πÉ prak·πõti·πÉ viddhi me parƒÅm
jƒ´vabh≈´tƒÅ·πÉ mahƒÅbƒÅho yayeda·πÉ dhƒÅryate jagat
BG 7.5

The world is of the jƒ´va and for the jƒ´va. The world does not exist without the jƒ´va. There is no reason for the world to exist without the jƒ´va. The world consists of the implements needed to satisfy the reason for a jƒ´va‚Äôs existence. The world is the arena of opportunity for the jƒ´va. The jƒ´va lacks fulfillment without the world. Thus the world and the jƒ´va are symbiotically related. They constitute the top and the bottom of the body of prak·πõti.

The jƒ´va is a subject in the empire of prak·πõti. The five primordial elements and others constitute its officials. Who is its king? Parame≈õvara - the Supreme controller - the aspect of Supreme Brahman that controls - whose functional forms are BrahmƒÅ, Vi·π£·πáu and ≈öiva.

aha·πÉ k·πõtsnasya jagata·∏• prabhava·∏• pralayastathƒÅ
BG 7.6

Both the world and the jƒ´va are endowed with form. Hence they undergo various modifications such as birth and death. ƒ™≈õvara is not subject to birth and death. While he himself is without birth or death, ƒ™≈õvara is the reason behind the modifications of the world and the jƒ´va such as birth and death. Thus Supreme Brahman is of the form of the trinity of BrahmƒÅ (the creator), Vi·π£·πáu (the preserver) and ≈öiva (the destroyer).

The Marks of Brahman

How is one to recognise the existence of ƒ™≈õvara? The characteristics of the presence of ƒ™≈õvara are described in the four verses beginning from “raso‚Äôhamapsu” to “dharmƒÅviruddho bh≈´te·π£u”.

raso‚Äôham apsu kaunteya prabhƒÅsmi ≈õa≈õi-s≈´ryayo·∏•
pra·πáava·∏• sarva-vede·π£u ≈õabda·∏• khe pauru·π£a·πÉ n·πõ·π£u
pu·πáyo gandha·∏• p·πõithivyƒÅ·πÉ ca teja≈õ-cƒÅsmi vibhƒÅvasau

The taste in food and drink, the light in the sun and the moon, enterprise in humankind, effulgence in fire, life in organisms, the austerity among the austere, the intelligence of the intelligent, the strength of the strong that is devoid of selfishness, the desire of those who do not perform adharma - all of these show the power of Brahman. Whatever is excellent in the world are all marks of the greatness of Brahman.

Thus, svƒÅmƒ´ here has mentioned only those qualities that are essentially the best because he wants to enumerate the salient signs and not everything. Even though all, including greed and the inclination for evil, is Brahman, BhagavƒÅn here talks only about the important marks. AdhƒÅrmic works come under the purview of Brahman but do not constitute its main markers. “Dharma + aviruddho bh≈´tesu” (that which is not against dharma). The same expression is seen in the tenth chapter as well.

Whatever in this world is glorious, auspicious, and brilliant is to be known as a mark of Brahman. There is a certain value associated with every single thing in this world. Whatever is tranquility in speech, whatever is acquiring and preservation in the incoming and outgoing of breath, whatever is the ability to do things with the hands, whatever is the power of movement in the legs, whatever is the power of satiation in rain, the energy in lightning (electricity) that is capable of many things, the handsome appearance in domestic animals, light in the stars - all these manifest Parabrahman. They are to be worshipped considering that Brahman is in them.

The Element of Asat in the World

As we just saw, the divine manifests in both human and superhuman activities. Just as what is considered useful has a place in our lives, even that which we consider useless has a place in our life‚Äôs arena. Even those seemingly devoid of value are divine in nature.

nilayana·πÉ cƒÅnilayana·πÉ ca

satya·πÉ cƒÅn·πõta·πÉ ca
- Taittirƒ´yopani·π£at

He became the well-founded and that without a foundation, the intelligent and the non-intelligent, the true and the untrue.

The above ≈öruti text has the same gist.

ye caiva sƒÅttvikƒÅ bhƒÅvƒÅ rƒÅjasƒÅs tƒÅmasƒÅ≈õ ca ye
matta eveti tƒÅn viddhi na tvaha·πÉ te·π£u te mayi
BG 7.12

Whatever is endowed with the qualities of sattva, rajas, or tamas, have all emanated from Brahman. But Brahman is not in those gu·πáas and their modifications. The gu·πáas, however, are in Brahman.

The ocean has water-bubbles and foam in it. But the foam does not contain the ocean in it. The sky contains clouds that are formed of water droplets; but the sky is not in the cloud. The body contains so many substances that are not really parts of the body. Hair and nails arise from the body, but are not necessary for the maintenance of life. Similarly, in prak·πõti - the body of Brahman - many things occur such as the imbalances of the gu·πáas such as exuberances in rajas and tamas. But those are not characteristics of Brahman. Brahman is not ‚Äòpresent‚Äô in them.

The Necessity for the Imbalance of the Gu·πáas

The quality of asat - that which is not sƒÅttvika - which refers to rƒÅjasa and tƒÅmasa are needed for the functioning of the world. Just sattva by itself is insufficient. The ≈õƒÅstras have mentioned these three gu·πáas at every step.

Why three gu·πáas? Why not just two? Or four for that matter? Conflict in this world becomes possible because of an “odd” number. No conflict is possible with only one. If there are two, one can defeat the other. A third is needed to separate the two. This imbalance has to exist constantly. The world cannot exist without this imbalance. For the world‚Äôs existence, that is, for the world‚Äôs activities to take place, a conflict amongst these three gu·πáas is fundamentally necessary. Prak·πõti has established this in her creation. “O Human, I have set up this conflict amongst these three gu·πáas. Overcome them if you can”, is a challenge that prak·πõti has thrown at us.

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-Jƒ´va-ƒ™≈õvara (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

MƒÅyƒÅ

Why does this discernment of thought not exist normally in people? BhagavƒÅn answers:

mƒÅyƒÅyƒÅ‚Äôpah·πõtaj√±ƒÅnƒÅ·∏•

MƒÅyƒÅ has taken away the discerning ability of people.

MƒÅyƒÅ is a special mechanism in the operation of prak·πõti. It is an error or mistake that arises during an inconsistency during the comprehension of other objects by the mind. Consistency here refers to compatibility; not just a lack of opposition but also positive agreement. It is important that there be agreement between these two aspects to see an object properly.

1. The seer‚Äôs vision has to be fit.
2. Adequate light should fall on the object of sight.

A deficiency in even one of these hampers the knowledge of the object. A lacuna in either the seer‚Äôs visual acuity or in how the object is viewed will lead to false or incomplete knowledge. Nothing else needs to be said for defects in both. Tradition terms the lacuna in the seer‚Äôs vision as avidyƒÅ and the change in the seen (say, the shine of silver mistakenly seen in nacre) is known as mƒÅyƒÅ. AvidyƒÅ that has the jƒ´va as its locus and the world-deluding MƒÅyƒÅ are counterparts that mutually reinforce each other.

The world dances; the eye throbs. The resultant vision is that of mƒÅyƒÅ.

A man is travelling to a town at dusk when darkness falls. He sees an object on the way. It appears to sway from side to side. He thinks it to be a snake and runs away afraid. He shivers and sweats. Another approaches him and inquires about the reason for his fear. When told that it was because of a snake, the latter laughs and tells him that it was not a snake but a piece of rope. MƒÅyƒÅ is that which made a rope to appear as a snake in dim light. That which made the man unable to see through that fiction is his own avidyƒÅ.

MƒÅyƒÅ is not falsehood. Neither is it true. The rope elicited all those reactions such as fear and sweating that a real snake would. The ‚Äòsnake‚Äô he saw appeared to be a snake, even though it was not. The memory of a snake seen elsewhere superimposed on the substratum of the rope caused the delusion of the snake. Thus MƒÅyƒÅ is that unique set of circumstances that makes one thing appear as another. MƒÅyƒÅ is not entirely a lie; but is definitely not the truth either. In the preceding story, the delusion would not have occurred had either the piece of rope or the memory of the snake not been there. That which caused fear and suffering in the person even before he could analyse the situation is avidyƒÅ.

When we travel in the hot sun in automobiles or trains, we sometimes see ‚Äòlakes‚Äô shimmering far away. Those are not lakes in reality but heat haze. Due to the variation in temperature from the air near the hot ground to the cooler air above it, air density gradually decreases with increasing temperature, thereby varying the refractive index of the air. This produces a shimmering effect that the seer considers water. This is MƒÅyƒÅ. The play of air and temperature outside and the thirst within.

When we lift our heads, it appears as if a blue clothed canopy has been pitched above us. But there is no tent or fabric or plank in the sky; it is space; empty space. The blue colour of the sky is an illusion. Due to the scattering of blue light by the earth‚Äôs atmosphere, the sky appears blue. Whatever the reason might be, this misapprehension in our vision is well known. That error stems from mƒÅyƒÅ.

Let us look at one more example. Assume we are travelling from Bengaluru to Maisuru. When our train reaches Maddur station, suppose that we see the train from Maisuru start for Bengaluru through the window. Though our train is stationary, it appears as if it is our train that is moving and not the train from Maisuru. The masked or changed appearance of the actual situation presented to our minds is mƒÅyƒÅ. A thing appearing as something else is mƒÅyƒÅ. Also, the non-appearance of an existing thing is also mƒÅyƒÅ.

The Twofold Nature of MƒÅyƒÅ

MƒÅyƒÅ acts in two ways.

1. Showing a thing as something else. This power of mƒÅyƒÅ is known as vik·π£epa. A waterless desert in the afternoon sun shining appears as a reservoir of water from afar. That is a mirage. That is an example of mƒÅyƒÅ‚Äôs vik·π£epa.
2. Masking an existing thing and showing it as non-existent is ƒÄvara·πáa. A big tree makes its generating seed invisible. When a plant grows into a big tree, we get the impression that the tree had existed in the same state forever. It makes us forget that a seed was its cause. MƒÅyƒÅ‚Äôs power of concealing the truth is known as ƒÄvara·πáa. The outer beauty of the body conceals urine, stools, and pus from bothering our mind. This is the power of ƒÄvara·πáa.

It is not possible to elucidate this two-fold mƒÅyƒÅ further because mƒÅyƒÅ can be considered existent via one perspective and non-existent via another. It is present if we consider it to be there and absent if we consider it as not there. MƒÅyƒÅ is something that is impossible to exactly delineate.

sannƒÅpyasannƒÅpyubhayƒÅtmikƒÅ no bhinnƒÅpyabhinnƒÅpyubhayƒÅtmikƒÅ no
sƒÅ·πÖgƒÅpyana·πÖgƒÅpyubhayƒÅtmikƒÅ no mahƒÅdbhutƒÅnirvacanƒ´yar≈´pƒÅ
Vivekac≈´·∏çƒÅma·πái 111

Neither being nor non-being; not simultaneously being and non-being; Not different; Not non-different; not simultaneously different and non-different. Not endowed with parts; not unendowed with parts; not simultaneously both. It is a great wonder and is beyond verbal description - such as ‚ÄúThis its origin; thus its existence‚Äù and so on.

The person who overcomes beginningless avidyƒÅ that is propagated through the succession of births is unaffected by mƒÅyƒÅ.

In conclusion, whatever false appearance we call a delusion or an error or mistaken perception is caused by mƒÅyƒÅ. We can see more of it in other places.

The Dominance of MƒÅyƒÅ

The reason for this long discussion on mƒÅyƒÅ is the impact it has on our lives. MƒÅyƒÅ is the universal power that brings the error of avidyƒÅ in the perceiver‚Äôs intellect to fruition. Because of that film on our perception, we are unable to see the ever present association between jagat and ƒ™≈õvara or the essential relationship between the jƒ´va and paramƒÅtmƒÅ. MƒÅyƒÅ causes the jƒ´va to view its normally perceived world as ever permanent. It is also the cause of the jƒ´va‚Äôs ego-centric delusions such as, ‚ÄúI am the ruler, I am the enjoyer‚Äù. Mighty indeed is mƒÅyƒÅ. It is impossible for us to comprehend the reality of the relationship between jagat and ƒ™≈õvara or that between jƒ´va and ƒ™≈õvara without overcoming mƒÅyƒÅ. As mƒÅyƒÅ is the greatest impediment towards the knowledge of reality, we had to have this lengthy discourse on it.

The Limitations of the Intellect

Just as fog envelops the body‚Äôs eye, the mind‚Äôs eye, so to speak, is also covered by a fog. The mind‚Äôs rays of attention are scattered on the one hand by the latent impressions of previous births (vƒÅsanas), and on the other hand by the tastes, glitter, and glamour of the world. Similarly, while there are long standing habits and unexamined beliefs on one side, new thought processes and new developments in the world seem to fly in their face. Our intellectual faculties are scattered between the two. While man‚Äôs intellectual capacity is essentially limited, it is also paralysed by latent vƒÅsanas and old beliefs. With these limits, the mind‚Äôs deficiencies double. One side of the mind is fogged and the world it sees changes every moment, escaping any kind of comprehension and analysis. How therefore can one glimpse reality with partial vision on one side and constant change on the other? With that, even tin will be valued like silver. The crow will be welcomed as a koel. The foam of water bubbles will be mistaken for a white rocky mountain. A lake stagnant with moss and hyacinth appears like a lush meadow. Thus does universal mƒÅyƒÅ trick the mind and intellect out of comprehending reality.

tribhir gu·πáa-mƒÅyƒÅir bhƒÅvair ebhi·∏• sarvam ida·πÉ jagat
mohita·πÉ nƒÅbhijƒÅnƒÅti mƒÅmebhya·∏• param avyayam ‡••
daivƒ´ hye·π£ƒÅ gu·πáa-mayƒ´ mama mƒÅyƒÅ duratyayƒÅ
mƒÅm eva ye prapadyante mƒÅyƒÅm etƒÅ·πÉ taranti te ‡••
BG 7.13, 7.14

The three gu·πáas:sattva, rajas and tamas present in prak·πõti have enveloped the world in delusion. As Brahma is beyond those three gu·πáas, the world cannot understand that Brahma is ever unchanging. MƒÅyƒÅ comprising these three gu·πáas is of divine origin and is hence difficult to overcome.

The principle of jagat, jƒ´va, and ƒ™≈õvara eludes us because the veil of mƒÅyƒÅ shrouds us. With that veil cast off, the Supreme Truth can be attained. Has not BhagavƒÅn himself declared that his mƒÅyƒÅ is inscrutable? BhagavƒÅn himself shows the way by declaring that only those who take refuge in him are able to cross mƒÅyƒÅ and attain the Supreme reality.

Crossing MƒÅyƒÅ

MƒÅyƒÅ with the gu·πáa triad is of divine origin. We should not complain that this mƒÅyƒÅ - this delusion - is cheating us because its place of creation is Brahma. Those who bear the thought of the Supreme Brahma in their minds are able to subdue mƒÅyƒÅ. MƒÅyƒÅ is one of the inferior activities of prak·πõti. How is it possible to get rid of something inferior? By encouraging the superior. To get rid of malodour, one uses perfumes. MƒÅyƒÅ, similarly, can be overcome through the practice of divine presence - by encouraging the knowledge of reality. As our conviction in the existence of the divine becomes firmer, the grip of mƒÅyƒÅ loosens.

The Worship of BhagavƒÅn

It is thus established that the worship of BhagavƒÅn is essential for the knowledge of reality. A couple of words now, on the method of worship

chatur-vidhƒÅ bhajante mƒÅ·πÉ janƒÅ·∏• suk·πõitino’rjuna ‡•§
ƒÅrto jij√±ƒÅsur arthƒÅrthƒ´ j√±ƒÅnƒ´ cha bharatar·π£abha ‡••
BG 7.16

Those who take refuge in BhagavƒÅn are of four kinds.

  1. ƒÄrta (The distressed) - Those who resort to the divine only when they encounter difficulties in life personifying the adage - ‚Äòsa·πÉka·π≠a ba·πÉdƒÅga vƒï·πÉka·π≠arama·πáa‚Äô - ‚ÄòVenkataramana is resorted to only when there is distress‚Äô. 2. Jij√±ƒÅsu (those desirous of knowing) - Those who are curious about the knowledge of the Supreme; students of the ≈õƒÅstras. 3. ArthƒÅrthi (those seeking material things) - Those who keep vows to attain specific material objectives. 4. J√±ƒÅnƒ´ (the knower) - those that have realised the knowledge of reality experientially.

All these four are suk·πõtis which means that they possess the pu·πáya from their good deeds. All the four are noble. The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ among them is one who has attained the object of his intention.

j√±ƒÅnƒ´ tvƒÅtmaiva me matam

The j√±ƒÅnƒ´ is a kevalƒÅtmƒÅ: one who has attained union with ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa.

bah≈´nƒÅ·πÉ janmanƒÅm ante j√±ƒÅnavƒÅn mƒÅ·πÉ prapadyate

BG 7.19

‚ÄúOthers, over several lives, gradually attain to the Supreme Abode through meditation upon the principle that VƒÅsudeva is everything. Such great personages are rare to find‚Äù.

The way of overcoming mƒÅyƒÅ is through the practice of ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs presence. None need be disheartened that such a practice is impossible for them. One must practice with patience and without haste. The thing to remember is that this practice takes time. Let as much time be taken as required. As time is infinite, there is no need to hurry. But it is important that the practice being undertaken is done thoroughly. Be it a man or a woman, devotion to BhagavƒÅn can be practised according to one‚Äôs birth, one‚Äôs bent of mind, and as possible by one‚Äôs intellect. Let any method of worship be followed.

yo yo yƒÅ·πÉ yƒÅ·πÉ tanu·πÉ bhakta·∏• ≈õraddhayƒÅrchitum ichchhati

BG 7.21 to 7.23

‚ÄúWhoever worships whatever divine form with ≈õraddhƒÅ, I will firm up the ≈õraddhƒÅ for him in that form. If he has worshipped the form with ≈õraddhƒÅ, his desires will be fulfilled. I have established this arrangement‚Äù.

When these words are recalled by us, it becomes clear how our religious animosities are nothing but insubordination (to the divine) and a lack of humility. Not just Hindus but Muslims and Christians too should pay attention to this principle. It is not important whether the Supreme Being is with or without form. But the devotion and ≈õraddhƒÅ of the devotee is all important. Also important are the devotee‚Äôs mental attitude and the keenness of his yearning for the divine.

Keeping one‚Äôs mind in the divine is the same as not keeping one‚Äôs mind on things non-divine - which translates to releasing one‚Äôs mind from the non-divine. What then about one‚Äôs spouse and children? Are those relationships not boons from the divine? The one practising divine presence everywhere sees all relationships as ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs blessing. Such a person regards his or her family duties as devotional service to BhagavƒÅn. There is nothing for such a person that is not BhagavƒÅn.

ichchhƒÅ-dve·π£a-samutthena dvandva-mohena bhƒÅrata

ye·π£ƒÅ·πÉ tvanta-gata·πÉ pƒÅpa·πÉ janƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ pu·πáya-karma·πáƒÅm

BG 7.27, 7.28

‚ÄúAll beings at the time of their birth lose their ability for discernment when they are subservient to desires, hatred, ego, envy, and other pairs of opposites. Those whose pƒÅpa has come to an end and those who have performed pu·πáya become free of this pair of opposites and take refuge in ƒ™≈õvara‚Äù.

This is the gist. Devotion to the divine means giving up selfishness and infatuation. As the thought that one‚Äôs family, kith and kin are blessings from the divine grows, selfishness and infatuation wane. As they wane, the jƒ´va becomes purer. As the jƒ´va becomes purer, contemplation of reality becomes easier. The one with the knowledge of reality understands what in one‚Äôs life is owed to the world and what is owed to one‚Äôs own inner self. Such a person, acting for the good of both, becomes free of worry. This is tranquillity.

The Upani·π£ad uses the example of the spider (≈™r·πáanƒÅbhi) to explain creation. The spider uses the sticky substance within itself to make a thread and weaves a web with it. It creates its own web-kingdom with the material created out of its own body and rules it as its king. During the creation of the web, it forgets that it is the creator. One who sings for one‚Äôs own happiness forgets oneself in the sweetness of one‚Äôs own voice. One enjoys it as if listening to someone else‚Äôs voice. The spider can similarly feel that its web creation was another‚Äôs creation that it had conquered for itself. Thus a creator of something can be deluded into thinking that he is different from his creation after seeing the wonderful things of his own creation. In reality, the creator, the instrument, and the creation are fundamentally one. The sentience of Brahma is the doer, prak·πõti is the instrument and the world is the creation. MƒÅyƒÅ is the strange and wonderful play of the world. The indivisible unity of the root cause of the universe is veiled by the illusion of mƒÅyƒÅ. ≈öƒÅstra shows us the concealing curtain and asks us to tear it and cast it away. As our ≈õraddhƒÅ in the Supreme Cause grows, the effect of mƒÅyƒÅ on us weakens.
