Summary

The svƒÅmƒ´ instructs Arjuna on the greatness of meditating upon the letter Om in the eighth chapter. Om is the essence, the representation of everything. The practice of meditation is predominantly emotional. The fundamental principle explained here is that such an emotional state can be reached with regular practice.

Chapter 8.Ak·π£arabrahmayoga orPra·πáavƒÅrthayoga

(The Yoga of the meaning of Om)

In the previous chapters was discussed the practice of karma as an external means of sƒÅdhanƒÅ. From the second to the sixth chapter, karma is important. Bhakti and j√±ƒÅna are only incidentally mentioned. Chapters nine to eighteen discuss the internal sƒÅdhanƒÅ of bhakti and j√±ƒÅna. The eighth chapter is like a bridge between these two stages. The previous chapters have demonstrated the principle of ƒÅtmƒÅ and the greatness of BhagavƒÅn. To realise this principle, the practice of an inward-looking sƒÅdhanƒÅ becomes necessary. This sƒÅdhanƒÅ is dhyƒÅna. SwƒÅmƒ´ is now ready to show the way to bring the form of the divine in the mind, by meditating upon profound symbols such as the pra·πáava. It is only fit that this chapter has been called ‚ÄòBrahmƒÅk·π£aranirde≈õa‚Äô by ancient philosophers because pra·πáava is verily the letter that denotes Brahma.

The important topics discussed in this chapter are -

  1. Some terminology 2. Importance of the moment of death 3. UpƒÅsanƒÅ of the letter denoting the Brahma 4. Adherence to karma with constant remembrance of Brahma 5. The two ways open for the jƒ´va

It appears that Arjuna had not clearly understood the full meaning of some technical terms used by BhagavƒÅn ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa earlier. Sometimes, our understanding of a word might be enough for us to roughly recognise the meaning but might fall short of the rigour required to explain it to someone else. We all use the word ‚Äòman‚Äô. If someone asks us the meaning of this word, we will find it difficult to explain. It is not enough to say, ‚Äúman is a kind of animal‚Äù. Similarly, when asked what rice is, it is not enough to answer that rice is a kind of grain. A proper, scientific answer can be provided for these questions by the dictionary. When this is the case with ordinary words, the terms used in advanced ≈õƒÅstras must be much more difficult. However, continuing with the study of ≈õƒÅstras without fully understanding these terms is meaningless. Such terms used in ≈õƒÅstras are collectively known as paribhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ. The common meaning of karma is work ‚Äî any work. The ≈õƒÅstric meaning of the word is ‚Äúspecific action that is ordained by ≈öruti and Sm·πõti, and results in gaining better worlds‚Äù.

Arjuna‚Äôs questions about the meanings of the technical terms are in the first two verses. Commentators have counted them variously as seven and eight, though there is no real difference between the two groups. Let us look at these questions, one by one.

1. Question: Ki·πÉ tad-brahma? ‚Äî What is that Brahma?

In this question, ‚Äòthat‚Äô ‚Äî ‚ÄòTat‚Äô implies an earlier reference. Arjuna is asking the meaning of ‚ÄúbrahmƒÅk·π£ara-samudbhavam‚Äù in the third chapter, and ‚ÄúbrahmƒÅrpa·πáa·πÉ bra·∏•mahavi·∏•‚Äù in the fourth chapter.

Answer: Ak·π£ara·πÉ brahma parama·πÉ ‡•§

Brahma is that which cannot be destroyed and is most supreme.

The word ‚Äòak·π£ara·πÉ‚Äô means both eternal and omnipresent. ‚ÄòK·π£ara‚Äô is destruction. Ak·π£ara means indestructible with respect to time and also with respect to place. ‚ÄòParama·πÉ‚Äô means the basis of all that is desired by man, and yet above it it all. ‚ÄúA·πáora·πáƒ´yƒÅn mahato mahƒ´yƒÅn ‡•§‚Äù, ‚Äúavyakto‚Äôyamacintyo‚Äôya·πÉ ‡•§‚Äù, ‚Äúacalo‚Äôya·πÉ sanƒÅtana·∏•‚Äù.

2. Question: Kim adhyƒÅtma·πÉ?

What is adhyƒÅtma?

Answer: SvabhƒÅvo‚ÄôdhyƒÅtmam-ucyate

‚ÄúHuman nature ‚Äì its entire structure - is called adhyƒÅtma‚Äù

A human being is the sum total of his body, senses, mind, intellect, ego, jƒ´va, and ƒÅtmƒÅ. This is collectively known as adhyƒÅtma. The collection of the means and channels through which a jƒ´va can connect with the world and is able to conduct its activities is adhyƒÅtma.

It is said in the bhƒÅ·π£ya of ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya ‚Äî ‚Äúparasya brahma·πáa·∏• pratideha·πÉ pratyagƒÅtma-bhƒÅva·∏• svabhƒÅva·∏• ‡•§ ‚Ä¶ ƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ dehamadhik·πõtya pratyagƒÅtmatayƒÅ prav·πõtta·πÉ paramƒÅrtha-brahmƒÅvasƒÅna·πÉ vastu‚Äù.

‚ÄúThe nature of Brahma is to exist in every body as the indwelling self. The thing that is the indwelling self of the body which is ultimately the same as the Supreme Brahma is adhyƒÅtma.‚Äù

a. The ƒÅtmƒÅ that is in the state of the jƒ´va is adhyƒÅtma. The jƒ´va includes attributes like the body, mind, etc.
b.The state where ƒÅtmƒÅ takes the form of the jƒ´va is adhyƒÅtma. All relationships created by a man for himself are adhyƒÅtma.

3. Question: ki·πÉ karma? ‚ÄúWhat is karma?‚Äù

Answer: bh≈´tabhƒÅvodbhavakaro visarga·∏• karmasa·πÉj√±ita·∏• ‡•§

‚ÄúKarma is the agglomeration of all the ways in which all beings use their energies and wealth in tasks that result in their rebirth‚Äù.

Our transaction with the world is in the form of giving and taking. In every moment, through his body, speech, and mind, man constantly releases parts of himself into the world around him. This constant giving is karma. Since a part of him spreads itself out in the world, its results and reactions come back to him in different forms, as the fruit of his karma. He is reborn again and again to reap these fruits ‚Äî to discharge his debts and to experience the impressions of his past. Thus, karma is the collective name for all dealings with the world that cause rebirth. In short pu·πáya and pƒÅpa constitute karma.

4. Question: Adhibh≈´ta·πÉ ca ki·πÉ? ‚ÄúWhat is adhibh≈´ta?‚Äù

Answer: Adhibh≈´ta·πÉ k·π£aro bhƒÅva·∏• ‡•§

‚ÄúAll destructible things in this world are adhibh≈´ta.‚Äù

‚ÄúK·π£aro bhƒÅva·∏•‚Äù means destructibility or the characteristic of destruction. ‚ÄòBh≈´ta‚Äô refers to something that has become or has happened. Here, we should pay attention to the difference between the words ‚Äòbeing‚Äô and ‚Äòbecoming‚Äô. Whatever becomes or happens, goes. Therefore it is k·π£ara. Thus, k·π£ara is something that lives for a short while and perishes later.

5. Question: Adhidaiva·πÉ kimucyate? ‚ÄúWhat is called adhi-daiva?‚Äù

Answer: ‚ÄúPuru·π£a≈õ-cƒÅdhi-daivatam‡•§‚Äù ‚Äú(The virƒÅ·π≠) puru·π£a is adhidaivata‚Äù

Brahma‚Äôs energy is present in every being, causing it to engage in various activities. The aggregated energy of all those beings in its most exalted state (the state of Brahma) is the VirƒÅ·π≠ Puru·π£a. This form has been described in the Puru·π£as≈´kta of the Vedas and in the eleventh chapter of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ. Puru·π£a is the Brahma in the form of the world. That is adhidaiva. This meaning has to be connected with

‚Äúdaiva·πÉ caivƒÅtra pa√±cama·πÉ ‡•§‚Äù (BG 18.14)

Adhidaiva is the fundamental energy that is the basis of all actions in the universe. It is the energy of Brahma, the universal consciousness, that creates the universe and controls it. Brahma in action is adhidaiva. That indeed is ƒ™≈õvara.

6. Question: ‚ÄúƒÅdhiyaj√±a·∏• katha·πÉ?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat is the nature of adhiyaj√±a?‚Äù

Answer: ‚Äúadhiyaj√±o‚Äôhameva‚Äù ‚ÄúThat to which the yaj√±a is addressed is adhiyaj√±a. I am that (BhagavƒÅn= ƒ™≈õvara).‚Äù

Yaj√±a is worship. There should be an object for worship. Different types of yaj√±as are expounded in the fourth chapter. Yaj√±as can have different objects of worship such as Indra, Varu·πáa, Soma, or Agni. Thus, when there are different devatƒÅs, are the presiding deities different and yaj√±as different or are they all one and the same? The answer is that even though the names of the devatƒÅs are different, it is only Brahma that is worshipped.

‚Äúeka·πÉ sad viprƒÅ bahudhƒÅ vadanti, indra·πÉ yama·πÉ mƒÅtari≈õvƒÅnamƒÅhu·∏• ‡•§‚Äù
‚Äúsarvadeva-namaskƒÅra·∏• keahava·πÉ pratigacchati ‡•§‚Äù

7. Question: ‚Äúko‚Äôtra dehe‚Äôsmin?‚Äù ‚ÄúWho is in this body?‚Äù

Answer: ‚ÄúAhamevƒÅtra dehe‡•§‚Äù ‚ÄúI (the divine) am the one in this body‚Äù.

The body comprises five sheaths. These sheaths are like a Russian doll - one inside another, yet another inside it and so on. Well-dressed men in the early twentieth century would wear five or six layers of clothes on them ‚Äî an overcoat, a short coat within it, a waistcoat inside that, and then a shirt and a vest inside, and further a jubba also. Similarly, the human body has five layers. The first is annamaya kosha. This is made of flesh, blood, skin, and bone. Within that is the prƒÅ·πáamaya ko≈õa, comprising prƒÅ·πáa, apƒÅna and other vital airs. The third is manomaya, consisting of experiences such as pleasure and pain. The fifth is vij√±ƒÅnamaya, comprising the intellect and decision making abilities. The fifth is ƒÅnandamaya, which comprises bliss. Within this resides the ƒÅtmƒÅ, the basis and origin of all layers. The five ko≈õas are only its attributes. ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is that consciousness which resides within these five ko≈õas.

‚ÄútƒÅsmƒÅt sarvagata·πÉ brahma‚Äù (Therefore is Brahma all-pervading) (BG 3.15)
‚Äúƒ™≈õvara·∏• sarvabh≈´tƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ h·πõdde≈õe‚Äù, (ƒ™≈õvara is situated in the heart of all beings) (BG 18.61)
‚Äúeko deva·∏• sarvabh≈´te·π£u g≈´·∏çha·∏• sarvavyƒÅpƒ´ sarvabh≈´tƒÅntarƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù (There is one deva concealed in all beings who is omnipresent and is the inner self of all beings) (≈övetƒÅ≈õvataropani·π£ad 6.11)

It has to be noted that the object of worship in the sixth question is the same as the worshipper in the seventh question, the only difference between them being their state.

8. Question ‚ÄúprayƒÅ·πáakƒÅle ca katha·πÉ j√±eyo‚Äôsi?‚Äù ‚ÄúHow is a man to know you at the time of the final journey?‚Äù

‚ÄúAt that time of departure, how should one meditate upon you? You have countless forms; your lƒ´lƒÅs are infinite. Which of them should we remember when our end is nigh?‚Äù

A: ‚ÄúantakƒÅle ca mƒÅmeva smaran ‚Ä¶ madbhƒÅva·πÉ yƒÅti‚Äù

‚ÄúIn those last moments, it is enough to meditate upon me in any form. My real nature will be understood.‚Äù.

Meditating upon any form among the infinite forms, any lƒ´lƒÅ among the infinite lƒ´lƒÅs of the divine can show us the presence of the divine.

The sixth verse of this chapter has to be contemplated upon here.

ya·πÉ ya·πÉ vƒÅpi smaran bhƒÅva·πÉ tyajatyante kalevara·πÉ ‡•§
ta·πÉ tamevaiti kaunteya sadƒÅ tadbhƒÅvabhƒÅvita·∏• ‡•• (BG 8.6)
‚ÄúWhichever form the devotee is meditating upon at the time of his end,
BhagavƒÅn shows himself to his devotee in the same form‚Äù.

This is the reason for our practice of naming children after devatƒÅs or Gurus. It is natural for humans to think of their loved ones at the time of death. Our ancients thought that divine names would be called out and the greatness of the divine would come to mind at least under this pretext.

Who knows when the end is going to arrive? Death does not give us prior notice to make an appointment with us. It can come without any warning. Therefore, a wise man is always prepared for it. Constant contemplation of the divine is the preparation.

‚ÄútasmƒÅt sarve·π£u kƒÅle·π£u mƒÅmanusmara yuddhya ca‚Äù (BG 8.7)
‚ÄúRemember me at all times; Fight as you remember me.‚Äù

The Object of DhyƒÅna

Ordinary people require a symbol or a form for dhyƒÅna. However, the supreme Brahma-tattva is ‚Äòacintyar≈´pam‚Äô (beyond description) and ‚Äòanirde≈õyavapu·∏•‚Äô (with a form that cannot be pointed out). Even so, BhagavƒÅn has pointed out two characteristics -

sarvasya dhƒÅtƒÅram-acintyar≈´pam ƒÅdityavar·πáa·πÉ tamasa·∏• parastƒÅt ‡•• (BG 8.9)

  1. Sarvasya dhƒÅtƒÅram ‚Äî One who rules over everything and protects everyone. 2. ƒÄdityavar·πáa·πÉ ‚Äî Bright like the Sun.

These are the main characteristics. The marks of Brahma have been discussed extensively earlier; such as ‚Äúraso‚Äôham apsu‚Äù and ‚ÄúprabhƒÅsmi ≈õa≈õi-s≈´ryayo·∏•‚Äù. We can bring to mind any of these features: ‚Äúya·πÉ ya·πÉ vƒÅpi smaran bhƒÅva·πÉ‚Äù. It is important to concentrate the mind.

The pra·πáava has to be meditated upon during dhyƒÅna. Pra·πáava means ‚Äúprak·πõ·π£·π≠ƒÅ nuti·∏•‚Äù [Most excellent praise] (from the root ·πáu stutau) ‚Äì the praise of Parabrahma.

OmityekƒÅk·π£ara·πÉ brahma vyƒÅharan mƒÅmanusmaran ‡•§ (BG 8.13)
The japa of Om has to be performed while meditating upon BhagavƒÅn.

OmityekƒÅk·π£ara·πÉ brahma ‡•§ (Om the letter denotes Brahma) (GƒÅyatrƒ´-mantra)

Omiti brahma ‡•§ Omitƒ´dagm sarvam (Taittirƒ´yopani·π£ad1.8)
‚ÄúOm itself is Parabrahma. Om is all this (the entire universe)‚Äù

Thus, Upani·π£ads like Ka·π≠ha, MƒÅ·πá·∏ç≈´kya, ChƒÅndogya and B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka extol the greatness of the Pra·πáava.

There are three letters in Om ‚Äî a, u and m. These three letters denote the following, respectively -

  1. a ‚Äî Sat (existence), the gross universe, the earthly plane, the male animal, the waking state, sattvagu·πáa, BhagavƒÅn BrahmƒÅ [Not to be confused with Brahman] 2. u ‚Äî Cit (consciousness), jƒ´va, the subtle universe, the atmosphere, the female animal, the dream state, rajogu·πáa, BhagavƒÅn Vi·π£·πáu 3. m ‚Äî ƒÄnanda (bliss), ƒ™≈õvara, the causal universe (kƒÅra·πáa-prapa√±ca), the sky, an animal of the neuter gender, the state of deep sleep, tamogu·πáa, BhagavƒÅn Rudra. 4. Om ‚Äî (the union of all of the above) = Peaceful, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ, the unmanifested, genderless, the universe, the infinite prak·πõti, virƒÅ·π≠-puru·π£a, transcending the three gu·πáas, Parabrahma.

Thus, the letter om is a symbol that denotes everything. It denotes all existence, all knowledge and all powers and energies. The hidden meaning of this great mantra should be learnt from experienced people. I am not one.

The mantras that have been passed to us through tradition ‚Äî like Om Namah ≈öivƒÅya, Om Namo NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒÅya ‚Äî show us one of the infinite forms of BhagavƒÅn. It is difficult to visualise the infinite. Visualising an image of RƒÅma, K·πõ·π£·πáa, Some≈õvara, Ga·πáapati or ƒÄ√±janeya is not that difficult. M≈´rtis and pictures help with that. Therefore, ordinary people hold on to dhyƒÅna-mantras of a specific deity and engage themselves in its worship. However, the Pra·πáava is not specific to any form; contemplation is its mainstay. It includes both manifest and unmanifest, single and manifold. The three worlds, the three gu·πáas, the three states (jƒÅgrat, svapna and su·π£upti), the three deities ‚Äî the essence of the universe is thus evinced in threes as the separate letters a, u and m ‚Äî and brings to mind one group among the three. Then, the combined letter Om establishes in the mind ‚Äî that the union of these three is greater than the sum of its parts. Initially, such contemplation seems impossible. It becomes possible gradually - little by little - with continuous effort and practice.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 8 Yoga of the Meaning of Om (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Importance of Feeling

During dhyƒÅna, it is not syllables that are important, neither are sound or meaning. Feeling is paramount. The syllable is a means to bring the right feeling to the mind. M≈´rtis and pictures of deities, worship with incense sticks and lamps are also the means to bring to mind the emotion associated with the divine. Therefore, the mind should be made to focus on the meaning of the syllable ‚Äî the feeling associated with the icon. This is dhyƒÅna-yoga.

Is it not easier for dhyƒÅna if the syllable of a mantra has only one meaning, rather than a multitude of them? We saw earlier that pra·πáava can have many meanings; will not the mind get scattered here and there by that? The answer is thus: a mantra that has a single meaning is suitable in the beginning. However, should not the meaning expand gradually? Initially, let it be “Om Nama·∏• ≈öivƒÅya” or “Om Namo NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒÅya”. Steadily, let the focus increasingly move towards Om. It is fine if any one among the various meanings of the pra·πáava strikes the mind. It could be the triad of Brahma, Vi·π£·πáu and Mahe≈õvara ‚Äî or Earth, space and sky ‚Äî or sattva, rajas and tamas ‚Äî or energy, water and food ‚Äî whichever triad of these strikes the mind first, it gradually expands and covers all other triads, and transcends them all. This is the power of practice. As already conveyed, the secret has to be learnt from adepts; I am not one. Let us now move to the next topic.

ananyacetƒÅ·∏• satata·πÉ yo mƒÅ·πÉ bhajati nitya≈õa·∏• ‡•§
tasyƒÅha·πÉ sulabha·∏• pƒÅrtha nityayuktasya yogina·∏• ‡•• (BG 8.14)

‚ÄúA yogi is one who does not let his mind wander, but follows me always. I (BhagavƒÅn) am easily obtained by him, who is always one with me‚Äù

ƒÅbrahma-bhuvanƒÅl-lokƒÅ·∏• punar-ƒÅvartino‚Äôrjuna ‡•§
mƒÅmupetya tu kaunteya punarjanma na vidyate ‡•• (BG 8.16)

The entire universe ‚Äî starting from the world of BrahmƒÅ is born again and again, and perishes each time. “Punarapi janana·πÉ punarapi mara·πáam” is true for everything and everyone, until the jƒ´vatma becomes one with Parabrahma. The liberated, pure ƒÅtmƒÅ always abides in the presence of the Supreme Brahma ‚Äî that is, in the best of lokas. The SvƒÅmi now explains this exalted state.

In the previous chapter, it is said that Brahma exists in two states ‚Äî vyakta or manifest and avyakta or unimanifest. Vyakta is the visible or tangible universe. Avyakta is invisible or something that transcends the visible universe. The single fundamental substratum for both of these is sanƒÅtana (eternal); that is Brahma. Mok·π£a is the constant experience of Brahma. Achieving Mok·π£a is the fulfillment of Yoga.

parastasmƒÅttu bhƒÅvo‚Äônyo‚Äôvyakto‚ÄôvyaktƒÅt sanƒÅtana·∏• ‡•§
ya·∏• sa sarve·π£u bh≈´te·π£u na≈õyatsu na vina≈õyati ‡•• (BG 8.20)
‚ÄúParabrahma is that which is beyond the manifest and unmanifest. It is the eternal element in transient bodies‚Äù.

avyakto‚Äôk·π£ara ityuktastamƒÅhu·∏• paramƒÅ·πÉ gati·πÉ ‡•§
ya·πÉ prƒÅpya na nivartante taddhƒÅma parama·πÉ mama ‡•• (BG 8.21)

After reaching the abode of Brahma which is beyond the universe, intangible and imperishable, there is no returning. That is the supreme abode, the presence of the divine. That is the state of mok·π£a. A sƒÅdhaka might achieve it in his lifetime on earth, in this world. Such mok·π£a is jƒ´vanmukti. Our ≈õrutis and purƒÅ·πáas mention that ·πõ·π£is like ≈öuka and VƒÅmadeva were jƒ´vanmuktas.

Even if that does not happen, if a sƒÅdhaka is free of kƒÅma and krodha and is engrossed only in Brahma, he may attain mok·π£a when he departs from his body and leaves this world. That is videhamukti. Thus, mok·π£a is of two types.

There is no calculation of tithi, vƒÅra and nak·π£atra required for the attainment of mok·π£a. It happens by itself. No outward force can speed it up or slow it down. It is an experience that happens deep within one‚Äôs heart. It does not have external dos and don‚Äôts.

The liberation that is achieved by a jƒ´va after experiencing the fruits of its past actions and finally giving up his body is of two kinds ‚Äî sadyomukti and kramamukti.

Sadyomukti is that which is achieved when a sƒÅdhaka leaves this world and becomes one with Brahma without stopping at any intervening stations. This path is called DevayƒÅna. When a jƒ´va on the way to mukti pauses at other, gradually better lokas, it is kramamukti or pit·πõyƒÅna. The SvƒÅmi describes it thus ‚Äî

agnirjyotiraha·∏• ≈õukla·∏• ·π£a·πámƒÅsƒÅ uttarƒÅya·πáam ‡•§ (BG 8.24)

The characteristics of the path to the Brahma are fire, light, day, purity, and the half of the year that is called uttarƒÅya·πáa.

dh≈´mo rƒÅtristathƒÅ k·πõ·π£·πáa·∏• ·π£a·πámƒÅsƒÅ dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana·πÉ ‡•• (BG 8.25)

The characteristics of the path to the other pu·πáyalokas are smoke, night, darkness, the six months of the year that are known as dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana.

≈õuklak·πõ·π£·πáe gatƒ´ hyete jagata·∏• ≈õƒÅ≈õvate mate ‡•§
ekayƒÅ yƒÅtyanƒÅv·πõttim anyayƒÅ‚Äô‚Äôavartate puna·∏• ‡•• (BG 8.26)

Through devayƒÅna is achieved the state of Brahma and the cessation of births. Through pit·πõyƒÅna, one goes through multiple births ‚Äî gains pu·πáya again and again, spends it, and gains it again ‚Äî thus continues the circle of births.

Pit·πõyƒÅna is the way of gradually better lives ‚Äî good family, justly acquired wealth, good karma, good children, good pastimes ‚Äî these are indicative of pu·πáya. Even if a man established in Brahma is not able to achieve mok·π£a immediately, even if he has to take a few more births because of various reasons, he sometimes attains better worlds and is again born on the earth in suitable families and leads a life established in Brahma.

prƒÅpya pu·πáyak·πõtƒÅn lokƒÅn u·π£itvƒÅ ≈õƒÅ≈õvatƒ´·∏• samƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
≈õucƒ´nƒÅ·πÉ ≈õrƒ´matƒÅ·πÉ gehe yogabhra·π£·π≠o‚ÄôbhijƒÅyate ‡•• (BG 6.41)

Thus, he ascends in steps. This is the mukti of Pit·πõyƒÅna. It is not to be understood as inferior or fearsome. Good progeny and good family are gained by the blessings of Pit·πõdevatas; it is training to the jƒ´va. Should we be scared of training and tests? One who refuses such training is not eligible to experience Brahma.

The belief that death during the uttarƒÅya·πáa brings mok·π£a and death during the dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana brings about rebirth is older than the time of ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa. It is in the Vedas [Ya eva·πÉ vidvƒÅnudagayane pramƒ´yate devƒÅnƒÅmeva mahimƒÅna·πÉ gatvƒÅ’‘dityasya sƒÅyujya·πÉ gacchatyatha yo dak·π£i·πáe pramƒ´yate pit·πõ·πáƒÅmeva mahimƒÅna·πÉ gatvƒÅ candramasassƒÅyujya·πÉ salokatƒÅmƒÅpnoti (Taittirƒ´yopani·π£ad 4)].Bhƒ´·π£ma would have believed in it ‚Äî which is why he bore the severe pain of lying on a bed of arrows and waited for the arrival of uttarƒÅya·πáa.

Should we now believe in it or not? This belief is not troublesome; there is no reason to stop believing it. Just lack of direct evidence is not enough to erase this ancient belief. There should be a concrete reason to disbelieve in it. In any case, what do we lose by believing in it?

We can have three kinds of attitudes towards any concept ‚Äî 1. Belief 2. Disbelief 3. Suspension of belief.

All of us believe in our own existence. We say that eight elephants carrying the world is reality but is a mere story. But in the matter of pa√±cƒÅ·πÖga and jƒÅtaka, we do not argue. If someone condemns it as untrue, we cannot prove it to be true. If someone obstinately argues that it is true, we cannot argue and prove him wrong. When many people have been believing in something for a very long time and it is not really troubling to us, it is better to follow it as much as possible. If someone says that the attack by China [in 1962] was because of the confluence of eight planets, we cannot say that it was not so. If someone says that the two are not related, we cannot argue with them either. Our consideration should only be this ‚Äî on the pretext of the a·π£·π≠agrahas, the minds of at least a few people turned towards the divine. Even that is beneficial. Some people found courage and satisfaction because of those p≈´jas and homas. That is beneficial too.

The concept of uttarƒÅya·πáa-devayƒÅna and dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana-pit·πõyƒÅna should be viewed similarly. It is about something that happens after death ‚Äî something that cannot be seen by us here with our physical eyes. Actually, ordinary people like us cannot clearly discern the difference between uttarƒÅya·πáa and dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana. Physicists or meteorologists may explain the physical difference to us. However, who can explain the passage of a jƒ´va?

The matter in the minds of those who harbour questions about this topic is actually a doubt about the superiority of devayƒÅna and the inferiority of pit·πõyƒÅna. At the bottom of this is the question ‚Äî why should we say that those who die in dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana are inferior? They fear that their end might arrive in dak·π£i·πáƒÅyana. There are two things here.

  1. Pit·πõyƒÅna is not base or vile. If someone thinks that they are eligible for more, they are deluded. That sense of entitlement itself shows their ineligibility. 2. Pit·πõyƒÅna paves the way to obtain worldly wealth, pleasure, prosperity and progeny. How many of us can say no to these?

Those with the firmness and greatness of Bhƒ´·π£ma do not have to raise this question at all. He was a svecchƒÅmara·πái ‚Äî he could give up his body whenever he wanted. There is no remedy for the delusion that that just dying in uttarƒÅya·πáa can bestow mukti. The goal of this chapter is mainly to inculcate ennobling emotion in people. It is certainly not the supreme truth. Like in other places, this is an instructive means of drawing attention to differences in the eligibility of aspirants to achieve mukti. The most important principle to take away from this chapter is -

tasmƒÅt sarve·π£u kƒÅle·π£u mƒÅmanusmara yuddhya ca ‡•• (BG 8.7)
(Therefore, at all times, fight while remembering me)

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Note

sarvagatamirdum ƒÅtma·πÉ
nirvik·πõta·πÉ sarva≈õaktam adu ni·π£karmam ‡•§
nirvaira·πÉ sarvasama·πÉ
nirv·πõtida·πÉ patrasumajalƒÅrpakari·πÉgam ‡••

The ƒÅtmƒÅ, though all-pervading,
is immutable, and though omnipotent, is actionless.
It is without a rival, and is the same everywhere.
It yields supreme bliss to even those offering a leaf, a flower or water.

Summary

The objects of the world function because of Brahma. Because of this, we confuse those objects for Brahma. We worship the glamour of the world while in fact, it is Brahma that should be worshipped. This is a mistake indeed. One should always remember that the world is a modification of Brahma-consciousness and that Brahma is beyond all the objects of the world.

BhagavƒÅn assures us that he will take up the responsibility of the entire well-being of whoever is completely dependent on him. What more assurance does one need?

BhagavƒÅn has affirmed that all devotion with ≈õraddhƒÅ reaches him and that he is propitious to those devoted to him. If all worldly actions such as taking in food and giving dƒÅna are performed as offerings to ≈örƒ´K·πõs·πáa, the jƒ´va attains the Supreme Goal. We see the heart of the Gƒ´tƒÅ-teaching in this chapter.

Chapter 9RƒÅja-vidyƒÅ-rƒÅja-guhya-yogaor Brahma-jagat-sambandha-yoga

(The Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World)

In the previous chapter, after considering seven or eight questions such as ‚Äúki·πÉ tadbrahma‚Äù (What is Brahman?), ‚Äúadhibh≈´tam kim?‚Äù (What is adhibh≈´ta) and what a prƒÅ·πáƒ´ (being) is, BhagavƒÅn taught that OM (pra·πáava), which denotes the entire collection of Jagat (world), Jƒ´va and I≈õvara, has to be mentally meditated upon. Now will be elucidated the relationship between Brahma and Prak·πõti - which is also the relationship between ƒ™≈õvara and the world.

This chapter covers the following topics:

  1. The omnipresence of Brahma 2. The subservience of the world to Prak·πõti 3. The two-fold nature of Prak·πõti 4. The attainability of I≈õvara 5. The worldly aspect of Dharma 6. Surrender to BhagavƒÅn

ida·πÅ tu te guhyatama·πÅ pravak·π£yƒÅmy-anas≈´yave ‡•§
j√±ƒÅna·πÅ vij√±ƒÅna-sahita·πÅ yaj-j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ mok·π£yase‚Äô≈õubhƒÅt ‡••
BG 9.1

The chapter begins with the above verse. The topic that BhagavƒÅn is about to tell us is the greatest secret! A mystery! What is that secret? A marketing trick or a profit-minded manoeuvre or a scheme for greater fame? This strategy is not for any worldly attainment but pertains only to the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Therefore, only the eligible will be instructed here. If the ineligible are instructed in this matter, there is a chance of misunderstanding or misuse or trivialisation - all of which is harmful to the world. This verse thus is an exhortation to share this secret only after considering the student‚Äôs worthiness.

Don’t think of this secret as BrƒÅhma·πáa obscurantism. It is well known that our government limits the sales of drugs that are mixed with mercury, sulphur, lead or mandate a prescription for those medicines that can have significant side-effects upon accidental consumption. Such medicines or prescription drugs carry labels with warnings like ‚Äòpoison‚Äô or ‚Äòfor prescription use only‚Äô or ‚Äòoverdose can cause injury.‚Äô On the other hand, home remedies such as ginger, pepper, and cumin can be used as medicine by almost anyone. Even a healthy person is not adversely affected by their consumption. However, those medicines explicitly labelled are meant only for patients and not for general consumption. It is dangerous for others to consume such drugs. Therefore the pharmacist is legally bound to sell such drugs only when accompanied by a prescription and only to those for whom the drug has been prescribed.

Similar is the rule regarding the teaching of the Vedas, ≈õƒÅstras, and the Gƒ´tƒÅ. They have to be imparted only after due discernment about the fitness of the taught. These are not like commercial goods that are sold to the general public. These words of Matthew Arnold are worth remembering here ‚Äì

Some secrets may the poet tell,
For the world loves new ways;
To tell too deep ones is not well‚Äî
It knows not what he says.

Moreover, this is ‚Äúj√±ƒÅna·πÅ vij√±ƒÅnasahitam‚Äù (knowledge with realisation) ‚Äì which is essentially experiential and not bookish learning. The theoretical understanding gained through external sources of knowledge such as teachers and ≈õƒÅstras is denoted as j√±ƒÅna. To this should be added vij√±ƒÅna ‚Äì the experiential realisation of j√±ƒÅna through vichƒÅra. VichƒÅra is the analysis of experience; a practical application of theory. BhagavƒÅn is now all set to teach the principle that is in agreement with both theory and experience.

This instruction is deemed ‚ÄòRƒÅja-vidyƒÅ‚Äô (the Royal Science) which means that it is the king of all vidyƒÅs. Just as the King‚Äôs power enables all his subjects employed in different posts to enjoy proportionate benefits during the discharge of their duties, this rƒÅja-vidyƒÅ enables assignment of the right values and positions of other vidyƒÅs. Thus this knowledge of reality ought to be at the head of all other vidyƒÅs.

rƒÅja-vidyƒÅ rƒÅja-guhya·πÅ pavitram-idam-uttamam ‡•§
pratyak·π£ƒÅvagama·πÅ dharmya·πÅ susukha·πÅ kartum-avyayam ‡••
BG 9.2

RƒÅja-vidyƒÅ is also fittingly called RƒÅja-yoga as it can be known through direct experience, is consistent with dharma, is easily performed, does not cause harm, is imperishable, and is easy to perform. Ha·π≠ha-yoga has opposite characteristics to RƒÅja-yoga. While Ha·π≠ha-yoga is a teacher that brings the fear of punishment to students, RƒÅja-yoga is a gentle and tactful teacher.

What then is the gist of this charming vidyƒÅ?

mayƒÅ tatam-ida·πÅ sarva·πÅ jagad-avyakta-m≈´rtinƒÅ ‡•§
mat-sthƒÅni sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni na cƒÅha·πÅ te·π£v-avasthita·∏• ‡••
BG 9.4
na ca mat-sthƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni pa≈õya me yogam-ai≈õvaram ‡•§
bh≈´tabh·πõn-na ca bh≈´tastho mamƒÅtmƒÅ bh≈´ta-bhƒÅvana·∏• ‡••
BG 9.5

(MayƒÅ) By me (Brahma), (avyaktam≈´rtinƒÅ) who has no external characteristics such as form and quality, (jagat idam sarvam) all this world (tatam) is pervaded.
(Through one perspective) all beings reside in me, I am not in them.
(Another perspective) The world‚Äôs beings really do not reside in me. See my (Brahma‚Äôs) divine and wondrous yoga in the aspect of ƒ™≈õvara. It is Brahma-consciousness that is the origin and sustenance of this multitude of beings. But Brahma itself is not in them.

This is a complicated statement. It needs to be patiently reflected upon.

The inquiry here is about existence. In Samsk·πõtam, existence is known as astitva. The same is sat + tƒÅ (sattƒÅ) or sattva. The subject of existence, termed ontology, is an important aspect of Western philosophy. What are some questions about existence?

  1. A certain thing might exist and still not be perceived by anyone. 2. Even if it is perceived, it might be perceived as something else. 3. Even if it exists, it might be attached to something else like a shadow. 4. It might be something that only the mind perceives but not the eye. 5. It might exist during one moment and not exist in the next.

Many doubts can thus arise about existence. Does our world really exist? Or is it merely an appearance? Is not appearance a level of existence? Should not an appearance have some kind of substratum? What might that be? Such are the questions.

Independent existence (svatantra-sattƒÅ) is something that exists without requiring anything else to exist as a substratum or for protection. It existed before, exists now, and will continue to exist later. It cannot be repudiated, modified, or destroyed in any place or time. Such is the existence of Brahma; completely independent.

When a thing‚Äôs existence requires something else to be present, the thing is said to have a dependent existence (adhƒ´na-sattƒÅ). The reflection in a mirror is an example. An object’s reflection is seen as long as the object stays in front of the mirror and disappears when the object is moved. We have already come across the illustration of the glass and the red rose. As long as the rose is near the glass, the glass appears red. No red glass without the red rose. Shadows too are in this category. They require another solid body for them to be seen. The shadow is a projection of the object. Brahma is existence itself, while the world is an appearance. The shadow is seen as long as the object is present. Once the object is gone, the shadow goes as well. But the object itself is not a shadow. It has an independent existence while the shadow has a dependent existence. Brahma has an independent existence; the world is like its shadow and hence has a dependent existence. Let us return to the treatise keeping this in mind.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The two ≈õlokas beginning with ‚ÄúMayƒÅ tatamida·πÅ‚Äù have the following seven points.

  1. MayƒÅ tatam-idam (All of this is pervaded or extended by me) 2. Mat-sthƒÅni sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni (All beings exist in me) 3. Na cƒÅha·πÅ te·π£v-avasthita·∏• (I am not in them) 4. Na ca mat-sthƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni (The beings are not in me) 5. Bh≈´ta-bh·πõt (The sustainer of beings) 6. Na ca bh≈´ta-stha·∏• (Not in these beings) 7. MamƒÅtmƒÅ bh≈´ta-bhƒÅvana·∏• (My Self constitutes the existence of beings)

There seems to be an inconsistency in these. How do we reconcile ‚Äòmat-sthƒÅni‚Äô and ‚Äòna ca mat-sthƒÅni‚Äô? Can a consistent meaning be gleaned from these seven statements? Let us see.

1. MayƒÅ tatam-idam ‚Äì This entire universe is extended from Brahma. The word tatam (extended) implies an extending energy as well as a material that is extended. A cloth is the extension of yarn; the yarn is an extension of cotton. Only when cotton as the raw material is present can the skills and energies of the yarn-maker and the weaver come into play. A vessel is an extension of metal. Only in the presence of the metallic raw material can the blacksmith‚Äôs hammer and anvil go to work. Similarly, the fundamental energy needed for the creation of the universe is that of Brahma. What about the material for creation? The answer again, is Brahma.

Our experience in the world is that anything that is born or created has two causes ‚Äì a mother and a father. One is the bƒ´ja (seed) and the other the k·π£etra (field). Take a look at some man-made creations. For a pot, the k·π£etra is clay and the bƒ´ja is the potter‚Äôs pot-making ability. In ≈õƒÅstric terminology, the clay is known as the upƒÅdƒÅna-kƒÅra·πáa (material cause) and the potter‚Äôs felicity is known as the nimitta-kƒÅra·πáa (efficient cause).

However, Brahma is not a created object like a pot or a cloth; it is self-existent. Brahma is by itself the field or material cause as well as the seed or the efficient cause.

A thing‚Äôs efficient cause is active only during its creation. An object‚Äôs material cause always lies latent in the object just like clay that exists in a pot. The clay is the pot‚Äôs material cause. The potter‚Äôs fashioning of the pot ends just after the pot is made and is therefore the efficient cause.

So far so good. We just said that Brahma is itself both the material and efficient cause. Is there an example for that in the world? Yes, there is. We saw that at the end of our discussion of the seventh chapter.

yathor·πáa-nƒÅbhi·∏• s·πõjate g·πõh·πáate ca ‡••
Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£at 1.1.7

For a spider-web, the efficient cause is the spider‚Äôs ability to weave a web whereas the material cause is the web fluid. Both of these are within the spider. Similarly, Brahma can assume two forms as well as possess two capabilities. Much like our Upanishadic spider, Brahma can make its own web fluid and weave those fantastic webs. It appears to us that Brahma prepares its own colours and costumes, assumes roles and disguises by itself and plays the world-drama.

Another instance is found in the BhƒÅgavata where ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa himself became the cows, calves, and cowherds, in an exhibition of his divine mƒÅyƒÅ (Note:This example was added by the translator in lieu of DVG‚Äôs untranslatable example.).

svayam ƒÅtmƒÅtma-govatsƒÅn prativƒÅryƒÅtma-vatsapai·∏• ‡•§
krƒ´·∏çann-ƒÅtma-vihƒÅrai≈õ-ca sarvƒÅtmƒÅ prƒÅvi≈õad-vrajam ‡••
BhƒÅgavata-purƒÅ·πáa 10.13.20
(The Self of all entered Vraja enjoying himself with his own play ‚Äì becoming the cows and calves himself as well as the cowherds.)

The conclusion is this: Creation is an independent lƒ´lƒÅ (pastime) of Brahma that is not ordered or inspired or impelled by another. Brahma does not need material or help from anyone else.

2. Now to the second point ‚Äì “mat-sthƒÅni sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni” (all beings exist in me). Brahma is the substratum of all that exists. Brahma pervades all that exists. There is nothing that exists apart or outside of Brahma ‚Äì there will not be anything else. This is the essence of the first statement of the ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsyopani·π£at ‚Äì ƒ´≈õƒÅvƒÅsyam-idam sarv·∫°m (All this is the dwelling of ƒ™≈õvara). The word ‚Äòexistence‚Äô includes whatever we see, experience, or infer. It is not possible to even talk about something as separate from Brahma. There is no existence for anything other than Brahma. The verb asti (is) can be used without qualification only with respect to a specific subject ‚Äì Brahma. There is no absolute existence for anything other than Brahman. Whatever exists ‚Äì as much as it exists ‚Äì exists within Brahma, enclosed in its greatness like the shards of clouds in the atmosphere. It is Brahma that wholly and continuously pervades everything within and without, above and below, and all around. That is indicated by ‚Äòmat-sthƒÅni sarva-bh≈´tƒÅni‚Äô.

3. The third point is “na cƒÅha·πÉ te·π£u”. Just because beings exist in Brahma and are able to act only because of Brahma‚Äôs support, they cannot be equated with Brahma. Doing so would be in error. In reality, Brahma is not limited either by forms and functions of things or by their shapes and modifications. It is beyond all these.

The world is a modification of Brahma-consciousness. A modification cannot alter the fundamental nature of the causal consciousness. A pot is an altered form of clay. This alteration cannot change the nature of clay. Modification is temporary; the causal substance is eternal.

A human being has nails and hair; but a human is not in those hair and nails. Shaving and cutting hair or nails does not affect the person. The sea has foam and bubbles; but there is no sea in foam and bubbles. The sea is undiminished even in the absence of foam and bubbles. Just as hair and nails are for the body and foam and bubbles are for the ocean, the things of the world are adventitious and momentary for Brahma. Though they appear real, they lack essence. The essence of Brahma lies not in the objects of the world. Even though husk might have come from paddy, it is not paddy by itself. Though an aspect of paddy might be seen in the husk, the husk is not the essence of the paddy.

Let us look at it in another way. Right now we have two things on our minds - Brahma and the world. Consider that they are opposite shores of a river and that the jƒ´va is the river in between. When we see the world-shore from the Brahma-shore, it appears to us as not a rocky solid shore but a sandy one. It pleases the eye with its lush green appearance, but hides the marsh beneath it. It feels better than a coarse boulder. But when we stand in the world-shore, we feel that it is not solid and that it might collapse anytime. The opposite shore seems safer. Both the rock and sand are earth. But the earth’s quality of stability manifests itself not in the sand but in the rocky shore. Similarly, Brahma’s essence lies in the Supreme Pure Brahma that is beyond the visible world. But the world does not completely reflect Brahma’s essence. The same is conveyed by the twelfth verse of the seventh chapter.

matta eveti tƒÅn viddhi na tvaha·πÅ te·π£u te mayi
“I (Brahma) am not present in the three qualities of Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. But they are in me (Brahma).”

Sleep and mumblings exist in a human being; but there is no human being in sleep and mumblings.

It is delusion to consider that the essence of Brahma is the world, an extension of Brahma. But the world has no substratum other than Brahman.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

4. Now on to “na matsthƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni”. Was it not said earlier that matsthƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni (all objects are in me)? But when we analyse reality, the objects do not exist in me; but only appear to be in me. Brahma is the substratum for that appearance. A traveller sees flowing water at a distance. But it is nothing other than a mirage. It is only a phenomenon; not an actual stream. That false appearance is created by a combination of sand, sunlight, and distance. The world, similarly, is a strange phantom that is indicated by BhagavƒÅn as “pashya me yogamai≈õvaram”. The world-causing mƒÅyƒÅ is the effect of ƒ™≈õvara’s Yoga. In the second canto of the BhƒÅgavatam, ≈öuka says this to King Parƒ´k·π£ita.

ƒÅtma-mƒÅyƒÅm ·πõte rƒÅjan parasyƒÅnubhavƒÅtmana·∏• ‡•§
na gha·π≠etƒÅrtha-sambandha·∏• svapna-dra·π£·π≠ur ivƒÅ√±jasƒÅ ‡••
BhƒÅgavatam - 2.9.1
bahu-r≈´pa ivƒÅbhƒÅti mƒÅyayƒÅ bahu-r≈´payƒÅ ‡•§
ramamƒÅ·πáo gu·πáe·π£v-asyƒÅ mamƒÅham iti manyate ‡••
BhƒÅgavatam - 2.9.2

The objects seen in a dream do not really belong to the dreamer. The relationship between them is only because of the dream. Similarly, the world and man are related only because of mƒÅyƒÅ. Without mƒÅyƒÅ, the relationship does not exist. This mƒÅyƒÅ is multifarious and due to it, even the world appears so. Man relishes the tastes and refinements offered by mƒÅyƒÅ with the feelings of ‚Äòme‚Äô and ‚Äòmine‚Äô. MƒÅyƒÅ is that which shows unreal things as real and vice versa. In this three-fold world of the seer, seen and sight, mƒÅyƒÅ takes the form of natural movement. The seeing eye shudders; the illuminating light flickers; the object to be seen shakes. Sight is thus affected. This imbalance in sight is mƒÅyƒÅ‚Äôs effect. It is mƒÅyƒÅ that attracts and traps our attention thereby making Brahma imperceptible. We are reminded every moment of the world‚Äôs existence but forget Brahma that is the basis of it all. We offer to the glamour of the world that which should be offered to Brahma. This is a mistake. Knowledge or j√±ƒÅna lies in understanding that the world is different from Brahma and that Brahma is not to be confused with the world.

yathƒÅ mahƒÅnti bh≈´tƒÅni bh≈´te·π£≈´ccƒÅvace·π£v-anu ‡•§
pravi·π£·π≠ƒÅny-apravi·π£·π≠ƒÅni tathƒÅ te·π£u na te·π£v-aham ‡••
BhƒÅgavatam 2.9.35

These are BhagavƒÅn’s words in the BhƒÅgavatam: “Just as Earth and other primordial elements simultaneously enter beings big and small and do not enter them, I am in them as well as outside of them.”

A mango tree grows due to the combination of earth, water, heat, and other elements. But none recognise the elements of Earth, Water or Light while eating a mango. The five great elements are pravi·π£·π≠ƒÅny-apravi·π£·π≠ƒÅni - that is - have entered the mango and have not entered the mango. Similar is Brahma with the objects of the world - It is in them and not in them.

The pƒÅrijƒÅta tree is born and grows because of contact with these five great elements. Even then, we do not think of the pƒÅrijƒÅta flower as belonging to any single element. The five great elements are pravi·π£·π≠ƒÅny-apravi·π£·π≠ƒÅni - they have entered the pƒÅrijƒÅta and have not entered it. Brahma has also simultaneously entered and not entered the beings of the world - “tathƒÅ te·π£u na te·π£u”. Brahma‚Äôs relationship with these flora is similar. In a certain perspective, they are related and unrelated from another perspective.

Brahma’s relationship with all beings from microorganisms and insects all the way to Hira·πáyagarbha (the divine creator) is to be viewed similarly.
Brahma exists in the world from the Absolute or Transcendental viewpoint. Not in the transactional or relative viewpoint.
The world exists in Brahman from a transactional viewpoint. Not the transcendental one.

The pampered child cries for an elephant. The grandfather buys her a toy elephant from the market. The satisfied child proudly exults in showing her elephant to everyone. The elephant is made of either wood or mud. But will anybody call it ‚Äòmud‚Äô? If someone asks for some mud to scrub vessels, will the toy elephant be given to them? The toy appears outwardly as an elephant. But in reality, it is made of mud. Internally, it is earth but externally an elephant.

Let us look at another example of the great drama personality Varadacharya who strode the stage dressed as Hira·πáyaka≈õipu, the asura. The audience waiting with bated breath would watch it without batting an eyelid. Was that Hira·πáyaka≈õipu? No. It was Varadacharya. Was that Varadacharya? No, Hira·πáyaka≈õipu. Varadacharya was mild-mannered and of a gentle disposition. He who appeared to be a heartless rƒÅk·π£asa to the audience was actually a compassionate soul to his friends and dependents. Varadacharya ("pravi·π£·π≠ƒÅny apravi·π£·π≠ƒÅni”) entered but did not enter Hira·πáyaka≈õipu, SƒÅra·πÖgadhara, Du·π£yanta and other characters.

A thing or a person might have multiple qualities. None of those qualities by themselves can be the person or the thing. Likewise, Brahma-consciousness has an infinite variety of forms. None of those forms or behaviours by themselves, is Brahma. Form, behaviour, and state are apart from Brahma. They belong to mƒÅyƒÅ.

The same opinion is succinctly expressed by this verse.

All these you are, and each is partly you,
And none is false, and none is wholly true.
Stephen Vincent Ben√©t

Is mƒÅyƒÅ different from Brahma? In one view, it is different and non-different from another view. An object is different from its shadow. But since the shadow cannot exist without the object, they are non-different. Is a wave different from the ocean? It is different in one aspect and in another, it is the same. The leaves of a tree flutter with the wind, but the trunk itself is unshaken. A still picture cannot capture the motion of the leaves, but it captures the trunk easily. Is the tree fluttering? Not from the view of the trunk. Is the tree immobile from the leaf‚Äôs perspective? No, because the leaf is shaking. Thus Brahma, that is one without a second, assumes a form like its shadow, its wave or like a leaf on the top of a tree. That form is mƒÅyƒÅ. MƒÅyƒÅ is not Brahma, but it cannot exist without It. Hence mƒÅyƒÅ that does not fit the definitions of existence and non-existence, or truth and falsehood and cannot be known definitely in any way is traditionally designated anirvacanƒ´ya (indescribable). The world is different from Brahma to the eye shrouded by mƒÅyƒÅ. When the shroud is removed, however, the world is non-different from Brahma.

5. ‚Äú(MamƒÅtmƒÅ) bh≈´tabh·πõt‚Äù - Brahma-consciousness bears or supports all beings; It nourishes and protects the world. All the powers of the Universe belong to Brahma. Man does not possess those in the least.

6. ‚Äú(MamƒÅtmƒÅ) na ca bh≈´tasthah‚Äù - Brahma-consciousness does not reside in beings. It is not possible to point at a specific being and say, “This is Brahma” as Brahma is omnipresent and all pervading. It cannot be mixed piecemeal with anything.

These above six sentences seem to indicate that Brahma is different from a being, where a ‚Äòbeing‚Äô could refer to an animal, insect, anything with a body, or a jƒ´va. During our time, the word jƒ´va is more in use than the word bh≈´ta or being. Let us use that for now.

Our next question is about the relationship between jƒ´va and Brahma. The jƒ´va is something that all of us have experienced to a limited extent. Brahma is something that has not been experienced but something whose name has been just heard. How are they mutually related? Let us look at the seventh item in our list before trying to answer that.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

7. “MamƒÅtmƒÅ bh≈´tabhƒÅvana·∏•” : Brahma-consciousness is the cause of a jƒ´va’s rise and fall. The term bhƒÅvana·∏• can variously mean birth, existence, sustenance, or control. Brahma has embedded the seed of ·πöta (Cosmic order) and dharma in human nature. ·πöta is the law in creation. “Deeds beget appropriate rewards and a jƒ´va has to experience them” is the cosmic law of ·πõta. The practical application of ·πõta in life is dharma. Dharma and adharma result in pu·πáya and pƒÅpa respectively and therefore in svarga and naraka. “A jƒ´va follows dharma or adharma to experience elevation or degradation” - is the decree of Brahma. Brahma-consciousness becomes bh≈´tabhƒÅvana by virtue of this universal decree which controls the jƒ´va’s birth and life. Hence it is Brahma that is responsible for the journey of the jƒ´va.

It might be helpful to use an allegory to clarify the combined meaning of these three statements.

  1. MamƒÅtmƒÅ bh≈´tabh·πõt 2. MamƒÅtmƒÅ na ca bh≈´tastha·∏• and 3. MamƒÅtmƒÅ bh≈´tabhƒÅvana·∏•

Consider a traditional joint family (common fifty years ago) in India with the head of the family, his wife, their four or five children, and six or eight grandchildren making it fifteen to twenty members in the family.

  1. Apart from himself and his wife, the head of the family is either the father or grandfather to most of the family members and is bh≈´tabh·πõt (as their head) to them. He guides them, educates them, establishes them in a suitable vocation, and bears responsibility for their welfare. He is bh≈´tabh·πõt for all of them as their nourisher. 2. Even so, he does not enter their personal lives much. He allows them their freedom according to their age and circumstance. He wishes for the general welfare and happiness of his daughters-in-law and grandchildren. He leaves them to their own devices thinking, “Let them live according to their discretion. They don’t have to live for me. Let them lead their lives for their own well-being.” He takes care of them, but does not impose his wishes upon them. Such a person - na ca bh≈´tasthah - if asked for their share of property by any of his children wishing to lead separate lives, justly gives to them what they deserve and asks them to lead lives wisely. He lives with his younger children as long as they want him to. When they do not need him anymore he separates from them, allowing them their independence. His disposition thus is one of detachment and thus is “na ca bh≈´tasthah”. 3. He educates his children, corrects their ways, and trains them to be prudent. The know-how of what is good and what is not that he imparts to his children will keep them in good stead. They will fail miserably if they reject his teachings. On the other hand, they will benefit from suitably applying his instruction. In this way, he is bh≈´tabhƒÅvana (the giver of welfare) for his family.

This is the gist.

  1. The world is a family of jƒ´vas created by ƒ™≈õvara (Brahma). 2. Family hassles, however, do not affect ƒ™≈õvara. 3. ƒ™≈õvara has supplied jƒ´vas with necessary means of sustenance. 4. ƒ™≈õvara demonstrates rules and guidance through the mechanisms of prak·πõti to help jƒ´vas lead a better life. This set of rules is dharma. 5. He also provides them with the requisite intellect to understand and discern the good and bad of those dharmas. 6. The jƒ´va attains welfare or otherwise depending on how well it maintains dharma. 7. ƒ™≈õvara is aloof from the world. Nothing of the world affects him. 8. It is the jƒ´va who needs the world to refine himself and achieve purification. 9. The jƒ´va benefits by getting closer to his source, Brahma. 10. MƒÅyƒÅ clouds the jƒ´va’s understanding and keeps him away from Brahma. MƒÅyƒÅ is that deluding power found in Prak·πõti.

We have now briefly discussed the relationship between Brahma and the world, the Brahma-jƒ´va relationship, and the relationship between the world and the jƒ´va. This is requisite preparation for the next chapter. It is useful to understand their background as these topics appear repeatedly.

It has been stated above that the world exists in Brahma just like the clouds in the atmosphere. BhagavƒÅn relates the same through another comparison.

yathƒÅkƒÅ≈õa-sthito nitya·πÅ vƒÅyu·∏• sarvatra-go mahƒÅn ‡•§
tathƒÅ sarvƒÅ·πái bh≈´tƒÅni mat-sthƒÅnƒ´tyupadhƒÅraya ‡••
BG 9.6

Brahma is like the sky. The world is like the wind in it.

Good. Brahma is independent; the world is not. Who created this dependent-independent relationship? Brahma anyway is self-existent, uncreated, and unborn. But is the same thing with the world? Or, if it is created, who created it? The answer again is Brahma.

prak·πõti·πÅ svƒÅmava·π£·π≠abhya vis·πõjƒÅmi puna·∏• puna·∏• ‡••
- BG 9.8
mayƒÅdhyak·π£e·πáa prak·πõti·∏• s≈´yate sacarƒÅcaram ‡••
- BG 9.10

Brahma assumes the aspect of ƒ™≈õvara and creates the world again and again through Its power of Prak·πõti. Prak·πõti gives birth to this animate and inanimate world with Brahma as the adhyak·π£a (the presiding entity).

In a regular assembly or gathering, the word ‚Äòpresident‚Äô denotes a position that performs a set of specific activities. Neither does the president of an assembly give a speech nor does he proffer any opinion. The president listens to others‚Äô speeches and observes the proceedings. The position by itself ensures dignity in the assembly‚Äôs proceedings. The president is a witness who is present during an assembly, not one who does anything. The president‚Äôs presence ensures propriety in proceedings. Thus the word ‚Äòpresidency‚Äô is apt in our discussion.

Brahma does not do anything by Itself. It is ‚Äòpresident‚Äô because it observes prak·πõti‚Äôs activities. Prak·πõti is but one aspect of the limitless power of Brahma. It has been earlier said that Brahma is the master of the world-family. The mistress of this family is prak·πõti. Or prak·πõti can be likened to the Prime Minister of a well-ruled country. All the administrative duties are discharged by the Prime Minister. It has already been mentioned that Brahma is like the Constitutional Monarch who does not have the strain of administration, which is the domain of prak·πõti. A thief stole; a policeman arrested him and the judge sentenced the thief to six months of imprisonment. The thief was handcuffed. What did the king have to do here? All the activities were done as part of the rule of law. Similarly, jƒ´vas obtain their rewards or punishment for their activities as determined by the rule of dharma. Brahma is an unattached witness. It witnesses goings on ‚Äúfrom above‚Äù. Hence ‚Äúadhi + ak·π£a‚Äù - adhyak·π£a.

tapƒÅmyahamaha·πÅ var·π£a·πÅ nig·πõ·πáhƒÅmyuts·πõjƒÅmi ca ‡•§
am·πõta·πÅ caiva m·πõtyu≈õca sadasaccƒÅhamarjuna ‡••
BG 9.19
‚ÄúI heat the waters, gather them upwards into clouds and rain the waters down. I am Immortality as well as Death. I am Being as well as Non-being.‚Äù

The above ≈õloka as well as these from the third chapter are also worth reflecting upon.

i·π£·π≠ƒÅn bhogƒÅn hi vo devƒÅ dƒÅsyante yaj√±abhƒÅvitƒÅ·∏• ‡•§ (3.12)

Just as the Supreme ƒ™≈õvara is the inner controller of the jƒ´va, he is its sustainer as well. ƒ™≈õvara is the one who provides all the means necessary for life and is the basis for everything.

Not just that; he is Death as well. The Ka·π≠hopani·π£ad outlines this gory truth.

yasya brahma ca k·π£atra·πÉ ca ubhe bhavata odana·∏• ‡•§
m·πõtyuryasyopasecana·πÉ ‡••
‚ÄúFor Brahma, both the wise and brave are morsels of rice. And Death is a tasty pickle.‚Äù

Who rules the world? It is prak·πõti who controls the world. She is of two forms - daivƒ´ and ƒÅsurƒ´. The ones who take refuge in the daivƒ´ form become BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs devotees.

bhajantyananyamanaso j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ bh≈´tƒÅdimavyayam
satata·πÅ kƒ´rtayanto mƒÅ·πÅ yatanta≈õca d·πõ·∏çhavratƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
namasyanta≈õca mƒÅ·πÅ bhaktyƒÅ nityayuktƒÅ upƒÅsate ‡••

BG 9.32
(Even those born of sinful origins such as women, vai≈õyƒÅs and ≈õ≈´dras will attain the Supreme Goal by taking refuge in me.)

A controversy might arise here. Are women, vai≈õyƒÅs and ≈õ≈´dras considered to be of sinful origin? BhagavƒÅn has already said ‚Äúsamo’ham‚Äù (I am equal everywhere). By using the word ‚Äúapi‚Äù (also), why is he showing step-motherly treatment towards women, vai≈õyƒÅs and ≈õ≈´dras? Is this not taking sides? Is this not discrimination?

We have pondered over this nitty-gritty aspect of dharma in the past chapter. The practice of internal equality finds fulfillment only in the external practice of hierarchy. Equal love towards all, and circumstantial awareness is the operative principle here. Let\ us look at it from this perspective.

The practice of bhakti and ≈õraddhƒÅ come to a brƒÅhma·πáa through his lineage as well as societal influence. Bodily penance and mental concentration are easier for him than for the others. Therefore, the path of divine contemplation might not be that hard for him.

Similar is the case for a K·π£atriya. If the BrƒÅhma·πáa‚Äôs penance is through the practice of knowledge, a K·π£atriya‚Äôs penance is through practice of weaponry and physical exercise. Bhakti and focus may not be difficult for him due to the refinement of the body and mind.

A woman, however, because of her body‚Äôs natural structure, has a few physical limitations and differences in mental perspective. Her menstrual and postpartum conditions impede her physical practice of tapas and agitate her mind. More importantly, prak·πõti fills a woman‚Äôs heart more with motherly love and affection than a man‚Äôs heart. This is prak·πõti’s strategy for sustaining the world. Whatever might be the father‚Äôs disposition, is it not the mother‚Äôs love that ensures a child its future? However a husband is, it is only the love and commitment of the lady of the house that makes a family. Thus, the female heart is the first instrument of prak·πõti‚Äôs duty of protecting the world. This indeed is the strength of the feminine. There is however, an associated side-effect - non-concentration of the mind. The top of a coconut palm is single-pointed, whereas a mango tree has many ends owing to its many branches. A woman needs her husband, her children as well as ƒ™≈õvara. She cannot give up on anyone. She needs ƒ™≈õvara for her husband and children. Thus one-pointed devotion is harder for a woman than for a man. Even so, if she is devoted even for a moment, the same benefits that accrue to others accrue to her as well. This is the significance of ‚Äòapi‚Äô - that there is a path even for those who are incapable of intense devotion and penance.

One-pointed concentration is hard even for vai≈õyas (businesspeople). A vai≈õya needs to maintain his business with hundreds of individuals to successfully run his business to make a profit. The thought of profit and loss in business cleaves his mind into two. His worldly associations are complex. He has to give a part of his devotion to the world. Difficult are his circumstances. In spite of all that, if he takes refuge in BhagavƒÅn even momentarily, divine grace visits him as well. This too is signified by ‚Äòapi‚Äô.

After these two explanations, we see that not much else needs to be said in relation to the ≈õ≈´dras. A person known as a ≈õ≈´dra (by definition) lacks in knowledge and the company of the refined. He is not invested with much responsibility and only needs to do what is asked of him. Where is the time or the requisite tranquillity for BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs worship for one who is constantly engaged in the service of other people? But in the middle of all his duties, if he takes refuge in ƒ™≈õvara for even a brief period of time, he too gets to partake of BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs munificence. Even here, the words ‚Äúte api‚Äù (they too) are not meant to reject a ≈õ≈´dra for his inferiority but to denote compassion for the effort he undertakes.

SvƒÅmƒ´ has taught us that he will look after the welfare of those who are constantly engaged in divine contemplation. Whatever the method of worship, or whoever the worshipped might be, all adorations performed with ≈õraddhƒÅ reach ƒ™≈õvara who is the one controller of the Universe. This instruction applies to everyone - be they wise or wealthy or strong or even world-weary or unlettered. BhagavƒÅn is easily accessible to all. This is a life-maxim for us.

Section 11 / Chapter 10. Vibh≈´ti-yoga orƒ™≈õvara-vaibhava-yoga

(The Yoga of ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs Glory)

In the preceding chapters, we have outlined the following important topics with their subtopics.

  1. Brahma-consciousness or ƒ™≈õvara that is the origin of the universe. 2. ƒ™≈õvara as the basis for everything and as the inner controller of the jƒ´vas. 3. The jƒ´va‚Äôs position as an enjoyer of different world objects 4. The mƒÅyƒÅ of Prak·πõti that prevents the jƒ´va from experiencing the Divine

In this chapter we discuss the expressions of Divine glory.

These are the main topics discussed in this chapter ‚Äì

  1. BhagavƒÅn is beginningless and non-attached 2. Prak·πõti‚Äôs artifice of opposites 3. Buddhi-yoga (the Yoga of intellectual understanding) that results from bhakti 4. Guiding lights for the seeker of BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs abode

Let‚Äôs remember one of the puzzling items from previous chapters. ƒ™≈õvara is seen in three different ways from the vantage of the world ‚Äì

  1. ƒ™≈õvara is the inner controller of the world.
    ‚Äúsarva-bh≈´tƒÅtma-bh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äù (BG 5.7) 2. But ƒ™≈õvara is unmodified by the world.
    ‚Äúna ca mat-sthƒÅni bh≈´tƒÅni‚Äù (BG 9.5) 3. Though everything resides in ƒ™≈õvara, he is unattached to anything. ‚Äúna tvaha·πÉ te·π£u‚Ä¶ te mayi‚Äù (BG 7.12)

The world is the abode of the jƒ´va. The basis of the existence and the activity of the jƒ´va is Brahma-consciousness. Even so, the deeds of the jƒ´va do not attach to Brahma. The jƒ´vas are responsible for their own actions.
Brahma-caitanya or the consciousness of Brahma is like a money-lending bank. The jƒ´va is like a customer of the bank. When a customer of the bank takes out a loan, it is the customer‚Äôs responsibility to ensure that the loan amount is profitably utilised rather than squandering the money and going to jail as a loan defaulter. The customer‚Äôs lack of judiciousness does not concern the bank. The principle here is that the jƒ´va is responsible for his own action and that ƒ™≈õvara is unattached. The jƒ´va is an appointed employee of the enterprise of world-activity ‚Äì representing the vya·π£·π≠i (individual) aspect. The chief executive officer of this enterprise is ƒ™≈õvara ‚Äì the sama·π£·π≠i (collective) aspect of Brahma-consciousness. Thus it is essential for the jƒ´va to understand the nature and omnipotence of ƒ™≈õvara. BhagavƒÅn K·πõ·π£·πáa now bestows this teaching upon us.

aham-ƒÅdir-hi devƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ mahar·π£ƒ´·πáƒÅ·πÉ ca sarva≈õa·∏• ‡••
BG 10.2
bhavanti bhƒÅvƒÅ bh≈´tƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ matta eva p·πõthag-vidhƒÅ·∏• ‡••
BG 10.5
sukha·πÉ du·∏•kha·πÉ bhavo‚ÄôbhƒÅvo bhaya·πÉ cƒÅbhayam-eva ca ‡••
BG 10.4
‚ÄúArjuna, I (ƒ™≈õvara) am indeed the origin of all the Devas and the great ·πö·π£is.‚Äù (ƒ™≈õvara has no other origin. He is the origin of everything. He is not someone who was born in a remote moment of time. He is present everywhere at all times.) ‚ÄúThese different mental states in all these beings stem from me. Pleasure, pain, birth, death, being, going, meeting, separating, fear, fearlessness ‚Äì all of these arise from my power.‚Äù

aha·πÉ sarvasya prabhavo matta·∏• sarva·πÉ pravartate ‡••

‚ÄúI, the Supreme ƒ™≈õvara, am the origin of all creation. All of this proceeds from me (the Supreme ƒ™≈õvara).‚Äù

The words ‚Äôsarvasya‚Äô and ‚Äôsarva·πÉ‚Äô include both what we consider good and bad.

Opposites are a part of this creation. Rights and wrongs are mixed up in it as well as things desirable and despicable, wholesome and unwholesome, as well as facts and falsehoods. The Taittirƒ´yopani·π£ad states the same:

so.kƒÅmayata ‡•§ bahu syƒÅm prajƒÅyeyeti ‡•§…idam sarvamas·πõjata‡•§ ..sacca tyaccƒÅbhavat‡•§ nirukta√±-cƒÅnirukta√± ca‡•§ nilayana√±-cƒÅnilayana√±-ca‡•§ vij√±ƒÅna√±-cƒÅvij√±ƒÅna√±-ca‡•§ satya√±-cƒÅn·πõta·πÉ ca ‡•§ satyamabhavat ‡•§ yadida·πÉ ki√±ca ‡•§ tatsatyamityƒÅcak·π£ate‡••
Taittirƒ´yopani·π£ad 2.6.1

How then can we get out of this tight spot? By the practice of remembering ƒ™≈õvara-samak·π£atƒÅ (the presence of ƒ™≈õvara).

mac-cittƒÅ mad-gata-prƒÅ·πáƒÅ·∏• bodhayanta·∏• parasparam ‡•§
kathayanta≈õ-ca mƒÅ·πÉ nitya·πÉ tu·π£yanti ca ramanti ca ‡••
BG 10.9
te·π£ƒÅ·πÉ satata-yuktƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ bhajatƒÅ·πÉ prƒ´ti-p≈´rvakam ‡•§
dadƒÅmi buddhi-yoga·πÉ ta·πÉ yena mƒÅm-upayƒÅnti te ‡••
BG 10.10
‚ÄúThey whose minds and breaths are engaged in me, who talk with each other about me, who always remember me and are happily engaged in me, to them of continuous devotion, I give buddhi-yoga (Yoga of the Intellect) through which they attain me‚Äù.

Buddhi-yoga referenced here is what was described in the previous chapter (9.1) as ‚Äúj√±ƒÅna·πÉ vij√±ƒÅna-sahitam‚Äù ‚Äì an amalgam of knowledge and experience.

The take-away nugget here is about the benefit of Buddhi-yoga. BhagavƒÅn gives the strength of Buddhi-yoga, the path of knowledge, to those to whom he wishes to reveal his true form. We have an age-old bickering. Is bhakti the result of j√±ƒÅna? Or is it j√±ƒÅna that results from bhakti? Sometimes we feel that this controversy is just hair-splitting. In reality though, the more the knowledge of an object, the greater is the love towards it. The reverse is true as well ‚Äì the greater the love towards an object, the more one learns about it. Suppose that j√±ƒÅna stems from bhakti. Will bhakti deteriorate or increase after the dawn of j√±ƒÅna? Or if bhakti stems from j√±ƒÅna, will j√±ƒÅna be washed away in the flood of bhakti? Both of these views are extreme. It is possible for both j√±ƒÅna and bhakti to co-exist and this is the common situation. Buddhi-yoga is a fruit of bhakti ‚Äì in other words, the result of the bhakta‚Äôs own efforts. Once bhakti permeates the instrument-triad of the bhakta ‚Äì his body, speech and thought, and is wholesome and pure, it becomes worthy of BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs appreciation. Such an appreciation is not partiality but an acceptance of the bhakta‚Äôs eligibility or the recognition of the bhakta‚Äôs ability. This indeed is the Divine protection of the devotees and an indicator of BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs love of dharma.

Given the nature of bhakti and j√±ƒÅna, it would be incongruous to hold that they are mutually exclusive. Both perform the same activity just as both our eyes unite to see the same object.

Verses 9.12,13 informed us that Prak·πõti has instituted two mutually opposite paths for the jƒ´va ‚Äì the daivƒ´ (Divine) and the ƒÅsurƒ´ (Demonic). As the previous chapter has taught us that the daivƒ´ path is conducive to welfare, it can be inferred that the jƒ´vas have the freedom to distinguish between the daivƒ´ and ƒÅsurƒ´ paths and can choose to follow the former. [[Ch. 10 Yoga of ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs Glory (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

What is buddhi-yoga? Buddhi is a faculty of the anta·∏•kara·πáa. Manas (mind), sa·πÖkalpa (will), j√±ƒÅpaka (recall) and other mental faculties hanker after so many external objects, collecting sensory information about them. The buddhi (intellect) gathers all these pieces of information under its purview, analyses them, classifies them, assesses their qualities and strengths, and ascertains their usefulness. This is the work of the buddhi.

buddhir-vivecanƒÅ r≈´pƒÅ sƒÅ j√±ƒÅna-jananƒ´ ≈õrutau ‡••

It is the buddhi that gathers the true knowledge of a certain object. Buddhi-yoga is a mechanism to unite the buddhi with the para-tattva ‚Äì Supreme Principle. This mechanism is a boon that BhagavƒÅn bestows upon the eligible jƒ´va. There is no summum bonum without this boon.

Buddhi-yoga is not a set of subtle intellectual acrobatics. Mathematicians, scientific researchers, lawyers, and logicians perform many intellectual feats. Their life lies in performing these cerebral adventures. But that does not constitute buddhi-yoga. Normally, the scholarly exercises of the ≈õƒÅstrik scholars do not beseech the Divine for boons ‚Äì those proceed independently. However, when the intellect tries to attain the Supreme, the illumination for its path has to come from the destination. That blessing of the light has been variously referred to as either inspiration or revelation or a vision. Thus attaining the Supreme is impossible without Divine blessing. The Upani·π£ads convey the same message.

The vile aspects of the Divine body are temporary; not long-lasting. Therefore those wishing to experience Divine glories must worship the pure and auspicious aspects of the world. Whatever be the object on which bhagavat-prakƒÅ≈õa - Divine illumination falls, it becomes excellent. Section 12 / Chapter 11Vi≈õva-r≈´pa-sandar≈õana-yoga

(The Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form)

The Gƒ´tƒÅ declares in the third chapter that the Supreme Principle is beyond the reach of buddhi (intellect).

yo buddhe·∏• paratas tu sa·∏• ‡•§
BG 3-42

If a principle is out of reach of the buddhi, how can the latter grasp it?
It was said in the sixth chapter that the bliss of Brahma-experience can be grasped by the buddhi.

buddhi-grƒÅhyam atƒ´ndriyam ‡•§
BG 6-21

The apparent inconsistency in these two statements can be resolved through some reflection.
The buddhi functions by cooperating with the manas which in turn works in conjunction with the sense organs. Thus, the buddhi is usually influenced by the actions of the sense-organs. That the Supreme Principle - paravastu is beyond such an imperfect and wavering buddhi is the gist of the statement - yo buddhe·∏• parata·∏•. Therefore, the instruction in the third chapter is to ‚Äî

jahi ≈õatru·πÉ mahƒÅ-bƒÅho kƒÅma-r≈´pa·πÉ durƒÅsadam ‡•§
BG 3-43
(O Strong-Armed one! Destroy this enemy‚Äîdesire‚Äîthat is difficult to overcome)

In the phrase buddhi-grƒÅhyam from 6-21, buddhi refers to the intellect unsullied by the actions of the sense-organs - a purified intellect. Anything that is imagined or thought of by such a buddhi is an intellectual concept.

Another question arises now. Can everything ‚Äúunderstood‚Äù by the intellect be truly experienced?

School children are normally posed with problems like the following in arithmetic. Ten workers work for eight hours a day and build a house in a month. How many days will it take to build the same house if ten thousand workers were to work similarly for 8 hours a day? The arithmetical answer can be intellectually understood, but it cannot be realised in experience. Can ten thousand workers even stand in the same space that ten workers work?

Scholars say that zero in a number has a certain value. How can ordinary people experience the value of zero?

Buddhi is generally known to have two aspects. On the one hand, it is tainted by sense organs that connect to it through the manas. On the other hand, it is weakened due to sense experience. Though the buddhi can grasp whatever is inaccessible to the eye, ear and other sense organs through inference and imagination, it is but a fraction of knowledge; surely incomplete. Complete knowledge can arise only from experience.

Not everything grasped by the buddhican be experienced. The principle independently understood by buddhi must first permeate into the mind. From the mind it should descend to the physical realm of bodily sense organs to become experience. Experience is complete knowledge. That which is only understood by the buddhi is not complete knowledge.

The difference between buddhi-grƒÅhyam (grasped by the buddhi) and buddhi-mƒÅtra-grƒÅhyam (grasped only by the buddhi) should be borne in mind. So must the distinction between buddhi-g·πõhƒ´ta-mƒÅtram (understood only by the buddhi) and anubhava-siddham (born of experience). Attainment through experience is higher than attainment via buddhi. Answers to some mathematical problems are attained at the intellectual level only and cannot be experienced.
The heart is the site of experience. The fruit of the activity of the manas and buddhi is experienced in the heart. This is vouchsafed for by several statements from the ≈õruti and the sm·πõti.

ƒ™≈õvara·∏• sarvabh≈´tƒÅtmƒÅ h·πõddeshe ‡•§ (ƒ™≈õvara, the self of all beings, in the heart)
Bhidyate h·πõdyagranthi·∏• ‡•§ (The heart-knot is rent asunder)
Agnirme vƒÅci ≈õrita·∏• ‡•§ vƒÅggh·πõdaye ‡•§ h·πõdayam mayi ‡•§ (Agni is in my speech; the speech in my heart; the heart in me.)

The heart is the arena of experience. It is the heart that touches the truth. The heart is larger than the manas and buddhi for it encompasses both.

The knowledge of the Supreme Principle is predominantly experiential. Intellectual comprehension is imperative for experience. Other instruments are also necessary. Man‚Äôs external organs bahi·π£kara·πáa must be subservient to his anta·∏•kara·πáa, which in turn must cooperate with one of them - the buddhi. Experience of the supreme principle is possible only when all these instruments unite in harmony. The eleventh chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ - dealing with the cosmic form - illustrates this concept.

The concepts of j√±ƒÅna·πÉ vij√±ƒÅna-sahitam and buddhi-yoga were expanded upon in the ninth and tenth chapters. The theoretical knowledge of the principle (j√±ƒÅna) was enumerated with ≈õƒÅstric basis as well as logical reasoning. The practical aspect (vij√±ƒÅna) was expounded with illustrations of well-known personages and well-known phenomena. With this, Arjuna‚Äôs confusions and fears were put to rest. It appears, however, that a few doubts continued to bother him. The first - ‚ÄúWill my acquired belief endure firmly?‚Äù The second - ‚ÄúHow eligible am I to attain spiritual knowledge?‚Äù Arjuna felt that only personal experiential testimony could resolve these niggling questions. He therefore implored BhagavƒÅn for such a vision who then bestowed it upon him. This is the gist of this chapter.
Though the entire matter of the chapter can be conveyed in a small number of words, this chapter‚Äôs greatness cannot be overstated. It is an established practice to recite this chapter of the vi≈õva-r≈´pa while the monastic name is given to the ordained renunciate during the rite of accepting sa·πÉnyƒÅsa (renunciation).
At the beginning of this chapter, Arjuna clearly states that his mind was purified.

yat tvayokta·πÉ vachas tena moho‚Äôya·πÉ vigato mama

Questions such as ‚ÄúWho is the jƒ´va? What is the world? Who is ƒ™≈õvara? What is the path towards good? What is dharma?‚Äù - all received appropriate answers. There was no doubt left uncleared. But was it not Arjuna‚Äôs desire to attain the state of a sthitapraj√±a (one of steady wisdom)? BhagavƒÅn had indicated this to Arjuna in the beginning -

≈õruti-vipratipannƒÅ te yadƒÅ sthƒÅsyati ni≈õchalƒÅ ‡•§

Arjuna then inquired about the characteristics of a sthita-praj√±a. He wanted to be a sthita-praj√±a (one of steady wisdom) rather than a chala-praj√±a (whose wisdom is unsteady). The wisdom obtained from ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£na‚Äôs words could slip away due to another‚Äôs words - like old water pushed away by new flowing water or a lamp getting extinguished by the wind. Arjuna wanted to ensure that this knowledge learnt from BhagavƒÅn remained firm and did not flow away. This was Arjuna‚Äôs intent.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 11 Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

Here, by ‚Äúdivine eyes‚Äù we do not need to imagine a pair of extra-physical eyes with their own eyeballs and eyelids. It is enough to think that BhagavƒÅn endowed the eye with the ability to behold divine effulgence. This is what we have to understand - when we pray to ƒ™≈õvara for a boon, we need to ask for the requisite strength to bear and control the blessing. Our desires know no limits and make us forget what is suitable and what is not. If BhagavƒÅn gives us what we deserve, we‚Äôre dissatisfied. However, if he grants us whatever we ask of him, it is akin to committing suicide. Gastric issues are guaranteed if one forgets one‚Äôs digestive ability and indulges in a feast. When we pray for a meal, we need to ask for medicine for indigestion as well. When taking up a vow in a deity‚Äôs honour for progeny, one must not forget to ask for means of sustenance. When asking for a kingdom, we must not forget to ask for a treasury and an army too. When asking for a boon, we need to also ask for the ability to use the blessing well.
