Did you understand the impact of direct experience? What a difference in effect between j√±ƒÅna (intellectual understanding) gleaned by the intellect and vij√±ƒÅna (experiential wisdom) seen by the eyes and felt by the manas! When he asked for the vision of the cosmic form, Arjuna never even for a bit thought that the experience would be this terrorising! He thought that witnessing the vision with his eyes would be as easy as arguing with his words. What happened during the vision, though? Fear, trembling, distress! This shows that Arjuna‚Äôs understanding of the truth was not complete. He had only seen the pleasant side of BhagavƒÅn but not the terrible aspect. Suppose a person knows only one face of a two-faced thing, how can we say that he has complete knowledge of it? The seeker of truth must know as many facets of the truth as there are. It is not enough to just have heard of something. One should have seen the thing with one‚Äôs own eyes. It is not just enough to have seen and heard the thing, but the thing must be grasped by the buddhi as well. And not just intellectually grasped by the buddhi, but should have been experienced by the manas and the seeker should become one with the sought. Becoming one with the sought ‚Äî becoming it ‚Äî is complete experience. Similar was Arjuna‚Äôs state now after experiencing the vision of the Universal form. When the ≈õruti says - ‚Äúcak·π£urvai satyam‚Äù (the eye is the truth), it does not mean that whatever is seen by the eye is the truth but that the eye is one of the instruments for reaching the truth. Even theoretical knowledge strengthened by intellectual inference and logical strengthening is insufficient. The truth is experienced only when the theory is confirmed by visual validation. Arjuna needed such a direct confirmation and he got it now.

Even though BhagavƒÅn had bestowed divine vision upon Arjuna, the latter‚Äôs human frailty had remained. The strength of his manas had not increased. Hence the fear. Even after what he sought after appeared in front of him, he experienced fear. Those who think that Brahma-experience is nice and pleasant must repeatedly recollect this episode. Brahma is not a grocery item to be bought from a store. If we make Brahma-experience cheap, it is us who suffer, not Brahma. Hence it is better to limit idle talking and casual listening about Brahma and mok·π£a.

Did Arjuna not already accept that ƒ™≈õvara is the ‚Äúsarva-dharma-goptƒÅ‚Äù (the eternal protector of dharma) in the eighteenth verse? The responsibility of protecting dharma is that of ƒ™≈õvara, not of Arjuna and not of Bhƒ´·π£ma or the others. Whatever was needed to establish dharma had already been planned and set in motion. The same is referred to by BhagavƒÅn later as ‚Äúdaiva·πÉ caivƒÅtra pancamam‚Äù (18-14) (Divine providence is the fifth factor that determines the outcome of any action). A war had become inevitable for the survival of the world. Without it, essential and eternal dharma would not have held out amidst mortals. This was not a war just for one Arjuna or five PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas. Arjuna‚Äôs role in it was not as a cause, but as an instrument. Any conflict needs two sides. One side was ready and the other was wavering. It was necessary for the protector of eternal dharma to firm up the fickle side.
The secret of the universe that had eluded Arjuna in the lectures on sƒÅ·πÖkhya, karma and j√±ƒÅna became evident to him now. BhagavƒÅn is the controller of the world. He has assigned us a dhƒÅrmic duty only to benefit us. If we do not perform that duty, it is not dharma that will be affected but our own progress. BhagavƒÅn can use others if we disregard our duty. But we are the ones who will be left without a resort. When such a beneficial opportunity arises, it becomes a dhƒÅrmic obligation for us. Arjuna finally understood this and expressed remorse for having protracted this investigation thus far.

BhagavƒÅn now said - ‚ÄúArjuna, you have witnessed a special form that cannot be attained by the merits gained from the Vedas, Yaj√±as, charity and other penances. The only path towards an experience of the divine being is bhakti - single-minded Bhakti.

The vision of the universal form enabled a great inner experience in Arjuna. But it should not be forgotten that behind that universal form exists a supra-universal principle that is the basis of even the universal form. Both the universe and the supra-universe have to be borne in mind. They are not really two - but one. The universe has form and so can be seen. The supra-universe is formless and therefore cannot be seen.

A form is marked by a well-established boundary ‚Äî a defining line, a perimeter that limits an area. Any form therefore, is finite. But pure existence is infinite, limitless. How does one bring form to it? An appearance of a finite form makes infinity disappear. Thus the supra-universe cannot be grasped by sense organs such as the eyes and the ears. How does one experience it then? It can be seen when the manas and buddhi meditate upon it. The tapas of the manas and buddhi is Bhakti. However, that tapas needs an easily attainable focus. A form or a m≈´rti facilitates this. Just as the pradak·π£i·πáa of a temple has a m≈´rti of the divine as its centre, the manas and buddhi of normal people have the vi≈õva-m≈´rti (BhagavƒÅn in the form of the universe) as their object. The service of this visible universe, considering it as a form of BhagavƒÅn, is dharma. The service of the supra-universal principle is adhi-dharma. The one who lives a ‚Äúuniversal life‚Äù is able to experience the supra-universal as well. The universe is the bridge that takes the jƒ´va to the supra-universal.

At the beginning of our study, we had asked a question - ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt the Gƒ´tƒÅ a ≈õƒÅstra? How did it become a song?‚Äù We have seen an answer to that question to some extent in this chapter. Gƒ´tƒÅ or a song is a literary category. The arrangement of words accompanied by music, that causes waves of feeling to rise in the listener‚Äôs psyche and causes satisfaction, is a song. The song has to cause a uniquely pleasurable experience that calms our minds. By the vision of the vi≈õva-r≈´pa, Arjuna lost his grief and worry; and attained happiness and a definite understanding with the exit of fear and doubt. Suppose a lone traveller on his way to a distant land gets caught in a murky jungle and loses his sense of direction. He is distressed, tired and is almost resigned to the fate that a wild animal will end his existence. What if a friend brings light to him and gets him to his destination on an easily traversable path? The feeling that our poor traveler might have experienced upon reaching the destination is similar to what Arjuna felt now. This emotional experience is conveyed to our minds by the masterful words of VyƒÅsa. ≈öƒÅnta (tranquillity or peace) is the key rasa in this episode. It is nourished by the sub-emotions of karu·πáa and adbhuta. There is a lingering debate on the question whether ≈õƒÅnta is indeed a rasa. This, however, is not a place for that discussion. Arjuna‚Äôs words and behaviour show us that ≈õƒÅnta is not just a rasa, but that it is the parama-rasa or adhi-rasa ‚Äî Supreme rasa or a supra-rasa. The rasa ≈õƒÅnta is uniquely different from all other rasas in an aspect. It is not a rasa that can be achieved by all like ≈õ·πõngƒÅra and other rasas. Only those tormented by a≈õƒÅnti (disturbance, anxiety) can appreciate the nature of the ≈õƒÅnta-rasa. Can‚Äôt feelings such as separation or loss of money be considered a≈õƒÅnti? Yes - but those are fleeting and limited feelings that can be neutralised by trivial profits and dalliances. The a≈õƒÅnti that afflicted Arjuna was unlike this - it shook the very foundations of his existence. This a≈õƒÅnti was not based on the desire for some object, but about the fundamental meaning of life. The Gƒ´tƒÅ gives tranquillity to those tormented by questions such as - ‚ÄúWhat is the essence of life? What is its goal? How does one attain fulfillment?‚Äù The raison d‚Äô√™tre for the ≈õƒÅnti that the Gƒ´tƒÅ bestows upon its votaries is not based on scriptural exegesis or debates that are solely intellectual. It is an all-encompassing unique inner experience. The buddhi is merely the gateway to the inner world. When the teaching entered the heart through the buddhi, it became a ≈õƒÅstra. When that instruction took over all the sense organs and the instruments of knowledge such as the manas and buddhi and established the entire inner-kingdom in that Great Vision, it became poetry. The supreme effect of poetry is this achievement of engrossment. The same will be explored in a future chapter.

Summary

Giving up the fruit of our actions means that we experience the world with the notion that all felicity and happiness we experience is a favour from ƒ™≈õvara, and that adversities are training to the jƒ´va. This needs the jƒ´va to make mindful choices of karma to be performed, unwavering devotion to dharma, equanimity in the experience of the fruit of karma, and finally complete surrender to ƒ™≈õvara. Here, ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa instructs Arjuna on how to gradually diminish one‚Äôs affinity with ego and experience first hand the relationship with Divine.

Section 13 /Chapter 12Bhakti-yoga/Bhakti-sopƒÅna-yoga

(The Yoga of the steps of Bhakti)

At the end of the eleventh chapter, we analysed a significant concept. The supreme reality or sadvastu is of two kinds: One is vi≈õvar≈´pa ‚Äî the form that encompasses the entire universe, and the other supra-universal. Vi≈õvar≈´pa is tangible reality and it is evident. That is ƒ™≈õvara-yoga. The supra-universal is intangible truth and has to be inferred indirectly. That is Parabrahma. Arjuna asks which of these two he has to meditate upon. The SvƒÅmƒ´ answers his question in this chapter. There are four important points here.

  1. The difficulties in meditating upon the formless - nirgu·πáopƒÅsana. 2. Ease of worshipping the divine that has a form - sagu·πáopƒÅsana 3. Stepwise worship of the divine 4. The wealth of qualities that has to be earned by the worshipper.

Arjuna asked: ‚ÄúO Great one, what should I believe? You say ‚Äômat-karma-k·πõt mat-parama·∏•‚Äô ‚Äî one who does the work ordained by me and engrossed in me ‚Äî Who is ‚Äôme‚Äô here? Should I seek you and your form that is visibly manifest in the universe, or the invisible, unmanifest and intangible, pure and Supreme Brahma? You have instructed me in the worship of both of these. Which of them is better?”

“te·π£ƒÅ·πÉ ke yoga-vit-tamƒÅ·∏•”
BG 12.1

SvƒÅmƒ´‚Äôs answer is thus: “O Arjuna, when there are many ways to reach a destination, shouldn‚Äôt a traveller choose one that is right for his body and mind? One road might be uneven and bumpy, and additionally difficult to traverse because of sharp stones and thorns. It might, however, be shorter. A strong man in a hurry might choose this path because it is short. Another, weaker man would say that it is more important to not fatigue himself. With time on his side, the circuitous route would be better for him though it takes more time, because it does not harm his body. The journey that a jƒ´va undertakes towards better worlds is similar. The worship of the intangible Brahma is more suited for those who are stronger and can sustain strain. The worship of the manifest form is more suited for weaker people. Both will attain the same supreme state ‚Äî one directly and the other gradually.

mayyƒÅve≈õya mano ye mƒÅ·πÉ nitya-yuktƒÅ upƒÅsate ‡•§
≈õraddhayƒÅ parayo-petƒÅs-te me yukta-tamƒÅ matƒÅ·∏• ‡••

‚ÄúThose who rest their minds upon any one form of ƒ™≈õvara, and continuously meditate upon the Brahma with a form (sƒÅkƒÅra-brahma) are closest to him‚Äù.
Ye tvak·π£aram-anirde≈õyam avyakta·πÉ paryupƒÅsate ‡•§
·π≠e prƒÅpnuvanti mƒÅmeva sarva-bh≈´ta-hite ratƒÅ·∏• ‡••

‚ÄúThose who are friendly towards the whole world, who meditate upon the indestructible, indescribable, intangible and formless Brahma, reach ƒ™≈õvara Himself‚Äù.

The followers of both paths attain the same end; there is a slight difference only in the speed with which it is attained. The quicker way is more difficult; the other way is circuitous but easier. Why should we not choose the faster one?

kle≈õo‚Äôdhikataras-te·π£ƒÅm avyaktƒÅ-sakta-cetasƒÅ·πÉ ‡•§
avyaktƒÅ hi gatir-du·∏•kha·πÉ dehavadbhir-avƒÅpyate ‡••
BG 12.4

The journey towards better worlds is anyway difficult. Both paths require the practice of self-control and giving up carnal pleasures. Till we reside in a body that consumes salt and spices, it is difficult to subdue our senses. Therefore, it is a given that it is difficult to indulge in worshiping BhagavƒÅn. Further, worshipping the unmanifest and formless Brahma is much more difficult than worshipping the tangible Brahma with a form. The difficulties are of two kinds. The first is that of intellectual capability. Ordinary intellect cannot grasp the indescribable and unthinkable. The supreme tattva is described thus in the Vedas -

Yato vƒÅco nivartante ‡•§ aprƒÅpya manasƒÅ saha ‡••
Tai.U, BrahmƒÅnandavallƒ´
yanmanasƒÅ na manute yenƒÅhurmano matam ‡••
Kenopani·π£a·∏ç 5

Brahma is described as that very mysterious thing ‚Äî ‚Äú from where speech and mind return without being able to grasp it; that which cannot be held by the mind, but causes the mind to understand‚Äù. The intellect has to put great effort to understand this concept clearly. Even if we think that the intellect is able to grasp this, there is a second difficulty ‚Äî that of experience. Brahma should be experienced. It becomes truthful knowledge only then. ‚Äúsa·πÉniyamyendriya-grƒÅmam‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄôSubduing the collective influence of the senses‚Äô, ‚Äúsarvatra sama-buddhaya·∏•‚Äù ‚Äî ‚Äôdisplaying equanimity everywhere‚Äô, ‚Äúsarva-bh≈´ta-hite ratƒÅh‚Äù ‚Äî indulging in the well-being of all creation‚Äô. To whom is this easy? Each second, the body has to grapple with arising desire, love and infatuation. The enchanting beauty and glamour of Nature captivates our eyes and deviates our minds from the thought of true knowledge. If a man who has not yet escaped the clutches of mƒÅyƒÅ thinks that he is as capable as the people who have, his plight will be similar to that of a lame person trying to climb a hill. Therefore, the humility of worshipping Brahma with a form is safer than the strenuous exercise of meditating upon the formless Brahma.

ye tu sarvƒÅ·πái karmƒÅ·πái mayi sa·πÉnyasya matparƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
ananyena-eva yogena mƒÅ·πÉ dhyƒÅyanta upƒÅsate ‡••
BG 12.6

BG 12.7
‚ÄúBhagavƒÅn quickly holds and draws towards him those who give up the fruit of all their actions in him, seek his direction in everything, not indulging in anything else other than meditating upon him and rest their minds firmly in him‚Äù.

Is this method of upƒÅsanƒÅ easy for everyone? ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa did not think so.

ƒÅtha citta·πÉ samƒÅdhƒÅtu·πÉ na ≈õakno·π£i mayi sthira·πÉ ‡•§
abhyƒÅsa-yogena tato mƒÅm-icchƒÅptu·πÉ dhana√±jaya ‡••
BG 12.9
‚ÄúIf you cannot establish your mind in ƒ™≈õvara firmly and constantly, do it as much as you can, whenever you can. With practice comes focus‚Äù.

Is practice easy, though? In our houses, those who wear ma·∏çi and sit for worship know that it is an arduous practice. It is difficult to focus for long on something that cannot respond to us, something that does not react to our actions. Young people can concentrate on their loved ones for a little time. The reason for that is born from the natural reaction of the limbs. There is an echo to a sound, a sign in answer to another. Is BhagavƒÅn so wondrous and attractive? Blessed are they whom he attracts of his own accord. We are not talking about them. Let us look at the plight of those who are not so lucky. They have to go in search of BhagavƒÅn of their own volition. It is true that our mind does turn towards the Divine when worldly adversities arise. But the very next second, it turns back from there and focuses on something else. How can we discipline something that is so fickle? One way is to engage it in karma ‚Äî some good work. When the body and hands are engaged in a work, the mind is engrossed in it and does not flit here and there. The minds of carpenters, engineers, masons, and farmers are settled and rested in their work. Therefore, Arjuna, ‚Äúmatkarma-paramo bhava‚Äù ‚Äî ‚Äúperform karma as service toBhagavƒÅn‚Äù. Perform karma with the view that you are only doing it for the love of BhagavƒÅn.

·πÉadartham-api karmƒÅ·πái kurvan siddhim avƒÅpsyasi ‡••
BG 12.10
‚ÄúPerform laukika and vaidika karmas as an offering to ƒ™≈õvara. You will then achieve the supreme state”.

The world is a carpenter‚Äôs shop. You are a carpenter working there. Do your work diligently, to please the owner. From such work you will earn for life in this world, and blessing for the afterlife. This is the training of karma, the biggest and best of all trainings.

[[Ch. 12 Yoga of the steps of Bhakti (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

Well, then, is this path ‚Äî performing one‚Äôs duties with the sole purpose of pleasing BhagavƒÅn ‚Äî an easy journey? ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa himself was uncertain about it. BhagavƒÅn is not in front of our eyes; dharma is not in front of our eyes either. Performing our duties only for the sake of BhagavƒÅn or for dharma ‚Äî single-minded devotion to our duty without even an iota of selfishness ‚Äî is difficult. It is not easy to be a devoted servant who does his duties conscientiously even in the absence of the master who distributes the wages. Many people perform karma with the desire to obtain something or the other in return. Let them do so, but let them perform it with the notion that the fruits of the karma (or the lack thereof) belong to ƒ™≈õvara. If they obtain what they desire, let them think that it is the blessing of ƒ™≈õvara and not their earning. If their effort doesn‚Äôt bear fruit, let them bear it with the reasoning that it is punishment meted out to them, and that this will erode their defects. Thus, one has to live in the belief that good or bad results both belong to ƒ™≈õvara and not to us, and remember him always.

sarva-karma-phala-tyƒÅga·πÉ tata·∏• kuru yatƒÅtma-vƒÅn ‡••
BG 12.11
‚ÄúWith effort, suppress the ego that says that you are the doer, or that you achieved this. Accept the results of your action as given by BhagavƒÅn, and not as your own. Seek refuge in him, in happiness and in adversities‚Äù.

What does ‚Äúgiving up the fruits of karma‚Äù mean? We have to understand this for ourselves.

tyaktvƒÅ karma-phalƒÅ-sa·πÉgam ‡••
BG 4.20
yukta·∏• karma-phala·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ ‡••
BG 5.12
mƒÅ phale·π£u kadƒÅcana ‡•§ mƒÅ karma-phala-hetur-bh≈´·∏• ‡••
BG 2.47
AnƒÅ≈õrita·∏• karma-phalam ‡••
BG 6.1

As we note above, this instruction is seen many times in the Gƒ´tƒÅ. What does ‚Äúgiving up the fruit of karma‚Äù mean? Does it mean that one should cook food and throw it out without eating? Or plant a garden, and when it yields fruits and flowers, throw them in the gutter? No, it isn‚Äôt like that. Instead of eating cooked food by oneself, it should be shared with others. Surely, there‚Äôs no harm in the cook smelling the aroma of the food he cooked? Or should he crumple his face saying that the pƒÅyasam is bitter or spicy, just because he prepared it? Should he not experience pleasure? Even if he experiences pleasure, should he not express his experience of pleasure? Is dharma only in calling a flower disgusting? Is karma-phala-tyƒÅga only about calling a steaming bowl of rice as plain mud?
We should try and deliberate upon what constitutes karma-phala-tyƒÅga. There are four aspects in this sƒÅdhanƒÅ. If we are not clear about them, karma-phala-tyƒÅga becomes just a word ‚Äî an imposing sound that hits the eardrums. Let us look at these aspects.

1.Karma means kartavya-karma. Kartavya is that work, failing to perform which amounts to dereliction. The three main deciding factors for this karma are three -

The first is the felicitous inspiration that arises in us. It is a feeling that if this work is done, it is good for everyone.
The second is the capability and means to do the work, something that we already possess.
The third is an understanding of the necessities of the world around us ‚Äî to our family, society and country.

Kartavya is work done using our energy and wealth to better the lives of others. We might make mistakes when we try to undertake certain activities. We might try to take on more than we can handle; or display our worldly benevolence where it is not required. Thus, we might start performing something that is not our kartavya; and also forget our kartavya. Taking unnecessary karma upon oneself might create problems. Karma entails coming in contact with the world; coming in contact with the world means that we are stepping into the lives of others. Thus in our haste to perform a duty that we think we have to do, we get embroiled in the pains and pleasures of others. To perform a p≈´ja with a hundred thousand jasmine flowers, one may have to enter the gardens of unknown people and jostle among them to obtain the flowers. To feed a thousand people, he may have to fall at the feet of unworthy people. Thus, even an activity done with the objective of pu·πáya might cause us to come in contact with pƒÅpa during its course. Therefore, one must be careful when deciding what is kartavya and what is not. Kartavya should not be given up, a work that is not kartavya should not be taken up.

2. Secondly, once a kartavya is decided upon, we should not procrastinate, thinking whether this activity will be beneficial or not. Regardless of whether it results in victory or defeat, a kartavya in accordance with dharma should be performed. If our conscience proclaims something as dharma, we should consider it divine ordinance and do it, even if a hundred people are against it or a hundred obstacles are in its way. Just because it faces defeat, a dharmic kartavya does not become adharmic. Whether a kartavya is indeed a kartavya or not, whether dharma is indeed dharmic or not does not depend on its result ‚Äî profitable or detrimental. Dharma is dependent on Universal Truth and existence; Therefore, kartavya is performed as an offering to BhagavƒÅn. ‚ÄúParameshvara prƒ´tyartha·πÉ‚Äù, ‚Äú≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáƒÅrpa·πáamastu‚Äù ‚Äî this is the method of kartavya.

  1. Thirdly, one should not worry about the fruit of karma that has been performed. The fruit of karma or the lack thereof, is decided by daiva. Who knows our karmas in the past, or the eligibility of others related to our karma? There is no one who can figure out the cause and effect-relationship among various entities in this world thoroughly. The fruit of karma is accorded to each jƒ´va, based on their ability accrued for many lives from past karmas. The important philosophy here is to not to be mentally stirred by this change. Whatever comes, due to BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs will, and therefore it has to be surrendered to. If we are impatient, we will become defiant towards the Divine. Therefore, we should always be indifferent towards the fruits of our karma, and not let our mind be disturbed by it.

Sukha-du·∏•khe same k·πõtvƒÅ lƒÅbhƒÅlƒÅbhau jayƒÅjayau ‡•§
sama·∏• siddhƒÅ-vasiddhau ca k·πõtvƒÅ‚Äôpi na nibadhyate ‡••
BG 2.38

  1. Fourthly, we should accept what comes to us, as the prasƒÅda from ƒ™≈õvara.

Tena tyaktena bhu√±jƒ´thƒÅ·∏• ‡••
ƒ™≈õopani·π£ad - 1

The above statement does not mean that one should not experience pleasure. One should experience pleasure, but with the feeling that it is a prasƒÅda obtained in a temple.

[[Ch. 12 Yoga of the steps of Bhakti (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

≈örƒ´ KanakadƒÅsa, the great mystic, said this -

·π¢a·∏çurasadannak√® nalidƒÅ·∏çuva jihv√® ‡•§ ka·∏çurucigo·πÉbuva rucigu·πáa ninadayya ‡••
(Yours is the tongue that enjoys food with six rasas;
yours is the nature that deeply relishes all tastes)

The beauty, the very essence of the things that are present in the universe, the senses that experience them, and their capability to discern and enjoy belong to BhagavƒÅn.

anna·πÉ ca brahma ‡•§ bhoktƒÅ ca brahma ‡••
(Food is Brahma, the eater is Brahma).

Therefore,

brahmƒÅrpa·πáa·πÉ brahma-havi·∏• brahmƒÅgnau brahma·πáƒÅ hutam ‡••
BG 4.24

Therefore, one should experience pleasure with the feeling that the thing that is giving happiness, and one‚Äôs own energy that is experiencing pleasure are both the boons of BhagavƒÅn. BhagavƒÅn is the owner of everything, and I am a mere beggar ‚Äî this is the common meaning of some of our traditional statements. Hindus first offer the food that is cooked, fruits and even flowers that are to be worn, to the divine. Only after that do they consume it themselves as prasƒÅda. Muslims have this tradition (Bismillah) too; Christians also have Grace. Objects of pleasure are not one‚Äôs own, nor are they of one‚Äôs own earning. They belong to the Divine, who has given it to us as a boon. A man who enjoys worldly pleasures in this manner will never need to have apprehensions about his karma accruing pƒÅpa. Even if the fruit of the karma is obtained from his karma ‚Äî his own effort, he should not try to own it, that is karma-phala-tyƒÅga. Thus, removing the connection of ego from the result and connecting ƒ™≈õvara with it instead, is karma-phala-tyƒÅga.

Thus, karma-phala-tyƒÅga has four aspects : (1) Discernment about kartavya (2) equanimity about good or bad results (3) giving up the results to K·πõ·π£·πáa (the mindset of K·πõ·π£·πáƒÅrpa·πáa) (4) acceptance of prasƒÅda.

The summary of this discussion is to remember BhagavƒÅn in times of happiness and think of it as his boon, and remember him in times of adversities and look upon them as training for the jƒ´va.

Thus, the instruction is step-by-step. At its most advanced, it is worshipping the abstract. The second step is resorting to the worship of ƒ™≈õvara with form. The third step is the practice of the remembrance of ƒ™≈õvara and the fourth is the practice of performing one‚Äôs duties for the love of ƒ™≈õvara. The fifth is understanding ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs will.

J√±ƒÅna is at a higher level than practice; dhyƒÅna is higher than j√±ƒÅna; karma-phala-tyƒÅga is better than dhyƒÅna; from this renunciation of the fruit of karma results peace; peace itself is the ultimate fruit.

AbhyƒÅsa is to believe an instruction that is received, and to follow it without independent questioning or reasoning. J√±ƒÅna is internalizing the instruction by deliberating upon and analyzing it. DhyƒÅna is having this guiding philosophy constantly in one‚Äôs sight. When the mind is fixed upon this principle, selfishness vanishes. Thus, when ego and attachment gradually lessen and the jƒ´va offers itself completely to paramƒÅtma, peace is then readily obtained.

Bhakti has many outcomes ‚Äî worldly pleasures, wealth, fame, long life, children, accomplishment of all desires, getting rid of hardships and misfortunes, waning of sins, obtaining svarga ‚Äî thus there are many benefits. Above all, is ƒÄtma-≈õƒÅnti ‚Äî peace for the ƒÅtma. In the eight verses from ‚Äúadve·π£·π≠ƒÅ sarvabh≈´tƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ‚Äù to ‚Äúte‚Äôtƒ´va me priyƒÅ·∏•‚Äù, svƒÅmƒ´ enunciates the qualities of devotees who perform bhakti for peace of mind, so that we keep them in mind.

Introduction

Summary

BhagavƒÅn ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs instruction is chiefly about the method of gaining knowledge; about the greatest philosophy that is the object of gaining knowledge, and the discernment to distinguish between dharma and adharma that results from knowledge. All the works of the universe are due to the interaction between prak·πõti (Nature) and puru·π£a (the sentient being). Since these transactions are infinite, the variety and uniqueness we find in various forms of life and other things in the universe are also infinite. The method of realizing the single entity that is inside all this variety, the basis of everything, is explained in the Gƒ´tƒÅ.
Prak·πõti is the field where the plant of sa·πÉsƒÅra grows. ƒÄtmƒÅ is the farmer. The energy of the ƒÅtmƒÅ is of the form of true knowledge, and is always equanimous. Because it is equanimous, the knower of the field (lit. k·π£etraj√±a) perceives his field and also other fields and farmers. ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is the energy, the thread that binds and holds together the various aspects of the universe. BhagavƒÅn describes k·π£etra as a constituent of prak·πõti, and explains qualities such as humility and straightforwardness that have to be practised by those who want to realize the principle of the ƒÅtmƒÅ (ƒÅtmatattva).
Some realize the nature of mƒÅyƒÅ with their intellect and make their lives fruitful. Some others practise dhyƒÅna and realize paramƒÅtmƒÅ from that. Yet others learn the splendour that is the ƒÅtmƒÅ from others, worship that and obtain fulfilment. Worship is of paramount importance ‚Äî as it grows, divine experience comes along.
MƒÅyƒÅ is the wall raised by prak·πõti between jƒ´va and paramƒÅtmƒÅ. It comprises bricks that are the gu·πáa-triad. For those who want to understand the nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, it is necessary to understand the three gu·πáas.

Section 14 / Chapter 13K·π£etra-K·π£etraj√±a-Yoga /Prak·πõti-Puru·π£a-Yoga

(The Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being)

Exposition of knowledge starts in this chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. The eighteen chapters of the Gƒ´tƒÅ can be divided as three ·π£a·π≠kas ‚Äî Karma·π£a·π≠ka, Bhakti·π£a·π≠ka and J√±ƒÅna·π£a·π≠ka respectively. A ·π£a·π≠ka is an aggregate of six chapters ‚Äî a hexade. In a hexade, the respective topic is the principal topic, whereas an allusion to the other two is incidental. Looking at this in its entirety, karma, bhakti and j√±ƒÅna are like the three stones of a stove, all of them to be used together. Even though they appear as three separate entities, they work together in unison. The three can be considered separately only for the sake of intellectual understanding, not for practice and experience. Thus, the portion of the Gƒ´tƒÅ from the thirteenth to the eighteenth chapter helps in understanding the true nature of Brahma.

The principal topic of the present chapter is j√±ƒÅna or knowledge. What is j√±ƒÅna? It is a work of the intellect. If an animal recognizes another animal or thing that is different from it, that is j√±ƒÅna. There are two important strengths within us ‚Äî one is the manas and the other is the buddhi. The manas experiences deficiency or desire or pain, just as feeling happiness, pleasure, love and hatred is its job. Based on the reports submitted by the eyes, ears and other sense organs, the manas experiences want and insufficiency, and satisfaction and happiness. The buddhi then evaluates and informs about the nature and worth of the information thus gathered thus by the manas through the sense organs and its memory. The manas and buddhi are not completely different. They are like the two different sides of a single sheet of paper. It is merely shastric terminology to recognize the action of one side as feeling and classify it as that of the manas, and recognize that on the other side as that of the buddhi and call it j√±ƒÅna. Even though feeling and knowledge are one and the same at the etymological level, their common usage is slightly different.

It is the work of manas when a baby cries of hunger. It is the work of the buddhi when it stops crying on seeing its mother approaching, thinking that she might be bringing milk. It is the work of the manas when a mother grieves over her child‚Äôs illness. Then it is the work of the buddhi that sends the father to the doctor and gets medicine. The manas made Du≈õyanta fall hopelessly in love with ≈öakuntalƒÅ and wail to no end. Later, when she complained that a bee from the garden was trying to hurt her, it was his buddhi that made him rush forward on this pretext, bragging thus about his heroism ‚Äî ‚Äúwho can trouble the poor girl when I am here?‚Äù

Buddhi arranges information gathered by the manas about things and provides them for action. During this process, it deliberates upon their nature and inherent disposition, and what they can be used for. The result of this deliberation is j√±ƒÅna.

Bhakti is mainly a work of the manas. J√±ƒÅna is mainly a work of the buddhi. Karma is a bodily work that is directed by both manas and buddhi.
Let us now go to the text. In the beginning of the Gƒ´tƒÅ itself, BhagavƒÅn has noted the following ‚Äî

dehƒ´ nityam avadhyo‚Äôya·πÉ dehe sarvasya bhƒÅrata
BG 2.20
There is a body (deha), and there is a dehƒ´ (the ƒÅtmƒÅ that resides in the body) that rules over it and is separate from it. The body undergoes change and eventual destruction, but the dehƒ´ ‚Äî ƒÅtmƒÅ is unchangeable and eternal.

Since Parabrahma is extremely subtle and cannot be described by mere words, BhagavƒÅn has placed pointers to its nature within seemingly contradictory sentences. Only by examining the sentences again and again can we discern the underlying meaning hidden between these lines.

anƒÅdimat para·πÉ brahma na sat tan-nƒÅsad-ucyate ‡••
BG 13.13
‚ÄúParabrahma is without beginning, and is said to be both existing and not existing‚Äù.

Here, the first part anƒÅdimat para·πÉ brahma can also be split as ‚ÄúanƒÅdi+matpara·πÉ+brahma‚Äù. Then, we can read the meaning as ‚ÄúBrahma is that which is without beginning, and which is above my present birth of K·πõ·π£·πáƒÅvatƒÅra, which has a beginning‚Äù.

The second part is more difficult to understand. It has the following words ‚Äî

na + sat + tat + na + asat (ucyate). The meaning is as below:
tat = that Brahma
na sat = appears as though it does not exist ‚Äî that is, it is not directly perceptible but has to be inferred. It lies hidden under the blanket woven by prak·πõti, that is the universe. This blanket that we see undergoes change and destruction. Therefore it is asat. The ‚Äòsadvastu‚Äô Brahma lies hidden in the ‚Äòasat‚Äô universe, and imparts a feeling that it is not there. Therefore, ‚Äúna sat‚Äù.
‚ÄúNa asat‚Äù = In reality, it is not something that does not exist. It is present at all times in all places. Even if it is not seen, it is not something that does not exist.
In ‚Äúna sat tat‚Äù , ‚Äòsat‚Äô is something that can be discerned by the senses.
Brahma does not exist from the point of view of the sense organs. The same opinion is espoused by the ≈õruti also ‚Äî

asadvƒÅ idam agra ƒÅsƒ´t ‡•§ tato vai sat ajƒÅyata ‡••
Tait. Up. 7.1
‚ÄúIndeed, didn‚Äôt asat verily exist in the beginning? Sat was born from it‚Äù

From the verb ‚ÄúƒÅsƒ´t‚Äù, it is clear that there was something. But it was not possible to be known or understood. It was without a form, gender and other physical properties. What existed in the beginning was not vacuum, but something that was not perceptible by eyes and ears. Since it could not be seen physically, it was called asat. Asat means imperceptible. Something that exists but does not show itself, is avyakta. That is asat. Here, ‚Äúasat‚Äù does not mean complete nonexistence, but nonexistence from the point of view of perceptibility. It is the nonexistence that is inferred about the beginning of time, from the point of view of after the universe came into existence.

How is Brahma?

sarvata·∏• pƒÅ·πáipƒÅda·πÉ tat sarvatok·π£i-≈õiro-mukham ‡•§

This is what we have set out to understand ‚Äî something that cannot be defined, something that is not accessible to description. Which student of poetry can claim that the above lines are not poetry?
What is the source of knowledge? What is the one that reveals everything? What is that energy that reveals everything to everyone?

yathƒÅ prakƒÅ≈õayatyeka·∏• k·πõtsna·πÉ lokamima·πÉ ravi·∏• ‡•§
k·π£etra·πÉ k·π£etrƒ´ tathƒÅ k·πõtsna·πÉ prakƒÅ≈õayati bhƒÅrata ‡••

‚ÄúJust as one Sun lights up the whole world, the k·π£etrƒ´ (one who is the lord of the k·π£etra, that is ƒÅtmƒÅ) lights up the whole field‚Äù.

‚ÄúHow do we see one another? We think it is because of our eyes. However, mere eyes are not enough. On the night of AmƒÅvƒÅsyƒÅ, when there is no external light, we cannot see one another. If our eyes have to work, they need a common agent such as the Sun or a lamp that can communicate between the eyes and the object to be seen. The brightness of the eyes mingles with the light from the Sun or the lamp and impacts the mind. How does the mind attain the capability to sense and perceive this impact? From the paramƒÅtmƒÅ who is inside. Therefore the ƒÅtmƒÅ that dwells inside a body is called para√±jyoti. In the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka, this concept is established thus ‚Äî

ki·πÉ jyotis-tava bhƒÅnu-mƒÅn ahani me rƒÅtrau pradƒ´pƒÅ-dikam ‡•§

The guru asks his disciple:
Q: With the help of which light do you view objects?
A: With the help of the Sun
Q: In the night?
A: Lamp, fire, etc
Q: That is right, but with which light do you view the Sun and the lamp?

Q: When you have closed your eyes, how do you recognize objects?

Q: How do you recognize the buddhi?
Q: With the light of the ƒÅtmƒÅ within me.
Q: Then you are para√±jyoti ‚Äî supreme light, are you not?

A slightly changed version of the above verse can be found in the ≈õata≈õlokƒ´, ascribed to ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅchƒÅrya.

The Gƒ´tƒÅcƒÅrya says the following about this Supreme being :

J√±eya : This is the object of knowledge.

J√±eya·πÉ yat tat pravak·π£yƒÅmi yad j√±ƒÅtvƒÅ‚Äôm·πõtam a≈õnute ‡•§

kasminnu bhagavo vij√±ƒÅte sarvamida·πÉ vij√±ƒÅta·πÉ bhavati ‡••

‚ÄúSarva·πÉ‚Äù here means all that which we understand to be existing, not excluding even the tiniest, most insignificant bit. 3.j√±ƒÅna-gamyam: What is the use of understanding the ƒÅtmƒÅ? If the nature of that which is the basis and the raw material of all life is understood, the righteous or wrong way of leading a life will also be understood; the understanding of making life productive will also be understood. The discernment of dharma, adharma and adhidharma is the prime use of studying philosophy.

AnƒÅdi means that without beginning ‚Äî therefore it is not affected by the vagaries of time.
When is the birthday of prak·πõti or the universe? They are not born at all; they exist ‚Äî svata eva ‚Äî by themselves.
If they are not born, will they not die either? No, they do not die, but their death is as true and as real as their birth. This means that birth and death are small alterations but not the real form of the parabrahma.
To the eyes of someone who has understood parabrahma, creation and destruction are the momentary magnificent manifestations of prak·πõti, which is the formidable strength of Parabrahma. That is mƒÅyƒÅ. At once, exists and does not exist ‚Äî it depends on the knower. We have seen this idea earlier.
What is the greatness of prak·πõti?

Then what is jƒ´va? It is described thus‚Äî

‚ÄúWhen a man is enamoured by prak·πõti, he experiences the qualities of prak·πõti. The form that he chooses to take in this world and the family where he chooses to be born show what qualities of prak·πõti he chooses to accept‚Äù.

Thus the future of puru·π£a ‚Äî or jƒ´va ‚Äî depends on his discernment and discrimination of right and wrong, and his ability to critically examine virtues and vices.
We have seen the inspiration of prak·πõti and the responsibility of the jƒ´va. That is our life. We have to next examine the ƒ™≈õvara-tattva or the Puru·π£ottama-tattva.

The supervising agency ‚Äî the one who ensures that the fruit of an action reaches the doer ‚Äî is Mahe≈õvara. He does not need anything for himself. He does not say no to anything either. Therefore, he is ‚ÄúAnumantƒÅ‚Äù, meaning that he remains aloof and approves of everything. He says ‚ÄúDo whatever you want, and partake of the fruit of what you have done‚Äù. That Mahe≈õvara himself is the supreme being that is in the body. This is unaffected by the state of the body. We call him the ParamƒÅtmƒÅ.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Thus, the Parabrahma is conducting the activities of the universe in three forms ‚Äî prak·πõti, jƒ´va and ƒ™≈õvara.

Whatever is born in this world ‚Äî whether it is a living being or an inanimate object ‚Äî the instrument of its birth is the union of k·π£etra and k·π£etraj√±a, prak·πõti and puru·π£a, or the universe and jƒ´va. They are both equally responsible for the activities of the universe.
Isn‚Äôt the universe of innumerable forms? Therefore, the types of unions of prak·πõti and jƒ´va are also innumerable. There is no limit to the forms, hustle and bustle of prak·πõti. When we set out to learn a subtle and deep matter, it is easier if we start from a direct and perceptible concept and then move towards more subtle and abstract thoughts. Therefore, the SvƒÅmƒ´ starts with the following ‚Äî

  1. ida·πÉ ≈õarƒ´ra·πÉ kaunteya k·π£etram ityabhidhƒ´yate ‡•• - BG 13.2 2. etad yo vetti ta·πÉ prƒÅhu·∏• k·π£etraj√±a iti tad-vida·∏• ‡•• - BG 13.2 3. k·π£etraj√±a·πÉ cƒÅpi mƒÅ·πÉ viddhi sarva-k·π£etre·π£u bhƒÅrata ‡•§ - BG 13.3

As we saw above, the subject here is of the body, the embodied jƒ´va, and paramƒÅtmƒÅ. We shall look at these from the point of view of acquiring knowledge. Initially, ‚Äúida·πÉ ≈õarƒ´ra·πÉ‚Äù ‚Äî this body ‚Äî is k·π£etra, fundamental, base, field. All growth and prosperity starts from there. There is no jƒ´va without the body. The instrument that is the body has three sheaths ‚Äî sth≈´la, s≈´k·π£ma and lai·πÖga. The ƒÅtmƒÅ resides inside these as jƒ´va. etad-yonƒ´ni bh≈´tƒÅni ‡•• (BG 7.6)

The jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ was called the dehƒ´, or the one who resides in the body. Now the word k·π£etraj√±a is used. What is the difference? The difference is in the suffix ‚Äúj√±a‚Äù (*j√±a - avabodhane,*to know, comprehend, understand). In the word ‚Äúdehƒ´‚Äù, the action of knowing is not stated. ‚ÄúJ√±a‚Äù means one who knows.   1. k·π£etraj√±a·πÉ cƒÅpi mƒÅ·πÉ viddhi sarva-k·π£etre·π£u bhƒÅrata ‡•• (13.2)

Here k·π£etra is the first object and k·π£etraj√±a is the second. Knowledge is only possible when there are two objects. The activity of knowing needs two objects ‚Äî the knower and the known. The knower is j√±ƒÅt·πõ, the known is j√±eya. If we stick to the words j√±ƒÅtƒÅ and j√±eya, we can discuss the subject quickly without the strain of too many words.

How does the j√±ƒÅtƒÅ understand the j√±eya? This is an important topic. Isn‚Äôt j√±ƒÅna the relationship that is established between two objects through the activity of the mind and the intellect? What is the instrument that establishes this relationship? Now suppose I sit in the building of the Gokhale institute and talk to someone who is sitting in the Akashavani building. The relationship between us is established by the telephone wire between us. Let us call this instrument that transmits sound from me to him and back from him to me as the communicator. The communicator makes something known. The wire is attached to both sides and is equally related to both. In our present discussion, the body is the k·π£etra and the ƒÅtmƒÅ is the k·π£etraj√±a. If the ƒÅtmƒÅ has to understand the body, there should be a communicating cord between them. Which is that? The communicator should belong to both sides, should be equanimous towards both and should engulf both. What is this between the body and the jƒ´va? That is the paramƒÅtmƒÅ.

Let us see another example. I am speaking now. You are all listening kindly. What is the communicator between us? ‚ÄúSound‚Äù is not enough. If I speak Greek or Latin, only meaningless sounds will reach you. Then, the sound starting from my lips will reach your ears, but cannot reach your minds. My purpose will not be fulfilled if there is no communicator between my mind and yours. Kannada is that communicator. Kannada is the equal instrument for us both. Therefore it can establish a relationship between two minds. Therefore, common language is our communicator.

Similarly, what is the communicator between the k·π£etra and the k·π£etraj√±a, that is equally disposed towards both of them? That is the energy of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. Since this energy - the ƒÅtmacaitanya is equally disposed towards both sides, a k·π£etraj√±a can know his k·π£etra and also other k·π£etras and k·π£etraj√±as. ·πÉayi sarvamida·πÉ prota·πÉ s≈´tre ma·πáiga·πáƒÅ iva ‡•• (BG 7.7)

A thread strings beads of various shapes and colors and creates a necklace out of them. If the thread breaks, the beads will be strewn every which way. The various aspects of the universe are similarly arranged. The thread that strings them is paramƒÅtmƒÅ, and is the communicator that establishes the relationship of knowledge between them. Therefore, the ≈õƒÅstras call it the ‚Äús≈´trƒÅtama‚Äù.
There are three concepts to keep in mind here.

  1. k·π£etra ‚Äî which is the prak·πõti of the universe 2. k·π£etraj√±a ‚Äî which is the jƒ´vatma 3. paramƒÅtma, The thread that extends equally amongst all k·π£etras and k·π£etraj√±as

BhagavƒÅn has given the description of all the above. Let us first look at prak·πõti.

MahƒÅ-bh≈´tƒÅny-aha·πÖkƒÅro buddhir-avyaktam-eva ca ‡•§

These are twenty four objects together ‚Äî

(6) aha·πákƒÅra (the concept of I, ego)
(7) buddhi

Here, BhagavƒÅn lists the constituents of the type of prak·πõti that is k·π£etra. Among them, avyakta is one. Of the others, some ‚Äî like the five elements, are perceptible by everyone, whereas some ‚Äî like love and hatred ‚Äî are understood only by experience. ‚ÄúAvyakta‚Äù belongs to neither category. What is it?
Avyakta is something that is not manifest. It is reality that is not clear. It is the hidden energy that is invisible in spite of existing, that exists in spite of being invisible. We can call that as the hidden treasure, the reserve of the energy of the Brahma. Let us see a couple of examples. We all see water daily. We have seen lakes and wells. But when we stand in front of the Jog falls or look at the ocean, we experience an extraordinary feeling that is not felt when a lake or a well is seen. The capability to bring about such a reaction in us exists in the waters of lakes and wells, but is avyakta. It becomes perceptible when it is seen amassed in the waters of rivers and seas.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

The object that is water, is H‚ÇÇO for a chemist, and ambrosia for a thirsty man. The satiating and refreshing potential imperceptible in hydrogen and oxygen was perceived by the mind of a thirsty man when they together touched his tongue.
Beauty is also the perceived state of ‚Äúavyakta‚Äù. Eyes, ears, mouth, nose, cheeks and hair ‚Äî these are present for all faces. All bodies are equally made of skin, blood vessels and bones to a surgeon. A chemist does not see the difference in the physical makeup of one person from that of another. Can a connoisseur of beauty accept this? A face is beautiful if it has a quality that transcends that of organs, something that cannot be obtained by the analysis of a mere surgeon or a chemist; otherwise it is ugly. That quality might be a kind of brightness, movement, or expression. A frowning face might become gracious and pleasant on seeing someone. A plain face may appear beautiful to someone; it is the good fortune of the seer! The beauty that was hitherto imperceptible becomes known to the inner workings of the beholder‚Äôs mind.
This, then, is avyakta. It remains hidden always and shows itself and influences us from time to time. It is the innermost motion of prak·πõti.
To the innumerable avyaktas we see in the world, we can add the results of the development of human intellect. Steam power, petroleum energy, electricity were not known ‚Äî were avyakta ‚Äî a couple of hundred years ago. As human intellect developed and spread, scientific research was accelerated, it discovered and honed the ‚Äúavyakta‚Äù energies and made them clearly perceptible. Train, ship, car, aeroplane, the Sputnik ‚Äî all these are examples of avyakta manifesting in front of us.
Sweetness is avyakta in a raw mango. As time goes by, sweetness gradually expresses itself. Taste and digestibility are avyakta in freshly harvested rice. The same rice becomes tasty and easily digestible in a few months.
Thus, avyakta is that quality of prak·πõti that is hidden in the beginning and shows itself as time goes by. We can call it the root‚Äîprak·πõti, or the embryo‚Äîstate of prak·πõti.

avyaktƒÅd-vyaktaya·∏• sarvƒÅ·∏•‡••

Avyakta is the immense, unfathomable energy of prak·πõti that lays hidden. The world is forever new because of it. It can also be described as the energy of prak·πõti that rejuvenates the universe.
There are other inner workings and experiences that should be added to the twenty four concepts listed above.

AmƒÅnitva: Pride means to think of oneself as the best, and gives rise to arrogance. AmƒÅnitva is giving it up. That is humility, and willingness to be led.
Adambhitva: the desire to show off one‚Äôs own qualities and possessions that are deemed valuable by others is dambha. This should be given up.
Ahi·πÉsƒÅ, k·π£amƒÅgu·πáa, ƒÅrjava ‚Äî mean that one‚Äôs conduct is not crooked, but is simple and straightforward. Performing service to the Guru, maintaining purity of body and mind, steadfastness, giving up impulsiveness and never being distracted and inattentive, not hankering after carnal pleasures and not thinking only of oneself all the time, not being captivated by wives and children or land and wealth, not swaying according to one‚Äôs own whims ‚Äî these are some don‚Äôts.

The meaning of j√±ƒÅna-nityatva (or ni·π£·π≠hatva) may be understood as firmly rooted in knowledge or proficiency in learning. What does ‚Äúartha-dar≈õanam‚Äù mean? Reciting verses and explaining their meaning is not experiencing it. It is not enough if Philosophy is outwards, it should make one look inwards.
If someone asks us to prove philosophical concepts and to show evidence about the existence of Brahma, we should show the above list and ask them what qualities among them they have practised. If they have not passed the above exam, let them prepare themselves first. Of what use are spectacles to someone whose eyes are bandaged because of disease?

locanƒÅbhyƒÅ·πÉ vihƒ´nasya darpa·πáa·∏• ki·πÉ kari·π£yati?

(Hitopade≈õa)

The qualities of amƒÅnitva, adambhitva and ƒÅrjava are not easy to follow. We miss our steps because of transgressions that might appear small and insignificant. A man who commits a colossal offence might attain sadgati sooner. Ravana and Hira·πáyaka≈õipu were released quickly of their mortal coils. We are scared of committing big crimes, but overlook small snafus. We easily lie in small matters, and think that they will not affect anyone. Small corruptions deform the jƒ´va and crumple it. The jƒ´va is like a string. It can be easily bent, but cannot be straightened again with the same ease. The jƒ´va is like paper; it is easy to fold it, but it is difficult to get rid of the creases. Those who want to experience paramƒÅtmƒÅ should first lose their crookedness and deformities. The don‚Äôts in the above list demand long and careful practice. If we want to understand the supreme tattva, we should first make our jƒ´va get rid of its bad habits. Therefore, the first step to philosophy is self-examination and self-inquiry.
After explaining the devices to obtain knowledge comes the description of that which has to be known ‚Äî j√±eya. What is that? We saw in the chapter of karmayoga ‚Äî

Let us summarize and recall the points in our discussion so far. They are four.

  1. Prak·πõti: The material of the universe that is made of the five elements, it shelters other aspects; the body and its attributes; by itself it is inanimate. 2. Jƒ´va: It is the animate aspect that lives in the inanimate universe, and consumes the fruit of its actions, and it is directed by the gu·πáa-triad. 3. ƒ™shvara: It is present in all inanimate energies and is also present externally as an authoritative factor, and rules over the universe and the jƒ´va. Parabrahma: It is that, whose tiniest part of energy is the cause of all the activities of the universe, from whose immeasurable sunlight one single ray sustains life in all universe ‚Äî that eternal and fundamental energy. This is also called kƒÅra·πáa-brahma or ≈õuddha-brahma.

Thus, there are four aspects to the para-tattva. These four do not have any beginning. The former among them pales in front of the latter. From the first three arises sa·πÉsƒÅra which deviates from Brahma. When the jƒ´va meets Brahma, that sa·πÉsƒÅra ceases to be experienced. A person who knows Brahma looks at sa·πÉsƒÅra as a playful sport rather than a laborious task that has been imposed upon him. That is, even though all the above four are without any beginning, the attachment of the first three to sa·πÉsƒÅra is not eternal. The dominance of the first three is ended by the fourth.

Summary

The reason for the rampant violence and instability everywhere can be traced to the imbalance of the three gu·πáas that constitute the world ‚Äì sattva, rajas and tamas. This should be borne in mind by politicians who seek world peace and universal upliftment and organise summits and seminars on the same. Section 15 /Chapter 14 /Gu·πáa-traya-vibhƒÅga-yoga /Trigu·πáa-tantra-jƒÅgar≈´ka-yoga

(The yoga of attention towards the mechanism of the three gu·πáas)

This chapter deals with the effects of the three gu·πáas of prak·πõti that have been expounded upon by BhagavƒÅn right from the beginning of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. In the third chapter, BhagavƒÅn says

gu·πáƒÅ gu·πáe·π£u vartanta iti matvƒÅ na sajjate ‡••
(BG 3.28)
‚ÄúThe gu·πáas of man‚Äôs inner and outer nature act with and react to one another resulting in activity. The seer knows that these works do not attach to the Self.‚Äù

Thus the svƒÅmƒ´ repeatedly separates out the jƒ´va‚Äôs ƒÅtmƒÅ and the instruments of his work.

In the seventh chapter, he instructs again ‚Äì

tribhir-gu·πáa-mayair bhƒÅvair-ebhi·∏• sarvam-ida·πÉ jagat

‚ÄúThe myriad effects of these three gu·πáas have deluded the entire world causing the jƒ´va to not know his own Self. MƒÅyƒÅ is the power of these three gu·πáas.It is hard to cross her, but not impossible. Those who take refuge entirely in BhagavƒÅn can cross this ocean of MƒÅyƒÅ.‚Äù

What does this mean? The wall standing between the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ and the paramƒÅtmƒÅ was built by prak·πõti. The three gu·πáas are the bricks that make up this wall. Those desirous of experiencing paramƒÅtmƒÅ have to exert themselves in scaling this wall. This wall of mƒÅyƒÅ is the main topic of the fourteenth chapter.

This chapter is small without much scope for debate or polemics and hence, not much is said about this chapter in our commentarial tradition. That is not a reason, however, to consider this chapter unimportant. In my opinion, the description of the three gu·πáas is key to our analysis of reality. Plato, the Greek philosopher par excellence, has opined that human nature is tri-fold. Those interested can study this in his Republic. It is these natural gu·πáas that form and influence human life. These three gu·πáas are the source of all the actions and behaviours of this world. Without understanding the character of these three gu·πáas well it is impossible to understand the jƒ´va‚Äôs nature. Without knowing the nature of the jƒ´va, it is not possible to bring harmony to the world and the nature of our ƒÅtmƒÅ will remain distant from us. It is therefore that the svƒÅmƒ´ tells us -

yajj√±ƒÅtvƒÅ munaya·∏• sarve parƒÅ·πÉ siddhim ito gatƒÅ·∏• ‡••
(BG 14.1)
ida·πÉ j√±ƒÅnam upƒÅ≈õritya mama sƒÅdharmyam ƒÅgatƒÅ·∏• ‡••
(BG 14.2)

By realising the nuances of these gu·πáas, all the great sages attained great siddhis and became
similar in nature to BhagavƒÅn.

Gu·πáa here does not refer to specific human qualities transmitted from person to person or those imbibed by one‚Äôs own experience or via imitation of others or something non-existent that was gained via gradual practice. This chapter‚Äôs exposition is about the innate gu·πáas that are natural to us and accompany us from our birth.

We analysed two parts of the world in the previous chapter ‚Äì k·π£etra and k·π£etraj√±a. It is now pertinent for us to understand the amount of influence that the k·π£etra (prak·πõti) has on the daily life of the k·π£etraj√±a (jƒ´va). The three gu·πáas are the power of the k·π£etra. The svƒÅmƒ´ now tells us about the main aspects of the k·π£etra, which is none other than Universal prak·πõti - the vi≈õvaprak·πõti, the stuff of which the universe is made. The first evolved state of prak·πõti is mahat. Just as clay is used by a potter to make his wares, mahat is used by ƒ™≈õvara to create the world.

mama yonir-mahad brahma tasmin garbha·πÉ dadhƒÅmy-aham ‡•§
sambhava·∏• sarva-bh≈´tƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ tato bhavati bhƒÅrata ‡••
(BG 14.3)
‚ÄúMahat ‚Äì the primordial form of Prak·πõti ‚Äì is the generative organ in which I, Brahma, plant the seed. Then happens the birth of all beings.‚Äù

In words such as mahad-brahma and mahad-yoni, mahat refers to the primordial prak·πõti. All accounts of creation are intellectual concepts created by great sages for the instruction of common folk. It should not be thought that the act of creation happened on a specific day at a specific time or that there was nothing created before that moment. Creation is without beginning, it has been there forever, undergoing constant modification. It is just for the convenience of stating an account that we fix a time for creation. If we were to narrate the account of creation as a story ‚Äì in the beginning of creation existed pure Brahma ‚Äì which is the kƒÅra·πáa-brahma or the cause. KƒÅrya-brahma or Brahma that is an effect is a later modification of Pure Brahma. It is at that stage that Brahma ‚Äôdecides‚Äô to create. Brahma that is associated with a will to create is known as ≈õabala-brahma or Brahma with variety. Its power or energy is the Unmanifest or the avyakta.

avyaktƒÅd-vyaktaya·∏• sarvƒÅ·∏• ‡••
(BG 8-18)

From avyakta comes mahat ‚Äì an undifferentiated, amorphous mass. From mahat comes aha·πÖkƒÅra (ego); from it come the five tanmƒÅtras (the subtle substrata of the five elements); from it the five primordial elements and from them comes the world.

This is the order in which creation occurs.

mahata·∏• param-avyaktam ‡••
(Ka·π≠hopani·π£ad)

From mahat proceeds avyakta ‚Äì

prƒÅk·πõtam-annam tri-gu·πáa-bheda-pari·πáƒÅmatvƒÅt mahad-ƒÅdyam ‡•§
(MaitrƒÅya·πáyupani·π£ad)
The mass of prak·πõti because of the differentiated three gu·πáas becomes mahat.

Back to this chapter.

sarva-yoni·π£u kaunteya m≈´rtaya·∏• sambhavanti yƒÅ·∏•
tƒÅsƒÅ·πÉ brahma mahad-yonir-aha·πÉ bƒ´ja-prada·∏• pitƒÅ ‡••
(BG 14.4)
Wherever, whatever is born ‚Äì whatever be its shape or action ‚Äì its first mother is Prak·πõti, just as ƒ™≈õvara or Puru·π£a is its first father.

They are the ƒÅdi-dampati (the primordial couple) as well as the anƒÅdi-dampati (the beginningless couple). All the couples of this universe are Prak·πõti and ƒ™≈õvara. The world calls them variously as BrahmƒÅ-Sarasvatƒ´, Vi·π£·πáu-Lak·π£mƒ´ or as ≈öiva-Gaurƒ´.
Is this couple made of separate constituents? Or is it just one principle that manifests itself as two? This is a monumental question that we will deal with later. Let us now consider one of the two ‚Äì prak·πõti that is the k·π£etra or the field for the birth of the world.

sattva·πÉ rajas tama iti gu·πáƒÅ·∏• prak·πõiti-sambhavƒÅ·∏•
nibadhnanti mahƒÅ-bƒÅho dehe dehinam avyayam ‡••

‚ÄúSattva, Rajas, and Tamas, the three gu·πáas born of prak·πõti, bind the embodied ƒÅtmƒÅ to the body, though the ƒÅtmƒÅ is changeless. Thus, the changeless appears changed. Bringing the appearance of change to the changeless is the power of the tri-fold gu·πáas of prak·πõti.‚Äù

This is a principle we need to bear in mind. It is more important to remember that the bond of the world is made of the gu·πáa-triad than remembering that the world is made of five elements.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 14 Yoga of Attention towards the Mechanism of the Three Gu·πáas (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

What is a gu·πáa? A certain innate characteristic or natural power of a thing that causes affinity or otherwise with another thing is its gu·πáa. Thus the gu·πáa is an intrinsic power of a thing that attracts or repels another. It requires a counterpart just as love requires a suitable recipient; beauty requires a connoisseur; valour a competitor; scholarship a disciple; magnanimity requires one who seeks; pomp and show require an audience; the taste of a dainty dish requires a diner; darkness requires light; sorrow requires one who can take it away; pleasure requires one to renew it; infamy requires fame, and so on. Inviting or repelling another thing is the effect of a gu·πáa. Hence gu·πáa is something that requires something else to be with it. The graha-pratigraha^(^([1])) section of the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad 3.2 deals with the importance of gu·πáa. The relationship between Brahma and gu·πáa has two sides. While Brahma does not require anything else, gu·πáa is that which requires another for its existence. From gu·πáa rise the world and this life. The world exists as long as the gu·πáa exists. He who transcends the gu·πáas goes beyond the world.

In our current discussion, the gu·πáa is a natural disposition, tendency or impulse that manifests itself in man‚Äôs anta·∏•-kara·πáa^(^([2])). One could call gu·πáa an inner impulse. Gu·πáa is normally translated into English as ‚Äôquality,‚Äô but a translation as ‚Äôimpulse‚Äô or ‚Äôpropensity‚Äô is better. A gu·πáa manifests itself externally ‚Äì up from the depths of man. There are two effects stemming from this propensity ‚Äì

  1. Eroding of the past 2. Seeding the future.

The gu·πáa expresses a jƒ´va‚Äôs sa·πÉskƒÅras from past lives and rarefies them. Sa·πÉskƒÅra here refers to a jƒ´va‚Äôs learning from its trials and tribulations as well as persistent experience and practice. Every jƒ´va carries a bundle of sa·πÉskƒÅras from its lives from its beginningless past and its repeated contact with the world in each of its lives. Such residual impressions in a jƒ´va are termed vƒÅsanas. The natural gu·πáas expend each of these vƒÅsanas from previous lives by expressing them. When a jƒ´va contacts the world in its present life, its gu·πáas from previous lives are used to interact with other jƒ´vas who in response express their own gu·πáas. This response from the world and other jƒ´vas gives more sa·πÉskƒÅras to our jƒ´va. These new sa·πÉskƒÅras seed the jƒ´va‚Äôs future. In this way, our latent propensities or innate gu·πáas are the results of our previous sa·πÉskƒÅras as well as seeds for future lives.

A gu·πáa is usually defined as an internal quality of a thing that causes a distinct and definite effect. Examples are fragrance in sandalwood or coolness in water. A gu·πáa could also mean a rope or thread. Binding is a rope‚Äôs function. Therefore the statement ‚Äúgu·πáƒÅ nibadhnanti‚Äù (gu·πáas bind) is apt even in this way.

It is by philosophical convention that gu·πáas are three in number. In reality, there is no gu·πáa that exists purely by itself without an admixture of other gu·πáas. Is there just air in a city‚Äôs atmosphere? Especially on a busy public road with buses travelling on it? There are several substances mixed in it ‚Äì rattling noise from the bus‚Äôs engine, dust arising at its tyres, diesel fumes from its exhaust pipes, its pungent odour, and so on. These substances are always mixed in a busy road‚Äôs air. Similarly, the three gu·πáas coexist, and found always mixed with one another. The proportions of the gu·πáa mixture vary with each individual jƒ´va. Each jƒ´va has a unique ratio of the gu·πáa-combination. Infinite jƒ´vas imply infinite ratios in which gu·πáas are combined.

When only one of the three gu·πáas exists, activity cannot take place in the world as even when they are in equal proportion. This is an important concept. If the world has to be the world that is, in constant movement, two circumstances are necessary ‚Äì

  1. The gu·πáas have to be intermixed. 2. The gu·πáas should not be mixed in equal proportion.

For the world to be dynamic, the gu·πáas have to be mixed in unequal proportions.

What should one with viveka do then? He knows that sattva is conducive towards wellness and that he cannot escape from rajas and tamas. With the inevitable presence of all the three gu·πáas and only one of them preferred, the best help one‚Äôs discernment could give is towards the elevation of one‚Äôs sattva-gu·πáa. One should strive to increase one‚Äôs level of sattva and maintain a higher proportion of rajas than tamas as much as possible. This is the only freedom one has.

Pure sattva, by itself, cannot accomplish anything in this world. It needs rajas for it to act. But even when much rajas is accumulated, it must be subservient to sattva. Rajas should not lord over sattva. This combination is referred to as brahma-k·π£atram in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad (1.4).

brahma vƒÅ idam-agra ƒÅsƒ´tka ekam-eva ‡•§
tad-eka·πÉ sanna vyabhavat ‡•§
tacchreyo-r≈´pam atyas·πõjata ‡•§
k·π£atram ‡•§
yƒÅnyetƒÅni devatrƒÅ k·π£atrƒÅ·πái ‡•§
dharma·πÉ tad-etat k·π£atrasya k·π£atram ‡•§
yad-dharma·∏•…. tad-etat brahma-k·π£atram ‡•§…
‚ÄúBrahma existed first. Only it existed. It created an excellent form. That is k·π£atra. Those qualities that can protect even devatƒÅs are k·π£atra. Dharma can be established through k·π£atra and not just through brƒÅhma·πáya, which is pure sattva. If dharma, of the form of obedience of men to devatƒÅs, has to be established in this world, the gu·πáa of brƒÅhma·πáya - sattva, should unite with rajas ‚Äì the gu·πáa of k·π£atra. Pure sattva is insufficient for this world‚Äôs work.‚Äù

Let us now look at the characteristics and differences across the three gu·πáas in this table. This has been described in twelve verses. A summary is given below.

| Gu·πáa | Nature | Indication | Activity | Effect | Path to | Conclusion | |———-|——————|—————————-|——————–|————————|————————–|———————| | Sattva | Purity | Illumination | Knowledge | Bliss | Higher worlds - svarga | Peace | | Rajas | Desire and anger | Being excessive, agitation | Action orientation | Craving, Anxiety | Middle world - earth | Repetitive movement | | Tamas | Delusion | Inaction | Ignorance | Error, Laziness, Sleep | Lower world - naraka | Sorrow |

We have already discussed that these three gu·πáas are always found combined in unequal proportions.

rajas tama≈õ-cƒÅbhibh≈´ya sattva·πÉ bhavati bhƒÅrata
raja·∏• sattva·πÉ tama≈õ-caiva tama·∏• sattva·πÉ rajas tathƒÅ ‡••
(BG 14.10)

‚ÄúSattva pushes Rajas and Tamas down; Rajas in turn tries to dominate Sattva and Tamas; Tamas also tries to overpower Sattva and Rajas. This contest between these gu·πáas results in world activity.‚Äù

If these gu·πáas were to settle down in equal proportions, world activity will come to a standstill. ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara and ≈örƒ´ RƒÅmanuja have indicated the same in their commentary on the following Brahma-s≈´tra.

a·πÖgitvƒÅnupapatte≈õca ‡•§ (2.2.8)

The bhƒÅ·π£ya of ≈örƒ´ RƒÅmanuja is as follows ‚Äì

gu·πáƒÅnƒÅm-utkar·π£a-nikar·π£a-nibandhan-ƒÅ·πÖgƒÅ·πÖgi-bhƒÅvƒÅddhi jagatprav·πõtti·∏• ‡•§
sƒÅmyƒÅvasthƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ sattva-rajas-tamasƒÅm anyony-ƒÅdhikya-ny≈´natv-ƒÅbhƒÅvƒÅt a·πÖgƒÅ·πÖgi-bhƒÅvƒÅ-nupapatte·∏• na jagatsarga upapadyate ‡•§
(The increase and reduction in the proportion of gu·πáas and subsequent bondage and one gu·πáa being subservient to another results in world activity. When sattva, rajas and tamas are in equal proportions, due to their not being more or less than each other, there is no relation of principal or subordinate between them, and hence there is no creation of the world).

People who ardently aspire thus ‚Äì ‚ÄúWars should stop on this earth. Peace should be established. There should be universal upliftment‚Äù ‚Äì should remember this. When there is infection in the gut, pus in the blood, and lice in the hair, there is no point in distributing face powder as the means towards happiness. The situation is similar to aspiring for world peace while their interiors are filled with rajas and tamas. Of what good is nuclear disarmament when the insides are boiling with poison?

Don‚Äôt ask if peace isn‚Äôt needed. Who doesn‚Äôt want peace? There is no wealth greater than peace for those belonging to Vaidika-dharma. There is no happiness greater than peace.

p·πõthivƒ´ ≈õƒÅntƒÅ sa‚ÄôgninƒÅ ≈õƒÅntƒÅ sƒÅ me ≈õƒÅntƒÅ ≈õucag·πÉ ≈õamayatu‡•§
…p·πõthivƒ´ ≈õƒÅntirantarik·π£agm ≈õƒÅntirdyau·∏• ≈õƒÅntirdi≈õa≈õ≈õƒÅnti·∏•…‡•§

The above is the daily prayer of Vaidika-·πõ·π£is. However, such a prayer does not yield fruit with no efforts on our part. They have shown us the path to attain that peace.

≈õrƒ´≈õca hrƒ´≈õca dh·πõti≈õca tapo medhƒÅ prati·π£·π≠hƒÅ ≈õraddhƒÅ satya·πÉ dharma≈õcaitƒÅni ‡•§

This path is difficult. Peace can definitely be attained by those who accept this path and walk on it. This path, however, is not for politicians who desire their own victory and the defeat of their enemies which they confuse for peace. Will a person affected by scabies be cured by constant instructions of ‚ÄúDo not scratch!‚Äù? Only when the person consumes medicine that purifies the blood and destroys disease-causing micro-organisms will the itch be resolved. The path for those who desire world peace is similar. They have to first cross the three gu·πáas and bring those with a preponderance of rajas and tamas to the path of sattva. Who are those that can accomplish this? Do such people exist?

BhagavƒÅn said ‚Äì

‚ÄúnƒÅnya·πÉ gu·πáebhya·∏• kartƒÅra·πÉ yadƒÅ dra·π£·π≠ƒÅnupa≈õyati

(BG 14.19)
‚ÄúWhen the seer sees that there is nothing other than the three gu·πáas that performs action, he realises the one beyond the gu·πáas and attains the nature of ƒ™≈õvara.‚Äù

[[Ch. 14 Yoga of Attention towards the Mechanism of the Three Gu·πáas (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

A relevant matter here needs discussion. BhagavƒÅn says that the three gu·πáas have to be transcended or sublimated. Good. But even to transcend those gu·πáas, a gu·πáa or means is needed. Is that way a gu·πáa? What gu·πáa is that?

That gu·πáa is sattva, a preponderance of sattva to be precise. There is a state to be attained by elevating the proportion of sattva. What is the gu·πáa of that state? Even that is sattva. Sattva is obtained by enhancing sattva. What does it mean?

Sattva is of two kinds. One that is attached to rajas and tamas. The other is beyond even the contact of rajas and tamas and exists by itself. The former is combined sattva or sattva pertaining to Prak·πõti. The latter is pure sattva or sattva pertaining to Brahma. When combined sattva is purified of other gu·πáas and strengthened it becomes fit to attain BrƒÅhmƒ´-state.

The words ‚Äì ‚Äúexceeded‚Äù, ‚Äúsublimated‚Äù, ‚Äúgo beyond‚Äù ‚Äì do not just refer to rajas and tamas but also to that sattva that is blended with them. For experiencing Brahma, only the element of pure sattva is needed. The nature of pure sattva is described in the seventeenth chapter, thus:

sadbhƒÅve sƒÅdhubhƒÅve ca sadityetprayujyate ‡••
(BG 17.26)

Next in the fourteenth chapter.

gu·πáƒÅn etƒÅn atƒ´tya trƒ´n dehƒ´ deha-samudbhavƒÅn
janma-m·πõityu-jarƒÅ-du·∏•khair vimukto‚Äôm·πõitam a≈õnute ‡••
(BG 14.20)

‚ÄúThe three gu·πáas are born in the body. When the embodied ƒÅtmƒÅ goes beyond those gu·πáas, he becomes free of birth, death, old age and sorrow and attains immortality.‚Äù

Arjuna then asked ‚Äì ‚ÄúSvƒÅmin, what are the markers of one who has transcended the gu·πáas? How does he behave?

Now BhagavƒÅn shows us a method to win over the three gu·πáas and transcend them:

prakƒÅ≈õa·πÉ cha prav·πõitti·πÉ cha moham eva cha pƒÅ·πá·∏çava

‚ÄúIllumination is sattva; action is rajas and delusion is tamas. The knower does not hate any of these gu·πáas when they operate around him. He does not seek out any of them when they are absent.‚Äù

udƒÅsƒ´na-vad ƒÅsƒ´no gu·πáair yo na vichƒÅlyate

He appears udƒÅsƒ´navat (like an indifferent person). However, he is not really indifferent. The vat suffix after udƒÅsƒ´na shows similarity, not identity. Being indifferent would mean lacking innate compassion for the world, and without any interest in dharma. It should not be so. If a knower were to be really indifferent, it would conflict with BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs teaching about duty from the previous chapters. Can an indifferent person ‚Äì one that does not accept any duty ‚Äì have any ordained duty? Duties must be performed with sincerity and interest but with no desire for their fruit. This is the meaning from the suffix vat in udƒÅsƒ´na-vat. The seeker‚Äôs mental constitution should not alter. Just as the manas of an indifferent person is unattached, the one who is unattached to the results of an action is a knower. The manas of a knower is not agitated by the play of the gu·πáa-triad. He is not shaken up like common people who become slaves to the changes in their gu·πáas.

Peals of laughter, exclamations, cries, bawls, brawls and songs of inmates are all heard in a mental institution. When a person ‚Äì mentally sound or one who considers himself sound ‚Äì visits the mental institution, he considers all those displays of emotion as symptoms of mental illness. Similarly the one who has transcended the gu·πáas sees the agitations and celebrations of worldly people and considers them as a play of the natural gu·πáas, an illness caused by them. He himself is unaffected by them.

How does one reach this elevated state? Through constant remembrance of Brahma and practice of Brahma‚Äôs presence.

brahma·πáo hi prati·π£·π≠hƒÅham am·πõitasyƒÅvyayasya cha

‚Äú≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa is the direct form of Supreme Brahma. He is the greatest sattva without any modification or loss; he is the origin of eternal dharma; he is the fountainhead of unbroken bliss.‚Äù

The one who constantly reflects upon this sees all the gu·πáas, the desires and the agitations they cause, and the activity they inspire as things other than the ƒÅtmƒÅ. His focus is on dharma alone. By gradual practice of self-control, pure sattva preponderates in him and through that he experiences paramƒÅtmƒÅ.

Just as the cure for a disease becomes possible only after knowing its defining characteristics, it becomes easier to treat the jƒ´va after knowing about the method of the three gu·πáas. This seems to have been BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs intent in this chapter. Let us transcend the three gu·πáas through the blessings of BhagavƒÅn.
