Summary

We act according to our whims and desires, forgetting that it is us who have created our own life circumstances, and that it is our present behaviour that forms our future. BhagavƒÅn instructs us through a profound allegory that this world has its origin in Brahma. We are the ones who defile this sa·πÉsƒÅra that is born out of Brahma. It is possible to extricate ourselves from this relationship through a practice of detachment. The one who is detached is not weighed down by the world. The world becomes a place of entertainment for him.

Section 16 /Chapter 15 /Puru·π£ottama-yoga /ƒÄ≈õvattha-m≈´lopƒÅsana-yoga

(The Yoga of meditation on the root of the a≈õvattha)

At the end of the previous chapter, BhagavƒÅn showed us an excellent strategy of the escape from the web of the three gu·πáas and stated that it was him - the Supreme Self - that was the origin of dharma.

≈õƒÅ≈õvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikƒÅntikasya ca ‡••
BG 14.27

The first of the Puru·π£ƒÅrthas (the four primary human values) is dharma and the last is Mok·π£a - both of which reside in Brahma.

brahma·πáo hi prati·π£·π≠hƒÅham ‡••
ibid

(I am the support of ƒ™≈õvara)
The above statement tells us that it is Brahma that appears as dharma in this world system. How is Brahma the same as dharma? The SvƒÅmƒ´ now explains.
Dharma is an arrangement of relationships. For any relationship, there have to be two things. There is no talk of a relationship in the case of a story like Robinson Crusoe‚Äôs who is all by himself. There is a relationship only when there are at least two objects. Even Crusoe who lived on an uninhabited island considered himself as many and had to think - ‚ÄúMy body is dirty. I must wash it‚Äù, ‚ÄúMy stomach is feeling hungry. I must look for some food for it‚Äù - thereby considering his own bodily organs as different from him. At those moments, the relationship between him and his body is through the tactile sense; the relationship between him and his stomach is through the affliction of hunger. When that relationship - that can exist between two or more objects - is as good it can be, it is called dharma. In the relationship of dharma, the jƒ´va is one side while the jagat (the world) is on the other. Dharma sustains both of them.
BhagavƒÅn uses a beautiful metaphor to drive home this teaching. A metaphor (r≈´paka) is a figure of speech (an ala·πákƒÅra). The function of an ala·πákƒÅra is to compare a well-known object to a little-known or unknown object to better inform the reader about the nature of the latter. In such an ala·πákƒÅra, if the object of comparison and the standard of comparison are treated as one without any distinction between them, it is called a metaphor. Consider the following example from a Kannada classic.

≈õrƒ´vadhuvina·πÉbakacakoraka·πÉ‚Ä¶
devapura-lak·π£mƒ´-rama·πáanƒÅsyaca·πÉdran ƒÅna·πÉdama·πÉ namagƒ´yali ‡•§‡•§
-Jaimini BhƒÅrata 1.1

(Sought after by cakora-bird-eyes of ≈õrƒ´, may the moon-face of the deity of Devapura - Lak·π£mƒ´-rama·πáa - bestow bliss upon us.)

This is a r≈´paka (metaphor) in which all the features of the moon are shown established in the face of Lak·π£mƒ´-rama·πáa.

There are different r≈´pakas such as abheda (non-difference) and tƒÅdr≈´pya (having the same form). Let us not dwell upon the intricacies of ala·πákƒÅra-≈õƒÅstra (aesthetics) right now. What is relevant to us now is this - r≈´paka is a figure of speech that gives a better understanding of something we don‚Äôt know. The jƒ´va, the world, Brahma - are all things that are not directly perceived. BhagavƒÅn uses the metaphor of the directly perceived a≈õvattha tree to help us visualise the nature of the relationship between the jƒ´va, the world, and Brahma.

≈´rdhva-m≈´lam adhahÃ£-≈õƒÅkham a≈õvatthamÃÅ prƒÅhur-avyayam ‡•§
chandƒÅmÃÅsi yasya parnÃ£ƒÅni yas tamÃÅ veda sa veda-vit ‡••
BG 15.1
‚ÄúThere is an indestructible Peepal tree. But its roots are above and its shoots are towards the bottom. Its leaves are the Vedas. Whoever knows is the knower of the Veda.‚Äù

This is a topsy-turvy, root-over-head tree! Look at its speciality! Its roots are up somewhere - unseen by our eyes, unreachable by our hands while its branches point downwards where we can reach them. This means that the branches and twigs of this tree form the entire material of the world. This tree is - avyayam prƒÅhu·∏• - said to be unmodifiable; that can never be destroyed; always of one form. The Vedas are the leaves of this tree. He who knows the secret of this tree knows everything.

adha≈õ cordhva·πÉ prasrÃ£tƒÅs-tasya ≈õƒÅkhƒÅ
gunÃ£a-pravrÃ£ddhƒÅ visÃ£aya-pravƒÅlƒÅhÃ£ ‡•§
adha≈õ ca m≈´lƒÅny-anusantatƒÅni
karmƒÅnubandhƒ´ni manusÃ£ya-loke ‡••
BG 15.2
‚ÄúThe tree‚Äôs branches extend both upward and downward. The three gu·πáas of sattva, rajas and tamas are the fertiliser that nourish the tree. The objects of desire are its tender shoots. Its props and roots sprawl across the human world, binding jƒ´vas with karma.‚Äù

As long as the three gu·πáas of sattva, rajas and tamas are operating, this tree stands well-nourished. The shoots of this tree - visÃ£aya-pravƒÅlƒÅhÃ£ - are objects of desire that are ever fresh; making us think ‚ÄúI need this, I desire that‚Äù and have myriad cravings. This tree‚Äôs props and roots are anusantatƒÅni - which continuously follow, and are karmƒÅnubandhƒ´ni as well - they bind us with our own karmas. ManusÃ£ya-loke is mentioned here as humans are endowed with more awareness and responsibility than animals and birds. The world of humans lies between the upper heavens of the devas and the nether regions. The human jƒ´va can go up or down.
The origin of the world-a≈õvattha cannot be comprehended by the human mind. It is not possible for humans to newly extend the tree. It is Prak·πõti that has sustained the growth of the tree from time immemorial using her three gu·πáas. It is only the tree‚Äôs fruit that is for man‚Äôs consumption.
Let us look at the many interesting features of this sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree. Sa·πÉsƒÅra is not to be construed just as family and children. It is the river of life of the form of birth and death. Whatever we meet in our life journey - all of it constitutes sa·πÉsƒÅra while being - karmƒÅnubandhƒ´ni - binding us with karma.
Any tree could have been used as the object of this metaphor. Why was the A≈õvattha or the holy Peepal tree chosen? The use of this tree as a metaphor is as ancient as the Vedas. Why did the great sages choose this tree? What is the secret behind their choice of the A≈õvattha? The features of the A≈õvattha tally well with the circumstances of sa·πÉsƒÅra. This great tree has four special characteristics that are the same as sa·πÉsƒÅra.

  1. Longevity: The A≈õvattha has a long lifespan. While one of its sides wilts away another side blossoms.Sa·πÉsƒÅra is similar - non-existent on one side while growing on the other. Through the succession of offspring, it is long-lived as well. 2. Widespread: The branches, the roots and props of the A≈õvattha extend in all directions for a long distance. The branches of sa·πÉsƒÅra too extend afar from hither to thither. 3. Many knotted: The props and the branches of the A≈õvattha are knotted and braided haphazardly. Sa·πÉsƒÅra similarly is knotty in its numerous narrow and arduous circumstances that arise due to the push and pull of relationships. 4. Nourishes many: The A≈õvattha gives refuge to many insects and birds and protects them. Sa·πÉsƒÅra too protects and nourishes many relatives, friends, guests, strangers, and those who come in contact with us through their professions and trades.

Thus the comparison is quite apt. This is an ancient metaphor described in the YajurƒÅra·πáyaka as follows.

≈´rdhvam≈´lamavƒÅk≈õƒÅkham ‡•§ v·πõk·π£a·πÉ yo veda samprati ‡•§ na sa jƒÅtu jana·∏• ≈õraddadhyƒÅt ‡•§ m·πõtyurmƒÅ mƒÅrayƒÅditi·∏• ‡•§
-Taittirƒ´yƒÅra·πáyaka 1.11.5
‚ÄúThe one who knows the secret of the tree with its roots at the top and branches at the bottom will not be afraid that death might strike him. This is because he knows that the tree‚Äôs roots lie in eternal Brahma-consciousness.‚Äù

BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs statement echoes the same. The one who knows that the world originates in Brahma does not need to fear death. There is no need to fear for the tree‚Äôs existence just because a branch dries and falls off. Likewise, there is no danger to the primordial consciousness because of one man‚Äôs death. A j√±ƒÅnƒ´ thus has realised the eternality of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. This indeed is the essence of statements from the second chapter such as ‚Äúnaina·πÉ chindanti ≈õastrƒÅ·πái‚Äù, ‚Äúacchedyo‚ÄôyamadƒÅhyo‚Äôyam.‚Äù The same is taught in the Upani·π£ads as well. The Ka·π≠hopani·π£ad is clear about this.

≈´rdhvam≈´lo‚ÄôvƒÅk≈õƒÅkha e·π£o‚Äô≈õvattha·∏• sanƒÅtana·∏• ‡•§
tadeva ≈õukra·πÉ tad brahma tadevƒÅm·πõtamucyate ‡••

Ka·π≠hopani·π£ad 2.3.1
‚ÄúThe roots are above and the shoots below. This a≈õvattha is eternal. That is the light. That indeed is Brahma. That indeed is immortal. All the worlds are dependent on it. There is nothing beyond it.‚Äù

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a≈õvattha (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

What is the reason behind the name a≈õvattha for a tree thus extolled in the Veda? ≈öva·∏• in Sa·πÉsk·πõt means tomorrow. ≈övastha is something that will exist tomorrow just as it exists today. A≈õvattha then refers to something that will not be the same tomorrow as it is today. It is something that changes every instant - something constantly changing or fickle.

na ≈õvo‚Äôpi sthƒÅtƒÅ iti a≈õvattha·∏• ta·πÉ k·π£a·πáapradhva·πÉsinam a≈õvattham
(As it will not exist tomorrow, as it is changing every instant, it is known as a≈õvattha)
-≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara‚Äôs commentary on Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ 15.1

The word jagat means the same as well - something that is moving, revolving, and changing.
The same Brahman that is firm, uniform, and immutable in its absolute aspect, is dynamic, of myriad forms and ever-changing in its active form. Whatever appears to our eyes as something born, dying, laughing, suffering, adventuring, emaciated, defeated, victorious or in one of those innumerable states is originally birthless, deathless, indefatigable, free from worldly limitations, of one form, and tranquil.
It is to bring that primordial origin to our notice that BhagavƒÅn mentions ≈´rdhvam≈´lam.
A question here. ≈™rdhva - means the direction above our heads or pointing to the sky. What is uniquely great about that? Does not Brahman exist in the direction below? Does Brahman discriminate between upward and downward directions? Aren’t all directions the same for it? The answer is as follows - ‚ÄúBrahman is omnipresent and has no directional differences. In fact it is beyond the distinctions of space. The notions of “above” and “below” are for us - humans. Whatever we consider good or better, we denote by words such as ‚Äúhigh‚Äù, ‚Äúhead‚Äù or ‚Äútop‚Äù. Just placing an object worthy of reverence in a high position brings us satisfaction. In reality, there is no ‚Äúabove‚Äù or ‚Äúbelow‚Äù for Brahman which is omnipresent. We attribute to it an ‚Äúexalted‚Äù or ‚Äúhigh‚Äù position to satisfy our devotional attitudes. The Taittirƒ´ya Upani·π£ad states -

satya·πÉ j√±ƒÅnamananta·πÉ brahma ‡•§ yo veda nihita·πÉ guhƒÅyƒÅ·πÉ parame vyoman ‡•§
so‚Äô≈õnute sarvƒÅn kƒÅmƒÅn ‡••
(Brahman is truth, knowledge and without end. He who knows the supreme space in one‚Äôs heart, he attains all desires.)
Taittirƒ´ya Up. 2.1.1

Brahman is the greatest mystery - beyond even the reach of speech and mind. If such a mystery has to be indicated, a most excellent position needs to be pointed to. Such a reference in the previous Upani·π£adic statement is - guhƒÅyƒÅ·πÉ parame vyoman. The thrust behind ≈´rdhvam≈´lam is similar.
The author of the BhƒÅgavata expands upon the description of the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree in the Gƒ´tƒÅ with poetic flair. When ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa was in the womb of Devakƒ´, the four-faced BrahmƒÅ and other Devas extolled him thus - ‚ÄúO BhagavƒÅn! You are the seed of this sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree which is non-different from the world.‚Äù What is the nature of that tree?

ekƒÅyano‚Äôsau dviphalas-trim≈´la≈õ-cat≈´rasa·∏• pa√±ca≈õipha·∏• ·π£a·∏çƒÅtmƒÅ ‡•§
saptvag-a·π£·π≠ƒÅvi·π≠apo navƒÅk·π£o da≈õacchado dvikhago hyaadiv·πõk·π£a·∏• ‡••
-BhƒÅgavatam 10.22.27
EkƒÅyana·∏• ‚Äî There is one but one basis for it which is the primordial prak·πõti.
Dviphala·∏• ‚Äî It has two fruits - of pleasure and pain.
Trim≈´la·∏• ‚Äî Three roots of the three gu·πáas - sattva, rajas and tamas. Whoever rends asunder these roots will no longer be bound by the world.
Chat≈´rasa·∏• ‚Äî Four tastes ‚Äî dharma, artha, kƒÅma and mok·π£a.
Pa√±cashipha·∏• ‚Äî Five prop roots of our five sense organs.
·π¢a·∏çƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äî Six characteristic qualities - hunger, thirst, fatigue, delusion, old age and death.
Saptatvak ‚Äî Seven types of bark ‚Äî skin, blood, flesh, fat, bones, nerves and seminal fluid

With these two birds is created this huge sa·πÉsƒÅra-world. This is the primordial world-tree that has been created by you, O BhagavƒÅn‚Äù - thus did BrahmƒÅ and other Devas praise ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa.

-BhƒÅgavatam 10.22.28
‚ÄúYou alone are the world‚Äôs origin! You alone are its residence! You are its caretaker! Those deluded by your MƒÅyƒÅ see world-objects as different from one another. Those with knowledge are not deluded and see you as the undifferentiated one everywhere!‚Äù

There are many more purƒÅ·πáic descriptions of this sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree metaphor. ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya quotes a few of them. ≈örƒ´ K·πõ·π£·πáa himself states this in the tenth chapter.

a≈õvattha·∏• sarvav·πõk·π£ƒÅ·πáƒÅm ‡•§
-BG 10.26

He praises the greatness of the a≈õvattha which is a visible symbol of the invisible Brahman. It is with this feeling and belief that all Hindus consider it sacred and worship it by p≈´jƒÅs and pradak·π£i·πáas - even while being mocked at by foreigners for ‚Äúworshipping trees, sticks and stones.‚Äù Even some of us who consider the words of those foreigners as great testimony join them in deriding ourselves. So be it. This too is the effect of the a≈õvattha whose nature it is to wither on one side while flowering on the other.
We need to bring our attention to two points about this tree.

1. ChandƒÅ·πÉsi yatra par·πáƒÅni ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Vedas are the leaves of this tree!‚Äù What does this mean? The leaf performs a vital function in the life of a tree. The leaf protects the tree. The leaf absorbs various nutrients from the environment and nourishes the tree. If all the leaves are plucked off, a tree becomes akin to a skinless man and perishes. How are the Vedas the protectors of the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree? It is dharma that nourishes our lives and dharma in turn is known through the Vedas.

vedo‚Äôkhila·πÉ dharmam≈´lam ‡•§
-Manusm·πõti 2.6

Therefore the Vedas protect the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree. From the Vedas proceeds dharma and through dharma is the sustenance of the world-system. Brahman that is the cause of the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree is thus also the cause of dharma and the ≈õƒÅstras that teach dharma. It is because of dharma that sa·πÉsƒÅra stands. It is through the Vedas that there is a social system. Without the structure of a social arrangement, society would get pulled apart in all directions. We see a similar statement in the Upani·π£ads as well. When BhagavƒÅn as the VirƒÅ·π≠-puru·π£a created the universe, the created beings began consuming one another. BhagavƒÅn saw this anarchy and he thought to himself, “Having done so much, I forgot to appoint a policeman here.” Thinking thus, he created dharma. This allegory is narrated in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad. It is dharma alone that can protect people. That is the reason for BhagavƒÅn comparing the Vedas to the leaves of the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree ‚Äî chandƒÅ·πÉsi yatra par·πáƒÅni.
Despite the greatness of this tree, a violent statement has been made about destroying it.

asa·πÖga≈õastre·πáa d·πõ·∏çhena chitvƒÅ ‡••
-BG 15.3

This seems to imply on the surface that the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree is insignificant, and befits destruction. That, however, is not the intended purport. How can we destroy the tree created by BhagavƒÅn, for the protection of which he established a system in the form of the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras? As sa·πÉsƒÅra has Brahman for its origin, it is worthy of our worship. Its origin is the excellence of excellence. We, the jƒ´vas, manage to desecrate it, that is all. How do we escape this impure relationship is the question. The answer for this question is ‚Äî “asa·πÖga≈õastre·πáa d·πõ·∏çhena chitvƒÅ”. Detachment is the mechanism to be followed in sa·πÉsƒÅra.
2. There is another point worthy of our special attention - “karmƒÅnubandhƒ´ni manu·π£yaloke”. All the bonds that bind us - be they friendly relationships or barbed wires of rivalry - are results of our former karmas. Old actions, old debts, and old tendencies result in impediments, irritations and complexity in our lives. We experience pleasure and suffering in our lives thinking that these are accidental, seemingly absolving us of any responsibility towards them. We forget that all of our experiences are due to our previous actions. In reality, whatever we experience is the result of our old karma. The responsibility is ours.
Why do the learned say that this sa·πÉsƒÅra is beginningless and endless? Because this sa·πÉsƒÅra is the creation of Brahman. What, then, about us who are enmeshed in it? Should we be stuck in it eternally? Is there any release from it? They reply - “Yes. There is release from it.” Those who earnestly seek release from sa·πÉsƒÅra have a chance at it. However, for those who say - ‚ÄúWhy release? We like it here!‚Äù, BhagavƒÅn says, ‚ÄúSo be it. Stay here itself!‚Äù. How does release happen for those who seek it? Will the world vanish once there is release? The world does not go anywhere. We are no longer deluded by it, that is all. The power that created the world will continue to protect it. It is not possible for us to destroy it. Why should we even try to destroy it? It is enough to destroy the web of misunderstanding that we have about the world. It is enough if there is no suffering from the world for us. We don‚Äôt have to desire the destruction of the world. It is enough if the reason behind our view of the world as burdensome or evil is resolved once and for all. Mok·π£a is also the same. For one who does not consider the world a hard place, the world becomes a place of enjoyment and entertainment. Such a person could not possibly desire for the world to be destroyed.

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a≈õvattha (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

We saw in the previous BhƒÅgavata ≈õloka a mention of two birds in the primordial tree - dvikhago hyƒÅdiv·πõk·π£a·∏•. When there is a tree, there is usually a bird in it. The metaphor of the two birds comes to us again from the Veda. The Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad describes the two birds of the sa·πÉsƒÅra tree thus.

dvƒÅ supar·πáƒÅ sayujƒÅ sakhƒÅyƒÅ samƒÅna·πÉ v·πõk·π£a·πÉ pari·π£asvajƒÅte ‡••
Mu·πá·∏çakopani·π£ad 3.1.1

The mention of these two birds is seen elsewhere in the Vedas as well. Two birds; from afar they appear identical. However, their inner characteristics are entirely different. Their external looks are the same. SayujƒÅ (appearing similar). Who are those two birds? BhagavƒÅn says that here.

dvƒÅv imau puru·π£au loke k·π£ara≈õcƒÅk·π£ara eva ca
k·π£ara·∏• sarvƒÅ·πái bh≈´tƒÅni k≈´·π≠astho‚Äôk·π£ara ucyate ‡••
uttama·∏• puru·π£astvanya·∏• paramƒÅtmetyudƒÅh·πõta·∏•
yo loka-trayam-ƒÅvi≈õya bibhartyavyaya ƒ´≈õvara·∏• ‡••
BG 15.16-17

  1. K·π£ara refers to the jƒ´va. It means something that is perishable. Bearing a body that is perishable, performing works good and bad, enjoying their desirable and undesirable results, lamenting frequently, crying with joy, adventuring exuberantly - the jƒ´va is a fragment of the Universal consciousness. It is k·π£ara - something that can be eroded and exhausted. Though it exists momentarily, it is eventually cast off. The ƒÅtmƒÅ that exists in this temporary changing state is the jƒ´vatmƒÅ. It is a sentience that has entered the insentient. The jƒ´va-consciousness that permeates and animates the body‚Äôs limbs, sense organs, manas, buddhi and aha·πÖkƒÅra is known as k·π£ara. 2. Ak·π£ara is the unattached state of the same universal consciousness. It is the indestructible consciousness latent in the destructible body and is therefore known as k≈´·π≠astha (unchangeable). The k·π£ara can act only because of the presence of the ak·π£ara. As the basis of the k·π£ara, the ak·π£ara is beyond the k·π£ara-jƒ´va‚Äôs experiences of pu·πáya and pƒÅpa and is a changeless witness known as the s≈´trƒÅtmƒÅ (the Self that is the common thread in all jƒ´vas). It is also known as the k≈´·π≠ƒÅtmƒÅ (the chief Self). The self that is embodied in the body and is the k·π£etraj√±a (knower of the field/body) in the k·π°etra (field/body) is ak·π£ara which is in turn “used” by the k·π£ara-jƒ´va. The function of an electric power company is to just supply power. The power company or outlet does not restrict the use of power to specified uses only. Electricity could be used for good or bad. The use of electricity is the responsibility of the user. The power company is not concerned with that. Similar is ak·π£ara. Both the jƒ´vatmƒÅ and the k≈´·π≠ƒÅtmƒÅ are vya·π£·π≠i (individual) experiences - considerations that are necessary when viewing each being separately. 3. The ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is the sama·π£·π≠i (collective aggregate) of all separate sentiences of the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅs. When a rupee is counted separately as each paisa, each paisa is considered individually - as vya·π£·π≠i. The combined value of a hundred such paisas is sama·π£·π≠i. When all the characteristics that are unique to a jƒ´va are separated and discarded, a remainder is left. When all such remainders are viewed as an aggregate, it is considered ParamƒÅtmƒÅ.We should understand that the characteristics of the vya·π£·π≠i and the sama·π£·π≠i are quite different.

The features of a hundred separate single paisa coins are completely different from that of a single rupee note. However, the purchasing value of both is the same. As the saying in English goes, ‚ÄúTwelve of the one and a dozen of the other”, both are the same in a marketplace. However, a hundred paisas are different from a single rupee in these cases - timewise - when we have to count each of those coins out; weightwise - when we have to carry a hundred coins around; and in terms of satisfaction when we present dak·π£i·πáƒÅ to brƒÅhma·πáas. Similarly, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ and k·π£ara-ak·π£ara are quite different in transactional or relative reality. But from the perspective of the Absolute, they are all the same. The one who exists changelessly as a whole during all times and circumstances is the one beyond both k·π£ara and ak·π£ara - known as puru·π£ottama (best among puru·π£as). The best among puru·π£as is ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. He permeates, sustains, and protects all the three worlds.
To use an analogy from physics, ParamƒÅtmƒÅ can be likened to potential energy and the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ to kinetic energy. While the former is like the ocean, the latter is like the wave. The substance is the same but forms are different.
BhagavƒÅn has clarified that the jƒ´va is a part of Brahma-consciousness.

mamaivƒÅ·πÉ≈õo jƒ´va-loke jƒ´va-bh≈´ta·∏• sanƒÅtana·∏• ‡•§
mana·∏•-·π£a·π£·π≠hƒÅnƒ´ndriyƒÅ·πái prak·πõtisthƒÅni kar·π£ati ‡••
BG 15.7
‚ÄúIt is my (Brahma‚Äôs) aspect that exists in the world of beings as the eternal jƒ´va. That rules over the five sense organs and the sixth instrument of manas that reside in prak·πõti.‚Äù

It is the caitanya (sentience) of the jƒ´va that animates all bodily and mental organs. This caitanya of the jƒ´va belongs to paramƒÅtmƒÅ. When the primordial Brahma-consciousness expresses itself by flowing through transient bodily instruments, it becomes known as k·π£ara.

Why does Brahma have to become the jƒ´va? Does Brahma have any goal? Because it is impelled by another? Or because of fear? Or a desire? No. Without Brahma, it is impossible for anything to even exist. All of what is - is Brahma. When there is nobody else anywhere, why should there be fear? When one is all-powerful, what is the reason for desire? What could the reason for world creation be? The B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyakopani·π£ad informs us.

sa vai naiva reme‡•§ ekƒÅkƒ´ na ramate‡•§
sa dvitƒ´yamaicchat‡••
-B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka 1.4.3
‚Äú(When Brahma was all by itself) It was not happy. There is no happiness for one who is lonely. Therefore It sought another as a companion.‚Äù

Thus the world is a companion that Brahma created by itself. The Taittirƒ´yopani·π£ad states -

so‚ÄôkƒÅmayata ‡•§ bahu syƒÅ·πÉ prajƒÅyeyeti ‚Ä¶. tadƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ svayamakuruta ‡•§
tasmƒÅt tatsuk·πõtamucyata iti ‡•§
Taittirƒ´ya 2.6.1
‚ÄúBrahma was all alone. It desired thus - ‚ÄúMay I be many‚Äù. Then it created itself manifold as the world. The seers say that it did well thus‚Äù.
devasyai·π£a svabhƒÅvo‚Äôyam ‡••
MƒÅ·πá·∏ç≈´kya KƒÅrikƒÅ 1.9
‚ÄúThat is BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs self-expression. Though he neither has any lacunae nor fear, though he is not impelled by any other‚Äôs desire or need, he creates the world and plays the drama of a jƒ´va as a sport‚Äù.
lokavattu lƒ´lƒÅkaivalyam ‡••
Brahmas≈´tra 2.1.33
Just as the people of the world engage in sport for amusement, ƒ™≈õvara does not have any other motive and has created the entire world as his lƒ´lƒÅ (sport/pastime).

The baby in the cradle enjoys itself by laughing and kicking its limbs in sheer joy. For whom is this activity? A healthy and strong baby, unaware of another‚Äôs existence, does it for its own happiness. Lƒ´lƒÅ is an activity done for one‚Äôs own joy without any thought about others.
A beautiful damsel when alone sees herself in the mirror. When we are alone, we enjoy ourselves by singing a verse or tune in our own ordinary voices. The rich man, while his family members are asleep, closes the door of his room to relish the sight of his valuables. Parents delight in lovingly gazing at their children asleep. Thus, contemplating one‚Äôs own beauty, valuables and accomplishments without any need for another or without other desire, for one‚Äôs own joy is something we observe in human behaviour. The Supreme Brahma too sports in lƒ´lƒÅ in seeing the majesty of its own potency. What is lƒ´lƒÅ? It is an activity done for one‚Äôs own joy without involving others, without asking for external help, and without any extraneous goal. In this way, the universe is *Brahma‚Äô*s lƒ´lƒÅ. The consciousness expressed in this lƒ´lƒÅ can be thought of in three aspects. 1. The jƒ´vatmƒÅ that animates bodily organs. 2. The K≈´·π≠ƒÅtmƒÅ or the internal witness-self. 3. ParamƒÅtmƒÅ or the Supreme ƒÄtmƒÅ. Of these three, the contact with sa·πÉsƒÅra and therefore the world is only for the jƒ´va.

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a≈õvattha (part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Let us now conclude this topic. The jƒ´va has come in contact with the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree. The root of that tree is in the supreme position (‚Äúparame vyoman‚Äù). In its lower part are branches and twigs in the form of the world. The higher the jƒ´va goes - towards the root - the farther he gets from the bitterness, all the bothersome pests and filthy odours of the tree. That is mok·π£a. The upward journey towards the origin is fueled by the effort of discernment. How, though, can that be done? It is dark; the tree is knotty in places and is many-branched. The jƒ´va has lost his way in it. When he sees fruit, he greedily consumes more than what he can take, and suffers indigestion and other maladies of the gut. ‚ÄúThis world is filthy,‚Äù he reflects. ‚ÄúI should not entangle myself in it. I should go beyond this. I should go to the root of the tree where these twigs and props will stop bothering me. How do I attain that state?‚Äù

a≈õvattham ena·πÉ su-vir≈´·∏çha-m≈´lam
asa·πÖga-≈õastre·πáa d·πõ·∏çhena chhittvƒÅ ‡•§
tata·∏• pada·πÉ tat parimƒÅrgitavya·πÉ
yasmin gatƒÅ na nivartanti bh≈´ya·∏• ‡••
BG 15.3
‚ÄúHow does one cut this deep-rooted a≈õvattha? By the axe of asa·πÖga (detachment) - the consideration that ‚Äúthis is not mine‚Äù that translates to giving up pride and attachment. He needs to hack through the thicket of branches with this weapon thereby marking a way out for Brahma-experience.‚Äù

Asa·πÖga is the consideration that the world is not mine. Who created this world? The Supreme Brahma. Therefore it is not mine. I have to look for a way out of this world. But what do I do about the leaves - ChandƒÅ·πÉsi (the Vedas)? One must use the Vedas and dharma to reach the source. Our attention, however, has to be on the top - the root of the tree. ‚ÄúThis tree is not mine. It has come from elsewhere for whatever reason and belongs to someone else. It is not my property.‚Äù This is how the Vedas can be used. As the ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsyopani·π£ad asks

kasyasvit dhanam?
ƒ™≈õa Up. 1
‚ÄúWhose indeed is wealth?‚Äù

I did not create it! It belongs to ƒ™≈õvara. My duty is that of service only. My job is to build a bench for the root of the a≈õvattha tree, to water it, rid it of dirt. But for whose joy? For the joy of this tree‚Äôs creator. That is how the tree is nourished. When it grows thus, its shade and fresh air benefits many jƒ´vas. My responsibility is to just do what has been said. There is dharma to which I should be subservient. A gardener in a mango grove cannot ask questions like, ‚ÄúMaster, why did you not plant the grafted mango?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWill you eat this fruit yourself or sell it at the market?‚Äù
When dharma is followed, the branches and props do impede us but on the contrary, they actually help us. It is with their help that we are able to get to the root. It is through dharma that we get a vision of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ. The Supreme dharma is that of detachment.
Another Upani·π£ad states -

·πÉameti badhyate jantu·∏•
·πáa mameti vimucyate ‡•• ≈öiva Up. 7.114
(Saying ‚Äúmine, mine‚Äù, the creature is trapped. Saying ‚Äúnot mine‚Äù releases it)

What becomes a binding rope when we say ‚Äòmama‚Äô (mine) becomes a garland of flowers when we say ‚Äúna mama‚Äù (not mine). Mok·π£a is a perspective of the manas. When the manas is of one kind, it is binding; when it is of another kind, it is emancipating. The blossoms of the sa·πÉsƒÅra-tree are sweet, lovely, desirable, and worthy of praise. They infatuate us at every step making us feel, “Ah! Such a beautiful world! How can I renounce it? On the other hand, I should make it my own! It should all be for me!”

Many of us feel proud thinking thoughts like - “My husband is so smart!”, “How lovely is my wife!”, “My son is amazing!” We have to be cautious at such moments. Whose is this wealth? Who created these relationships? Where did my son‚Äôs intelligence and daughter‚Äôs beauty come from? None of these is mine. I did not earn any of it. All of this is the blessing of ƒ™≈õvara, due to his will. This must be the kind of asa·πÖga (detachment) that we practise.

The word parimƒÅrgitavyam has been used here. It means that one should search again and again. The supreme goal is not easy to attain. We have to return to where sa·πÉsƒÅra stems from by climbing up the path. The jƒ´va has to think thus about the tree he inhabits - “This is not mine. This is not for my enjoyment. Let me be trained and cleansed instead by it.” This is the path towards Brahma.

After this, BhagavƒÅn describes his own nature.

gƒÅmƒÅvi·π£ya ca bh≈´tƒÅni dhƒÅrayƒÅmyahamaujasƒÅ ‡•§
BG 15.13
‚ÄúAfter entering the world, I sustain all beings with my power.‚Äù
aha·πÉ vai≈õvƒÅnaro bh≈´tvƒÅ prƒÅ·πáinƒÅm dehamƒÅ≈õrita·∏• ‡•§
prƒÅ·πáƒÅpƒÅna-samƒÅyukta·∏• pacƒÅmyanna·πÉ caturvidham ‡••
BG 15.14
“I (ƒ™≈õvara), in the form of the digestive fire, combine with prƒÅ·πáa, apƒÅna and other vital airs to digest whatever food beings ingest.”

Vai≈õvƒÅnara is the energy, heat to be specific, naturally present in all the beings of the Vi≈õva (the world). The hands, feet and other bodily organs gain their energy from food. Food is converted to energy through the process of digestion, which in turn takes place because of the heat energy that is characteristic of the digestive system. This digestive fire is ƒ™≈õvara‚Äôs creation.
In the fragment - anna·πÉ caturvidham - the four types of food are those that can be classified in multiple ways as follows.

  1. Chewed 2. Licked 3. Drunk 4. Slurped.

Or

  1. Cooked 2. Roasted 3. Fried 4. Raw

Or

  1. Grains 2. Greens 3. Milk products 4. Meat

Or

  1. Sweet 2. Spicy hot 3. Salty 4. Sour

Or

  1. The origin of food 2. The method of its cooking 3. The method of consumption 4. Taste

In conclusion, the intelligent mechanism that converts inanimate substances for use by living beings is that of ƒ™≈õvara. This means that all activities of the world are an expression of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ‚Äôs power.

Summary

Man is a mixture of daivƒ´ and ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities. The human world is the place where he can examine and filter his qualities and train him for better things. Prak·πõti influences him with the gu·πáa-triad and makes him move forward because of the influence of his daivƒ´ aspects, or regress because of his ƒÅsurƒ´ aspects. Man has freedom to discerningly choose to progress or regress.
The path of dharma, which has two main qualities ‚Äî acceptance of ƒ™≈õvara and submission to him ‚Äî becomes visible by the contemplation and examination of daivƒ´ and ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities. Because Vedas and ≈öƒÅstras are disregarded, the consciousness of pu·πáya and pƒÅpa has vanished. Here can be seen the seed of various kinds of misery and agony the world is currently experiencing. At least now, will human attention veer towards the Vedas which are the sole means of gaining true knowledge, or towards ≈õƒÅstras that teach how the manas and buddhi should prepare themselves for understanding philosophy?

Whichever way we see, it is irrefutable that the effort of the buddhi is necessary. However, if buddhi has to understand the principle that is beyond the grasp of the senses, it has to work within the precincts of acceptance of the authority of the Vedas. The moral strength obtained by the study of ≈õastras nurtures buddhi‚Äôs ability for philosophical deliberation, and accelerates the process of understanding. Human intellect is paramount in the sensual world. In the realm of other-worldly knowledge, Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras are paramount. The effort of the buddhiin understanding the supreme tattva, in accordance with the supreme tattva is always desirable.

Section 17 /Chapter 16 /DaivƒÅsura-sampad-vibhƒÅga-yoga /DaivƒÅsura-viveka-yoga

(The Yoga of Distinction Between ƒÅsurƒ´ and daivƒ´ qualities)

In verses 10-13 of chapter 9, we have seen prak·πõti express itself in two ways. One is “ƒÅsurƒ´·πÉ rƒÅk·π£asƒ´·πÉ caiva” ‚Äî ƒÅsurƒ´ or demonic and the other is “daivƒ´·πÉ” ‚Äî divine. Both of these are the expressions of prak·πõti. The past karmas of the jƒ´va are the reason they appear together or separately in a man. Birth is taken according to karma; pu·πáya results in better lives; pƒÅpa results in poorer lives.
This is the intention behind the following line ‚Äî

≈õucƒ´nƒÅ·πÉ ≈õrƒ´matƒÅ·πÉ gehe ‡•§
BG 6.41

Hasn‚Äôt even good karma performed with great devotion and good intentions gone in vain some times? The truth is that even though there are no tangible results of that karma, they are always there. The result of pu·πáya often expresses itself in rebirths, as being born in good and wealthy families that practise purity.
The sixteenth chapter deals with the cause and effect relationship between various lives. Firstly, the characteristics of divine beings are listed ‚Äî

abhaya·πÉ sattva-sa·πÉ≈õuddhi·∏• j√±ƒÅna-yoga-vyavasthiti·∏• ‡•§
dƒÅna·πÉ dama≈õca yaj√±a≈õca svƒÅdhyƒÅyas-tapa ƒÅrjavam ‡••
BG 16.1

“Abhaya” means there is no fear in saying the truth or in performing dhƒÅrmic duties. Truth hesitates when there is fear. Fearlessness is the primary requirement for truth and justice. Many people fear the consequences of telling the truth. Fear of what others may think and a crafty mindset that gives a convenient, if dishonest answer to all questions ‚Äî these are very common in today‚Äôs world. That should give way to the trust that one should be faithful to BhagavƒÅn, and he will protect us always. This trust gives rise to fearlessness. We can see this fearlessness in Gandhi. This is the mark of a person who believes in BhagavƒÅn.

abhaya·πÉ vai brahma ‡•§
B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka

“Abhaya” is not audacity or haughtiness; it is humble fearlessness; it is the courage of truth.
“Sattva-sa·πÉ≈õuddhi·∏•” : keeping the manas pure, limpid and wakeful ‚Äî take care so that it is unselfish and guileless and always pleasant. It should be as gracious and clear as a stream flowing from a mountaintop. That is serenity. The manas should not entertain doubts and crookedness.
“J√±ƒÅna-yoga-vyavasthiti·∏•” is constant devotion to deliberating about the Brahma and bringing it into daily practice. ‚ÄúI have to understand this tattva, I will perform whatever sƒÅdhanƒÅ to that end, I will definitely attain this tattva‚Äù - such intense diligence and effort should be there.
‚ÄúDƒÅna‚Äù: Freely giving up something belonging to oneself for the use of others. This is also an attribute of daivƒ´ nature. We have seen in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka ‚Äî ‚ÄúdƒÅmyata datta dayadhva·πÉ‚Äù. Dama is the instruction given to the Devas; dƒÅna is the instruction to humans; and dayƒÅ is to the rƒÅk·π£asas. Thus, the daivƒ´ quality that humans have to practise is dƒÅna. Only if it is there, it is confirmed that our hearts have melted, and that we sympathise and empathise with other beings.
DƒÅna is a quality that is becoming significantly scarce in present times. We call Paurohitya as ‚Äúpriest-craft‚Äù ‚Äî and accuse them that the purohitas want money and therefore raise such brouhaha. An English philosopher called T.H.Green says that there are many amongst us with good intentions; but they just end in words and do not get expressed as work. It is said that there is a Japanese story about a man who spent his life in tall talks. When he went to the afterworld, he was pushed into a room that was full of people wagging their mouths and tongues. Wherever he looked, he saw tongue wagging in mouths; whichever way he turned, there were open lips and shaking tongues. When he asked why this was so, he was told ‚ÄúDear fellow, isn‚Äôt this all you did on the Earth?‚Äù. Green says that we should not speak too much about great things. As talk increases, morality decreases.
Our ancestors have greatly praised the quality of dƒÅna, especially of the secret variety. An old woman in the house would not sit down for lunch, till everyone else in the family was fed, and give up some morsels from her portion of food to beggars or stray animals that needed to eat. That is bh≈´tabali.
‚ÄúDama·∏•‚Äù: Keep one‚Äôs senses under control.
‚ÄúYaj√±a·∏•‚Äù: Worship of ƒ™≈õvara. The word sacrifice is used in English. That means ƒÅhuti or bali offered to a deity; it means that the feelings of ‚Äúme‚Äù and ‚Äúmine‚Äù ‚Äî ego and attachment ‚Äî are offered as sacrifice.
‚ÄúSvƒÅdhyƒÅya·∏•‚Äù: Studying texts and treatises related to one‚Äôs profession ‚Äî humility that there is a lot to know - these help cultivating the buddhi . ‚ÄúSva‚Äù here means the study of something related to oneself. For a brƒÅhma·πáa, this could be studying one‚Äôs own ≈õƒÅkhƒÅ. Engineers might want to study engineering texts, and doctors might want to study Ayurveda. Our culture considers worldly sciences such as dhanurveda, sculpting, Ayurveda as upavedas.
‚ÄúTapa·∏•‚Äù: Steadfast devotion that does not allow the thought of anything other than the object of devotion. Just as one has to practice giving up what he has earned, he should also practise reducing his desires and wants, and strive day and night to achieve his objective. Tapas is constant mindfulness about one‚Äôs goal.
‚ÄúƒÄrjava‚Äù: Straightforward conduct that is not crooked or deceitful, and practises what the conscience preaches.
In addition to the qualities that have been described above,

ahi·πÉsƒÅ satyam-akrodha·∏• tyƒÅga·∏• ≈õƒÅntir-apai≈õunam ‡•§
dayƒÅ bh≈´te·π£valoluptva·πÉ mƒÅrdava·πÉ hrƒ´r-acƒÅpalam ‡••
BG 16.2

‚ÄúApai≈õuna·πÉ‚Äù means the absence of calumny. Aloluptva means not being licentious or forget oneself in worldly pleasures. This does not mean that one should not experience pleasure. It just means that one should not lose oneself in sensual pleasures. ‚ÄúHrƒ´·∏•‚Äù means modesty. This is a great quality. It is a natural boon given to humans by BhagavƒÅn. It is a limiting boundary drawn because of concern that someone may think ill of us. If there is even a tiny bit of good manners left in this world it is due to this quality of ‚Äúhrƒ´‚Äù. It is the fundamental quality that gives rise to all other forms of propriety. That is why it is specially extolled in the Vedas.

teja·∏• k·π£amƒÅ dh·πõti·∏• ≈õaucam adroho nƒÅti-mƒÅnitƒÅ ‡•§
bhavanti sa·πÉpada·πÉ daivƒ´m abhijƒÅtasya bhƒÅrata ‡••
BG 16.3

Lustre, patience, courage, purity, not being treacherous, ‚Äúna atimƒÅnitƒÅ‚Äù means not swelling our affections and pride. Some level of self-respect and affection is unavoidable; but it should not increase much. If there is no self-respect and love at all, there might not even be affection between a parent and child! However, self-conceit and haughtiness are not acceptable.

[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ƒÅsurƒ´ and daivƒ´ qualities (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

All the above are sƒÅttvika qualities. ‚ÄúAbhijƒÅta‚Äù means one who is born after performing pu·πáya. Such a person is blessed with daivƒ´ qualities. Whoever thinks he is born in a good family and acts accordingly ‚Äî one who has earned the qualification to worship the Divine ‚Äî he will be blessed with the wealth of these above qualities. It releases the jƒ´va from bondage. All this is divine wealth.
The qualities opposite to the above are ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities.

dambho darpo‚ÄôtimƒÅna≈õca krodha·∏• pƒÅru·π£yam eva ca ‡•§
aj√±ƒÅna·πÉ cƒÅbhijƒÅtasya pƒÅrtha sa·πÉpadam ƒÅsurƒ´m ‡••
BG 16.4

Dambha is the display of pride, and conceit that one possesses something that others do not. Darpa is vanity, hardness of the manas. It is the feeling that others are inferior to oneself. Excessive infatuation, malice, cruelty, lack of knowledge, lack of discernment ‚Äî all these are tƒÅmasic qualities. They are the result of pƒÅpas committed in past lives. They tighten the bonds of the jƒ´va.
SvƒÅmƒ´ now elucidates the results of these two kinds of qualities.

daivƒ´ sa·πÉpad-vimok·π£ƒÅya nibandhƒÅyƒÅsurƒ´ matƒÅ ‡•§
mƒÅ ≈õuca·∏• sa·πÉpada·πÉ daivƒ´m abhijƒÅto‚Äôsi pƒÅ·πá·∏çava ‡••
BG 16.5
‚ÄúDaivƒ´ qualities are those that help in attaining mok·π£a. ƒÄsurƒ´ qualities are those that cause bondage. Arjuna, do not grieve thinking whether you are qualified to strive for mok·π£a. You are born with daivƒ´ qualities. You are eligible to tread the path towards mok·π£a‚Äù.

There is one thought here. BhagavƒÅn listed daivƒ´ qualities; he listed ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities as well; he will describe them further. Why did he not mention human qualities? Are there no such qualities as human qualities? The purport here is that all the above qualities are human only. There is no human trait that does not fall into either daivƒ´ or ƒÅsurƒ´ category. Humans are a mix of divine and demonic aspects. This is what the Vedas say:

pu·πáyena pu·πáya·πÉ loka·πÉ nayati ‡•§ pƒÅpena pƒÅpam ‡•§ ubhƒÅbhyƒÅm eva manu·π£yalokam ‡••
Pra≈õnopani·π£at

When both kinds of traits commingle, he comes to the mortal world. This is an opportunity for him; he can either ascend to better states, or plummet to viler states. In his management of this universe, BhagavƒÅn has given this freedom to humans. The B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka says the following -

sa vƒÅ ‚Ä¶ kƒÅmamayo‚ÄôkƒÅma-maya·∏• krodhamayo‚Äôkrodhamayo dharmamayo‚Äôdharmamaya·∏• sarvamayas-tadyad-etat-ida·πÉmayo‚Äôdomaya iti yathƒÅkƒÅrƒ´ yathƒÅcƒÅrƒ´ tathƒÅ bhavati ‡••

Since we cannot give a finite list of human traits, the upani·π£at says ‚Äúidammaya·∏• adomaya·∏•‚Äù. A jƒ´va is full of all necessary and unnecessary qualities. He becomes what he does and how he conducts himself.
Since a human is thus a mix of both good and bad qualities, he cannot be steady where he is, and should continuously move up or down every second.
Plato gives the same instruction:

‚ÄúIn the human soul, there is a better and also a worse principle; and when the better has the worse under control, then a man is said to be master of himself (which is a term of praise); but when, owing to evil education or association, the better principle, which is also the smaller, is overwhelmed by the greater mass of the worse ‚Äî in this case he is blamed and is called the slave of self and unprincipled.‚Äù
(The Republic, Book IV)

The same feeling is echoed in the poem ‚ÄúA Death in the Desert‚Äù by Browning.

Man is not God, but hath God‚Äôs end to serve ‚Äî
A master to obey, a course to take, ‚Äî
Somewhat to cast off, somewhat to become.
Grant this, that man must pass from old to new,
From vain to real, from mistake to fact,
From what once seemed good to what now proves best.
How could man have progression otherwise?
Progress, man‚Äôs distinctive mark alone,
Not God‚Äôs and not the beasts‚Äô; God is, they are;
Man partly is and wholly hopes to be.

What the Gƒ´ta calls ‚ÄòƒÅsura‚Äô, Browning calls beastly or animalistic. Every second, daivƒ´ aspects keep pulling man upward, or ƒÅsurƒ´ aspects keep pulling him down. There is progress if he ascends; if he descends, he will deteriorate. He cannot keep quiet even for a second and say that he wants neither progress nor deterioration. He cannot remain where he is. Indeed, prak·πõti does not leave him alone! She keeps poking him with the trident that is the three gu·πáas and troubles him constantly. Daivƒ´ and asurƒ´ are both the energies of prakrti.

dvau bh≈´tasargau loke‚Äôsmin daiva ƒÅsura eva ca ‡••
BG 16.6

Prak·πõti has placed man on a greasy pole. He cannot embrace it and remain where he is. He should fold his hands in front of it and keep moving upwards with fortitude. Even if he forgets himself for a moment, he will slide down. Our daily life is this dangerous game.
Divine beings do not face this instability. They reside perpetually in the higher worlds. They do not get down from there. If they do climb down, the balance of the universe will go haywire. The sun, moon, clouds and lightning, air and water should perform their assigned tasks constantly, without fail. That is what prak·πõti has decreed. They cannot make mistakes there. They do not slip down.
On the other hand, Asuras do not have even an iota of an idea of progress. They do not understand the difference between high and low, honorable and contemptible. They do not even worry that they are inferior and that they might fall further. Such is ƒÅsurƒ´ delusion or beastly confusion. They are born again and again in low forms and thus spend their accumulated pƒÅpa. They might be born as humans at some point of time and then they might qualify to discern the difference between progress and regress. It is an uncertain future.
Humans have the freedom to examine progress and retreat wilfully and with full volition and use of one‚Äôs buddhi . It is not required for divine beings; and not possible for ƒÅsurƒ´ beings. In this creation, the opportunity to progress towards better states is possible only for humans.
After suggesting this principle, BhagavƒÅn explains the grimness of ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities ‚Äî we might choose to think that it is to create dread and alarm in common people and awaken them. BhagavƒÅn did not need to create fear in Arjuna. He had not displayed ƒÅsurƒ´ qualities. There was absolutely no doubt that he was rich with the wealth of daivƒ´ qualities. Didn‚Äôt ≈örik·πõ·π£na himself say this? Love for truth, devotion to dharma, sympathy towards all beings ‚Äî all these are clearly manifest in Arjuna. Therefore it is possible that this instruction is for other common people of this world. I feel that ≈örik·πõ·π£na had the people of 1963 CE (or 2023 CE perhaps) in his mind when he spoke this. I believe you would think the same if you see these sentences from the Gita.

asatyam- aprati·π£·π≠ha·πÉ te jagad-ƒÅhur-anƒ´≈õvaram ‡•§
aparaspara-sambh≈´ta·πÉ kimanyat-kƒÅma-haitukam ‡••
BG 16.8

‚ÄúWhat is Truth? There is nothing called Truth. If there is Truth, who has seen it? Where is the ƒ™≈õvara who rules the universe? This is anarchy. It is haphazardly placed (aprati·π£·π≠ha·πÉ); the establishment of dharma is fake. All things in the universe are born out of randomness; there is no relationship between them ‚Äî they are not related to one another in accordance with precepts like ‚ÄúƒÄkƒÅ≈õƒÅd-vƒÅyuh‚Äù, etc., or from other lives. If you say there are so many life-forms, they are all the results of lust between male and female‚Äù ‚Äî this is what asuras say. That is atheism. That is the theory of cƒÅrvƒÅkas.
They do not agree that jƒ´vas are born out of interaction between various karmas, by set rules, and obligations between jƒ´vas and that they are thus related to one another. They do not agree that the rope of karma binds the whole universe within a single sack.
‚Äúaparaspara-sa·πÉbh≈´ta·πÉ‚Äù can mean two things. First meaning is ‚Äúfrom the union of male and female‚Äù: ‚Äúapara·∏•+ca+para·∏•+ca‚Äù ‚Äî when one joins another. Since there is ‚ÄúkƒÅmahaitukam‚Äù next to this word, we can understand it as a union between male and female. Another meaning could be the union of two completely unrelated things that have randomly and arbitrarily somehow come together.
In ancient Greece, there were philosophers called Atomists. They had not accepted the existence of ƒ™≈õvara. They believed that interactions between atoms was the reason for the birth, death, and rebirth of the universe. They believed that the nature of these atoms drove them to behave in this way. The energy that makes them move or stops them from movement does not come from the external environment. They unite with other atoms and divide from them, of their own volition. They do not have an authority that makes them do this.
We see that many animate and inanimate things constantly collude together and disperse from one another. What is the reason for this? The atheist says that it is by chance, and that it does not have a reason. The theist says that it is because of impressions from the past. From the point of view of a theist, nothing happens without reason.

[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ƒÅsurƒ´ and daivƒ´ qualities (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

In the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, after Da≈õaratha left to the heavenly abode, when Bharata begged RƒÅma to return to AyodhyƒÅ and become the king, SrirƒÅma says the following -

yathƒÅ kƒÅ·π£·π≠ha·πÉ ca kƒÅ·π£·π≠ha·πÉ ca sameyƒÅtƒÅ·πÉ mahƒÅr·πáave ‡•§
sametya ca vyapeyƒÅtƒÅ·πÉ kƒÅlamƒÅsƒÅdya ka√±cana ‡••
eva·πÉ bhƒÅryƒÅ≈õca putrƒÅ≈õca j√±ƒÅtaya≈õca dhanƒÅni ca ‡••
(2.105.26, 27)
Srƒ´rƒÅma‚Äôs opinion is ‚Äî ‚ÄúJust as two logs coming from different places travel together for some time and then disperse in a vast ocean, similarly wives, children, relatives and wealth are with us for some time and leave us. This union and parting are characteristics of sa·πÉsƒÅra. Nothing is permanent in this world, except dharma‚Äù.

In the analogy of logs of wood above, the energy that makes the logs move is the current of water. Each river pushed a log into the ocean. Remnants of debts from past lives and the obligations of pu·πáya and pƒÅpa of the beings of the world have caused them to come together in various ways. Vaidika dharma believes that all friendships and other relationships and all hatred and distress happen for a reason. Materialists (Those who believe in the absolute independence of the physical world) aver that there is no such reason. They say that life is just whatever we directly perceive.

Materialists say that the universe is just a collaboration of atoms; they say that death and pralaya are the dispersal of atoms. Combination and dissolution happen solely because of the nature of atoms and nothing else. The bonding ability and valency of atoms make them behave thus. Who created them in this way? Nobody knows who it is. The universe is a result of their attractive and repulsive forces. Likewise, a man and his manas are the result of the play of atomic forces. After playing for a long time like this, atoms might lose their energy and become still. That is death. Till that comes, whatever a man finds pleasure in, is good for him. Pu·πáya, pƒÅpa and rebirth are cock-and-bull stories. There is nothing after death.

This is a summary of the atomic theory. It is ≈õ≈´nyavƒÅda ‚Äî or the theory of voidness; because there was vacuum before the birth of the universe and after its death. It is an atheistic theory, because it does not accept the existence of the ƒÅtmavastu that is different from temporary and fleeting atoms. That is materialism. In today‚Äôs world, it is a known fact that communists are the materialists, opposing religious beliefs and upholding the supremacy of the material world.

This is the answer the Veda gives to atheists and materialists ‚Äî

Authority of ≈öƒÅstra

What does our buddhi have to do if ≈õƒÅstra itself is the supreme authority? Should there be no freedom for independent working of the buddhi ? These questions have been answered earlier. Let us briefly recall them.
Sense objects are required for human buddhi to do its work. Where there are no senses, the buddhicannot do anything. The manas provides material to the buddhi. Senses provide material to the manas. If the senses do not collect information, the field of the manas is empty. If the manas is unemployed, the buddhihas to be quiet too. Thus, the field where the buddhican work is bounded. Concepts such as jƒ´va, ƒÅtmƒÅ, ƒ™≈õvara, many lives and many worlds ‚Äî are far from it. Senses cannot touch those mysteries. How can the manas enter where senses do not? Thus, the supreme principle cannot be grasped by the buddhi.

Not only that, senses can trap the buddhi. They can distract the manas with pleasure and its attainment, and make it forget that there is a supreme principle beyond them that is worth striving for in our lives. Even here, the buddhi becomes weak because of its slavery to the senses. Therefore SvƒÅmi instructs us again and again to control our senses.

It is not possible for mere buddhito comprehend paramƒÅtmƒÅ, the most mysterious principle in life. Vedas are the only means to know the nature of something that is beyond senses. The Vedas are the words of those who have directly seen and experienced the paravastu. Without understanding that, we cannot obtain true knowledge. But is the buddhi not required there? It is certainly required. The Vedas do not carry any meaning to someone whose buddhi is not purified. It is the job of the buddhi to understand the hidden meaning in the Vedas correctly and make them his own.

≈öƒÅstras help in two ways.
They explain the subtleties of philosophy
They teach us the preparations required for bringing philosophy into our daily lives. Our understanding of philosophy is according to the preparation of our buddhi and morality. Any teaching is imparted according to the ability of the receiver. This is the scheme to be followed to grasp ≈õƒÅstra. The two objectives of ≈õƒÅstra are to develop the right aptitude and propriety of instruction.

The buddhi works in two ways
Understanding the Vedas
Using reasoning and past experiences, critically examine what has been understood and establish the concept firmly.
Our mindset towards ≈õƒÅstra should have two aspects. The first is ≈õraddhƒÅ and the second is viveka. ≈öraddhƒÅ is belief. Just as we trust food served by our mother and the medicine given by a good doctor, we should trust and understand the instructions given by ≈õƒÅstra. After that, just as we would remember the food or medicine and their effect on us, we should critically re-examine our understanding by pondering upon the cause-and-effect relationship, and changing ‚Äî updating our understanding of ≈õƒÅstra if necessary, again and again. This has to be performed by the buddhi. Thus, it does not mean ‚Äú*buddhir-apramƒÅ·πáam (*Meaning that the buddhi is not a pramƒÅ·πáa.)‚Äù just because ‚Äú≈õƒÅstram pramƒÅ·πáam‚Äù was said. It just means that mere buddhi is not enough. The buddhi is certainly required, but it is not sufficient by itself. The raw material for the working of the buddhi-machinery should come from ≈õƒÅstra ‚Äî that is the essence of this discussion. Only buddhi can explain what has been said in the ≈õƒÅstra.

It is not possible for even the greatest buddhi to independently perceive the parabrahma that is beyond senses and all understanding. It has to be understood only through the help of the Vedas. [[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ≈öraddhƒÅ (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Summary

Food, yaj√±a and dƒÅna are three-fold according to the three components of prak·πõti - sattva, rƒÅjas and tƒÅmas. During all of our life activities, our focus must be on encouraging an exuberance of sattva.

Section 18 /Chapter 17 /≈öraddhƒÅ-traya-vibhƒÅga-yoga /≈öraddhƒÅ-traya-viveka-yoga

(The Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ≈öraddhƒÅ)

The subject of this chapter is ≈õraddhƒÅ that is of three kinds.

≈öraddhƒÅ can be defined as trust or what is referred to in English as faith or belief. It is implicit trust placed in something - prior to reasoning, and without any examination or analysis. Such faith is seen even among Christians and Muslims. When an object is believed to exist and function even in the absence of any immediate or inferential testimony for its existence, such a belief is known as ≈õraddhƒÅ.

In that case, isn‚Äôt ≈õraddhƒÅ the same as blind belief or superstition? Does it not appear to be against the buddhi‚Äôs logical reasoning?

Well, yes and no. While the buddhi has already been accepted in earlier chapters as the most important instrument to obtain j√±ƒÅna, we have also seen that there is a limit to the buddhi‚Äôs capabilities. There are many areas where the buddhi cannot venture into independently. Jƒ´va, ƒÄtmƒÅ, ƒ™≈õvara, pu·πáya, pƒÅpa, transmigration, different lokas - are all matters that the buddhi cannot address by itself. This is because such matters are beyond the grasp of the sense organs as well as the touch of the manas. The buddhi too, therefore, is away from such subjects. If the buddhi has to enter such areas, it has to be led there by entities that are knowledgeable in them. Vedas, ≈õƒÅstras, guru, and ≈õi·π£·π≠a (learned, wise) traditions are such trustworthy and knowledgeable guides for the buddhi. If we say no to these trusty and wise guides in matters that are beyond the buddhi, we are essentially saying no to an offer of light while we scramble in pitch darkness. In such matters, where worldly wisdom counsels us -

nƒÅnya·∏• panthƒÅ vidyate‚ÄôyanƒÅya
“There is no other way towards that abode.”
-≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara Upani·π£ad (3.8)

only the ≈õƒÅstras and gurus can be our guides. The mental readiness to trust them is ≈õraddhƒÅ. Upade≈õa (instruction) to one without ≈õraddhƒÅ is like planting a seed on a boulder. The instruction to Arjuna would be fruitful only if he had ≈õraddhƒÅ in it. So, in order to ascertain whether Arjuna really had ≈õraddhƒÅ in his teaching, BhagavƒÅn now - towards the end of the Gƒ´tƒÅ - bestows upon us this instruction on tri-fold ≈õraddhƒÅ, using Arjuna as a pretext.

When there is agreement between ≈õƒÅstric teaching and conclusions based on independent reasoning, there is no reason for concern. However, in present circumstances, agreement between worldly thought and the ≈õƒÅstras is dwindling. The ≈õƒÅstras prohibit travel overseas for a brƒÅhma·πáa; but the buddhi says that it is necessary. The ≈õƒÅstras are in favour of the system of var·πáƒÅ≈õrama; the buddhi considers it unsuitable. The ≈õƒÅstras mandate a ≈õikhƒÅ (tuft of hair) for males, but the buddhi likes cropped hair. The ≈õƒÅstra necessitates black beads for married women (in the ma·πÖgalas≈´tra), but the buddhi considers it a primitive practice. The ≈õƒÅstras say that the bond of marriage is unbreakable; but the buddhi says that the institution of marriage is optional. We can quote a thousand such examples. In such dilemmas, what is the path to welfare? The ≈õƒÅstra or one‚Äôs own buddhi?

There is scope for both ≈õƒÅstra and buddhi in our lives. In that case, should both of them function in the same spheres of life? Or do both have mutually exclusive areas of operation? This has to be discussed.

When it comes to the operation of the buddhi, it must be borne in mind that the buddhi needs raw material to work with. An expert potter cannot function without clay or a carpenter cannot carve without wood. Similarly, a farmer needs land to cultivate, a merchant needs wares to trade with, and a doctor needs medicine in treating her patients. In short, any function needs some input material to refine or work with. Likewise, the buddhi needs raw material which is supplied by the manas. Sense organs such as the eyes and ears gather information about the world and convey it to the manas, which in turn is conveyed to the buddhi. At the same time, the manas informs the buddhi of its likes and dislikes. In addition to the manas, old memories also influence the buddhi. Thus, the buddhi gets its input raw material from the sense organs, manas, and memory. This implies that as long as the sense organs and the manas cannot function, the buddhi cannot either. We have now thus established the limits for the buddhi‚Äôs functioning.

We have seen before that satya (truth) is of two kinds. One is truth that is seen and the other is truth that cannot be seen. The seen truth is accessible via the sense organs and corresponds to the world that we directly perceive. The unseen world is not accessible through the sense organs. It is a secret consciousness that is beyond the world. We cannot perceive it but can only witness its power and effects in our world and lives.

Some of our life activities pertain to the directly perceived world and can be attained by our buddhi. Others are beyond this world and thus imperceptible by our sense organs. The buddhi cannot operate by itself there.

Through this distinction we can ascertain their respective spheres of influence. In areas of activity perceived by our sense organs, thus permitting its operation, human buddhi assumes primacy and the ≈õƒÅstras become secondary. Where sense organs cannot operate and the buddhi does not get material to work with, the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras become paramount making human buddhi secondary.

Jƒ´va, ƒ™≈õvara, pƒÅpa, pu·πáya, svarga, naraka - all of these are concepts or objects that cannot be directly perceived by our sense organs. The buddhi therefore cannot operate independently here. Sputniks and spacecraft that go beyond our solar system cannot touch the world of adhyƒÅtma (pertaining to the Self). It is impossible for them to even know of its existence. In that secret kingdom of adhyƒÅtma, the buddhi‚Äôs activity is restricted to understanding the statements of the ≈õƒÅstra. In that kingdom, the buddhi lacks the authority to formulate new theories and impose them. If the buddhi independently surmises the origin and progress of a jƒ´va and arrives at a conclusion about satya and dharma through conjecture and logic, such a conclusion will be found lacking in testimony, thereby becoming doubtful.

Human buddhi suffers from two natural defects. First - the incompleteness of its raw material. Second - the imperfection of sense perception.
The buddhi‚Äôs main functions are the analysis of objects and the estimation of their worth. Analysis requires objective material to analyse. The buddhi cannot create such material through its independent imagination, because it is not in direct contact with the world. The objects for the buddhi‚Äôs analyses have to be supplied by the manas or memory. The manas or memory, in turn, fetch the material from sense organs. Thus the sense organs are the messengers that supply information to the buddhi. The faculties of the sense organs are severely limited and are tainted by pleasure and desires. Our eye can see only one side of an object at a given moment. It cannot see all sides of an object simultaneously. Sight can extend only up to a limited distance, say for ten or a hundred metres, and no further. Thus the ability of an eye is one-sided and limited by distance. The abilities of other human sense organs too are similarly one-sided and limited. Therefore any information collected by such instruments is likewise one-sided and limited. Such incomplete information cannot convey the complete nature of an object. Hence the inevitable deficiency in the buddhi‚Äôs raw material.

Moreover, the sense organs desire pleasure, thereby subjecting them to the defects of partiality and infatuation while collecting information.

Also, is the buddhi so capable that it can reach the end of any inquiry? No. Just like the body, the buddhi too can become languid or dull. In its partial and piecemeal examination of an object, the buddhi can become lazy, forgetful, and prejudiced, leading to errors in judgement.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ≈öraddhƒÅ (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

There are four kinds of activities of the buddhi. The first is analysis which means separating the object of inquiry into its constituent elements. The second is classification which is grouping the various components and properties of the object of inquiry. The third is causality which is identifying the cause-effect relationship as well as the estimation of the amount of a certain substance needed to achieve a specific effect. The fourth kind of activity is deciding whether to perform an activity or not. After considering its current circumstances, the buddhi helps decide whether a specific action will have its intended consequences, how much of the result would be beneficial, as well whether such an action is suitable to perform. Such activities can together be termed value judgement. But all four of these activities are possible only after the buddhi has found the input material for its work. The buddhi can only analyse material made available to it through the sense organs and the manas. The objects of our world are perceivable by our sense organs. Our buddhi can reason and hypothesise only after grasping these sense-objects. But it cannot proceed with objects that are beyond the ken of the sense organs and the manas. The buddhi has no purview over objects that are beyond sensory perception. Many ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic (spiritual) elements are beyond the senses. Neither can our eyes, ears, and hands nor can the manas touch ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic principles. The manas might indicate that something is ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic. The buddhi can accept it as such but it cannot be claimed that the spiritual is under its sway.
The principles of ƒÅtmƒÅ, ƒ´≈õvara, and the jƒ´va‚Äôs progress or regress cannot be perceived by the sense organs. However, the sense organs are able to experience the effects of such elements. With this experience as the basis, the buddhi can guess and grasp at the nature of the origin of these principles. Spiritual principles are thus accessible to the buddhi but not subordinate to it. Also, spiritual principles become accessible only after the buddhi accepts the ƒÅstika ≈õƒÅstras. It is not that the nƒÅstikas lack the faculty of buddhi. But since they lack ≈õraddhƒÅ in the ≈õƒÅstras, they cannot grasp ƒÅdhyƒÅtma. If they had been able to grasp it, they would not have been nƒÅstika. The ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic principles can be realised only after acceptance of the ≈õƒÅstras. There is no external testimony for the existence of the ƒÅtmƒÅ other than the statements of the ≈õƒÅstra. Can something like the jƒ´va be pointed at with our fingers and physically be transferred from one‚Äôs arms to another? How can the existence of svarga and naraka be shown in the external world? Where are the records to show transmigration? The purƒÅ·πáas tell us that PrahlƒÅda proved BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs existence by making him appear in a pillar. Where are those who can make BhagavƒÅn appear in front of us? All these ideas - jƒ´va, daiva, ƒÅtmƒÅ, brahma, pu·πáya, pƒÅpa, svarga, naraka - are part of the knowledge that has come to us from the Veda. These cannot be established by human buddhi. Thus, even for those who would like to inquire after the Supreme Principle as well as those desirous of leading a principled life, the Veda becomes the fundamental testimony. It is after considering all the defects of human buddhi such as doubt and error that BhagavƒÅn VyƒÅsa declared

tarkƒÅprati·π£·π≠hƒÅnƒÅt ‡••
‚ÄúAs logic has no foundation‚Äù
-Brahma S≈´tra 2.1.11

in his s≈´tras and has clarified that mere human reasoning is insufficient to reach the supreme tattva. ≈örƒ´ ≈öa·πÖkara‚Äôs commentary on the above is as follows.

puru·π£otprek·π£ƒÅ-mƒÅtra-nibandhanƒÅstarkƒÅ aprati·π£·π≠hitƒÅ bhavanti, utprek·π£ƒÅyƒÅ nira·πÖku≈õatvƒÅt ‡•§… puru·π£a-mati-vair≈´pyƒÅt ‡•§ …kapila-ka·πáabhuk-prabh·πõtƒ´nƒÅ·πÉ paraspara-vipratipatti-dar≈õanƒÅt ‡•§ tarkƒÅ·πáƒÅm-aprati·π£·π≠hitatva·πÉ tarke·πáaiva prati·π£·π≠hƒÅpyate ‡•§ sarva-tarkƒÅ-prati·π£·π≠hƒÅyƒÅ·πÉ ca loka-vyavahƒÅroccheda-prasa·πÖga·∏• ‡•§
“The chain of tarka (reasoning) comes from human conjectures and their extensions. As these conjectures are unchecked, tarka lacks a sound basis. Human buddhi assumes different forms which is why Mahar·π£i Ka·πáƒÅda could not accept Mahar·π£i Kapila‚Äôs arguments. Hence, tarka, which is an effect of human buddhi, is incapable of establishing the supreme principle by itself. This can be established by the conventions of tarka itself. If tarka is not established anywhere, even worldly activities become impossible.”

Thus tarka, a product of the buddhi, is necessary in a few areas and inconclusive in others. In such a dilemma, the Veda is our only refuge.
Suprasensory knowledge can be attained only through the Veda.

pratyak·π£e·πáƒÅnumityƒÅ vƒÅ yast≈´pƒÅyo na buddhyate ‡•§
ena·πÉ vidanti vedena tasmƒÅdvedasya vedatƒÅ ‡••
-SƒÅya·πáa in Taittirƒ´ya-sa·πÉhitƒÅ-bhƒÅ·π£ya-bh≈´mikƒÅ
‚ÄúThe suprasensory knowledge that cannot be obtained by an analysis of the perceived world or be inferred from sense perceived objects - the path to the supreme that cannot be gained by tarka alone - can be ascertained by the Veda. Thence is the Veda-hood of the Veda.‚Äù

This is the conclusion. In suprasensory matters, the Veda is the sole authority. In other words, the Veda‚Äôs primary authority is in matters pertaining to adhyƒÅtma. However, in those areas that are not ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic and pertain only to this world (secular investigations), the faculty of discernment from human buddhi plays the chief role.
Does it mean that buddhi cannot help those who rely on the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras? No. Buddhi is required in all areas. But the buddhi has to restrict itself within the boundary of the Veda. Can a calf not ramble about in a meadow? It can and it should. But it cannot cross the fence. If it crosses the fence, it can fall prey to tigers and leopards. Cattle are free within the limits of the meadow. The buddhi is free within the enclosure of the Veda. Freedom here is relative to what is to be achieved. If human buddhi cannot act unfettered, the meaning of the Veda will not become apparent.

ƒÅr·π£a·πÉ dharmopade≈õa·πÉ ca veda≈õƒÅstrƒÅvirodhinƒÅ ‡•§

‚ÄúOnly the Veda is the means to understand dharma. The practical aspects of this understanding are ascertained by the buddhi in the form of mƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsƒÅ.‚Äù

The conclusion is this: In ƒÅdhyƒÅtmic matters wherein concepts such as jƒ´va, ƒ´≈õvara, pu·πáya, pƒÅpa, svarga, naraka, transmigration and mok·π£a assume importance, ≈õraddhƒÅ in Veda assumes primacy. Human buddhi acts as its helper. In areas where the jƒ´va‚Äôs welfare is not directly addressed and the worldly arithmetic of profits and losses holds sway, the buddhi‚Äôs independent skill assumes priority. In a few areas of our life, therefore, ≈õraddhƒÅ in the ≈õƒÅstras is the main actor with the buddhi in a supporting role. In other areas, the faculty of discernment from the buddhi has to be strong and capable to help lead a life that is aligned to the Vedas and ≈õƒÅstras. Thus both ≈õraddhƒÅ and buddhi; and hence the vaidika and worldly ways, can be mutually reconciled.
Let us now go back to Arjuna. From the perspective of ≈õraddhƒÅ in the vedas and ≈õƒÅstras, Arjuna had to follow his K·π£atriya-dharma. The instruction of the Veda-≈õƒÅstra is as follows - ‚Äúthe ƒÅtmƒÅ cannot be destroyed; it is eternal; its complete realisation is the greatest attainment of life; for such an attainment, the jƒ´va has to be rid of its impurities and imperfections; for such a complete purification of the jƒ´va, performing dharma is imperative; by performance of dharma is implied one‚Äôs own dharma‚Äù. This is not merely an intellectual theory but one of ≈õraddhƒÅ in the ≈õƒÅstras. Arjuna getting battle ready is manifesting ≈õraddhƒÅ in the ≈õƒÅstras.
With his battle-readiness come issues such as the design of army formations, the selection of a commander-in-chief, specific choices of weapons, and decisions of what missile to employ in response to a specific enemy missile. They can be solved only through the ability of one‚Äôs own buddhi.
In short: ≈õƒÅstra is needed for the knowledge of the Supreme Principle whereas buddhi is for its application in the world.
This is evident even in the activities of common people like us. To celebrate a wedding, for instance, the matching of the bride and groom is a matter for the ≈õƒÅstra and so is the selection of the auspicious muh≈´rta. Charming the families of the bride or the groom; choosing the right menu for the feasts; the list of invitees; the venue of the wedding - should it be the neighbourhood temple or one‚Äôs own house? Should money be borrowed or should just the wedding groceries be bought on credit? Should the interest rate be 10 percent or 12? - are all problems that are in the domain of worldly buddhi. It is sufficient if there are no lies or cheating in it. Thus both the ≈õƒÅstra and our buddhi have a place in our lives. Both of these, perhaps, have to coexist everywhere. ≈öƒÅstra and the discernment from buddhi do not have to contradict each other. In fact, both are complementary to each other. We had to say so much about this matter now because our society is vacillating without any certainty. What is right - the ≈õƒÅstra or the mundane way of the world? Should we trust it, or analyse it independently? Veda or science? The contentment of the past? Or the glitz and glamour of today? This is the dilemma that haunts us. If we have to resolve this, we need to clarify to ourselves what the respective domains of veda≈õƒÅstras and human buddhi are.

We often see such people around us. There are new gurus everyday teaching their newer meditative practices. A man‚Äôs progress is influenced by the object he values most and believes to be of utmost importance. A man‚Äôs final state depends on whatever he believes in. Every man is defined by the ≈õraddhƒÅ he professes. Therefore there must be intellectual caution even in the object of his ≈õraddhƒÅ.
≈öraddhƒÅ is of three types - sƒÅttvika, rƒÅjasa, and tƒÅmasa. BG 17.8
Foods that are delicious, soft, can be easily absorbed into the blood and muscles, and give strength to the heart are sƒÅttvika.

If one is desirous of longevity, activity, strength, pleasure and happiness, then one must partake of sƒÅttvika foods.

This ideal of food must not be forgotten by the students of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Praising the greatness of the sƒÅttvika ideal while gorging on tƒÅmasa food is meaningless. The quality, strength and nature of man are all influenced by what he eats. Whatever be the disease, right food is the first medicine.
