Even modern doctors hold that the traditional food habits of our people are best. Rice obtained from threshing paddy at home, flour from grinding stones, a substance (now rarely found!) known as ghee, gingelly oil from wooden oil presses - are all sƒÅttvika foods. DƒÅl/hu·∏∑i made of pulses, sƒÅru/rasam, obba·π≠·π≠u/p≈´ra·πá po·∏∑i, and salads are considered healthy. Doctors say that these old style traditional food preparations constitute a ‚Äòbalanced diet.‚Äô These have unfortunately been replaced by biscuits, ice creams, candies and other foods with unpronounceable names in our ultra-modern age. Preparing foods of yore requires patience in our minds, strength in our arms, and respect towards cooking as an important duty. How can we expect that grand old lady‚Äôs qualities in this era of superficially shiny and dainty appearances?

If one wants anxiety, flaring tempers, and fatigue, one can consume sour, salty, pungent, hot and hard foods.
Stale, spoiled, and dry items, and remnants of food eaten by another are the foods of tƒÅmasas.

There are three kinds in yaj√±a and dƒÅna as well.

aphalƒÅ-kƒÅ·πÖk·π£ibhir-yaj√±o vidhid·πõ·π£·π≠o ya ijyate ‡•§
ya·π£·π≠avyam-eveti mana·∏• samƒÅdhƒÅya sa sƒÅttvika·∏• ‡•§‡•§
BG 17.11
A yaj√±a carried out with no expectation of reward, a firm faith that performing the rituals prescribed in the ≈õƒÅstra is an obligatory duty, and a calm mind are deemed to be of sƒÅttvika-≈õraddhƒÅ.

The yaj√±a performed with the expectation of a reward, or for one‚Äôs own vanity or to get praise from the world is considered rƒÅjasa.
That activity bereft of mantras or dak·π£i·πáƒÅ (remuneration offered to the officiators in a yaj√±a) or purity, not following a prescribed set of rules, and is wantonly done is called tƒÅmasa.

Tapas (penance) also is of three kinds.

anudvegakaram vƒÅkya·πÉ satyam priyahita·πÉ ca yat
svƒÅdhyƒÅyƒÅbhyasana·πÉ caiva vƒÅ·πÖmaya·πÉ tapa ucyate
BG 17.15
Restraining oneself in one‚Äôs mental, verbal and bodily activities, thereby not causing any anxiety, and keeping one‚Äôs mind clear is tapas that is sƒÅttvika.

Tapas performed with the objectives of felicitation, honour, or reverence from others is rƒÅjasa.
The activity performed with obstinacy and an intent to harm others is tƒÅmasa. ƒÄsurƒ´ activity is such.

DƒÅna (charity) too is of three types.

dƒÅtavyam-iti yad-dƒÅna·πÉ dƒ´yate‚ÄônupakƒÅri·πáe ‡•§
de≈õe kƒÅle ca pƒÅtre ca taddƒÅna·πÉ sƒÅttvika·πÉ sm·πõtam ‡••
BG 17.20
The dƒÅna that is made to a person incapable of returning the favour after ascertaining his circumstances and his worthiness and done as an obligatory duty is termed sƒÅttvika.

The dƒÅnas given with the expectation of a favour in return or carelessly or without regard for who is receiving the dƒÅna are deemed rƒÅjasa and tƒÅmasa.

After expounding upon how the three-fold ≈õraddhƒÅ is expressed with regard to the recipients and methods of worship and yaj√±a, dƒÅna and tapas with relevant illustrations, BhagavƒÅn now shows us the path of worship of the supreme j√±ƒÅnƒ´ who is beyond the three gu·πáas.

Om tatsaditi nirde≈õo brahma·πáas-trividha·∏• sm·πõta·∏• ‡•§
brƒÅhma·πáas-tena vedƒÅ≈õca yaj√±ƒÅ≈õca vihitƒÅ·∏• purƒÅ ‡••
BG 17.23
Designating the Supreme Brahma through the three symbols is an ancient practice. 1. Om 2. Tat. 3. Sat - are those three sound symbols. Through that designation by Brahma were ordained - at the time of creation - brƒÅhma·πáas (those who instruct BrahmavidyƒÅ), the Vedas (the repositories of BrahmavidyƒÅ), and the yaj√±as (the acts that worship Brahma).

The above means that all those words, treatises, and activities that are for the worship of Brahma - whatever is worthy of worship and is holy - all of that is indicated by ‚ÄúOm tat sat‚Äù. Whatever is directed by Brahma and whatever is offered to Brahma - all of it is covered under ‚ÄúOm tat sat‚Äù.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVG‚Äôs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-gƒ´tƒÅ-tƒÅtparya or Jƒ´vana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ≈öatƒÅvadhƒÅni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ≈öraddhƒÅ (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Let us now reflect a little upon its meaning.

1.Om

tasmƒÅdomityudƒÅh·πõtya yaj√±adƒÅnatapa·∏•kriyƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
pravartante vidhƒÅnoktƒÅ·∏• satatam brahmavƒÅdinƒÅm ‡••
BG 17.24
“The votaries of Brahma perform yaj√±a, dƒÅna and tapas after uttering Om”.

We have discussed the meaning of Om in the eighth chapter under “OmityekƒÅk·π£ara·πÉ Brahma.” Om has three constituent units of a + u + m. When considered separately, they can be construed as representing either the trinity of Brahma-Vi·π£·πáu-Mahe≈õvara or the triad of sattva-rƒÅjas-tƒÅmas or the waking-dream-sleep states or earth-atmosphere-sky or svarga-martya-pƒÅtƒÅla or energy-water-food or masculine-feminine-neuter genders or day-night-twilight, thereby bringing to mind all the aspects and qualities of the universe organised into triads. With Om - that is the culmination of the three units - we can not only bring the world to mind but also that which is beyond the world. Thus Om is a complete and all-encompassing symbol of the worldly and supra-worldly, the expressed and unexpressed energies, as well as the visible and invisible aspects of truth.

2. Tat

tadity-anabhisandhƒÅya phala·πÉ yaj√±a-tapa·∏•-kriyƒÅ·∏• ‡•§
dƒÅna-kriyƒÅ≈õca vividhƒÅ·∏• kriyante mok·π£a-kƒÅ·πÖk·π£ibhi·∏• ‡••
BG 17.25
“After uttering the syllable tat, those desirous of mok·π£a perform yaj√±a, dƒÅna and tapas without wanting anything else.”

Tat refers to “that” or “it” in English. We use “it” and “that” to refer to something familiar. For example - “That man” or “at that time”. Though Brahma is well-known, it is not directly perceived. Hence, the use of the word tat is appropriate here. There is yet another interesting reason. Any object that has no established name or whose nature is unexplainable by human language is also referred to by “that”. In traditional families, a wife did not address her husband by name, choosing instead to address him by words such as avaru. The husband too would not call his wife by name and would use the words - “she” or “her”. Similarly, it is an established tradition that the knowers of Brahma use the word tat to refer to Brahma.
Tattva can be resolved as tat+tva - “a thing being itself.” The state of an object devoid of all its external attributes like its form or colours, its activities - as just itself - unrelated to anything other than itself, without any other adjuncts is tat+tva. Brahma is such.

3. Sat

sadbhƒÅve sƒÅdhubhƒÅve ca sat+ityetat prayujyate
pra≈õaste karma·πái tathƒÅ sat+≈õabda·∏• pƒÅrtha yujyate‡ß∑‡ß∑
yaj√±e tapasi dƒÅne ca sthiti·∏• sat+iti cocyate.
karma caiva tadarthƒ´ya·πÉsat+ityevƒÅbhidhƒ´yate‡ß∑
BG 17.26,27

The word sat has two meanings.

  1. Sat is that something that has eternal existence. Sat is existence - in one state for all time. That indeed is the truth. Supreme Brahma is the supreme truth - satyasya satyam - the truth of the truth.
  2. Whatever is fit or good is also denoted by sat. For example, sat+jana, sat+karma etc.,. This second meaning comes from the first. It is the truth that is good. Untruth cannot be good. Only whatever is eternal is good; not transient objects. ParamƒÅtmƒÅ is the truth, and eternal. Hence any action or object or event related to him is good and is the most excellent. Whatever takes us towards the truth, whatever gets us divine grace is sat. That is the absolute good. All auspiciousness and good come to us from that truth. Brahma is the repository of all auspiciousness, it is the source of all that is good. Therefore, the worship of Brahma is sat+karma.

The word sat thus indicates eternal existence as well as something that is good and right. Any worthy endeavour deserves the prefix sat as well. Therefore all actions of yajna, dƒÅna and tapas offered to BhagavƒÅn befit the prefix sat.
It is instructive to examine the similarities between the Sa·πÉsk·πõta word sat and the Kannada word u·∏ª. In Kannada, the word u·∏ª refers to something ‚Äúthat is‚Äù, from which is derived the word u·πá·π≠u (present). The Kannada word for good - o·∏ª·∏ªeyadu - also comes from the root u·∏ª. Whatever is related to or can take us closer to the ever present (u·πá·π≠u), is also good (o·∏ª, o·∏ª·∏ªeyadu).

Thus the word “Om tat sat” is worthy of reverence from all perspectives. It designates the entire universe, all the devatƒÅs, all the jƒ´vas, and in fact everything! Therefore these three words are used to reference any devatƒÅ or dharma. The meaning of this word-triad declares that it is a happy obligation for anyone devoted to truth to have ≈õraddhƒÅ in it. ≈öraddhƒÅ in such a great mantra is life-redeeming.
Placing ≈õraddhƒÅ in any one object ensures an easier path towards progress. Whatever is done without ≈õraddhƒÅ is waste, for without it, there is neither worldly nor other worldly achievement.

Summary

The concluding chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ - a veritable lamp showing us the path to a fulfilling life - gives great courage and fortitude to people who are immersed in worldly karma. Here, BhagavƒÅn explains the necessity of karma that is devoid of desire for results and is performed only as a service to ƒ™svara. He propounds the principle that it is not the renouncing of karma that elevates the jƒ´va, but giving up the results of karma. Karma provides the jƒ´va an opportunity to get rid of its selfishness. The jƒ´va is blessed with many innate capabilities and qualities. The practice of using these natural abilities for the benefit of the world increases sattva in the jƒ´va. Through that, it also makes life meaningful.

The natural differences that are present in the composition of the universe itself are the basis for the system of var·πáa. The objective of this system is to benefit society from the constructive aspects of the nature of each person. The two goals of dhƒÅrmic karma are ‚Äî the prosperity of the individual jƒ´va and the sustenance of the world. Following one‚Äôs own svadharma that is in accordance with one‚Äôs nature is the way to elevate oneself. The instruction of svadharma that is the crown-jewel of the Gƒ´tƒÅ-≈õƒÅstra is especially necessary in our times - when incompetence and complexity are prevalent in all fields of work. This teaching is indeed most suitable to be practised by all.

BhagavƒÅn enumerates the steps on the ladder of the jƒ´va‚Äôs progress such as being immersed in one‚Äôs own duties, fortitude (dh·πõti), self-control (sa·πÉyama), selflessness (niraha·πÖkƒÅra), and non-covetousness (aparigraha). He delineates the qualities of a Brahma-realised-person such as equanimity and devotion only towards Parabrahma. Further, he declares there is no opposition between the performance of karma and dharma and the knowledge of the highest truth. He explains that it is futile to oppose karma that is impelled by prak·πõti. As part of this instruction is an exposition of the mechanism of the machinery of the universe which is worthy of constant contemplation.
Karma should be performed before the dawn of Brahma-knowledge, and after that as well. While karma is an instrument when a man is a seeker of knowledge, it becomes his second nature once the knowledge is attained. Being free of infatuation and hatred (rƒÅga and dve·π£a), and keeping the mind composed and clear are all duties for a seeker, and are attainable only with effort. For a j√±ƒÅni, however, freedom from infatuation and a clear mind are natural and effortless, joyful and playful. The view of a seeker is admixed with ego; but that of the j√±ƒÅni is with a view that everything is Brahma, and is for the happiness and well-being of all.

Section 19 /Chapter 18 /Mok·π£a-sa·πÉnyƒÅsa-yoga /Tadeka-≈õara·πáatƒÅ-yoga

(The yoga of single-pointed surrender)

This is the last chapter of the Gƒ´tƒÅ. Here, SvƒÅmƒ´ summarises the instructions from all the previous chapters, and in conclusion teaches an great method that can be adopted by one and all. In one word, it is ‚Äútad-eka-≈õara·πáatƒÅ‚Äù ‚Äî taking refuge in him alone.

There is a warning for us all in the way this chapter begins. In the previous chapters, Arjuna had said a few times that his doubts were cleared and that he was satisfied.

If Arjuna, who thought he was satisfied with BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs instruction was riddled thus again and again with new doubts, what to say of us, ordinary mortals? To get that clarity, it is not enough to listen to a lecture once or read the text twice. It should be repeated again and again in the mind. The question asked now by Arjuna had already been answered many times. It was the main subject of the fifth chapter.

We have seen earlier that karma is of many kinds. There are three main types:

  1. Laukika karma : This is of the form of one‚Äôs profession, interaction with others, friendship and other relationships, neighbourly actions, duties towards one‚Äôs country and so on. The concept here is not giving up karma, but giving up the results of karma. A sa·πÉnyƒÅsin gives up only kƒÅmya-karmas. A tattvaj√±a gives up the results of all his karmas. Karma is inevitable for all of us who are still embodied. Even a j√±ƒÅni performs laukika-karmas. Why is that? He performs those karmas without any desire ‚Äî for his own conditioning, for the love of the BhagavƒÅn and to help the world. A tyƒÅgƒ´ ‚Äî whether he wears ochre robes signifying sa·πÉnyƒÅsa or not ‚Äî gives up the results of all karmas for the love of ParamƒÅtmƒÅ.

A g·πõhastha performs karmas out of desire ‚Äî for the wellbeing of his wife and children and for the sake of his friends and relatives. Worldly life becomes possible only if householders have those desires. His dharma is to take care of his family. Therefore, he performs certain karmas to support his dharma. If he thinks that he is performing all the karmas as it‚Äôs dharma and not for his own pleasure and satiation, it is as good as tyƒÅga. This feeling should be within him. In spiritual matters, one‚Äôs own conscience is the judge, it need not be explained to others. The ≈õƒÅstras say that the works of pu·πáya should not be advertised to the world. Those who trumpet their works of pu·πáya are called ‚Äúdharma-dhvaja‚Äùs by Manu. DƒÅna and dharma should be done in secret. Even Christians follow the same precept. If this is the case of ordinary works of pu·πáya, what to speak of the ƒÅtmƒÅ ‚Äî does it behove of anyone to proclaim that he is a j√±ƒÅni and a tyƒÅgi?

A tyƒÅgi performs all his prescribed karmas. His mind is not attached to the good or bad results of any of them. One who thinks ‚ÄúAll karma is worship of the divine; good or bad that results from it does not belong to me. The karma that I performed is for the love of BhagavƒÅn; May he do as he pleases‚Äù is a tyƒÅgi. His love for BhagavƒÅn makes him do his karmas.

The question of karma appears in the Gƒ´tƒÅ again and again. Even in this eighteenth chapter, a large part deals with karma. Therefore, it is established that the Gƒ´topade≈õa is for ordinary sa·πÉsƒÅris like us. Karma is for sa·πÉsƒÅris. Sa·πÉsƒÅra itself is karma.
Our TrimatƒÅcƒÅryas were yatis ‚Äî ascetics ‚Äî they had accepted sa·πÉnyƒÅsa. Mok·π£a was their immediate goal. Therefore, the Gƒ´tƒÅ became a mok·π£a-≈õƒÅstra for them. Though it cannot be said that g·πõhastha-dharma was not in their purview, it was a puru·π£ƒÅrtha that was far from and beneath mok·π£a. Theirs was the way of niv·πõtti ‚Äî the way where they tried to unshackle themselves from the fetters of karma. Ours is the way of prav·πõtti ‚Äî where we compulsorily have to perform karma. Dharma-karma is near to us; mok·π£a is far off. Therefore, the important instruction for us in the Gƒ´tƒÅ is the instruction of karma. In this last chapter, BhagavƒÅn, for a large part, expounds the principle of karma. This gives courage and encouragement to people like us. If the nature of karma is understood with right judgement and performed as it should be, mok·π£a will come to us when it has to. We do not have to think urgently about mok·π£a now.

Any karma is fraught with faults. Therefore, some say that all karma should be given up.

These are nitya-karmas that are prescribed according to one‚Äôs circumstances. They may be laukika-karmas or vaidika-karmas. They are not performed out of desire for their fruit, and train the jƒ´va. They are prescribed for everyone.
What is the reason for such an abundance of dialectic literature about the relationship between karma and j√±ƒÅna, and that between karma and mok·π£a in our ≈õƒÅstras? As far as I know, this question is not so pervasive in the texts of other religions like Islam and Christianity. Whereas, in Hinduism, the discussion about karma and akarma is an integral part of ƒÄtma≈õƒÅstra, and has grown to be equally important. In his works, ≈örƒ´ ≈öankarƒÅcƒÅrya has devoted much space to deliberation about karma. This is because he had to answer the p≈´rvamƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsakas. The p≈´rvamƒ´mƒÅ·πÉsakas argued that there is no j√±ƒÅna without karma, and that karma itself is j√±ƒÅna. ≈öa·πÖkarƒÅcƒÅrya‚Äôs bhƒÅ·π£yas were their counterargument. However, it appears that this dispute has been there for a very long time. The ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsya-upani·π£ad says the following:

sa·πÉbh≈´ti·πÉ ca vinƒÅ≈õa·πÉ ca yastadveda ubhayag·πÉ saha ‡•§

ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsya-upani·π£ad 11

The same concept is explained in the Ka·π≠hopani·π£ad as well. Why has dialectical literature about karma grown so much? We have to ponder carefully about this.
Karma is worldly action ‚Äî take something from the world and give something back to it. This is our daily life. There is no karma in our life that is not of the form of giving or taking. Even while breathing we take in air and bestow it back upon the world. All the works done in the world are thus in the form of accepting and remitting, and either further one‚Äôs selfishness or erode it. Karmas done for our own pleasure, our own happiness, our own benefit, our own prosperity and prestige nurture selfishness. When those objects fructify, our selfishness is encouraged. As selfishness increases, we take more and more from the world and give back less and less. Thus, our debt to the world increases and the thread of sa·πÉsƒÅra lengthens. As worldly transactions with selfish motives increase, the possibility of pƒÅpa increases. As the fruits of pu·πáya multiply, the attraction towards pƒÅpa also increases. This is the danger in karma. This is present even in satkarma, because selfish desires are at the heart of our devotion to the divine, like opium that is dissolved in pƒÅyasam. What is the story of Hiranyaka≈õipu, RƒÅva·πáa, BƒÅ·πáƒÅsura, BhasmƒÅsura and otherrƒÅk·π£asas? It is a story of descending to the world of pƒÅpa through the doors of pu·πáya. They performed rigorous penances and worshipped Brahma, Vi·π£·πáu and ≈öiva. The boons they acquired as a result of their pu·πáya instigated them to perform pƒÅpa. Tamasic devotion resulted in delusion and infatuation, and therefore they attained naraka.

Therefore, some people argue that they do not want to have anything to do with karma.

tyƒÅjya·πÉ do·π£avad-ityeke ‡••
BG 18.3

So, then, is there no fault at all if we give up karma entirely? That is not true. This is because by giving up karma entirely, the jƒ´va loses opportunities to eradicate its selfishness. Selfishness is attached to the jƒ´va ‚Äî just like some people have cold all the time. If selfishness has to wear away, constant interaction with the world is necessary. Friction with the world loosens the strings of the heart and strengthens the manas as well. The three kinds of afflictions ‚Äî adhibhautika, adhidaivika and adhyatmika ‚Äî melt the jƒ´va. The great poet Bhartrhari explains the same to us in these charming words ‚Äî

mƒÅtarmedini tƒÅta mƒÅruta sakhe teja·∏• subandho jala ‡•§

This is the great benefit of karma. When Bhart·πõhari realized that his end was near, he folded his palms and beseeched thus ‚ÄúO Mother Earth, Father Wind, Friend Sun, dear Water, brother Sky, here is my last obeisance to you. (I have benefitted from you). My selfishness and delusion are removed because of my purifying contact with you. As a result, I have obtained the pure, vast and limpid light of understanding of the self. Because of that, I am now able to become one with ParamƒÅtmƒÅ.
For a j√±ƒÅni, sa·πÉsƒÅra is akin to tapas. The house is a smithery. Just as a smith heats metal and makes it pliable, the heat of sa·πÉsƒÅra softens human nature. Just as a smith would pat and hit the iron when it is hot, the blows delivered by the world correct human nature and temper it, thus making it useful to the world.
A vacana by Basava·πá·πáa goes thus ‚Äî

(This world is a smithery of the creator. Those who thrive here will thrive there also).

Heat from a kiln and blows of a hammer make a coin of a piece of metal. A good coin is valuable both in this world and the other. The pressures of one‚Äôs spouses and children, run-ins with relatives, skirmishes with shopkeepers, brawls at banks, wrangles at the workplace ‚Äî all these activities squeeze the tight knots of the jƒ´va and soften them; they straighten its crookedness and firm up the feeble parts; they dilute its self-centeredness; and they expand the boundary of affection and attachment. Thus, karma can subdue selfishness. For this reason,

Na tyƒÅjyam-iti cƒÅpare ‡••
BG 18.3

Should we perform karma, or give it up? Should we have a nose, or should we cut it off? If there is a nose, there might be the possibility of catching a cold also. However, there is no breath without the nose! Performing karma encourages selfishness. But if it is not performed, it does not mean that the existing selfishness goes away. Both of these are dangerous. The tactic here is to prevent selfishness that can enter karma. That is the principle.

Yaj√±a is worshipping the divine. DƒÅna is making the world happy. Tapas is self-control. Daiva, the world and the jƒ´va ‚Äî these three are an integral part of human life. Service to them is a must ‚Äî they should never ever be given up. Yaj√±a, dƒÅna and tapas are the means of purification for an intelligent person. When these karmas are performed with full knowledge of their meaning and with viveka, they can purge the faults of selfishness and purify the jƒ´va.

BhagavƒÅn, it appears, does not agree to this!

kƒÅryam-ityeva yat-karma niyata·πÉ kriyate‚Äôrjuna ‡•§
sa·πÉga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ phala·πÉ caiva sa tyƒÅga·∏• sƒÅttviko mata·∏• ‡••
BG 18.9
Na dve·π£·π≠y-aku≈õala·πÉ karma ku≈õale nƒÅnu·π£ajjate ‡•§
tyƒÅgƒ´ sattva-samƒÅvi·π£·π≠o medhƒÅvƒ´ chinna-sa·πÉ≈õaya·∏• ‡••
BG 18.10
‚ÄúSƒÅttvic renunciation is that, where one‚Äôs ego and the desire for reward are given up while performing duties that are necessary to be performed because they are one‚Äôs prescribed karma, or circumstances demand that they be performed. Such a sƒÅttvic renunciate does not hate the karma prescribed to him because it is difficult or disgusting, nor does he get attached to it because it is pleasing. He neither wanes on EkƒÅda≈õi nor waxes on DvƒÅda≈õi. He does not fear duties at a hospital, or jump with joy at the duties at a drama company. He neither runs away from the duty of carrying a corpse nor does he stand at the front of a wedding procession. He is equanimous towards auspicious and inauspicious ‚Äî that is, he is far from the consequences of dualities, and is impartial. He is free of all doubts and is established in objectivity.

Our belief that the Gƒ´tƒÅ is a book of dharmic life will be firmly established if we see the importance given to karma performed with sƒÅttvic renunciation in this chapter and the previous chapters. Karma is inevitable to some extent for all human beings.

·πáa hi dehabh·πõtƒÅ ≈õakya·πÉ tyaktu·πÉ karmƒÅ·πáy-a≈õe·π£ata·∏• ‡••
BG 18.11

Karma is indeed inevitable for everyone. Then how can we escape the possibility of pƒÅpa while performing it? By renouncing only the fruit of the karma. Let us finish doing what we have to do. We are not concerned with its use. We are mere servants following instructions on how to perform actions. We only do what we are told. In the satra of BhagavƒÅn, there is a feast being served everyday. If the supervisor says ‚ÄúHey you, clean the dirty plates‚Äù, it is not our place to ask ‚ÄúHow many people ate?‚Äù.

Let us apply this instruction to the political duties of our age. Suppose it is election day. It is tƒÅmasic tyƒÅga to think that it is a holiday and spend the day sleeping or playing cards and completely forget about the election. It is rƒÅjasic tyƒÅga to think ‚ÄúWho will go that far in the sun and suffer in the queue‚Äù and not go to the election and give up one‚Äôs duty out of fear of exertion. SƒÅttvic tyƒÅga is to go to the election booth, choose a candidate who is agreeable to one‚Äôs conscience and vote for him and not worry about the results of the elections ‚Äî whether his candidate wins or loses. This is the tyƒÅga where one is not anxious about the result. He is established in objectivity.

Let us come to the filth and pollution in our city. It is tƒÅmasic tyƒÅga to give up any action to correct it and shrug it off saying ‚ÄúWho can do anything about it? I couldn‚Äôt care less‚Äù. It is rƒÅjasic tyƒÅga to stand in the city squares and grumble against the municipality and leave it at that. Their nationalistic fervour ends there. There is another class of gentlemen. Their sƒÅttvic tyƒÅga is seen when they give up fear of exertion and fear of rubbing officials on the wrong side, when they write well-researched and detailed reports, publish them and poke to wake up the concerned officers.

Whatever karma we perform, there is definitely a result associated with it. But who is it for? It is for those who are attached to it; not for the ones who give it up.

ani·π£·π≠ami·π£·π≠a·πÉ mi≈õra·πÉ ca trividha·πÉ karma·πáa·∏• phala·πÉ ‡•§
bhavaty-atyƒÅginƒÅ·πÉ pretya na tu sa·πÉnyƒÅsinƒÅ·πÉ kvacit ‡••
BG 18.12
Thus sorrow, happiness and a mixture of the two are always present for a human if he performs karma with an eye for its rewards, whether it is in this world or others. For a tyƒÅgi ‚Äî a sa·πÉnyƒÅsi ‚Äî it is not there.

This is because they have given up their desires and anxiousness for the result of their karma. What they have declined is not allotted to them.
Are we so courageous? No. BhagavƒÅn‚Äôs instruction is required for worldly people like us. We are concerned about the result of our actions. Therefore, we have to understand the structure of karma and its results. Who is responsible for karma? Who or what are responsible for the consequences of karma? The doer? The influencer? The regent? The one who approves? Those who help? The method of work? We need an explanation for results ‚Äî good or bad. Any karma cannot be performed by a man alone, without the help of anyone else. It happens only with the help of other people and others‚Äô wealth. Whether it is big, easy, small, difficult or whatever else, there are many people who are deserving of the rewards of karma. They can be divided into five groups.

adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna·πÉ tathƒÅ kartƒÅ kara·πáa·πÉ ca p·πõthag-vidha·πÉ ‡•§
vividhƒÅ≈õca p·πõthak-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅ daiva·πÉ caivƒÅtra pa·πÉcamam ‡••
BG 18.14

To understand this verse, I feel that we have to tread a slightly different path from the explanations offered by earlier commentators. This is because of the difference in our views. In the eyes of the gurus of yore, mok·π£a was the most important attainment and karma in daily life was unimportant. In our case, karmas in our daily lives are of paramount importance and for now, mok·π£a is irrelevant. Before climbing the stairs, we have to first take firm steps on the ground. Can those who cannot climb to the loft jump to the sky? Mok·π£a is near and karma is far for religious gurus. Whereas, for us, karma is near and mok·π£a is far off. What applies to them might not apply to us. The immediate objective of sa·πÉnyƒÅsis is giving up karma and that of sa·πÉsƒÅris is in performing satkarma. Sa·πÉsƒÅra is itself just karma ‚Äî a bundle of many vaidika and laukika karmas.

Since sa·πÉsƒÅris are thus different from sa·πÉnyƒÅsis, the interest and regard of sa·πÉsƒÅris towards karma is different from that of sa·πÉnyƒÅsis. However,the meaning that we derive from the above ≈õloka from the point of view of sa·πÉsƒÅra is not conflicting with or incongruous with that derived from the point of view of sa·πÉnyƒÅsa. This new path will set a context for people in the present age and time.

Let us see the individual words of the above verse, one by one.

  1. Adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnam : Our ancients have called this the body. However, there is not much appeal in interpreting it as body, because in the next verse, the phrase ‚Äú≈õarƒ´ra-va·πÖ-manobhih‚Äù is explicitly called out. There is no necessity here for reiteration. Therefore, it is more proper to interpret ‚Äúadhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnam‚Äù as situations that influence a person to act in a certain way - circumstance or situation. A man‚Äôs karma is influenced by the circumstance. ‚ÄúAdhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnam‚Äù is a collective name for situations that become the basis for performing a karma, the circumstances due to which karma is performed. 2. KartƒÅ : The ancients and us do not differ in the interpretation of this word. KartƒÅ is one who does, the man who performs the karma.He consumes the fruit of good or bad deeds that he performs. When we say kartƒÅ, we should remember that it is the sum total of the qualities of the jƒ´va, the remnants of pu·πáya and pƒÅpa from his past lives, associations due to past obligations, the impressions on the manas because of them, the combinations of the three gu·πáas and so on. KartƒÅ is not the pure ƒÅtmƒÅ, but a jƒ´va that is shackled by the impressions of karma. Hence the responsibility of consuming their good or bad result. The pure ƒÅtmƒÅ neither performs karma nor consumes its fruit.The jƒ´va along with collected past impressions and obligations is ‚ÄúkartƒÅ‚Äù. 3. kara·πáa·πÉ ca p·πõthag-vidha·πÉ : Different means used to perform karmas. Earlier commentators have interpreted ‚Äúkara·πáa‚Äù as indriyas. However, as we saw above, indriyas are alluded to in ‚Äú≈õarƒ´ra-vƒÅ·πÖ-manobhi·∏•‚Äù . Therefore, there is the possibility of a different interpretation here. The people and instruments that assist in performing an activity are collectively called upakara·πáa. They are the wealth that aid in performing karma.
  2. vividhƒÅ≈õca p·πõthak-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅ·∏• : Earlier commentators interpret this as the changes that air causes in our body ‚Äî such as inhalation,exhalation,yawning, sneezing, etc. It makes more sense to interpret this differently ‚Äî as it seems difficult for us to believe that the results of a karma are dependent on yawns and dozing. The effects of the five prƒÅ·πáas are seen in one of the next words, ‚Äúsarƒ´ravƒÅk‚Äù. It is proper to interpret ce·π£tƒÅ as the manner in which a task is carried out. It is apt to understand it as a plan of action, programme, policy, strategy, tactic etc. It is like the skill displayed by a pawn in a game of chess. ‚ÄúvividhƒÅ≈õca p·πõthak-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅ·∏•‚Äù therefore means the four strategies ‚Äî sƒÅma, dƒÅna, bheda, da·πá·∏ça, and many other means of performing a task, the manner in which it is performed. 5. Daivam : Earlier commentators have construed this as the ruling deities of sense-organs ‚Äî such as the Sun and the Moon, or the energy that is internally present in the jƒ´va. It is not possible to demonstrate any special property of karma by just this much. There is no doubt that divine powers such as the Sun and the Moon and the internal energy exist. It is also well-known that they are also party to the performance of a karma. By saying ‚Äúthe body, speech and mind‚Äù, we do not mean a dead body, but a living and thriving one. When there is a jƒ´va, there are senses and the deities ruling those senses and the ƒÅtmƒÅ that is present inside it. There is another thing that has to be explained apart from these. That is Fate. That itself is daiva.

The Yoga-vƒÅsi·π£·π≠ha says :

prƒÅktana·πÉ pauru·π£a·πÉ tad-vai daiva-≈õabdena kathyate ‡••
Yoga-vƒÅsi·π£·π≠ha 6.35

Daiva is that which has the power to allocate good or bad outcomes to people who take part in a karma and who have to consume its result, according to what they have earned in the past. That is fate. That is the controlling agent of the universe. In the eleventh chapter, BhagavƒÅn said -

mayaivete nihatƒÅ·∏• p≈´rvameva ‡••
BG 11.33

Daiva is that supreme authority who had already decided the outcome of the war that was yet to be fought and said ‚ÄúIf you do not fight, the battle will not stop; do not think that if you exit the war, those who are supposed to be killed by you will remain alive; they have all been slayed already‚Äù. Daiva is that omnipotent entity that has been praised by the Vedas as

yƒÅthƒÅtathyato‚ÄôrthƒÅn vyadadhƒÅt ≈õƒÅ≈õvatƒ´bhya·∏• samƒÅbhya·∏• ‡•§
ƒ™≈õƒÅvƒÅsya Upani·π£ad, 8 ‚Äúhe allotted different tasks to the years‚Äù.

And,

dhƒÅtƒÅ yathƒÅp≈´rvam-akalpayat ‡••
·πögveda, 10.190.3
‚ÄúIn the beginning, DhƒÅt·πõ created‚Äù.

We call it ad·πõ·π£·π≠a, vidhi, prƒÅcina, prƒÅpti, niyati, yoga, fate, past karma, etc. Daiva is the controlling force, the ruling authority of the universe. In other words, it is destiny, providence. That is daiva.

Though there are different interpretations of the word ‚ÄúDaiva‚Äù, they all converge towards the meaning ‚ÄúFate‚Äù. The performance of karma and the blessing of the divine are both two forms of fate. Both are not directly perceptible. The following verse from the ƒÄdiparva of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata should be recalled here:

daive puru·π£akƒÅre ca loko‚Äôya·πÉ sa·πÉprati·π£·π≠hita·∏• ‡•§
·π≠atra daiva·πÉ tu vidhinƒÅ kƒÅlayuktena labhyate ‡••
MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ƒÄdiparva 122.21

The time taken to obtain results from our past karmas or divine blessings cannot be gauged by us. Their fruition might happen at some time. It is not meant to be understood by us. It works independently according to its timetable.
Let us apply the above five principles to an example. In the Kuruk·π£etra war,

  • Adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna: The dispute between PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas and the Kauravas about dharma. The just claim of the PƒÅ·πá·∏çavas for the kingdom, and the enmity of the Kauravas that didn‚Äôt allow them to part with it. This situation of dharmic conflict is the adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna for the war. - KartƒÅ : DharmarƒÅya - Kara·πáa : Bhƒ´ma and Arjuna, Drupada and other warriors who helped them, Kaurava warriors such as Bhƒ´·π£ma and Drona are all numerous kara·πáas. - Ce·π£·π≠a, upƒÅya : Yudhi·π£·π≠hira requesting Bhƒ´·π£ma‚Äôs blessings, letting Drona know of A≈õvatthƒÅma‚Äôs slaying, different vy≈´has of the armies, the deliverance of various ≈õastras (weapons without mantras) and astras (weapons with mantras), Arjuna acquiring weapons like PƒÅ≈õupata ‚Äî all such deeds are ‚Äúp·πõthak-ce·π£·π≠ah‚Äù. - Daiva : ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa‚Äôs attempts at bringing peace, MahƒÅdeva bestowing the pƒÅ≈õupata weapon on Arjuna and appearing as Bhairavarudra on the battlefield ‚Äî this is daiva. Both ≈örƒ´k·πõ·π£·πáa and MahƒÅdeva are not concerned with the results of the war. They only came for the sake of protecting dharma. They came only with the noble objective to establish dharma in the world. The work of daiva is in accordance with that of dharma.

What is the meaning of the above? It means that all thoughts and plans of man are subject to the rule of a superhuman rubric; it means that the human work is under the authority of the superhuman.

Let us apply the theory of five organs of karma to a wedding. A girl being of marriageable age and the father being prepared to perform the ritual of a marriage ‚Äî these are the adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna. The father is the kartƒÅ. The bridegroom is the kara·πáa. The marriage brokers and mutual friends and relatives are the other kara·πáas. The various acts of service and civility ‚Äî such as perfume, feasts, the honorarium given to the bridegroom are the ce·π£·π≠ƒÅs. Then comes the daiva. It is daiva‚Äôs blessing if the wedding happens without the bride or the bridegroom falling sick at the time of the lagna or no obstacles in the form of bad news are encountered.

Let us look at a meal from the same perspective. The hunger of the stomach and the desire of the palate are the adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅnas. KartƒÅ is the hungry man. Cooks and vessels are the kara·πáas. Struggling in shops to buy the items on credit and exhorting the workers and cooks are upƒÅya-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅs. It is the blessing of daiva to be able to finish the meal without stomach ache, or without hearing appetite-killing bad news or to be harangued by time-eating visitors.

There are more examples of the wrath of daiva than its blessings in the experience of people.

The summary is this. Daiva is hidden, a secret. It comes suddenly and unexpectedly, and cannot be grasped by the logic of causality. The word in Sa·πÉsk·πõta is ‚ÄúƒÅkasmika‚Äù ‚Äî kasmƒÅt means from where ‚Äî ‚ÄúakasmƒÅt‚Äù means that one doesn‚Äôt know from where it came. It is not possible to determine the causes and effects of such an occurrence. Since daiva is not directly perceptible, we forget it. The blow of despondency, if it hits us, becomes tolerable if we keep daiva in our minds while performing karma. The sorrow of efforts gone futile becomes hard to bear if daiva is forgotten while performing a karma.

≈õarƒ´ra-vƒÅ·πÖ-manobhir-yat karma prƒÅrabhate nara·∏• ‡•§
nyƒÅyya·πÉ vƒÅ viparƒ´ta·πÉ vƒÅ pa√±caite tasya hetava·∏• ‡••
BG 18.15
‚ÄúWhether the work started by a man is that of the body or that of the mind ‚Äî whether it just or otherwise ‚Äî the reason for its success or failure has to be looked for in the above five organs‚Äù.

Adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna : Circumstance ‚Äî we probably have made a mistake in gauging the pressure or the lack thereof, of a situation. Then the effort will go in vain.
Kart·πõ : His enthusiasm and belief might wane. Arjuna is a great example.
Kara·πáa : Friends and helpers might change. Duryodhana had believed in ≈öalya. ≈öalya forsook him when he became the charioteer for Kar·πáa. Kar·πáa had a divine weapon, but it did not come to him at the right time.
UpƒÅya-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅ : In Macbeth‚Äôs story, the footsoldiers of the army cut trees down and hid themselves while walking to the enemy castle. The enemies mistook the forest to be moving and ran away. In the history of Mysore, there is a story of a king who tied torches to the horns of oxen. The enemies mistook them for light-ghosts and ran away, scared. These are p·πõthak-ce·π£·π≠ƒÅh.

The above four belong to human power. Even if all of them are okay, everything will be futile if daiva does not cooperate.

sarva·πÉ ni·π£phalita·πÉ tadeva vidhinƒÅ daive bale durbale ‡••

Why does daiva become adverse? The past karmas of all individuals who are engaged in the present karma might individually or collectively be adverse. Therefore, karma is perhaps not for one person alone. It follows that even the results of karma are not for an individual alone.

In a great karma, the fates of a thousand people might come together. In our tradition, it is customary for people who perform propitious karmas like going on pilgrimages or building temples to first collect alms from a few houses. Why is this? Among the people who give alms, there might be at least a few with pu·πáya in their account; the idea is that the work may finish without encountering any obstacles. There may be one kartƒÅ, and a thousand helpers and approvers. Even they have a share in the results of the karma. Thus, daiva is the result of collective karma.

kartƒÅ kƒÅrayitƒÅ caiva preraka-≈õca-anumodaka·∏• ‡•§
suk·πõte du·π£k·πõte caiva catvƒÅra·∏• sama-bhƒÅgina·∏• ‡••
(subhƒÅ·π£ita)

To protect the order and dharma of the universe, daiva might modify the results of the individual karmas ‚Äî whether they are good or bad. Let us set daiva aside for a moment; it is not available for our examination and inquiry. Let us see the four parties that are in control of man. For a karma to be successful, all four of them should be favourable.

  1. Adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna or the circumstance might be favorable in the beginning, but may become adverse later. 2. The kartƒÅ himself may experience change of thought, or his energy might wane 3. His kara·πáas ‚Äî or the ingredients/instruments may be spoiled 4. Even if the above three are alright, there may be a mistake in his method.

Thus, the kart·πõ is not the only reason for an effort to succeed or fail or yield adverse results. The other three companions of his ‚Äî or one or two of the above parties may be the reason. Even if daiva is helpful, an effort may go in vain because of human errors.

tatraiva·πÉ sati kartƒÅram ƒÅtmƒÅna·πÉ kevala·πÉ tu ya·∏• ‡•§
pa≈õyaty-ak·πõta-buddhitvƒÅt na sa pa≈õyati durmati·∏• ‡••
BG 18.16
‚ÄúWhen the actual responsibility thus rests with so many people, one who thinks that he alone ‚Äî the jƒ´vƒÅtmƒÅ in him alone ‚Äî is the kart·πõ, is devoid of intellect. Such a fool cannot know the truth‚Äù.

Here there are two concepts :

  1. The kartƒÅ is not alone. There are other claimants along with him. 2. ‚ÄúI‚Äù is also an aspect of a jƒ´va and not just ƒÅtmƒÅ.

The ƒÅtmƒÅ that is present within a jƒ´va is the same ƒÅtmƒÅ that is present in all jƒ´vas. The energy of the ƒÅtmƒÅ is whole, never-changing and indivisible. One who has understood the omnipresence of the ƒÅtmƒÅ realises that the relationship between the kartƒÅ and karma is unimportant and only circumstantial, and therefore it is transcendental and impermanent.

Indeed, didn‚Äôt this topic appear in our discussion because of the question of dharma? If Duryodhana were dhƒÅrmic and had said ‚ÄúI will give whatever is entitled to you. You please take it and be happy‚Äù and acted accordingly, we would have completely missed the story of the Mahabharata. We would not have obtained the BhagavadGƒ´tƒÅ either. Therefore we have to praise BhagavƒÅn for giving Duryodhana his evilery and scheming mind ! Duryodhana‚Äôs evil mind became the pretext in the scheme of daiva.
A j√±ƒÅnin understands that the state of jƒ´va that has been obtained by the ƒÅtmƒÅ is not permanent and that the doership of the jƒ´vi is not permanent.

yasya nƒÅha·πÉk·πõto bhƒÅvo buddhir-yasya na lipyate ‡•§
hatvƒÅ‚Äôpi sa imƒÅn lokƒÅn na hanti na nibadhyate ‡••
BG 18.17
‚ÄúOne who is not tainted by ego and does not think of himself as the doer, one whose intellect is not stained with concern for the results of a karma ‚Äî even if such a man destroys all the worlds, he will not be a killer. It will not shackle him‚Äù.

This is the mark of a man who has progressed beyond dharma. We will see this adhidharma ‚Äî going beyond dharma ‚Äî later.

It is a crime when one person slays another. The same slaying done by a j√±ƒÅnin is not a crime. This is because other people act out of ego and selfishness. A j√±ƒÅnin does not have them. The objective of a j√±ƒÅnin is for all jƒ´vas to obtain better states. Is it necessary to wipe out whole worlds to move all jƒ´vas to a better state? BhagavƒÅn is not saying that. To illustrate a principle, a figure of speech called utprek·π£ƒÅ is used. Idiomatic language cannot be understood by making sense of mere words. Only the intent should be grasped here.
It is impossible for a person who has understood the true nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ to be a sinner. This is because he is not acting out of selfish desires or hatred for others. Even if he does something that is characteristic of an egoistic and mean person, that work will inherently not carry any evilery. Instead, it will be for the welfare and prosperity of the world only. The only desire that such a person carries is the welfare of all beings. Therefore, there is no possibility of pƒÅpa in his dealings.

That is fine. While describing the five components of karma, it is said ‚Äî

daiva·πÉ caivƒÅtra pa√±camam ‡••
BG 18.14

Daiva is mentioned here separately. Does not this special component called daiva have authority over the other four? Cannot daiva fix or make favourable the adverse factors, if any, among adhi·π£·π≠hƒÅna, kartƒÅ, kara·πáa, tantrasƒÅdhana ‚Äî or make them adverse if they are favourable? Is daiva not omnipotent? The answer to that is below :

Daiva cannot rule over all human aspects of karma. A part of human endeavour does depend on divine blessings, but all of it does not. If all aspects of human effort are dependent on daiva, what is left for humans? How can he earn pu·πáya or pƒÅpa? The responsibility of the doer comes to a naught in that case! A human has pu·πáya and pƒÅpa. Once we say that he has pu·πáya and pƒÅpa in his account, it is clear that he will have responsibilities and freedom as well. He has the authority to discern and act accordingly. A man will be concerned with pu·πáya and pƒÅpa only if human effort is of importance in a karma. Thus, the kart·πõ has some amount of freedom when it comes to dos and don‚Äôts. There are authoritative statements in the Brahma-sutras, etc., that declare that man has freedom to examine his progress or decline through his intellect and work towards what he wants.

kartƒÅ ≈õƒÅstrƒÅrthavattvƒÅt ‡••
Brahmas≈´tra 2-3-33

What does ≈õƒÅstra say? It says that there is pu·πáya and there is pƒÅpa; it says that there are good and bad results; it says that pleasure and pain are in accordance with dharma or adharma. Therefore, if the instruction about dharma and adharma has to be meaningful, man should have freedom and authority to understand both of them and rationally distinguish between them based on the situation. If that freedom is not given to man, he will not be responsible for dharma or adharma that happens through him.

Let us look at ≈örƒ´ RƒÅmƒÅnujƒÅcƒÅrya‚Äôs commentary for the above s≈´tra. The interpretations of the three schools of Vedanta differ from one another only in parts where it is not possible to give proof to anyone. Where it is possible to provide proof, they have no objections.

≈õƒÅsanƒÅcca ≈õƒÅstram ‡•§ ≈õƒÅsana·πÉ ca pravartanam ‡•§ ≈õƒÅstrasya ca pravartakatva·πÉ bodha-janana-dvƒÅre·πáa ‡•§ acetana·πÉ ca pradhƒÅna·πÉ na bodhayitu·πÉ ≈õakyam ata·∏• ≈õƒÅstrƒÅ·πáƒÅm arthavattva·πÉ bhoktu≈õ-cetanasyaiva kart·πõtve bhavet ‡••

≈öƒÅsana means ruling. Since ≈õƒÅstra rules us it is given that name. Pravartana is to instruct to act in such and such a way. How does ≈õƒÅstra instruct? ‚ÄúBodha-janana-dvƒÅrena‚Äù ‚Äî by producing knowledge within us. ≈öƒÅstra provides knowledge and impels us to act or not act in a certain way. What is the use of tutoring a benumbed body that does not have any freedom? ‚Äúacetana·πÉ ca pradhƒÅna·πÉ na bodhayitu·πÉ ≈õakyam‚Äù ‚Äî there is no use in teaching someone who does not have power that he can use freely. ‚Äúata·∏• ≈õƒÅstrƒÅ·πáƒÅm arthavattva·πÉ bhoktu≈õ-cetanasyaiva bhavet‚Äù : ≈õƒÅstras become meaningful when the doer himself consumes the fruit of his actions. If a man has freedom to do or not do a certain karma, then it makes sense to tell him to do or not do it, since he is anyway free to accept or disregard it. If he wants to do it, he does it out of his own volition, just as he disregards it out of his volition as well. Therefore the pu·πáya or pƒÅpa accrued from his performing or not performing a karma will get attached to him. ‚ÄúƒÅtmana·∏• akart·πõtve kuryƒÅt iti ≈õƒÅstrƒÅnarthakya·πÉ syƒÅt‚Äù ‚Äî if a man does not have freedom in doership, is it not meaningless to instruct him to do it or not do it in a specific way? The person to whom this is being told ‚Äî if he is not free to either do or not do something, all dharma≈õƒÅstra of the form of dos and don‚Äôts will become useless. ‚ÄúBoddhyureva hi ≈õƒÅsanam‚Äù : ≈õƒÅstra is only for the one who is eligible for instruction. If he is not eligible for it, the education given to him is akin to educating a rock or a wall. ≈öƒÅstra should be taught only to the one who has the freedom to follow or transgress it. He will accrue pƒÅpa if he disregards it; he will accrue pu·πáya if he complies with it. Who then obtains pƒÅpa or pu·πáya? The one who is free to perform ‚Äî or in other words, has kriyƒÅ-svƒÅtantrya. Here, kriyƒÅ means the ability to distinguish between dos and don‚Äôts; between dharma and adharma. ≈öƒÅstra and its dos and don‚Äôts can only be taught to one who has this ability to differentiate. Dharma-≈õƒÅstras and rules are necessary only because this freedom exists. It is true that the freedom of man is limited. Why is that? It is because of daiva. However, the little freedom he has should be used for differentiating between dos and don‚Äôts.

There are three stages in the lifecycle of any karma ‚Äî beginning, execution and consequence. Among these three, the last one ‚Äî consequence ‚Äî is mostly under the authority of daiva. The other two ‚Äî beginning and execution ‚Äî are mainly dependent on human effort. What is the nature of these two stages? The beginning is related to the internal working of the human mind ‚Äî it belongs to the realm of knowledge. Execution is external ‚Äî it happens in the domain of doing. Therefore SvƒÅmƒ´ expounds upon the realms of j√±ƒÅna and kriyƒÅ now.

j√±ƒÅna·πÉ j√±eya·πÉ parij√±ƒÅtƒÅ trividhƒÅ karma-codanƒÅ ‡••

The inspiration for karma happens because of the confluence of three aspects : knowledge, the object to be known and knower. This can also be said ‚ÄújnƒÅt·πõ-j√±eya·πÉ parij√±ƒÅnam‚Äù. He is the knower or jnƒÅt·πõ. He comes to know this because of the savoury smell. The knowledge of the smell that started from the eatable reached his nose and tempted him. By the commingling of food, nose and mind, there is an urge to steal the laddus from the basket. This urge happens within. Then comes the external work.

A ladder and other means to reach the basket are kara·πáa; karma is putting one‚Äôs hand into the box and stuffing the laddu into the mouth; the one who later smacks his lips is the kartƒÅ. Thus, there are three parts to a karma.
Inspiration for a karma comes from the triad of jnƒÅt·πõ, j√±ƒÅna and j√±eya which are internal, the execution of a karma is through the triad of kartƒÅ, kara·πáa and karma. First, a jƒ´va obtains j√±ƒÅna. After that, the execution of a karma happens through that j√±ƒÅna.

Here, gu·πáa means the gu·πáa-triad of sattva, rajas and tamas. All our transactions are according to the differences between them. Therefore, the difference in the qualities of the three aspects of karma - j√±ƒÅna, karma and kartƒÅ are explained now.

Let us first look at the three types of j√±ƒÅna.

sarvabhute·π£u yenaika·πÉ bhƒÅvam-avyayam-ƒ´k·π£ate ‡•§

BG 18.20
‚ÄúThe knowledge of one who has seen that the same energy of the ƒÅtmƒÅ pervades all beings, and resides fully in different bodies and is sƒÅttvic‚Äù.

This is the complete experience of the supreme tattva.

A man who does not understand this all-pervading principle and thinks that all beings are different from one another, is said to have rajasic knowledge.

One who disregards the complete principle and confines the innumerable and multifarious manifestations of the supreme principle seen in the universe to one form is said to have tamasic knowledge.

The sƒÅttvic form of knowledge keeps in view the complete and vast expanse of the supreme tattva.

Now let us look at the three kinds of karma. SƒÅttvic karma is that which is performed without passion or hatred, ascertained from the ≈õƒÅstras and tradition and one‚Äôs own judgement, without a touch of egoism and without any desire for its reward.

niyata·πÉ sa·πÖga-rahitam arƒÅga-dve·π£ata·∏• k·πõtam ‡•§
apala-prepsunƒÅ karma yat-tat-sƒÅtvikam-ucyate ‡••
BG 18.23

This verse is the essence of all principles of karma-yoga.
Karma performed with an objective, performed with great difficulty and egoism is rƒÅjasic.
TƒÅmasic karma is that which is performed obstinately and foolishly, without thinking about the pros and cons of the karma, expenditure, or the difficulty to be undergone by others, or an understanding of one‚Äôs own capabilities and their limitations.
Thus, the mark of sƒÅttvic karma is to intelligently distinguish between proper and improper and act accordingly.

Now let us look at the three kinds of kartƒÅs.
A sƒÅttvic kartƒÅ is one who performs karma without attachment or delusion, is not selfish, is stable and enthusiastic and is not altered by victory or defeat.
A rƒÅjasic kartƒÅ is one who performs karma with a desire for its result, is deluded and passionate, does not mind resorting to violence and other base means, and one who is overjoyed by victory and cowed down by defeat.
A tƒÅmasic kartƒÅ is one who is careless, egoistic and hypocritical, forgets propriety and is lazy, wails all the time and procrastinates.

In the context of karma, j√±ƒÅna, karma and kartƒÅ are important. Next, we shall look at the three-fold classification of buddhi (intellect) and dh·πõti (constancy) that are important in the execution of karma.

prav·πõtti·πÉ ca niv·πõtti·πÉ ca kƒÅryƒÅkƒÅrye bhayƒÅbhaye ‡•§

The buddhi that knows when and how much to enter into what worldly transaction, and when and how to stop, which work has to be done and which should not, when should one be fearless and when to be fearful, what might bind the ƒÅtmƒÅ and what can release it ‚Äî is sƒÅttvic. A hasty intellect that does not examine dharma and adharma, dos and don‚Äôts according to philosophy and misunderstands them is rƒÅjasic.
A tƒÅmasic intellect mistakes adharma for dharma and and in its stupor makes sense of everything in a perverted way.
In the beginning, Arjuna had rƒÅjasic intellect. The mark of sƒÅttvic intellect is to understand subtle differences between dharma and adharma. Arjuna had to learn this quality of discernment.
Dh·πõti is the ability to hold. Both courage and steadiness are consolidated in this word.
SƒÅttvic dh·πõti is the firmness of the mind that keeps the manas, senses and prƒÅ·πáas in control through continuous practice.
RƒÅjasic dh·πõti is that which keeps only the immediate goal in view while performing works of dharma, kƒÅma and artha. The activism that we all showed when Gandhiji was alive is an example of that. It is only concerned with the immediate result.
TƒÅmasic dh·πõti is that which is not ready to give up sleep, groaning, dreaming, wailing or conceit.

There are three types of pleasure as well.

yat-tadagre vi·π£amiva pari·πáƒÅme‚Äôm·πõtopamam ‡•§
tat-sukha·πÉ sƒÅttvika·πÉ proktam ƒÅtma-buddhi-prasƒÅdajam ‡••

  1. SƒÅttvic sukha is that in which the mind rests and finds that its sorrows cease, that which appears distasteful in the beginning but then results in am·πõta-like sweetness. It is due to the purity and pleasantry of oneself. This is the sukha experienced when the intellect completely understands the principle of the ƒÅtmƒÅ and the mind is fully rid of impurity, delusion, and confusion, and there is peace and tranquillity. 2. RƒÅjasic sukha is pleasure derived from worldly pursuits. It is sweet at first but gradually becomes bitter like poison. 3. TƒÅmasic sukha is pleasure that is experienced out of sleep, laziness and carelessness. It creates confusion and delusion in the jƒ´va.

Selfishness ‚Äî a note : A friend has asked this question. Isn‚Äôt at least a little selfishness required to be present in a man? How can worldly life progress without that? The answer to that can be answered in three aspects.

  1. Firstly, selfishness is natural. One does not have to put any effort into becoming selfish. It comes naturally by birth. The jƒ´va experiences both profit and loss due to it. The objective of dharma is to correct it so that there is more profit and less loss to the jƒ´va. Dharma does not say that selfishness should be completely eradicated. ‚ÄúasmƒÅka·πÉ saha-ku·π≠umbƒÅnƒÅ·πÉ k·π£ema-sthairya-vƒ´rya-vijaya-ƒÅrogya-saubhƒÅgya‚Ä¶‚Äù isn‚Äôt this the sa·πÉkalpa for any dharmic karma? 2. Secondly, why should we live? Is life just for living or with any objective? Plants and trees, snakes and lizards live just for the sake of living. If another objective is not included in such lives, who will be at loss? If we say that a man has to live for the sake of an objective, it is necessary that this objective be above selfish wants.Then the objective of life becomes great; selfishness only becomes a tool to achieve the real object of life. 3. Thirdly, even selfishness is three-fold, like sukha, dh·πõti etc.
    1. TƒÅmasic selfishness is that which thinks only of its palate, its comfort, its decoration and prestige, and thinks of the rest of the universe as something that exists to satisfy its need for pleasure. It takes whatever it needs from the world, and does not give anything in return. It does not repay its debt to the world. It does not even have an iota of feeling that it has benefitted from the world.
    2. RƒÅjasic selfishness is that which expands to include one‚Äôs family, community, town and country, is part of their happiness and sorrow and shares a part of life with a part of the world. It is better than tƒÅmasic selfishness. It feels that these people are one‚Äôs own, they should be part of one‚Äôs happiness and sorrow ‚Äî thus it includes others, loved ones, closely related ones in its circle of me and mine; it expands to that extent. It takes whatever it wants from the world, and gives back whatever it deems possible.
    3. The ƒÅtmƒÅ within oneself is the ƒÅtmƒÅ of the universe; the universe is the body where BhagavƒÅn sports; one has to experience oneself within this universe and become all-containing ‚Äî the desire to experience Brahma thus is sƒÅttvic selfishness. It realises that it owns nothing and offers everything to BhagavƒÅn and feels happy, or thinks that everything belongs to itself and there is nothing against it; and feels its own ƒÅtmƒÅ pervading the entire universe.

This verse in praise of mamatƒÅ by Appayya Dik·π£ita is fit to be recalled here.

tyaktavyo mamakƒÅra·∏• tyaktu·πÉ yadi ≈õakyate nƒÅsau ‡•§

VairƒÅgya-≈õataka-77
‚ÄúIt is only right to give up self-interest and selfishness. If it cannot be given up, it becomes a duty to be self-interested; but that self-interest should be exercised everywhere‚Äù. All beings should be included in the realm of self-interest. SƒÅttvic selfishness is that where ‚Äúsva‚Äù includes the entire universe.

Thus, BhagavƒÅn explains the form of sattva in j√±ƒÅna, karma, kart·πõtva, buddhi, dh·πõti and sukha and establishes its supremacy. Then he shows that sattva is not easily found or easy to be followed in the world.

We saw that unless the impurities attached to the jƒ´va in the form of the gu·πáa-triad are washed away clean, the nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ cannot be seen. This cleaning-up does not happen easily or quickly, because the dirt of the gu·πáa-triad comes from crores of past lives. It takes long and constant effort to erode them, and there should be a proper method in that effort. That method is svadharma.

We have already seen the nature of dharma. Let us recall it now. Dharma is the mutually beneficial relationship between the jƒ´va and the universe. Every person‚Äôs jƒ´va comes with some capabilities, some tastes and predispositions attached to it naturally. These capabilities, tastes and predispositions are made of the three gu·πáas. In the exercise of using them for the benefit and welfare of the world, the dirt in them diminishes and sattva becomes dominant. This is the main principle of dharma. On one side we have an individual person ‚Äî his alities and capabilities, his likes and dislikes, his remnant pƒÅpas; on the other side we have the universe ‚Äî its attractions and conflicts and its difficulties. The energy of the ƒÅtmƒÅ pervades these two spaces, within both of them equally. On both sides, it is hidden by the veil of prak·πõti and cannot be seen. That ƒÅtmƒÅ is what has to be known. Mok·π£a is bringing it to one‚Äôs own constant experience. However, the veil of prak·πõti is impregnable. The trickery of nature shows itself in layers and in colours ‚Äî it appears as flowers, fruits, man, woman, wealth and song in front of the jƒ´va and calls to him ‚ÄúSee how beautiful I am, what pleasures I can give you ! Will you leave me and go? Come to me, my child‚Äù. This is why when we begin the study of Vedanta, we first recite ≈õƒÅnti-mantras such as ‚Äî

bhadra·πÉ kar·πáebhi·∏• ≈õru·πáuyƒÅma devƒÅ·∏• ‡••
≈õa·πÉ no mitra·∏• ≈õa·πÉ varu·πáa·∏• ‡••

Why do we prostrate to inferior deities when we are trying to experience the Supreme Brahman? Aren‚Äôt we desirous of seeing the parabrahman? The answer is this. Before seeing and experiencing the parabrahman, the necessary thing is peace of mind. Before peace of mind, the necessary thing is peace of the body. Stability of the world is required for the stability of the body. Thus, the worship of paramƒÅtmƒÅ and worldly life are not mutually exclusive, they are always together. Therefore, the ≈õƒÅnti-mantras at the beginning of the upani·π£ads pray to Indra, S≈´rya, Varu·πáa and other deities to remove their obstacles and approve of their effort. Aren‚Äôt those deities different manifest forms of prak·πõti herself in the world? Hence, the devotee prays thus. ‚ÄúO divine beings, do not stop the progress of my ƒÅtmƒÅ thinking that I might forget you if I experience the Supreme Brahman. Till I am alive I will offer you what I have to. Be favourable towards my worldly well-being and show me the way for my future progress‚Äù. This is the intent.
Prak·πõti should be favourable to us. We should not be subservient to her. Worldly life should continue well. But one should not stop there, thinking that that is the be-all and end-all. One should always progress. That is the meaning of the above words. When we visit temples at places like Belur, it is possible that we are marvelled by the beauty of the sculpture of the outside walls and forget the inner sanctum itself. Such are the caresses of prak·πõti. How do we go beyond it? There is already a scheme for that. That scheme is dharma. Dharma is the means and tactics of dealing with prak·πõti so as to escape from the web of infatuation with which she is trapping us. Dharma is the set of rules and methods that help in the elevation of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, and is equally beneficial to both jƒ´va and the universe in their relationship.

The dirt of the gu·πáa-triad attached to the jƒ´va should erode, the sƒÅttvic capabilities of the jƒ´va should grow and help in the welfare of the world. Tamas should decrease and rajas should increase; rajas should decrease and sattva should increase. Both tamas and rajas should decrease further and sattva should reign supreme among the three. This is the manner of ascendance of the jƒ´va. The opportunity to erode rajas and tamas and to encourage sattva is given by interactions with the world. It is not easy to grind down the dirt of the gu·πáas. Shouldn‚Äôt a piece of sandalwood be rubbed on a grinding stone for it to wear down? Similarly, our past impressions should be ground on the stones of the world. When our temperaments are ground thus, they wear down and become sharp too. When a sword or knife is rubbed on a whetstone it wears down and becomes sharp. Thus, it becomes more capable in performing its work. Similarly, when an ƒÅtmƒÅ performs worldly karmas in the prescribed way, its rajas and tamas reduce and sattva increases. Its capabilities increase. It is trained. Along with these two advantages, there is a third ‚Äî it is the worldly welfare that was made possible because we used our ability in the right way. Sattva thus increases; the mind expands; The ability of the ƒÅtmƒÅ to be of use to the world increases. Impurities decrease; that is itself the decrease of evil. ‚Äúmama upƒÅtta samasta-durita-k·π£aya-dvƒÅrƒÅ ≈õrƒ´-parame≈õvara-prƒ´tyartham‚Äù.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 8) Source: prekshaa]]

Impurities comprise impressions carried over from many lives, or natural temperaments ‚Äî different tastes, wavering wants and infatuations, etc. Thus, the unconscious tastes and impressions from past lives are the impurities. Some of them are to be suppressed and purged. Others are to be experienced fully and then only can they be done away with. Purifying the sattva means eradicating the past impressions. This happens when they are indulged and used up in dealings with the world.

Thus, in the system of human relationship with the world, there should be a strategy to destroy tamas, control the rajas and encourage sattva. This strategy should be according to the natural capabilities of the jƒ´va. The system of var·πáas is a scheme of relationship between the jƒ´va and the universe that makes sure the capabilities of a jƒ´va are used to further the welfare of the world, pares its tamas and rajas, and develops the inner nature of the ƒÅtmƒÅ. The basis of this system is prak·πõti ‚Äî unimpeded prak·πõti. BhagavƒÅn says that the system of four var·πáas is based on the differences seen in the structure of the universe.

cƒÅturvar·πáya·πÉ mayƒÅ s·πõ·π£·π≠a·πÉ gu·πáa-karma-vibhƒÅga≈õa·∏• ‡•§
BG 4-13

Dharma is realist, not “fancyist”. There are different kinds of gu·πáas and karmas in this creation. On one side, we have people with different kinds of abilities and energies. On another side, we have the world with different needs and objectives. Therefore, diversity and differences are present in the basic nature of the universe itself.

It is a fact of prak·πõti that among beings, there are differences in capabilities and qualities. It is an exaggeration to say that everyone is equal. Indeed, don‚Äôt some idealistic seekers of excellence argue that everyone should be treated equally? If that comes into practice, we will suffer more than we do now. If all fingers of a hand become equal in length and thickness, can we hold a vessel or mix rice with them? When we say we want everyone to be equal, our only intention is that we should be treated on par with someone above us, and not that we want someone below us to be treated on par with us. This is the secret of the sloganeering about equality that is going on in the world now. Equality is only an external cover for self-prestige.

Dharma does not act according to such fancies. Short people are indeed short. Tall people are tall. Thin people are thin and fat people are fat. Dharma understands this reality. Treating a short man as a six-footer or a six-footer as a short person and acting accordingly is not dharma. One man might be brilliant, this other man might be dull. One person might have special abilities, another might be ordinary. Dharma is decided based on the differences between people. Satya or truth is factual. Dharma is that which does not follow anything but the actual fact. Giving a pu·∏ª·∏ªangayi (Pu·∏ª·∏ªangai un·∏çe is a sweet ball that is hard as a rock) ball to someone without teeth and tambi·π≠·π≠u(Tambi·π≠·π≠u is a traditional soft, sweet ball) to someone with strong teeth is not dharma. All dealings in the universe are a mishmash of things that are inherently different from one another. It will be necessary to adjust short with long, strong with weak. This is how different aspects are teamed together. A dull ox is yoked with a sharp one when oxen are yoked to a cart. One cart should not get only dull oxen; neither should another cart get only sharp ones. The idea is that we should take what help we can from the enchantments from the hands of prak·πõti. A man who has a good voice can learn music easily. It may not be easy for him to learn Mathematics or wrestling. Therefore, it is fit for those who set up a system in the world to consider the needs of the world, and estimate who is naturally more capable of contributing what it needs to the world.

The various types and extents of qualities and capabilities seen in human nature mainly fall into four categories. They are the four jƒÅtis.

brƒÅhma·πáa-k·π£atriya-vi≈õƒÅ·πÉ ≈õ≈´drƒÅ·πáƒÅ·πÉ ca parantapa ‡•§
karmƒÅ·πái pravibhaktƒÅni svabhƒÅva-prabhavair-gu·πáai·∏• ‡••
BG 18.41

The duties of people are prescribed based on which qualities are naturally predominant in them. None of human capabilities is useless; no man is unfit ‚Äî these are the fundamental principles with which all scholars of dharma-≈õƒÅstras agree.
There is no one in the world who is completely useless. The challenge is to evaluate the potential and harness it. Vai≈õyas are those who are more attentive towards money than others. A courageous and strong person can be a k·π£atriya. Thus, dharma-≈õƒÅstras evaluate the predispositions of people and decide their duties accordingly.
One should not think that this applies only to Hindu society. It is seen in all countries and all human societies. From the works of historians like Toynbee, we see that it was present in ancient Greece, Egypt and other countries. Just as there were some societal changes in India in the past two hundred years, there have been similar changes in England and other parts of Europe in the past three centuries. Distribution of wealth changed its course because of the industrial revolution. Since the distribution of wealth changed, the class and status of people also changed. In Shakespeare‚Äôs drama ‚ÄúTroilus and Cressida‚Äù, there is lamentation that class etiquette is eroding. It seems class differences existed in all societies. Westerners have not acknowledged it openly and have not named it as caste. The aspect exists, but it has not been evaluated philosophically. The var·πáa differentiation described in the Gƒ´tƒÅ is natural in all human societies. Our ancients noticed this natural contrast and gave it a name. Western ancients did not notice it as we did, and do not call it by name. We see that many things and feelings around us do not have names. There is no difficulty in inferring that names such as Smith, Mason, Cook, etc., probably came from the professions of individuals. Now, they are all mixed up in their societies. Our society has still not become so heterogeneous.

We said that the var·πáa differentiation outlined in the Gƒ´tƒÅ is naturally seen in all societies. We shall see the characteristics of BrƒÅhma·πáas.

≈õamo-damas-tapa·∏• ≈õauca·πÉ k·π£ƒÅntir-ƒÅrjavam-eva ca ‡•§
j√±ƒÅna·πÉ vij√±ƒÅnam-ƒÅstikya·πÉ brahma-karma-svabhƒÅvajam ‡••
BG 18.42
‚Äú≈öama, dama, tapas, ≈õauca, dayƒÅ, ƒÅrjava, knowledge of Brahma, knowledge of the world and belief in the divine ‚Äî one whose nature has these qualities is a BrƒÅhma·πáa‚Äù.

We have talked about these qualities many times earlier. J√±ƒÅna means the knowledge of the ƒÅtmƒÅ, the knowledge of Brahma. Vij√±ƒÅna is worldly knowledge ‚Äî ≈õƒÅstras like engineering, medicine, etc. It is said ‚Äúvij√±ƒÅna·πÉ ≈õilpa-≈õƒÅstrayo·∏•‚Äù - (Amarako≈õa 1.5.329) vij√±ƒÅna is the knowledge of sculpture and science One should develop one‚Äôs knowledge that helps worldly life, and it should be propagated ‚Äî this is a BrƒÅhma·πáa‚Äôs natural propensity. He is a teacher. He should first gain knowledge and then distribute it among others.

svƒÅdhyƒÅya-pravacane eveti nƒÅko maudgalya·∏• ‡•§ taddhi tapas-tadd-hi tapa·∏• ‡••
Tai. U. ≈öƒ´k·π£ƒÅvallƒ´

Vyasa himself talks about the qualities of BrƒÅhma·πáas elsewhere :

naitƒÅd·πõ≈õa·πÉ brƒÅhma·πáasyƒÅsti vitta·πÉ yathaikatƒÅ samatƒÅ satyatƒÅ ca ‡•§
≈õƒ´la·πÉ sthitirda·πá·∏çanidƒÅnam-ƒÅrjava·πÉ tatas-tatas-coparati·∏• kriyƒÅbhya·∏• ‡••
MBh, 12.169.35.1

Apparently, a BrƒÅhma·πáa does not have any wealth greater than this one thing. What is that? EkatƒÅ or consistency ‚Äî to be steady and self-restrained; being one in mind, speech and behaviour, without any conflict. SamatƒÅ means that the mind is unchanged by dualities. SatyatƒÅ means established in truth. Shƒ´la means good conduct. Sthiti means that if he believes in something, he constantly works towards it. Da·πá·∏çanidƒÅna means that he does not forget to correct himself in speech, mind and body. ƒÄrjava is being straightforward. There is one last quality that has been listed : ‚Äútatas-tata≈õ-coparati·∏• kriyƒÅbhya·∏•‚Äù. This is specific to BrƒÅhma·πáas. He should perform karma. Now and then, he should step back and give it a rest. A BrƒÅhma·πáa‚Äôs special quality is to not get attached to karma. It is detachment or withdrawal. BhagavƒÅn says ‚Äúsa·πÖga·πÉ tyaktvƒÅ‚Äù in the same sense. ‚ÄúThis duty is not mine. I performed it because BhagavƒÅn ordered it. I have performed the karma as required. Now I have to step back‚Äù ‚Äî a brƒÅhma·πáa‚Äôs mindset should thus allow him to rest from work.

Continuous work without rest is rajasic. It is the quality ofk·π£atriyasand vai≈õyas. A brƒÅhma·πáa is only established in karma when it is his duty; when there is no need for karma, he is established in the dhyƒÅna of BhagavƒÅn.

Very well. If we say that these qualities are that of a brƒÅhma·πáa, does a man born in a brahmin family become a brahmin just because of his birth? We cannot escape this question; it has to be faced. Do we decide whether one is a brahmin from birth or from qualities? There is no doubt that quality is the ultimate characteristic that decides whether one is a brƒÅhma·πáa. That birth influences quality, however, is a factor to be considered. Biologists now agree that familial qualities are passed on from generation to generation. It is an irrelevant question if we ask if the seed or field are different. Keeping this possibility aside, if we agree that there is an unbroken, straight lineage, we can conclude without a doubt that the above qualities of a brƒÅhma·πáa have been transmitted from generation to generation from ancient times to the present times, even if ever so slightly.
